subdebate.1.para: Bill presented by Mr Williams, and read a first time.

talker.name: Williams, Daryl, MP
Mr WILLIAMS
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

speech.para: Technological progress and globalisation are changing the structure of media markets and patterns of media consumption both in Australia and overseas. Consumers are no longer confined to the traditional media of radio, free-to-air television and newspapers available in their local area. And existing and potential media operators are forging innovative commercial strategies to secure their position in the new marketplace.

Internationally, media businesses are being driven by the imperative of delivering readily adaptable content across multiple platforms. Consolidation and diversification have created substantial global communications groups.

The government has long maintained the view that the regulatory framework for ownership and control of media assets in Australia unnecessarily constrains this sector within outdated and, in the long term, detrimental regulatory structures. Existing restrictions impede commercial flexibility and access to capital for infrastructure and content investment. They hinder the ability of Australian media organisations to succeed and grow in the new international market.

At the last federal election, the government committed itself to reforming the foreign and cross-media ownership restrictions in the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 (BSA). The Broadcasting Services Amendment (Media Ownership) Bill 2002 [No. 2] (the bill) seeks to give effect to this commitment.

The government's proposed reforms will improve the ability of Australian media companies to invest in new technologies. They will enable media companies to grow and expand in the new content driven converging global media environment. And they will ensure that Australian consumers have access to high quality media products.

When the government originally introduced its cross-media reforms, it invited sensible debate on these important media ownership issues. The government's response to the report of the Senate Environment, Communications, Information Technology and the Arts Legislation Committee on the bill, and to the debate on the bill in the Senate, reflects the government's willingness to take into account the genuine concerns of senators while still achieving substantial reform.
I turn now to the specific measures contained in the bill.

The current foreign ownership and control restrictions in the BSA, which apply to free-to-air and subscription television services, serve as a major deterrent to investment in Australian media organisations.

The bill therefore repeals the media-specific foreign ownership and control restrictions contained in the BSA. Foreign ownership of Australian media assets will continue to be regulated by the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act 1975 and Australia's general foreign investment policy. These provisions have the ability to address national interest concerns that might arise in relation to a particular investment.
Repealing these restrictions will improve access to capital, increase the pool of potential media owners and act as a safeguard on media concentration.
I turn now to measures to reform the cross-media rules.

Reform of the cross-media rules will clear the way for renewed market interest in Australian media assets. They will allow media companies to take greater advantage of investment opportunities as they arise.

The proposed changes will not affect existing limits in the BSA in relation to audience reach and the maximum numbers of commercial broadcasting licences that can be controlled in the same licence area.

The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission will also continue to have an important role to play in considering the competition effects of mergers. The bill in fact provides assurances that nothing in the bill, or in the ownership and control provisions as a whole, prevents the Trade Practices Act from applying to cross-media acquisitions.

The bill authorises the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) to grant cross-media exemption certificates on application. The ABA must maintain a register of active cross-media exemption certificates, which is to be available on the Internet.

Holders of exemption certificates are not in breach of the cross-media rules in relation to the media entities which they control, provided the conditions of the certificate are satisfied and they satisfy the separately controlled newspaper test, and provided an unacceptable three-way control situation does not exist. Linking control of more than one associated newspaper to continuing exemption from the cross-media rules will ensure that a cross-media exemption certificate holder will not be able to, over time, control both or all of the newspapers in a licence area. Certificates become active upon a person assuming control of two media entities in a way that would otherwise breach the cross-media rules.

The government is committed to ensuring ongoing diversity of opinion and information in the Australian media. The government recognises the need to ensure that media owners do not exploit their co-ownership of media organisations in a way that prevents those organisations from exercising separate editorial judgements.

To this end, the bill provides for a transparent and effective test in relation to maintaining separate editorial decision making responsibilities in cross-controlled media organisations. An exemption certificate can only be issued if the ABA is satisfied that the conditions included in the application will meet the objective of editorial separation for the set of media operations concerned. This objective is that separate editorial decision making responsibilities must be maintained in relation to each of the media operations.
Three mandatory tests are prescribed for the objective of editorial separation to be met. They are the existence of:
(a) separate editorial policies;
(b) appropriate organisational charts; and
(c) separate editorial news management, news compilation processes and news gathering and interpretation capabilities.

These requirements will not preclude the sharing of resources or other forms of cooperation in news gathering between organisations that could assist owners seeking to realise efficiencies from jointly owned organisations.

The bill provides that once an exemption certificate is active in relation to a set of media operations, those media operations must meet the objective of editorial separation as a condition of their licence.

The BSA gives the ABA the ability to investigate bona fide complaints of failures to adhere to licence conditions and to publish the outcome. If the ABA determines that a licensee has failed to comply with the editorial separation condition, it may issue a notice requiring the licensee to address the contravention within a specified time frame. Failure to comply with the ABA notice is a criminal offence, which can result in a large fine being imposed. The ABA is also able to suspend or cancel a licence if a licence condition is breached. Such action may be appropriate in the case of repeated or severe breaches of the editorial separation condition.

Prior to issuing an exemption certificate, the ABA must also be satisfied that the proposed merger will satisfy the minimum number of media groups test. The test applies to all media operations, other than remote areas, and provides a guarantee that a media merger resulting from a cross-media exemption certificate will not result in fewer than four media groups in markets in regional Australia, or five media groups in the larger markets of the state capitals. This provides another assurance of diversity in the media sector and will prevent any mergers in some smaller markets in regional and metropolitan Australia which will not have the minimum number of media groups required to allow any merger activity.

The bill will also ensure that no person in any market may control more than two types of media covered by the cross-media rules (the `two out of three' rule). The ABA must not issue a cross-media exemption certificate if it would enable a person to be in a position to control all three types of media in a single market.

Relevant media include commercial television broadcasting licences; commercial radio broadcasting licences; and associated newspapers (the BSA defines a `newspaper' as an associated newspaper that is in the English language and is published on at least four days in each week, but does not include a publication if less than 50 per cent of its circulation is by way of sale).

Small local newspapers are included in the `two out of three' rule in regional areas in certain circumstances. Any media group with accumulated holdings of local newspapers which together have a circulation of 25 per cent or greater in the licence area will be subject to the two out of three limit as if it held an associated newspaper. This means that small newspapers that provide relevant local voices will be counted in the application of the two out of three rule.

The bill also provides that a cross-media exemption certificate will have no effect if the holder controls more than one newspaper in the relevant market, either at the time of application for the exemption certificate or in the future. This provides additional reassurance that diversity of opinion will be maintained.
The bill imposes a general obligation to disclose a cross-media relationship on media outlets subject to the same exemption certificate.
The bill details two means of disclosure:
the `business affairs' model, which will apply to commercial television broadcasters and newspapers, and which will be the default disclosure model for commercial radio broadcasters; and
an alternative `regular disclosure' model which will only be available to commercial radio broadcasters.

The government recognises public concern about declining levels of local and regional news and information programs on both television and radio. Local services are important for developing community identity and for ensuring that important information is relayed in a timely fashion.

The bill amends the BSA to impose a condition on commercial radio broadcasting licences that have regional licence areas. This condition requires them to comply with prescribed minimum levels of local news and information services or to retain existing levels of local news and information where these are higher than the prescribed minimum.

The prescribed minimum levels include at least five news bulletins per week containing matters of local significance, broadcast of local community service announcements and the ability to broadcast emergency warnings if and when required.

The bill contains a provision requiring the ABA to impose licence conditions that require all commercial television broadcasters in four regional aggregated commercial markets, as well as Tasmania and the metropolitan markets, to broadcast a minimum amount of material of local significance.

The ABA has already imposed such conditions in relation to the regional aggregated markets of regional Queensland, northern New South Wales, southern New South Wales and regional Victoria. This was a result of its 2002 inquiry into the adequacy of local television news and information programs in rural and regional Australia. The inclusion of this requirement in the bill is designed to ensure that these conditions will continue to be in force in the future.

The bill also extends the requirement for the ABA to impose licence conditions to include Tasmania, which was not included in the ABA's inquiry, and the metropolitan markets (the mainland state capitals). This will ensure that broadcasters in these markets also satisfy their audience's need for local news and information. The requirement for the ABA to impose a relevant licence condition on broadcasters in these markets will enable a proper investigation to be undertaken into the appropriate level of local content for those markets.

The bill also allows datacasters to show programs that deal with local sporting events. This change has the potential to allow sport not previously broadcast on free-to-air television to be televised under a datacasting licence to increase coverage of local sporting events and to assist in promoting local sport.

The government is concerned to maintain a diverse range of commercial radio services of broad general appeal, especially in regional areas. Therefore, the bill prohibits contracts and arrangements that attempt to restrict the program format of commercial radio broadcasting services.

These provisions address a situation where contractual or other arrangements limit the program format of a commercial radio service, reducing the diversity of radio services and competition for audience and advertisers, particularly for the benefit of an incumbent commercial radio broadcaster. Civil penalties, including fines of up to $275,000 for a body corporate, will apply for entering into such contracts or arrangements. Furthermore, the bill renders the contract or arrangement void.

As well as written contracts, the prohibition will also apply to agreements or understandings that do not constitute legally binding contracts. An arrangement of this sort could be formal or informal, written or unwritten.

The prohibition will not apply to contracts or arrangements exempted by regulation. The ABA will also have the power to exempt particular contracts or arrangements. This is intended to allow some flexibility once the provisions commence, where there are legitimate types of transactions that should not be prevented.
The proposed changes will not affect the ability of the ACCC to scrutinise both existing and future arrangements that might have the effect of limiting competition.

The bill restricts the circumstances in which an approval of a temporary ownership or control breach could be granted under section 67 of the BSA. These provisions will restrict the capacity of broadcasters to use the temporary approval mechanism to engage in conduct designed to manage regional radio markets.

The bill forms an integral part of the government's commitment to respond to the rapidly changing communications sector with progressive communications policies which reflect evolving market conditions. Hence, it is logical that the government include a provision in the bill which will ensure the media ownership rules retain their currency in the near future and beyond. The bill therefore requires a statutory review to be undertaken of the broadcasting ownership and control provisions contained within Part V of the BSA, and tabled by 30 June 2007.

The bill will ensure that Australian media organisations, as well as the Australian public, are positioned at the forefront of an exciting new communications era. I commend the bill to the House and I present the explanatory memorandum to the bill.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the Select Committee on the Recent Australian Bushfires I present the committee's report, incorporating dissenting reports, entitled A nation charred: report on the inquiry into bushfires, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the committee.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: —by leave—Since the 2003 bushfires that devastated the forests of Australia and much private land, bushfires in Europe and most recently in California have made international headlines. Also the Australian bushfire season has already begun. The early commencement of the upcoming fire season makes it all the more urgent that authorities reflect on the experiences of January and February and seek to put in place policies and practices that are more effective in mitigating the effects of bushfire.

speech.para: In the summer of 2003, New South Wales, Victoria and the Australian Capital Territory experienced their worst bushfire seasons on record. Over three million hectares of public and private land were burnt across these jurisdictions. In addition, Western Australia suffered the largest loss of land to bushfires since 1960-61, with the loss of over 750,000 hectares, and Tasmania lost 50,000 hectares. All told, approximately four million hectares were lost in these states and territories alone. It was the extent of the fires and their severity that marked the 2002-03 season as so serious. Mercifully, there were fewer deaths than in other comparable fire seasons, but one death is one too many. As well, the fires left many residents and land-holders homeless and without a livelihood, and the time required for recovery of the natural environment must be measured in centuries rather than decades. It should never have been so devastating.

Following the fires there was a concerning level of disquiet in rural and regional Australia regarding the lack of appropriate bushfire prevention and mitigation measures on public lands and, in some instances, inadequate management of fire suppression efforts. I believe it was this disquiet that led the House to appoint the select committee to inquire into factors contributing to the severity of bushfires in recent years and to suggest ways in which the high levels of damage can be mitigated in future bad seasons.

The committee's call for evidence received a massive response from volunteers who risked their lives and contributed their time and equipment to the firefighting efforts; from land-holders and residents who suffered the devastation of being burnt out; and from individuals, community and industry organisations with long experience in land management and fire suppression. The inquiry also received a substantial body of scientific evidence from some of Australia's leading fire scientists, as well as from state agencies responsible for fire suppression and the management of public lands in Tasmania and Western Australia.

The strong response from local and professional communities stands in stark contrast to the astounding and very disappointing decisions by agencies responsible for the management of public lands and fire suppression in New South Wales, Victoria and the Australian Capital Territory—the very jurisdictions most severely affected by bushfires in 2003—not to participate in the committee's inquiry. I can only muse about the motivation behind such decisions. The wide ranging and detailed evidence received by the committee more than compensated for the refusal of some state and territory agencies to participate in the inquiry. The failure of these agencies to provide answers does not allow the committee to ignore or diminish the consistent evidence of systemic failures in the implementation of land management practices that mitigate bushfires and the inability, for whatever reason, to manage fire suppression efforts effectively in some instances.

Two consistent themes emerged through the more than 500 written submissions, 15 days of public hearings and eight days of inspections. The first theme centred on inadequate land management policies and practices, particularly on land under the care of public agencies in New South Wales, Victoria and the ACT. Current land management failed to mitigate the threat of intense bushfire by allowing fuel loads to accumulate to dangerous levels on public lands. It also made access to many areas of national park uncertain and dangerous because of obstruction and poor maintenance of fire trail networks. One of the more stark examples shown to the committee was the Grey Mare trail in Kosciuszko that took nine days to open up to allow safe access by firefighters. In May, when inspected by the committee, deep trenches had once again been dug across the fire trail, inhibiting access.

The second theme that emerged in evidence focused on the shortcomings in the management of some fire suppression efforts in these jurisdictions. Fire suppression efforts were hampered by the dismissal of local knowledge by some fire controllers. The disregard for local knowledge meant that some fires were allowed to burn when there was opportunity in terms of access, benign weather conditions and resources to suppress them.

One of the most disturbing elements in the disregard of local knowledge that emerged in evidence was the increasing level of alienation of volunteer firefighters from the upper echelons of the fire service bureaucracies. Also of concern was the ineffective tasking and deployment of resources, particularly aerial firefighting capability, and the failure of radio communications systems used by rural bushfire brigades. The lack of responsiveness to the needs of communities was evident in the inappropriate definition of assets to be protected in rural areas and the prevalence of inadequate insurance of assets.

The increased frequency, intensity and scale of bushfires in Australia have made them a national issue—one that requires a greater involvement from the national government. Throughout this report, entitled A nation charred, the committee has noted areas where a national approach may be beginning to take shape—examples being the National Aerial Firefighting Strategy and the recently established Bushfire Cooperative Research Centre. In making its recommendations, the committee was also cognisant of the upcoming inquiry into bushfires by the Council of Australian Governments. The committee has recommended that the Commonwealth use these fora to promote a national approach and policy in bushfire management. The Commonwealth has to this point played a largely passive role in relation to bushfires: providing disaster relief and making one-off payments to state and territory governments in support of their fire suppression efforts. In the view of the committee it is time for the Commonwealth government, through its agencies, to take an increased leadership role in setting and implementing a national approach and policy in the management of bushfires.

The committee has made recommendations that call for the Commonwealth, largely through COAG, to pursue land management practices that will more effectively mitigate the threat of bushfire to life, property and the environment. The committee has also called on the Commonwealth to use the COAG forum to review bushfire management arrangements to ensure the principles of rapid and effective initial response are adopted by all rural fire authorities and public land managers, including the possibility of indemnification of fire control officers for reasonable, responsible and informed decision making.

In addition, the committee recommends a review of bushfire incident control systems to better incorporate local knowledge and experience; the implementation of multi-agency protocols between land management and fire suppression agencies, similar to those in force in Tasmania; and the standardisation of equipment, procedures and communications across Australian states and territories. The committee has also called for the implementation of sufficient asset protection zones for the protection of private and community property; the development and delivery of an adequate spatial information system to all emergency service providers; the collection of fire levies through rates rather than insurance to ensure the burden of bushfire management is shared equitably; a review of arrangements for taxing of insurance premiums; a review of building and planning standards; and the implementation of a national bushfire education program. The role of volunteer firefighters was identified as absolutely crucial, particularly in light of the diminishing resources available to public lands. The committee has made recommendations that provide for the recognition of the indispensable role of volunteers to bushfire-fighting operations.

The report includes dissent from the member for Cunningham. However, it is effectively limited to the one aspect surrounding hazard reduction burning. The bulk of the report is in fact supported by him. The ALP's additional comments, disappointingly added after their acceptance of the report, were not released to other committee members until now but add nothing to the substance of the report and presumably are designed as some sort of appeasement to their state colleagues.

I recognise and thank the many people who contributed to this inquiry—in particular, those who told their stories at public hearings. It was often personally very difficult for them, and I admire their courage. Thanks also to my colleagues for the great support they gave me as chairman. The workload was very onerous. I give special thanks to committee secretary Ian Dundas, researchers Glen Worthington and Sarah Fielder and admin staff Marlene Dundas and Jeannie Brooks. They performed miracles at times and I thank them immensely.

This inquiry has been dogged by accusations that it is a politically motivated exercise of allocating blame. Such accusations may themselves be seen as political, and they discredit the individuals, communities and organisations that have provided evidence to the inquiry. The committee has identified shortcomings in land management practices and fire suppression arrangements, not to sheet home blame but to discover what is and is not working and to identify positive directions in which we as a nation may proceed in the face of a common threat. To deny that arrangements can be improved or to suggest that bushfires of the magnitude of recent seasons are simply inevitable is irresponsible to the point of betraying those who have lost their lives, loved ones, livelihoods and property as well as those who must take up the fight in future seasons. I commend the report to the House.

talk.start.para: —by leave—Over 500 submissions were received by the inquiry into the recent Australian bushfires. Although agencies responsible for land management and fire suppression in the ACT, New South Wales and Victoria did not provide evidence, evidence from former employees of state forestry agencies, volunteer firefighters, local land-holders, local governments, community and industry organisations and some statutory authorities from New South Wales and Victoria, along with public land managers and fire services in Tasmania and Western Australia, was received.

speech.para: The evidence stated facts that were honestly tendered, and the personal integrity and expertise of the individuals and organisations who gave it and the quality of the scientific evidence given were never in doubt. But, as mentioned earlier, the evidence we received was from the landowners and from people who were fighting fires, not from the people who have to allocate resources. With the 2003 bushfire season being preceded by drought, higher than average temperatures and lower than average rainfall, Australia needed all its bushfire resources and skills to come together at this crucial time. The committee's recommendations make the point that a national strategy could help us look across state boundaries and state agencies and give us a bigger overview of bushfire suppression and reduction.

Even though at times people spoke of considerable tension and were critical of some decisions at management level, without evidence from the relevant state agencies it was difficult to test these criticisms. As there are always two sides to a story, Labor members had some difficulties with some of the recommendations because there was no input from the states. But members felt that in the interests of a bipartisan report many of the recommendations could be tested by the CRC and further by the COAG inquiry, which will receive input from all parties. Labor members felt there was a need for some more explanation and this is included in `Additional comments'.

At the beginning, the report took an overly political turn because of the antics of the then Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government. It was not an acceptable position for either the Labor members or the states, and it led to the states resisting input into the report. But in the interests of continuing to hear evidence and our commitment to the communities, we continued to participate in the report. It was felt that the committee had a responsibility to parliament and the community to undertake the most comprehensive inquiry that was possible in the circumstances.

There have been a lot of inquiries over the years and many have led to similar recommendations to have some overall strategy, but we need to ensure that any such strategy includes integrated communications, inter-usage of aerial equipment et cetera. This has still not happened, and it would be a strong recommendation of the opposition. In fact, it has been part of Labor Party policy since January 2002.

It became clear throughout the evidence that more resources have to be committed to the prevention of fires and the maintenance of fire prone landscape. It was also clear that it is vital to ensure the safety of lives before making decisions on how to intervene in a fire. The occupational health and safety of the firefighters—both the volunteers and full-time firefighters—must be ensured in any attempt to undertake fire control. It was noted that in recent times there has been a change in land and fire management in relation to different land tenures, such as national parks, state forests, private land and private plantations. This has been in response to community pressure. But whatever one thinks of the impact of these different land uses on the environment it should not detract from the statutory responsibilities to guarantee wherever possible the safety of paid firefighters, and the unpaid firefighters under their control.

Fire is part of our landscape and it has no consideration for state borders. So any recommendations need to be undertaken nationally to ensure that fire can be controlled in the quickest and most effective way possible. Although a lot of recommendations go into some detail—especially on the training, proper communication, the types and interchangeability of equipment, and the community's understanding of fire and fire prevention—without a national approach, there will be no change. I thank the committee secretariat for all the hard work on this committee.

talk.start.para: —Before I recognise the member for Corangamite, I did not interrupt the member for Lyons but I should point out to everybody that it is appropriate for members to seek leave before they make a statement. I assumed that since there was no interruption the House was happy to give the member for Lyons leave anyway.
—I seek leave to make a statement and I second the report.
—The member for Corangamite might well. In that case I will see whether the member for Corio is kind enough to give him leave.
—Yes, most certainly.

—A nation charred is the result of 500 submissions from those people at the coalface of firefighting—firefighters, landowners, farmers and community people—who have been personally affected by the fires. The impact of this devastation is evidenced by the hearings that were held in Omeo, Buchan, Wodonga, Canberra and Cooma, so much so that those of us who attended those hearings were on the verge of crying when we heard about the devastation that was brought about by these fires.

speech.para: The fact of the matter is that four million hectares were burnt; nothing can refute that fundamental evidence. The fires burnt out about 56 years of forest production in current harvesting rates and the fires were so hot that it will mean that much of it will not recover. National parks were devastated and there is very strong evidence that this was the worst fire since 1939.

The observation I make is that there was a conspiracy of silence by state authorities, bushfire brigades and the green movement, who made no comment on the fires. They were strangely silent. They said nothing for weeks and weeks about this absolute devastation. There was overwhelming evidence that fuel reduction burning is a desirable technique for forest rejuvenation and for the reduction of fire possibilities. Creeping environmentalism meant that there was an attitude by the authorities that we do not have fuel reduction burning and we cut down on that, we let the fires burn and we destroy the fire trails. There is a lock-up mentality. If you lock up the national parks you need to make sure that national parks are managed—that the feral animals, weeds and fuel reduction techniques are taken into account.

This was the worst bushfire since 1939 and inevitably there will be another bushfire in the national parks. Having the goddess of biodiversity means that we do not attack the bushfires and we do not have biodiversity fuel reduction burning. The fires were not put out in the first instance. It is interesting to look at the evidence from a number of the witnesses. David Glasson said:

quote.para: On 8 January 2003 there were some 50 lightning strikes in the alpine areas from the Victorian border to the ACT. Approximately 30 of these strikes were in national parks, and the remainder were on private property. Within 24 hours, all the fires on private land were either extinguished or contained. As we all know, the section 44 on the Kosciuszko South complex of fires was revoked at 10 a.m. on Monday, 24 February 2003—some 47 days later.

speech.para: There we have it from Mr Glasson, who is a reliable witness. Likewise, Mr Val Jeffery was a most impressive witness with 40 years experience. He was a former chairman of the ACT Bushfire Council. He said:

quote.para: When those fires started with lightning strikes on 8 January, they should have been attacked immediately, hard and heavily with everything we could have thrown at them. That is the way we would have done it in the past. We never lost a lightning strike in my experience since the 1939 fire, so why did we lose them on 8 January? We did not try, frankly, as sad as it seems, to put those fires out. They could have been put out. Those fires were virtually all accessible by vehicle.

speech.para: The committee noted the following comments made by Mr Athol Hodgson—who is a very experienced firefighter and a reliable witness—about the fires in north-east Victoria:

quote.para: The Committee notes the comments of Mr Athol Hodgson who compared the 2003 fires in Victoria to those of the most comparable 1984/85 season. He pointed out that the 84-85 fires were contained in two weeks and burnt only 150,000 hectares of which only about one third was in alpine. This was compared to the 2003 fires which took seven weeks to contain and burnt out 1.3 million hectares.

speech.para: Giving further evidence, he said:

quote.para: They were ideal firefighting conditions, because there was no wind.

speech.para: We have it there that there was an attitude of mind not to attack the fires initially.
The fire trails is another matter that was brought before the committee. I quote the evidence of Mr Jurskis from New South Wales:

quote.para: There are roads and fire trails that were maintained on state forests that have been deliberately ripped up and blocked off in some of the state forest areas that have been transferred—

speech.para: that is, transferred to national parks. He went on to say:

quote.para: ... insufficient access is maintained in areas that have gone over to enable quick response and effective suppression when bad conditions are approaching.

speech.para: We see that the fire trails were ripped up, and that endangered limb and life.

This is a first-class report. I commend the chairman, Mr Gary Nairn, who had the patience of Job, the determination of Leighton Hewitt and the dedication of every firefighter throughout Australia to find the truth about firefighting in the southern part of Australia. I commend Ian Dundas and Dr Worthington for their outstanding job in compiling the report. This is a landmark report and is comparable to Judge Stretton's report of the 1939 fires. I only hope, with the experience of the USA in the fires at Yellowstone Park, that there will be a change in policy, that we will attack fires aggressively and that there will be a certain amount of enlightenment in how we handle national parks and forests in Australia.

talk.start.para: —by leave—Protecting the lives and property of all Australians, be they firefighters or members of households who live in fire prone areas, should be a goal that sits above partisan politics. Regrettably this inquiry was born out of the prejudices of the former Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government whose crude attempts to apportion blame at the height of the bushfire crisis during the 2003 season were, quite frankly, an affront to the dedicated efforts of unpaid volunteers and paid firefighters who had risked their lives in one of our worst bushfire seasons on record.

speech.para: This inquiry was one of two established by the federal government. It conducted its deliberations against the backdrop of state and territory inquiries in New South Wales, Victoria and the ACT, which have been completed and are being acted upon: a Victorian Auditors' report, a New South Wales coronial inquest, which has delivered its findings, and a coroner's inquiry in progress in the ACT. For several reasons this was not an easy inquiry for members to participate in. When people have lost property and their livelihoods and communities are threatened by a fire it is always difficult for those people to revisit the trauma of their experiences. It is also difficult for members of a parliamentary committee to hear and process that evidence in a rational and unemotional way. For me it was particularly difficult, representing an electorate that lost volunteer firefighters at Linton in Victoria many years ago.

I congratulate all the witnesses who gave of their time and expended so much of their emotional energy in retelling to the best of their ability their personal reflections and recollections of their difficult experiences. Despite the overt political circumstance of this committee's establishment and, on occasions, its overt political manipulation, Labor members stuck with the task in order to keep faith with the people and communities around Australia who tendered evidence and to keep faith with the processes of this great House of parliament which, despite its shortcomings and sometimes robust modus operandi, is a democratic institution that I passionately believe in.

Let me say that there are some recommendations that Labor members would not fully agree with, just as there are some that coalition members or the Green member would not wholly endorse in the way that they have been expressed or the emphasis that was finally given. For me, for example, recommendation 42 is of that nature. But we have been conscious of our duty to this parliament and its committee processes and to the citizens of this country, particularly those affected by the bushfire experience. We have assented to the report because we were of the view that many of the very practical recommendations made in the report ought to go further and be tested in the COAG process—which the states and territories, along with the Commonwealth, have all agreed to fully participate in—and that the recommendations should carry the full weight of the report without dissent. We have made some additional comments to clarify some aspects of those recommendations.

In closing, there are some matters that I think are important to state for the public record. The committee unfortunately did not have the benefit of the advice of state based agencies directly involved in the firefighting effort. Those perspectives would have been invaluable for all committee members in testing at least some of the evidence given to the committee. Secondly, let there be no dispute about the fact that the 2003 fire season was horrendous. The fact that we managed to get through it without greater loss of life and property is a tribute to the dedicated people from all walks of life involved in the firefighting effort: the emergency services personnel, farmers, volunteer firefighters, personnel from state based agencies, foresters, police and members of the general community.

Finally, careful reading of this report establishes a very strong and persuasive case for greater federal government involvement in a national bushfire strategy. My thanks go to the committee and staff for their patience and skill in putting this report together. It was no mean feat. My thanks go to fellow members of the committee from all political persuasions who came to the table and brought their considerable parliamentary expertise and their very practical expertise in formulating some very constructive recommendations on which this nation can move forward in this very important area of policy.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I commend A nation charred: inquiry into the recent Australian bushfires, the report of the House Select Committee on the recent Australian bushfires. I would like to sincerely thank the hardworking secretariat. I marvelled at the unworldly patience displayed by the committee chair throughout the committee's deliberations. This is a significant and historic report in that it is the first national inquiry into bushfires in this country. The inquiry was comprehensive in scope and received more submissions than any other recent bushfire inquiry. It was very disappointing to hear the member for Corio claim that this report was born of a direction from a former minister. Let me assure the member for Corio that those of us who represent areas that suffered in the recent Australian bushfires had constituents knocking on our doors demanding a federal inquiry. The member for Corio also seems to be at odds with the Labor deputy chair of the committee, who said that, without a national approach, there will be no change. The objective of the establishment of this committee, and its report, was to ensure that there is definite and real change.

speech.para: Over 500 submissions were received, of which more than 200 were from my electorate of Indi. This exceptional response reflects the groundswell of frustration and anger that has been accumulating over recent years within the ranks of volunteer firefighters and land-holders. I thank all those who took the time to write to and speak with the committee. I am particularly mindful of their efforts after such devastating bushfires. I believe this report is the beginning of desperately needed policy changes that incorporate fairness and commonsense in the preparation for and management of bushfires in this country. I have not forgotten the pledge I made to the people of Indi in my maiden speech, which was that their concerns would always be my principal priority. Their concerns were largely mirrored from one end of Australia to the other. Fundamentally, these concerns relate to increasingly inept land management by state and territory governments and an increasingly top-heavy bureaucracy, which has resulted in a diminished application of local expertise and knowledge in the preparation for and fighting of fires.

Although time constraints prevent me from engaging in a detailed examination of the inquiry's 59 recommendations, several of the recommendations will be of particular interest to my electorate. These include a more systematic and localised approach to fuel reduction burning, a review of the duty of care owed by governments to land-holders, rapid initial attack on fires, an overhaul of incident management systems to better incorporate local knowledge and expertise, and changes to the fire levy. Governments of all persuasions and at all levels have an unqualified obligation to take all steps to not only reduce the magnitude of bushfires but also effectively plan and prepare for them without fear or favour.

The committee pored over the draft of this report over many long and tortured hours. On one occasion, 45 minutes were spent arguing over one word. Finally, when the vote was taken last week to accept the report, not one of my Labor colleagues voted against it. I asked them to confirm that they agreed with the report as just voted on. Not one of them had the courage to look me in the eye; with bowed heads, they mumbled that they did support the report. What happened afterwards is open to conjecture. Without prior warning, my Labor colleagues saw fit to attach additional comments to the report. In all but two important aspects, these comments largely reflect the content of the report. These additional comments state that some bureaucrats, for a variety of reasons, were not able to give evidence to the committee to challenge some of the myths. This not only arrogantly devalues the knowledge and contributions of hundreds of volunteers but also covers up for the state governments that are control freaks.

I am disappointed with my federal Labor colleagues for buckling to pressure and protecting the likes of Victorian Minister Haermeyer, who gagged state government employees and agencies by not allowing them to participate in this inquiry. The Australian public are sick and tired of governments making excuses and abdicating their policy making to minority interest groups. The economic and environmental devastation caused by last summer's bushfires is a wake-up call for all governments to listen to mainstream Australia. This report, A nation charred, has prepared the groundwork to change government policy. It is now the responsibility of all of us who care enough to have the tenacity to ensure that its recommendations are implemented.

talk.start.para: —by leave—This inquiry was instigated by the government in the immediate aftermath of the tragic fires that swept through most of south-eastern Australia last summer—in particular, the ACT, where the damage and the impact were almost completely within my federal electorate of Canberra. It is fair to say, despite some recent comments in the debate this morning, that this inquiry began in a political climate. The then minister for territories, Mr Tuckey, had come to this region on or about 19 January—the day after the 18 January firestorm. To say that his remarks via the media were unfortunate is a gross understatement. At that time, the ACT was still in an emergency situation, with fire or the threat of fire remaining with us for some days, and the trauma and devastation was only beginning to be realised. The community of Canberra, when most vulnerable, felt assaulted by those remarks.

speech.para: It was against this background that the committee inquiry was established and I was appointed as a member of the committee. In fact, it was only two days after the Prime Minister announced his intention to establish a national inquiry through the Council of Australian Governments—an initiative supported by all heads of government in this country and by everyone involved. To my mind it was essential, given that the inquiry was to go ahead, that my community had a voice and a representative involved.

This has been a most difficult inquiry, held in emotional circumstances against a very short time frame, given the number of submissions and the amount of evidence to consider. The number of submissions was very high and I acknowledge and thank the people from my community in particular who were in a position to participate. I make all of these comments reinforcing and endorsing entirely the comments of my colleagues the member for Lyons and the member for Corio. However, at this point, when we talk about the number of submissions made, there is some comment required. There has been some comment and criticism about the lack of state or territory governmental response to this inquiry and I in no way disagree with those comments.

However, in the case of my community, the ACT government very quickly established the McLeod Inquiry into the Operational Response to the January 2003 Bushfires in the ACT, which subsequently reported on 1 August. As well, a study into non-urban land use and preparatory work for the coronial inquiry that is currently under way, along with other vital post-fire deliberations, well and truly occupied most of the ACT government and bureaucracy in circumstances unprecedented in the ACT. The ACT government advised that it was not possible to devote time, money and effort to yet another round of submissions to this inquiry at that time and instead made available the background and evidence provided to the McLeod inquiry.

talk.start.para: —What a load of rubbish! You don't believe that!

—I despair somewhat at the derision coming from the opposite side of this chamber when I make these comments. In those circumstances, I believe this reaction was understandable and acceptable. We should also note that the COAG inquiry has since agreed on terms of reference and work has now begun on that national inquiry.

speech.para: Readers of this report will see that Labor members of the committee have signed off on this report—we did not dissent and were happy not to, and we have also submitted some additional comments. There is no doubt that committee reports are more valuable to the community if they are unanimous or in majority opinion. I must say, however, that there are some aspects of the recommendations that I am less than comfortable with. Importantly, though, many recommendations are in line with our policies and reflect our long-held views on a national strategy to better deal with bushfires. Many recommendations are directed to the COAG inquiry and many will properly face further testing by others.

The recommendations of the McLeod inquiry, to which I have referred, have been totally adopted by the ACT government, which is being very proactive in its approach to the upcoming and future fire seasons. The ACT government is to be commended on its actions to date and on the work it does in continuing to address areas highlighted by McLeod and others. The McLeod findings are frequently referred to within this report and are used as a reference in many instances.

I also take this opportunity to note that the recovery process in the ACT is still very much in progress. The Lyons recovery centre and the Community and Expert Reference Group to the Bushfire Recovery Taskforce, of which I am also a member, are both still in operation and will be for some time yet. Given the extent of the 18 January fires here in the ACT, with the tragic loss of four lives and the huge property and environmental loss and damage, there is still a great deal of support and advice needed. The recovery process established in the ACT, while not considered in this report, is worthy of examination. We can never guarantee against bushfires or, in fact, other natural disasters. Sadly, there will be occasions in the future when recovery processes will be needed. I must commend everyone involved in that local process—in particular, Di Butcher and her team at the Lyons recovery centre, whose work continues with the support of the ACT government.

The number of submissions received by this committee reflects the level of concern people hold about the need for a carefully constructed national fire strategy—something we have been calling for over some time. I want to thank everyone who offered information, submissions, advice and support to the committee. I particularly thank those in my own community who submitted evidence to this inquiry under emotional and difficult circumstances. The most difficult thing for a committee of this kind is to find the balance between apportioning blame for political or other purposes and establishing objective findings that offer a way forward. This has been a difficult journey, with diverse and conflicting views across party lines within the committee. I trust that this does offer that way forward. The report is now available for consideration by the federal government and I will read with interest the government's subsequent response, which I hope and trust will be timely.

In the meantime, the recovery process and planning for the future continues in my community. Whilst a great deal has been achieved, many people, families, small businesses and community organisations are still coming to grips with their situation. I acknowledge the work of the committee secretariat and I thank especially the members of my own party on the committee and those particular members of the committee who offered me assistance during the more difficult and challenging periods of this inquiry. Finally, I commend the continuing dedication and commitment of the firefighters, volunteers, the SES and all others involved in protecting our communities around the country.

talk.start.para: —by leave—One of the things that I have concerns about is the way in which this committee, with all of its best intentions, has been frustrated by the lack of commitment by some members of the committee to really grasp what the 500 submissions and the verbal evidence given by volunteers and other groups in the community tried to convey about the seriousness of what happened in the fires in January this year.

speech.para: I make a prediction here and now, as I did in 1992, that despite the best intentions and the excellent recommendations of this report, nothing will be done by the state agencies to address or commit themselves to the very real concerns raised by volunteers during this inquiry. I say that in the context that since 1939 there have been various inquiries and the same message has come out of them—a strong point that we heard over and again, not only in New South Wales but right throughout the country—about the need for an initial aggressive attack on fires when they occur. We have seen this concern raised by volunteers through various coronial inquiries. Recommendations have been given and ignored by state governments. Local knowledge and decades of experience have been ignored year after year. There has been a massive build-up of administrative monoliths during that period of time.

The emphasis since the early days has been on containment rather than tasking all available aircraft, equipment and ground crews to put fires out in the early stages. We have seen millions and millions of dollars in training, uniforms, equipment and hierarchy control over the last 20 or 30 years, and what has been the outcome of all of those taxpayers' resources going into those areas? It has been absolutely nothing. I say that in the context that all those contributions made using taxpayers' resources have been less efficient than when we used wet hessian sacks and primitive—by today's standards—mobile fire tankers. The reason I say that is that, during those days, the single most committed objective of volunteers was to put the fire out quickly using local knowledge and experience.

I now want to make a comment on a part of this inquiry that I was very concerned about, following on from matters that I have raised publicly over the years about the way in which the New South Wales government, in particular, refuses to use fixed-wing aircraft in the early attack on lightning strikes and fires. This is not a concern expressed just by people in New South Wales; it is a concern expressed by people right across Australia. On page 218 of the report, under the heading `Use of aircraft during the 2003 fires', there is a quote from a submission made by Mr Col Adams, who is an agricultural pilot who operates out of Cootamundra. He said:

quote.para: Despite the fact that the situation was tailor made for fixed wing firebombing, no attempt was made to really hit them using fixed wing aircraft. While there were 9 fixed wing fire bombers engaged at the Kosciusko National Park fires, another 11 fixed wing firebombing aircraft were available for firefighting in NSW. These 11 aircraft were available to NSW RFS from the onset of the fires on 8/1/03 and it was not until the 17/1/03 that these aircraft were finally tasked (to other areas in locations in NSW).

speech.para: Those areas were well away from the fire. Would you believe it, Mr Deputy Speaker? I refer to that issue because the fire caused by the lightning strike in the McIntyre's Hut area flowed into and caused massive devastation in Canberra, and that should not have occurred. It would not have occurred if those aircraft had been pulled into the fire at an early stage. I say that because the evidence shows that the conditions were ideal for fixed-wing aircraft to suppress and contain the fire in the early stages so that the volunteer ground crews could get in and put the fire out.

Within 10 nautical miles of the fires in Canberra and in the Kosciuszko National Park there were agricultural airstrips that could have taken these aircraft and where they could have been fuelled up. If the Rural Fire Service had seriously addressed that issue and made even half of those aircraft that Mr Adams referred to—and I am talking about Dromaders and Air Tractor 802s—available for the fire, they could have used those local airstrips and delivered up to 36,000 litres of retardant mixture each hour to the fire front. That is the degree of assistance that they could have given to the firefighters. What happened? We allowed the fires to escalate and become uncontrollable so that ground crews could not get in to put the fires out as they were trained to do and, more importantly, as they were committed to doing.

I want to get back to the ALP members of the committee. Like the chairman, I was very disappointed that they made additional comments—which is their right—in this report. I thought it was absolutely disgusting that they did not have the courtesy, in the interests of all the volunteers throughout this country, to make those comments available to other members of the committee. One wonders what was behind that move. They have politicised the issue. It was very uncomfortable for them at times sitting and listening to people giving evidence and hearing the negative comments and the absolute rage and concern from volunteers about the way in which their Labor Party governments ignored those volunteers and did not assist them to get in and put the fires out, thereby putting people's lives, equipment and property at risk during that period of time.
A paragraph at page 7 of the additional comments from the ALP members says:

quote.para: We support the view expressed in this report that an initial attack fire fighting capacity is a desirable one for our fire fighters to possess.

speech.para: Well and truly said. It goes on to say:

quote.para: We note the strong views expressed in evidence that the eventual damage caused by the 2003 fires could have been ameliorated if resources had been brought to bear earlier. We also note that some fires occurred in remote and inaccessible areas, and conscious decisions were made by fire fighting agencies not to attend to them because appropriate resources were not available to be deployed.

speech.para: Talk about having two bob each way! On the one hand you agree with the people that gave evidence that there were aircraft that could have assisted in putting those fires out and saving lives and property, and on the other hand you say that there were not appropriate resources available to be deployed. What an abject exercise in hypocrisy that is, and you should be ashamed of yourselves.

I close by saying that in 1992, as a member of the state parliament of New South Wales, I made the prediction that any fires that occurred in the Kosciuszko National Park would be out of control very rapidly because of the fuel build-up and that lives and property would be put at risk. I warned rural fire brigade volunteer members around the Kosciuszko National Park not to go into those fires and put their lives at risk and, unfortunately, what I predicted in 1992 came to fruition in January 2003. Unless the mindset of the NSW Rural Fire Service in particular changes about getting in and putting fires out quickly, we will see more devastation and more lives lost. Unfortunately, it will be complemented by the political grandstanding of people, in this place and other places, who do not seem to understand or absorb the concerns raised by rural firefighters right throughout this country. I thank the House for the opportunity to make these brief comments on this particular report. I praise and compliment all of the staff, including the secretariat, that helped to put this report together in very difficult circumstances, particularly at those times, as my parliamentary colleague from Indi said, when we argued for 45 minutes over one word in the report. That is the sort of nonsense that rural firefighters do not want when they ask their political representatives to stand up and be counted to support them in very difficult times.

talk.start.para: —by leave—The A nation charredreport, and the over 500 submissions which accompany it, forms an important record for use by politicians, planning authorities, firefighters and the general public in the ongoing task of living with and managing bushfire in the Australian environment. I welcome the tabling of the report today and I would like to thank the parliamentary staff for their invaluable support and assistance. To my mind, perhaps the most significant aspect of our committee work was the opportunity it offered of bringing the community's views before the parliament. There is no doubt that this report strongly reflects the views presented to the committee by hundreds of ordinary Australians. We must remember the context here. The committee operated in a very, dare I say it, combustible and inflammatory environment. Large parts of south-eastern Australia experienced horrific fires during the most recent summer of 2002-03 and during the previous 12 months, with resultant loss of life, property and environmental assets.

speech.para: Make no mistake: wildfire can be terrifying and terribly destructive. Many of the submissions to the inquiry reflected the emotional trauma suffered by individuals and families as a result of the recent fires, and the environment in which the committee operated was also politically explosive. This is one of the reasons that the work of the committee was so severely curtailed in one vital area—that is, the involvement, or rather lack of involvement, of important state government authorities tasked with direct responsibility for bushfire management. These included, most notably, the New South Wales and Victorian firefighting authorities and national parks and forestry authorities, along with police and emergency services organisations. Whilst some governments offered assistance—most notably Tasmania and Western Australia—the lack of input from the Eastern States was telling. The Labor Premiers of New South Wales and Victoria have much to answer for: they called the inquiry political and they politicised it by their very actions. As such, the final report, while it accurately reflects the evidence presented to it, was flawed due to the absence of `the other side'. For example, there was widespread criticism of public authorities such as the New South Wales and Victorian national parks services. However, the committee never heard the parks services' side of the story. That story remains untold.

Also of concern to me, and directly related to the aforementioned boycott by certain state authorities, was the fact that much of the evidence was therefore untested. Assertions were made yet there was no way in which the committee could test those assertions or compare them with an opposing view. Many of these concerns were included within my dissenting report. My dissent also related to some of the committee's final recommendations, including certain aspects of recommendations 5, 6, 7, 9, 10, 12, 13, 16, 17 and 58. Whilst the Greens are not opposed to hazard reduction burning—and I will repeat that: the Greens are not opposed to hazard reduction burning—we do have real concerns that major environmental damage is being done by too much burning in certain areas and under certain circumstances, such as in south-west Western Australia, for example, under official prescribed burning regimes and in the northern part of that state, where there are no real controls on burning by pastoralists who use fire to promote non-indigenous grasses. We question the so-called `burning targets' which often have little, if any, scientific basis. We also have concerns about inappropriate burning in environmentally sensitive areas. Of major concern is the general lack of scientific analysis and backing to support where, when and how such burning regimes are managed. It is obvious there is no need to burn the proverbial `million wild acres' in order to save a house on a quarter-acre block, for there are other less environmentally destructive and resource intensive ways to achieve this aim. Targeted strategic asset protection zones are the way to go. Improved education is obviously a must. Local knowledge also must be used in both preplanning and in the actual firefighting task, and fires must be attacked at the earliest possible convenience.

More research needs to be carried out to determine the real impact of fire on the Australian environment. The bushfire CRC has a role here to do some of that work but also to act as a collection agency for the disparate knowledge banks out there amongst academia, the community and professional firefighters and environmentalists. As fire ecologist Nic Gellie clearly states in appendix E of the report, the way forward is more research, more detailed environmental assessment and better planning and management of firefighting resources and personnel. The Gellie report identifies that in many areas perhaps 30 per cent of the land has such environmental significance that it should never be subject to a prescribed burning regime, another 50 to 60 per cent can be subject to irregular prescribed burning over anything from a five- to a 25-year period, whilst the last 10 to 20 per cent should be dealt with as asset protection zones and managed accordingly. The Greens support such a detailed, targeted, scientific approach. This is the way forward in the management of bushfires in the Australian environment. I have no doubt that the work of the committee, and this report, will assist in that goal. I know that the effort that members of the committee, parliamentary staff and the community have put into this report has been worth while, and I commend it to the House.
Mr NAIRN (Eden-Monaro) (10.14 a.m.)—by leave—I move:

motion.para: That the House take note of the report.

speech.para: I seek leave to continue my remarks when the debate is resumed.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
(Mr Hawker)—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes.
—Please proceed.

—During their comments by leave, the members for Lyons, Corio and Canberra chose to commence their remarks by alleging that my remarks, as Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government, immediately following the wildfire devastation of Canberra were inappropriate and party politically motivated and as such insensitive. I challenge all three of those people to go back to the record and produce to this House clear, printed evidence of remarks that could be so categorised. I did not make such remarks and, what is more, any remarks I did make I had been making for three years as I attempted to save the houses that the member for Canberra did not care about.

motion.para: That the following order of the day, committee and delegation reports, be referred to the Main Committee for debate:
Recent Australian Bushfires—Select Committee—Report—A nation charred: Inquiry into the recent Australian bushfires—Motion to take note of paper: Resumption of debate.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek to make a personal explanation.
(Mr Hawker)—Does the member for Canberra claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I do, dramatically so.
—Please proceed.

—The member for O'Connor just placed a slur upon me and misrepresented entirely the circumstances surrounding the loss of life and property in the Canberra fires of January 2003. I take exception to that. It was misrepresentative of my role as a federal member for this community. I will at a later time today produce whatever evidence is required to back up the comments I made earlier in the chamber.

debateinfo.title: CRIMINAL CODE AMENDMENT (HAMAS AND LASHKAR-E-TAYYIBA) BILL 2003

subdebate.1.para: Bill presented by Mr Ruddock, and read a first time.

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

speech.para: The terrorist attacks on the United States on 11 September 2001 signalled a terrifying new phase in international terrorism. And they marked the beginning of what has become known as the war against terrorism.

Just 13 months later, the terrible reality of this war was brought home to Australia with the bomb attack on Bali, a favourite destination of many Australian holiday-makers. The recent bomb blasts in Jakarta and Baghdad have killed many innocent people.
Disturbingly, we have witnessed a trend of terrorist bombings targeting humanitarian organisations.

The war on terrorism is vastly different to traditional military engagements. It is proving difficult to adapt to a new type of war and a new type of enemy. Terrorist organisations are extremely difficult to penetrate because of the ever-changing structures in such organisations. And the enemy we confront is not only the bombers; it is the infrastructure that supports this type of warfare—the financiers and others who provide material support.

In recent months we have witnessed major developments in the war against terrorism. Key al-Qaeda and Jemaah Islamiah figures have been captured and prosecuted. In fact, the FBI estimates that more than 3,000 al-Qaeda suspects and 200 members of Jemaah Islamiah have been detained in some 90 countries. It is estimated that over $220 million in terrorist assets have been frozen. It is also estimated that 20 attacks in the US and a further 80 worldwide have been uncovered.
There is no doubt that the war against terrorism is ongoing, but these successes indicate that the war against terrorism is winnable.

Terrorism is a real threat to world peace and a real threat to Australia's national security. Individual countries have a responsibility to protect their own security and to deter and prevent terrorist activity through a range of measures, including strong criminal laws.
It is a responsibility that this government takes seriously.

Our response to the threat of terrorism has been comprehensive and wide ranging. It is a task which is ongoing. In the current environment, complacency is not an option. As part of our comprehensive approach to the new security environment, the government developed a package of strong counter-terrorism legislation—the bulk of which was passed by parliament in July last year.

Included in that legislation were amendments to the Criminal Code allowing the listing of terrorist organisations, subject to certain conditions, including the requirement that the terrorist organisation be identified as such by the United Nations Security Council.

The requirement that Australia wait for the UN Security Council to agree with our own assessment of what constitutes a threat to Australia and Australian interests before we can act was an amendment insisted upon by the opposition.

The government argued at the time that this potentially created problems because it puts Australia in the unsatisfactory position that we can not act independently of the United Nations to list a terrorist organisation posing a threat to Australia and Australian interests. Other countries can decide for themselves which terrorist organisations pose a threat to their citizens and their interests and act accordingly.

We know of no other country whose power to list terrorist organisations is linked to the United Nations. But, thanks to the opposition, Australia can not act independently of the United Nations Security Council.

We can not list the military wing of Hamas or the Lashkar-e-Taiba organisation because neither has been formally identified as a terrorist organisation by the UN Security Council. Yet we have advice from ASIO that there is evidence that both organisations engage in terrorist activity.

Matters that could be relevant in making that decision include the fact that the military wing of Hamas has been responsible for a series of suicide bomb attacks, shootings and kidnappings and the fact that the military wing has been involved in over 100 terrorist incidents, resulting in the deaths of over 500 people and injuries to more than 3,000.

In the case of LeT, it has been implicated in attacks in New Delhi and is alleged to have used hit-and-run tactics as well as suicide squads to attack Indian security forces and police stations. I understand that it has cooperated with al-Qaeda and other Islamic terrorist groups in training and undertaking operations.

It should be noted that both organisations have been listed by the Minister for Foreign Affairs under the Charter of the United Nations Act as terrorist entities, the assets of which must be frozen in Australia.
We are introducing this bill because we recognise there is a need to take swift action.
The simple fact is that we cannot wait for the opposition to wake up to the problems they created and support our terrorist organisations bill.

Under this bill, the military wing of Hamas and the Lashkar-e-Taiba organisation will be listed as terrorist organisations for the purpose of the Criminal Code provided that the Attorney-General is satisfied that each organisation is directly or indirectly engaged in, preparing, planning, assisting in or fostering the doing of a terrorist act, whether or not the terrorist act has occurred or will occur.

I appreciate that, while the activities of the military wing of Hamas are familiar to us all and we have seen the devastation caused by the suicide bombers in Tel Aviv and Jerusalem, many members may be less familiar with the activities of Lashkar-e-Taiba.
To assist members to participate in this debate, I table the original advice provided to me by ASIO about activities of both organisations. This is an unclassified document.
I will consider this information, as well as other available information, when I make a decision about whether to list by regulation either or both organisations as terrorist organisations.

The bill before us today sets strict criteria for deciding whether either organisation should be listed as a terrorist organisation. In accordance with the provisions of the bill, I will make a public announcement, and that announcement will be available on the Internet and in major newspapers if and when that decision is made.
Appropriate regulations, if a decision is made, will then be gazetted with effect from the date of that announcement.

The opposition has admitted previously that the UN listing process is flawed by acknowledging the inability to list the terrorist wing of Hezbollah and now the military wing of Hamas and the Lashkar-e-Taiba organisation.
We believe this is a serious matter of national security.

The government will not allow the opposition's obstinance to paralyse us and prevent us from doing what must be done to ensure the safety and security of Australia's interests. That is why this bill is before the parliament.

The bill itself and the processes that it will have to undertake will demonstrate the difficulties that do occur because we have not been able to legislate as initially proposed in the terrorist organisations bill, which is before the Senate.

That bill would permit a regulation to proscribe organisations to be made—still subject to parliamentary disallowance—and is eminently more sensible if we are going to be continually faced with other organisations that must be added.
To bring the parliament back on each occasion to pass separate bills is demonstrably not the sensible way to proceed with this matter.
I call on the opposition to put politics aside and support both of the bills in the interests of the security of Australia.
In that context, I commend this bill to the House. I table the explanatory memorandum.
Leave granted for the second reading debate to continue forthwith.

talk.start.para: —Labor support the Criminal Code Amendment (Hamas and Lashkar-e-Tayyiba) Bill 2003 because we are committed to fighting terrorism. The war against terrorism is a war that must be won, but it is a war that can only be won if there is genuine bipartisan commitment and a genuine honest attempt by the government to put all the information at our disposal—not just selectively leak it when it suits them. Australians do look to the government to provide effective security measures, but they want strong bipartisan approaches to that national security. What they do not like is the use of national security issues to political advantage, and too often we see this government prepared to talk up the fear of terrorism but failing to act effectively. This is the consequence of a government playing on fear but not being competent in the way in which they deal with that fear.

speech.para: It is true that this parliament has given the power to the parliament to proscribe organisations suspected of terrorism or of being a threat to Australia through the United Nations process, but it is not the only vehicle that this parliament provides for. If that were not true, why is it that we are debating this bill today? The parliament clearly provides another vehicle—and that is organisation specific proscription. That is what Labor proposed in relation to Hezbollah when the government was trying to play politics with it. It was Labor that proposed a private member's bill—I moved it—and ultimately the government adopted it because its little scare campaign was not working. But what is wrong with the parliament having the evidence before it, making the assessment and making the determination? That is what a democracy is.

What the minister wants of course is to take that power away from the parliament and leave it in his hands—a person whom we have seen on previous occasions manipulate the truth, manipulate the evidence and manipulate the circumstances. We remember the kids overboard, Minister, and we know of your role in it and we are not going to allow you to have the power to do the same thing playing with the fear of terrorism. It is too important for this nation that we deal with it honestly and in a bipartisan way, and that is why we will not give you the power that you are seeking in the bill—the power to proscribe by executive decision.

What we have proposed is a third limb, and this is what the minister—the Attorney-General—will not respond to us on. We proposed it five months ago: a process for judicial proscription, where the minister can go to a court—a court available every day of the week—in terms of suspected terrorism and get a decision of the court to proscribe the organisation. That we would support, and, interestingly enough, previous conservative governments have been prepared to support that too. Have a look at section 30A of the Criminal Code. Why is it, Attorney-General, that it was good enough for a previous conservative government, but not for you? In that regard, we can only question your motive.
