But do not come into this place and insult our intelligence or that of the Australian people and say the only way that you can get proscription is through the United Nations. I make this point: if indeed you had the evidence on Lashkar-e-Taiba, why did you not seek to do it through the United Nations? Do not come in here and give us the excuse that it would be too hard to do. Why not at least try it? If you genuinely believe this organisation is in need of proscribing, why not exhaust all avenues?

I would also be interested to know when you first became aware from the Brigitte questioning that Lashkar-e-Taiba was the organisation to which he was linked. Because if indeed it was in the weeks in which this parliament was sitting in joint session to hear President Bush and President Hu Jintao, that would have been an opportunity for you to declare a special session of the parliament when we were all here to deal with what we are dealing with now. So do not come in here with your cant and hypocrisy and suggest you have not got the powers, when clearly you have.

The bills before the House proscribe two terrorist groups—not just Lashkar-e-Taiba, the one that I have mentioned, but also Hamas. We support that. On the basis of the advice we have received from our security agencies, banning the two organisations, in our view, is the right thing to do. But that advice only came to us yesterday morning, and I know from that advice that it only went to the government on Monday night. So do not tell us that there is no capacity for expeditious dealings with these issues, when you were in fact told as a government on Monday night about Lashkar-e-Taiba—on the basis of ASIO's advice—we were told on Tuesday and we are legislating on Wednesday. Do not tell me you do not have the flexibility to deal with these issues when the evidence comes before you.

The circumstances are these: in the case of Hamas, the government was advised that Hamas was not a terrorist threat to Australia back—I think—in April, at the time of the advice about Hezbollah. We had advice from ASIO that Hezbollah was a direct threat at that time—it was interesting timing, because it was after the war in Iraq had commenced—but Hamas was not. On that basis, we said, `If it poses a threat, we as a parliament should legislate to proscribe it.' But, as I said before, I had to move the private member's bill which was ultimately adopted by the government—but not in relation to Hamas. The government acknowledged that the advice in relation to Hamas was not the same as it was in relation to Hezbollah, and so we made the distinction. I said that I wanted to be continually updated by ASIO whenever they had new evidence in relation to Hamas—or any other organisation, for that matter—and we would be prepared on that advice to act swiftly again. I had another meeting, in September—before I went to Indonesia—and asked the same question again in relation to Hamas, and I was told that it was still not a threat. We were advised that there were developments occurring in relation to it, but it was still not a threat then.

When I sought the briefing yesterday from ASIO—they did not offer it to me, nor did you—it was not in relation to these bills; it was in relation to the lack of powers you alleged ASIO had in dealing with terrorists in the aftermath of the Brigitte affair. Interestingly enough, I had been tipped off by our state governments that the Prime Minister had written to them seeking to proscribe Hamas and Lashkar-e-Taiba. He had gone to them without even coming to us first! That is the way you operate, Attorney-General, and we know it. Interestingly enough, that is why I asked ASIO, `When did the government first get briefed on these organisations?'—and the answer was Monday night. But you had already written, under the Prime Minister's hand, to state premiers on Monday afternoon. I therefore asked ASIO what the status of Lashkar-e-Taiba was and what the status of Hamas was in relation to a briefing sought and obtained on a different basis. You were not going to offer this. You were going to drop it out in the public domain and then say we could have a briefing. That is the way you operate. That is the way you have been exposed as operating already. You have hardly got the seat warm as Attorney-General and you are again up to the grubby little tricks we know you are capable of because we saw what happened in relation to the kids overboard affair.

So I sought that information out of the briefing. It was a long briefing yesterday. I was there with the shadow Attorney-General. It probably went for an hour and a half. On the basis of that information, I wrote to the Prime Minister. I think the timing was that the briefing finished at about one o'clock yesterday afternoon. I immediately called the national security committee of the shadow cabinet together to get approval to recommend support for this, and I wrote to the Prime Minister shortly after two o'clock, saying that we would support this legislation on the basis of the evidence that we had obtained.

I just want the public to know how difficult it is getting information out of you—it is like drawing teeth. We offer bipartisan support to fight terrorism in this country, but you do not reciprocate it. We can only come to one conclusion—that is, that you want to play politics with it and not address the real fears and concerns of the Australian community and deal with the fight against terrorism in an honest, genuine and bipartisan way. We are awake to this, Attorney, and we will try and keep ahead of you as much as we can. We kept ahead of you on Hezbollah, and we are ahead of you on this, because we have already agreed to support this legislation—the proscribing of the two organisations.

The advice that we got in relation to Hamas was different from the advice we got in relation to Lashkar-e-Taiba. Clearly, Lashkar-e-Taiba is a threat, posed by virtue of the fact that Willie Brigitte is associated with that organisation and he got into this country. But how did he get into the country? He got in because you let him in. You, as minister for immigration, allowed him in. You gave him a tourist visa—and you want people to believe that you are tough on terrorists! I want the public gallery to understand what kind of a person Willie Brigitte is. Willie Brigitte is a person that was suspected of terrorist activities in France when the World Cup was played there four years ago. He was listed on the French terrorist warnings as `terrorist suspect', but he was allowed into this country in May, staying right here up until the 2003 World Cup—and no alarm bell rang! What sort of operation are you running over there?

Attorney, you have to accept responsibility in two capacities. You have to accept responsibility in your capacity as Attorney-General and you have to accept responsibility in your former capacity as minister for immigration—a minister for immigration who was prepared, on the basis of Karim Kisrwani coming to him and offering money to the Liberal Party, to miraculously issue visas to people, allowing them to come in. We want to know how Mr Brigitte got his visa. There is no point telling us that you have great working relationships with the French in terms of security sharing. Why did they not share that information with you? There is a flaw in the system here. This is what I say about the argument: you are drumming up the fear, but you have been found wanting on competence.

You as a government and you as a minister let Willie Brigitte into this country in May. He was not deported until October. He was in this country for five months while he was listed as a terrorist suspect by the French—and you did not know about it. You did not know about it because what you had not done was to put in place proper intelligence sharing arrangements with the French. You had spent so long bagging them because they did not support the coalition of the willing in Iraq that you had no capacity as a friend or as a partner seeking to crackdown on terrorism to go to them effectively.

It is not just France that you failed on; it is Spain as well. What about the terrorist that was sent back to Spain that the Federal Police could not even get access to—and had not sought access to? In relation to the two biggest terrorist threats to this country your system failed this nation. That is what happened. The government failed to deal with the two biggest terrorist threats to this country—Willie Brigitte and the person returned to Spain whose name I cannot remember at the moment—because it did not have the appropriate reciprocal arrangements in place. Then, in relation to Willie Brigitte, you said on the Sundayprogramthat the government did not have the powers.

talk.start.para: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The Leader of the Opposition continually addresses the Attorney-General directly, rather than addressing his remarks to you, Madam Deputy Speaker.
(Ms Corcoran)—If the Leader of the Opposition would address his remarks through the chair, it would help me.

—I take the point of order. I should direct my remarks to you, Madam Deputy Speaker, but the difficulty in this debate is that we know who is actually responsible for driving wedge politics in this country. I think it is terribly important that we sheet that responsibility home, but I will try and keep my remarks directed through you, Madam Deputy Speaker.

speech.para: I have made the point about Willie Brigitte and the fact that Australia did not have the necessary sharing arrangements in place, but then we had the shameful appearance of the Attorney being interviewed by Laurie Oakes on the Sunday program. In that interview he said that the new ASIO powers were not sufficient to detain or question Willie Brigitte. That is wrong, Minister. You misled the Australian people in that assertion—and it is interesting that the Attorney came into the parliament on Monday and did not use the same terminology. He did not argue then that there was a lack of power; he said the question of power was `a moot point'. The language had changed. We actually asked the Attorney to table the advice upon which he relied to assert that it was a moot point, but of course that is secret. We cannot get that information—oh no, we would not want to show the Australian people the basis upon which he was making another outrageous allegation in this parliament. But of course the Attorney-General was hit for six by the shadow Attorney-General, who demonstrated just how effective the existing powers are. And when the Attorney then tried to assert that these were weakened powers, the shadow Attorney-General was able to show immediately that the powers sought originally by the government were what was in the legislation. The Attorney was hit for six in his first foray into his other little bit of wedge politics in this parliament.

But the point is this: when we had discussions on this question—the briefing that I mentioned before—what transpired was not that there was a lack of power but that there was a lack of information from the French. What does that come down to? It does not come down to the legislative base, Attorney; it comes down to what arrangements the government has put in place in relation to intelligence sharing with the French. You cannot blame the parliament or the Labor Party for that. That is all your own work—or lack of it—and you have been demonstrably found wanting in relation to it. The reason Willie Brigitte was sent back was that the French could get more information out of him than we could. Why? Because there had not been effective sharing of the information in the first place.

talk.start.para: —Because they have more extensive powers than we do.

—It does not have anything to do with the powers in that regard. The Attorney asserts this, but what the French had was more information. That is a very distinctive point. This is the difference between power and information—power through the legislative base; information through intelligence sharing. I also make the point, based on the information elicited after his return to France, that the follow-up investigations have been working smoothly, in accordance with our new laws, Minister. I have not heard you say that. I have not heard you say one peep about that, yet that is the truth. I would like you to deny it if you are of a mind to do it. I know what information I have obtained, and I think it important that the full truth is told in relation to this.

speech.para: I say this to the Attorney: of course we are prepared to support this legislation. The terrorist wing of Hamas is a threat to peace and stability in the Middle East. Its members have refused to accept Israel's right to exist behind secure borders. They reject the vision contained in the road map for peace for two states—one Jewish and one Palestinian. They reject the notion that these two nations can live side by side. The military wing has declared that the purpose of every operation is to kill Jews. But these are all issues which we have known of for years. So what are the circumstances that bring us to having to proscribe this organisation just now? I can understand it in terms of Lashkar-e-Taiba, and I accept that it is prudent to do it with respect to the terrorist wing of Hamas—but we would have been prepared to do that as part of the Hezbollah bill, had we had information to that effect. So it is incumbent upon the government to keep giving information—truth—to the opposition and to the Australian public and not just to continue to put forward deceit.

I also make the point that the earlier draft of this legislation did not restrict the proscription of Hamas to the terrorist wing; it concerned Hamas as a whole. Yet, when I sought advice in the briefing yesterday, we were told that the government were advised to proscribe only the terrorist wing. They were trying to push the parameters with the states, against the advice that they had received. I specifically asked that question, and in my letter to the Prime Minister yesterday indicating that we would support the proscription of these two organisations I said we would do it only if it was the terrorist wing of Hamas that was identified in the legislation. Thankfully, the legislation does that, but that was not where the government started.

The final point that I will go to relates to the Senate. The government say that we need to sit the Senate to get this legislation through. I do not believe that it is necessary to sit the Senate specially. I say that for two reasons. Firstly, this legislation is backdated to yesterday. Secondly, the fact that the Senate is not sitting this week as a whole is because of the government's legislative program. They have chosen to have Senate estimates on and not to have the Senate sit at the same time as the House of Representatives. If the normal pattern that we are used to were in operation this would not present a problem at all. Nevertheless, the government are not content with the backdating of the legislation or the indication from us that we support the legislation. They want the Senate to sit. In those circumstances, we would agree to that but on the basis that it sit this week when most of the senators are here for estimates so that the cost of recalling the parliament is minimised. We know what the government are up to. It is a stunt. The government do not really need the Senate to sit this week. What they want to try to do is to say, `Just look at how cumbersome and costly it is to get through what the Labor Party require us to do.'

I say to those who sit opposite that in a democracy the parliament does determine which laws go through. I think that there is a risk when you devolve important issues to ministers without a check. I know the argument about the check that says `a disallowable instrument', but the disallowable instrument can take 15 days from the parliament coming back and having a first sitting. What is to stop a government, and a minister in particular, over one of the longer breaks of parliament proscribing any organisation it sees fit to proscribe—making political mileage out of it and making a scapegoat out of it—when the parliament cannot review it for months? That is our concern.

The truth is that we do not trust the government on these issues—and we have plenty of good reasons why we should not. But we are prepared to give parliament the authority to deal with proscription, if the United Nations proscription route fails, and we have proposed a third option, which is judicial proscription: that is, the Attorney having to go to a judge to proscribe an organisation. I pose the question to those on the other side following in this debate: what is wrong with that suggestion? What is wrong with a merits based approach to reviewing these circumstances that the government wants? Nothing.

The merits based approach is what has been adopted in the UK. It is also, in terms of judicial proscription, a model that previous conservative governments have adopted. If it was right for them, why isn't it right for this government? Why isn't it good enough? In this modern day and age, if the argument is that we have gaps in which the parliament is not sitting and it is too costly to bring us back, let us look at a better alternative. But do not try to pretend the failure to address this issue is us being obstructionist. Do not pretend that for one moment. We have put forward constructive initiatives on every occasion in terms of dealing with this issue of terrorism. Why? Because we do stand shoulder to shoulder with every democratic political party in the world that knows the threat terrorism poses to them, to their existence and to the freedoms and security of the societies in which they live.

We are committed to fighting terrorism. We are committed to doing that with the government. We are committed to giving bipartisan support. But we are not going to have the government use its shoddy, tawdry little tricks to drum up the notion of fear, then fail on competence and use the excuse that it did not have a legislative base. In the case of Willie Brigitte, we gave a legislative base that the government did not even exercise. We have given a legislative base in terms of proscribing Hezbollah. We are supporting the government in a legislative base in proscribing these two organisations. We have proposed an initiative to enable judicial proscription so that these issues can be dealt with expeditiously in the future.

Join with us in a sensible solution, because we are about outcomes. We are about real solutions. We do not want to play politics with this issue, because the Australian public want to feel secure, not fearful. All you do is give them the fear; we give them the solutions. Join with us and we will be able to fight terrorism together.

talk.start.para: —It is particularly interesting to follow the Leader of the Opposition in the debate on the Criminal Code Amendment (Hamas and Lashkar-e-Tayyiba) Bill 2003. It was yet another attempt to try to bring the troops together and show his supposed leadership in this most important issue of terrorism. We do not doubt the sincerity of the Leader of the Opposition in being concerned about this issue. But when he comes into this House and says that his only solution to such a critical issue as the naming of these two organisations is to refer it to a court rather than to this parliament then you have to say it is no wonder that the leadership on the other side of the House is failing, when we have real solutions here in this House and accountability in this House.

speech.para: Why would you contract out your responsibility on such an important issue as the naming of terrorist organisations to the judiciary, when they are not accountable to the people of Australia? It is in this House that we are accountable. It is the minister who was attacked by the Leader of the Opposition who is accountable day in and day out in question time to the people of Australia. It is that level of accountability that we believe in. It is because we believe terrorism is such a threat to us and to the people of Australia that we should have the best approach to dealing with this issue.

There is no doubt that all of us in this House are concerned with the issues of terrorism and all of us are concerned with the issue of national security. In terms of the organisations that are proscribed—Hamas and Lashkar-e-Taiba—there is no doubt that all of us wish that they would be proscribed. We are talking about the mechanics of the bill in the way these organisations should be identified to be listed as terrorist organisations under Australian law and proscribed.

We have heard a lot about the proposals relating to the concern of the Leader of the Opposition. The bottom line, as I understand it, is that he is going to support the bill. We have had a lot of huff and puff, but the opposition are going to support it. We have a technicality, a bit of stuntmanship on the other side: `We've got the solution; we're going to refer it off to the courts.' That is the reality of it. That was the whole basis. If you come to the kernel of what was said, that is all that was in it: `We basically agree with it.' They are not prepared to admit that the line that they took, the blocking of the previous bill, insisting that it be about UN-designated organisations—

talk.start.para: —They caused the problem.

—The opposition caused the problem by insisting that it be UN-designated organisations and by not being prepared to see that this failed and that organisations brought forward which represent terrorist threats to us as a community need to be named as such organisations so that appropriate action can be taken, individuals associated with those organisations can be identified and funding for those organisations can be stopped. You need to move quickly.

speech.para: The reason I feel so strongly on this issue is that only this weekend I was at the memorial for the six victims of Bali in my electorate—six wonderful young girls. We went down with some visiting Indonesian and South Pacific MPs to visit that memorial. The fact is that, when the Bali bombing occurred, Jemaah Islamiah was not identified by the UN as an organisation that should be listed under this legislation. Of course, instead of the ability to simply allow the Attorney-General to identify those organisations that should be listed, we have to go through this charade of having organisations identified by the UN—no matter how long that takes. Here you have a classic example: Jemaah Islamiah not being named by the UN Security Council. And you say that the situation works—or that the matter can be taken to the court, which is not accountable to this place.

talk.start.para: —Of course it's not. That's the very reason we are here.

—You undoubtedly will have your chance to express your own views and convince your own colleagues of why they should take it, but from our point of view it is simply not acceptable. We have these two organisations before us, and they should be named and identified, as has rightly been done by the Attorney-General. The Leader of the Opposition has been caught with his own petard, having forced on this House the situation that we should only go via the route of UN identified organisations. We have had the organisation Hezbollah identified before. Now we have another two. Because of Willie Brigitte, Lashkar-e-Taiba has clearly come to the fore. What action do we take?

speech.para: To simply run away from it and say, `We've got another solution,' is the normal way that the opposition performs. If those members opposite could simply identify countries that have UN Security Council identified organisations as the criteria for banning organisations in their countries—if they could name them—we would all be very interested to hear about it. The fact is that there is no country that we can identify anywhere in the world that follows that route. So the Labor Party have forced on the government, through the Senate, a system that no other country in the world has.

We are playing with our own security and we are playing with people's lives, yet we have this nonsense of forcing us through the UN Security Council nomination. It is to the credit of this government that when Jemaah Islamiah was to be named this government and this country, in association with others in the region, brought forward the name to the UN Security Council. They eventually named it but there was a delay.

talk.start.para: —Two weeks.
—Well, isn't that appropriate.
—Order!

—I am sure the member for Denison, being a former minister, can outline his own case. He can go on with his own left wing rhetoric, but the fact is we are playing with people's lives. On this side of the House we are concerned with security and we want to identify organisations as quickly as we can. We do not want to go through bureaucratic niceties over the central planning authority that the member for Denison would like, but rather—
—You don't want to test the facts.
—Order!
—The member for Denison cannot forget the halcyon days when he was a minister.
—The member for Cook will not respond to interjections.

—This government does not want the hamstringing that the Labor Party wants to bring in of only going through the UN Security Council. We do not want to go through the nonsense, as proposed by the Labor Party, that we simply have the court take it away from us as if we do not want to take the responsibility, as if we do not have the skills and as if we do not have the accountability in this House.
—That is what we are saying: in this House.
—The member for Denison!

—For all that is said by the member for Denison, the fact is that this House is the one that should be accountable—that should be determining which organisations should be named. That is appropriate in terms of accountability. We have seen this issue put to many countries around the world. We have moved in terms of Hezbollah. We have now moved in terms of Hamas, which has had a long track record of terrorism in the Middle East.

speech.para: Now we have this new organisation, Lashkar-e-Taiba, which has come to our notice through Willie Brigitte. Is it appropriate that we should take this action or not? It is absolutely appropriate. Is it appropriate that we should move as quickly as possible to name these organisations, to ban them in our national life, to stop their funding as soon as possible? The answer is yes. Is this the quickest way we can achieve that end? Absolutely. Is this the best way to have accountability in terms of our national identity? The answer is yes.

We have this proposal before us, which is the listing of these organisations. It is clear that the opposition do not have any reasonable alternatives to put to us and that the proposal before us is appropriate. It moves to the heart of preventing terrorism in this country. It behoves us all to support this legislation, to not go through the political stuntmanship we have seen in the failed Leader of the Opposition. Rather, we should move on and take the strong leadership on terrorism that we have seen in this country to ensure that we have a safe environment. When I speak to my constituents—constituents who have been shattered by the events of Bali, in which six young people from my electorate were killed—I know full well the problems of terrorism right in my own electorate. That is the reason I stand here today and strongly support the initiatives of the Attorney-General in terms of this legislation.

It is appropriate that we should ban these organisations. It is appropriate that we stop their funding and ensure that we have an environment in Australia that restricts the activity of those terrorism organisations that we identify as quickly and as expeditiously as possible. I commend this bill to the House as a significant attempt to solve a problem in terms of these two organisations. There will undoubtedly be more in the future. That is why we need to have a serious rethink of the amendments that were put by the Labor Party in the Senate to change the nature of the bill, to tie us in to the UN Security Council's structure with all the problems that that creates in terms of timeliness. That is the key factor: our ability to move quickly. I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —In terms of the ability to move quickly, as referred to by the member for Cook, I note that we are debating the Criminal Code Amendment (Hamas and Lashkar-e-Tayyiba) Bill 2003 with less than 24 hours notice. I understand, as a result of agreement, that there will probably be a sitting of the Senate this Friday to deal with the matter. So in terms of expedition, you sensibly cannot do much better than that from the point of view of this outcome.

speech.para: The opposition supports this legislation, which will enable the Attorney-General, on the criteria in the bill, to proscribe the terrorist wing of Hamas. The explanatory memorandum makes it clear that it is indeed the military wing of Hamas and not the other bodies under the name of Hamas which, as I understand the situation, are involved in a number of charitable purposes in the Middle East, including providing sanitation and health services to the population in Palestine. We also support the proscription of the Lashkar-e-Taiba organisation, which has more recently come to light in the case of the Willie Brigitte affair, which has been a consideration of the parliament this week.

The details of the organisation have been listed today by the Attorney-General in a document that has been tabled. I of course refer to that as justifying the decision being made. In terms of a number of points made by the Attorney-General and also by the previous speaker, the member for Cook, there are questions to be asked as to why the government has not moved more expeditiously, certainly in the case of Hamas. The Prime Minister was interviewed about that organisation as recently as June of this year—as I recall, it was on Lateline. There has been ample opportunity to take steps with respect to that organisation.

With respect to Lashkar-e-Taiba, I understand the Australian government has known about it since at least the time that David Hicks was taken into custody. Again, even if you accept that the Willie Brigitte affair has given greater impetus to the consideration of that organisation, why has the government not taken steps to have that organisation listed as a terrorist organisation through the processes of the United Nations? It is noted that Lashkar-e-Taiba is in fact an organisation that is linked to al-Qaeda and the Taliban and, on that basis, it would fall fairly and squarely within the terms of the United Nations security resolution relating to the proscription of organisations.

For instance, when the Attorney-General went to the media before discussing these matters with the opposition—and he talks about not playing politics—and was interviewed by Laurie Oakes on Sunday,he was asked fairly and squarely whether his government had applied for the listing of Lashkar-e-Taiba by the United Nations Security Council, and his answer was:

quote.para: Well, look, I don't know whether we've - we specifically have asked for it to be listed.

speech.para: That was quite an extraordinary admission, particularly before someone went out and wanted to start bashing on that old wedge that the minister is so adept at doing. Certainly, in questioning this week, both he and the Minister for Foreign Affairs have had ample opportunity to make clear to the Australian people whether they have or have not taken that step. Irrespective of the outcome of this legislation, I might add, that is a step which should appropriately be taken, because the fight against terrorism is indeed an international fight. There is no use, quite frankly, in one country taking action; it has to be done at an international level.

In terms of the main focus of my contribution, I want to discuss the broader issue of proscription and the legislation, to which the Attorney-General and the member for Cook have referred, that is currently sitting in the Senate. As part of the background to it remaining there, I understand that the government is in some discussion with the states regarding their positions in respect of the legislation. That discussion is of course appropriate, but we would have liked to have been included in discussions, certainly in response to the proposals we put to the government in June regarding alternative models. Our concern with the government's model of executive proscription is that it does not have sufficient safeguards. I note the member for Cook is among the small `l' liberal grouping within the Liberal Party caucus. He will, I think, recall whether he asked himself—

talk.start.para: —It's a growing band. Oh, he's gone—maybe it's not a growing band.

—My colleague at the table indicates that it is a growing band. That is perhaps a healthy thing for Australian politics. That group will recall, when the initial bill was brought into the Liberal Party caucus in 2002, that there was considerable disquiet regarding the extent of the executive proscription model that was put forward in the government's approach. Indeed, those concerns have been reflected in the community more generally, and not simply in legal circles where you would expect there would be standards of concern regarding the process of natural justice, appropriate mechanisms for review of the primary material and so forth. It is for those reasons and in good faith that we spent considerable time—I might say, with some very talented advice—in developing a model which we believe involved and incorporated checks and balances through a model of judicial proscription which, quite frankly, was based essentially on section 30A of the Crimes Act, which enables the Attorney-General to make application to the Federal Court for an organisation to show cause as to why it should not be listed as an organisation that is involved in, if you like, subversive activities.

speech.para: That legislation was introduced by a previous conservative government, and there are a number of reasons why that approach was taken, not the least of which is the fact that we have a constitution in this country that distinguishes our system of government from any other in the world. But the tardiness and the discourtesy in the government's reply to the proposition put by the opposition in good faith raises concerns and legitimate questions about how fair dinkum the government is about getting apolitical outcomes in the national interest. We found out yesterday that we have got a reply, on prompting, on the Attorney's desk, but I can say at this point in time that I have not seen it on my desk.

There are concerns in the community about executive proscription. Indeed, if I might say so, these concerns were previously reflected by the Prime Minister. Members of the small `l' liberal faction of the Liberal Party would be quite enthralled by a paper prepared by the Prime Minister in July 1994, which was published in Quadrant, in which he acknowledged that past support for unrestrained executive proscription of organisations—with particular reference to the Communist Party dissolution acts—had blemished the Liberal Party's record. The Prime Minister, when speaking about the Liberal Party, said:

quote.para: It disobeyed Voltaire's famous injunction when it attempted to legally proscribe the Communist Party in the early 1950s.

speech.para: That injunction of Voltaire's was, of course, the need for the separation of powers—that, in respect of the enforcement of laws that result in an organisation or an individual suffering a punishment, hardship or disadvantage, there needs to be an impartial and independent body to review the nature of the application of those laws. As a say, members should read the Prime Minister's concerns which he expressed in that July 1994 paper.

You have to concede that there are risks in the exercise of executive proscription—and certainly, as we have said, in executive proscription with inadequate safeguards. Many learned, objective, impartial and sensible people in the community share our views. Aside from the fact of error, you have to look at the issue of public confidence in a system that imposes significant penalties—in this case, the potential for 20 years imprisonment for being a member of a proscribed organisation. Executive decisions are quite clearly open to error—we see it all the time. We have, I believe, successfully impugned the current Attorney-General's exercise of discretion when he was minister for immigration. I think we have successfully impugned the integrity of the exercise of that discretion and whether it was based on ulterior purposes.

talk.start.para: —What rubbish!

—That can be a subject for debate. All I am pointing out is that executive powers can be misused from the point of view of motive. Executive powers can also be misused from the point of view of the information they rely on. In respect of the area of security, we have seen how flawed primary intelligence material can be.

—Mr Deputy Speaker Lindsay, I rise on a point of order. I hesitate to pull the member up in the middle of his oration but I believe that the member, in saying that the then minister for immigration had his integrity impugned over the actions he took as minister, has breached standing order 76. It would assist the House if he would withdraw that imputation.

—For the purpose of getting on with this speech, I withdraw the suggestion that I have impugned the integrity of the then minister, but I assert and reassert that we have impugned the integrity of the decision making process. That is my point: if you do not have a review of and proper safeguards in a decision making process, its integrity is always going to be susceptible to being impugned. That goes not only to sorting out errors but also to the public's confidence in it.

speech.para: In respect of weapons of mass destruction, we have seen how flawed primary security material can be, in both its content and its emphasis. We, as members of this House, are making decisions at this time that are based on hearsay upon hearsay accounts regarding these organisations. In the case of these two particular organisations and what has occurred overseas, I think we can safely accept the reports from the general public which are on the public record. But that is not always going to be the case. Under the definition of `terrorist organisation' in the relevant legislation, organisations like the African National Congress—the ANC—and Fretilin in East Timor could quite conceivably have been proscribed. Whether that was appropriate would depend upon a consideration of the evidence against those organisations, which should be determined by an organisation or a body or a tribunal that is at arm's length from government.

The reality is that in this country we have a constitution that provides for the separation of powers. Before any penalty is applied, there needs to be a consideration of the relevant facts by an independent body or at least the opportunity for an independent tribunal to properly assess the decision making that has occurred. We acknowledge that the government's legislation contains a limited procedure for judicial review as to whether the minister has acted reasonably, but, quite frankly, that would simply involve the minister saying, `I have acted upon the basis of advice from my security agencies.' Under the government's proposal, there is no mechanism for independent merit review to look at that primary security material to see if it justifies the decision.

We must all bear in mind that one of the primary purposes of proscription is to express the public's revulsion at the conduct of these organisations. If the public does not have faith that the proscription process has been above board and that it has been operated fairly and reasonably and on the basis of actual evidence, we risk detracting from that public confidence. Moreover, to have either parliamentary or executive proscription certainly raises significant constitutional issues, and it is in no-one's interests for there to be a successful challenge to these acts of proscription which may simply result in those who permit these atrocities being released into the community and their funds being returned. There are alternative methods with appropriate safeguards. We invite the government to sit down and negotiate them with us in good faith so that we have one model that works and is constitutionally sound. We ask the government to put aside politics and sit down with us on this—they know the law and they have proper advice; we also have advice, of course—and let us come up with a model that actually works.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the Criminal Code Amendment (Hamas and Lashkar-e-Tayyiba) Bill 2003. Like many Australians, I found the news of the arrest of Willie Brigitte last week a further sobering thought in the reality of the serious threat posed by terrorists to our free way of life. Brigitte has demonstrated linkages with al-Qaeda and trained with LET, a Pakistani based terrorist group which is responsible for the deaths of scores of Indians and has connections with the evil al-Qaeda.

speech.para: For generations, the issue of terrorism has been viewed by most Australians as a tragic occurrence taking place in the far distant Middle East, in Ireland or in another distant place. The television footage and newspaper articles were viewed with disbelief but they posed no direct threat to our way of life. Not a second thought was given to taking the kids to school the following morning, catching the bus to work or catching up with friends for a coffee or a bite to eat. Of course, the circumstances of the organised, cold and calculated slaying of thousands of people in New York, Washington and Pennsylvania awoke our nation to a new threat to our free and easy existence. The wakening was more stark than it was for previous generations of Australians who had faced a known and identifiable enemy. Today's enemy can strike unassuming, innocent people anywhere in the world at any time.

By the time the tragic details of 11 September 2001 filtered through to Australians, our country and way of life had already changed forever. The horrific acts in Bali just over 12 months ago, not only in a place closer to home than ever before but also where our own people were among the dead and seriously wounded, only underscored the new reality. The new reality is a world where terrorists, many with a fundamental religious fanaticism, despise our Western culture and the freedom and democracy that until now many have taken for granted. The new reality is that our nation, not by choice but by necessity, has had to reassess our laws and regulations and create a capacity which will allow our intelligence and law enforcement bodies to minimise the threat posed to our society. The Australian people expect nothing less and it is the view of the Howard government that they will get nothing less.

The first priority of any government, and certainly of this government, must be the effective protection of its people. Frankly, economic success and all the other achievements of this government will count for nothing if we are not prepared to put the safety of the Australian people first and foremost, and that is what we are doing today. This bill introduced by this government must be the first step in rectifying deficiencies in current legislation, and the Labor Party must now take the decision as to whether they are capable of also acting in the national interest.

Earlier today, this parliament witnessed a contribution by the Leader of the Opposition which demonstrated in clear terms his inability to support a view held by the majority of Australians over a view held by the ideologically driven left of the Australian Labor Party. The Leader of the Opposition enunciated a view this morning on this broader issue of proscribing an organisation and he suggested—as did the shadow Attorney-General, the member for Barton, earlier—that proscribing a terrorist organisation should be left not to this parliament but to the judiciary. That is the Australian Labor Party's position. They say that the government of the day is incapable of making a decision to act in the best interests of the Australian people.

This position deserves much greater scrutiny because, putting aside any argument about the separation of powers, it highlights a fundamental flaw in this ideological position taken by the Australian Labor Party. The basis of their position, and the justification that their stance lies on, is an assertion that, because of the circumstances surrounding proscription some generations ago concerning debate over the Communist Party, the government of the day is incapable of making a decision to proscribe a terrorist organisation in this parliament. It is an absurd proposition. I say with complete conviction that it is one that the Australian people will see as ridiculous and unsustainable. The Australian people elect the government of the day to act in their best interests.

This is a demonstration of how the Howard government—the Australian government—will act in Australians' best interests. If we are hearing from the Labor Party that the elected government and the elected representatives in this place are incapable of taking an executive decision to proscribe an organisation because of something that happened 30 or 40 years ago in relation to the Communist Party then they really are not serious about providing an alternative to the Australian people. It shows an underlying problem in relation to the stance and position of the current Leader of the Opposition. He surely must be able to see that it is in the best interests of Australians and of this country that the government of the day is able to act swiftly and in accord with the view of the Australian people—and indeed of the world community—to proscribe these organisations for being a particular threat to the Australian people. Make no mistake about what it is that this government is trying to do and about the broader debate that we engage in today. The debate we engage in today is about providing for the Australian people, through their elected representatives, the ability to proscribe organisations that pose specific and definite threats to the safety and security of this nation.

If the Labor Party are arguing that this place and this government, or the government of a future day, are not capable of taking that decision and if they believe that that decision should rest with the judiciary—the unelected judiciary—then that is a shameful and untenable position. Like many positions that have been adopted by the Australian Labor Party in this debate before, I suspect that it will change in the fullness of time.

talk.start.para: —There are members opposite who interject on this issue and who hold very strong and passionate beliefs about terrorism that takes place overseas. If they want to thrust Australia into the same position and into an untenable future, they need to continue down the same line they are on in the debate today. We are talking about two organisations today that are at the tip of the iceberg. One of them is Hamas, which is a dreadful organisation that has wreaked havoc throughout the Middle East for many years. To suggest that this government or an Australian government of future days is not capable of taking a decision to proscribe such organisations really does leave the Australian Labor Party completely out of touch with the view of all Australians.

speech.para: It is important as part of this debate today that we look at the proscribing of terrorist organisations and the procedures that are in place before a listing can be made. We know that we already have in place a well-established process for listing an organisation. That process will not change as a result of this bill. It is very important to note that the only thing that will change is that one element of the assessment—that an organisation first be placed as a terrorist organisation by the United Nations—will be removed. The Australian Labor Party, not only in this debate, advocate that organisations should be first proscribed by the United Nations, which is a completely unworkable situation. They are saying now that there should be a further roadblock put in the way, that these organisations should be proscribed by the judiciary—not by this parliament, the people's parliament, the people's voice in the Australian community, but by the judiciary—after first being proscribed by the United Nations. It is an absurd proposition and it is one that is unsustainable if they want to offer themselves as an alternative government to the Australian people at the upcoming election.

I want to continue in relation to the listing of terrorist organisations. It is important to explain the very responsible position that this government puts. First, the Director-General of Security provides material to the Attorney-General's Department regarding the background, training activities, terrorist activities and relevant statements of the organisation in question. The Australian Government Solicitor then provides advice on whether the material provided by the director-general is sufficient to enable the Attorney-General to be satisfied on reasonable grounds that the relevant criteria for the listing of the organisation have been met. The Attorney-General's Department then provides a submission for the Attorney-General which sets out the information and recommends that the organisation be listed as a terrorist organisation, based on the evidence received by the Director-General of Security. The Attorney-General, who considers the submission, must be satisfied on reasonable grounds that the relevant organisation is engaged in, preparing, planning, assisting in or fostering the doing of a terrorist act, whether or not the terrorist attack has occurred or will occur. Importantly, if the Attorney-General is satisfied that the criteria have been met, he then signs a statement summarising the grounds upon which the organisation meets the requirements for a listing and approves the proposed regulation for the listing of the organisation and accompanying documentation.

I would suggest that it is the view of all reasonable Australians that that is a sustainable position to adopt. This government has taken a very measured stance and approach in relation to the proscribing of organisations and, indeed, to the measures strengthening the powers provided to ASIO. At every turn we have been blocked by the Australian Labor Party. The Australian people must recognise as part of this debate today that, behind the scenes, the Australian Labor Party seek to undermine the process taken by the government at every available opportunity. This is something that needs to be spelt out very clearly because, despite the rhetoric that we will hear from the opposition spokesperson for foreign affairs shortly, and from the member for Banks and the member for Denison—

talk.start.para: —How do you know what I'm going to say, boofhead?

—What you are going to say, member for Griffith, is very predictable. What you are going to do, like those before you and those who will follow you, is talk the talk but not walk the walk. As on many of these issues—and it is certainly no better demonstrated than in the issue of terrorist organisations and legislation—for the Australian Labor Party, led by the member for Griffith, the talk will be great and the action will be nothing. It has happened in many debates before. He aspires to be Leader of the Opposition and we know that that is the ultimate goal. I notice we only have one of the `roosters' in the chamber today. We know that in this circumstance they are setting up the Leader of the Opposition for yet another fall. The member for Griffith knows that that position is unsustainable and, despite the talk and the rhetoric that will come from him and other members opposite as part of this debate, we know that at the end of the day they are being undermined by the Left of the Labor Party and that the caucus are not with them on this issue.

speech.para: It is important as part of this debate today that the Australian people recognise that the Labor Party are not only weak in relation to trying to proscribe organisations that may pose some terrorist threat to the Australian people; they have also undermined every step that has been taken by this government to strengthen the position of our law enforcement and intelligence bodies in trying to combat the evils of terrorism.

I want to finish in support of this bill today by saying that the election is only 12 months away and it is time that the Australian Labor Party started to listen to the message that is being sent to them by the Australian people. The Australian people want to maintain our way of life. We want to maintain our freedom and our democracy. We can maintain that freedom and democracy in generations to come only if we take the hard decisions today in relation to clamping down on terrorism. This bill before the House today is a demonstration of this government's commitment to provide as best we can security to future generations of Australians.

Australia faces in the current age its greatest threat in many generations. Unless the Labor Party support us in clamping down with very definite measures on terrorism, we will witness atrocities like those that have taken place not just in the Middle East, the United Kingdom and the United States but as close to home as Indonesia. There can be no more horrific thought than a terrorism attack taking place on Australian soil and Australians being affected by such an atrocity. The reality is that this government needs to provide the greatest resources to our intelligence and security bodies so that they at least have a fighting chance of preventing that sort of atrocity.

My plea today is for the Australian Labor Party to support the government not just on this bill but on further measures which would see the sanctity of the Australian parliament preserved and give us the ability to make the decision in future times to proscribe organisations without having them first proscribed by the United Nations and certainly without having to have them proscribed by the judiciary. There is a disallowable instrument in relation to the proscription of these organisations which can be taken up by the Senate in extreme circumstances. Safeguards exist in relation to this legislation. The position taken by this government is an entirely sustainable and strong one, and our plea today, on behalf of the Australian people, must be for the Australian Labor Party to support the Howard government's strong stance on protecting Australia's interests.

talk.start.para: —I fear we are fixated on the muscle of the politics instead of the wisdom of the policy. This debate on the Criminal Code Amendment (Hamas and Lashkar-e-Tayyiba) Bill 2003 has been driven not by substance but by a desire to position the political opponents of this government in a way which will do them discredit. But it is unfair to proceed in this way and it illustrates what I believe is an increasing degree of vulnerability that is being shown by those on the government side and that is being manifested in an abuse of the offices that they hold.

speech.para: Abuse of the offices they hold is a strong charge to lay against those who hold executive government but it has been manifested in some of the great events that have played themselves out in the public life of this country: the `children overboard' affair, the intelligence briefings and the circumstances in which we went to war, and now the measures that are being proposed to deal with terrorism. In each of those circumstances there were substantial issues that required the attention of this parliament and the Australian community. No-one pretends that those who illegally bring to Australia persons seeking refuge are doing it out of the goodness of their hearts. Most of these people are people smugglers, and we do need to address policy measures to deal with that. But we do not need to engender fear and we certainly do not need to do it in a way which demonises those who are fleeing countries where they have faced persecution in circumstances under which they are entitled to claim protection under international refugee law.

In the case of the circumstances in Iraq, there were substantial issues again but we were confronted not by open disclosure of the full remit of intelligence but rather by a distorted picture, and our own government was as complicit in that process as the governments of both the United States and the United Kingdom appear to have been —and now we turn to terrorism. We turn to terrorism in a framework where it ought to be conceded that nobody in this parliament wishes to expose any Australian to harm, where we have joined together—every parliamentarian—in a year when we have seen, for the first time, young Australians travelling overseas exposed to a tragedy of the kind that happened in Bali. For the minister to come into this House and suggest that there is any desire on the part of any parliamentarian to allow those circumstances to arise again in this country is contemptible, but those opposite want to use this to engender fear.

Let us look at some of these situations that have been put up. It has been suggested that urgency attends these matters in such a way that the proposal that the opposition has put to this government five months ago, an efficient system that would allow for judicial proscription of organisations, is unworkable. I say two things to that. Firstly, such a scheme already exists under the laws of this country; it is perfectly workable. Secondly, I say it is unarguably constitutional. That is not the case with the measures that this government has thus far advanced. It is certainly the case that any constitutional scholar of any repute will say even the measures that we are passing through this House today are capable of challenge. But anyone who would suggest that giving to the executive of this country an unreviewable discretion to determine whether or not an organisation is to be proscribed—and thereby any Australian citizen who belongs to it then rendered subject to a criminal penalty of 20 years imprisonment—could survive constitutional challenge is really testing my patience. I find extraordinarily puzzling the fact that the Attorney-General of this country can come forward without raising the spectre that he must be advised that this very process which he asserts is the appropriate one has not been the subject of constitutional doubt.
It is clear that the doctrine of the separation of powers is integral to our Constitution. Section 71 of the Australian Constitution provides:

quote.para: The judicial power of the Commonwealth shall be vested in a Federal Supreme Court, to be called the High Court of Australia, and in such other federal courts as the Parliament creates, and in such other courts as it invests with federal jurisdiction.

speech.para: Among other things, the separation of judicial powers implies that parliament cannot confer on a non-judicial body the power to conclusively determine the limits to its own jurisdiction. The separation and insulation of judicial power achieved by chapter III of the Constitution play a crucial role in safeguarding the basic rights of individuals to be free of arbitrary government action. In Street v. the Queensland Bar Association, His Honour Mr Justice Deane, in the context of listing a number of rights contained in the Constitution, commented:

quote.para: The most important of them is the guarantee that the citizen can be subjected to the exercise of Commonwealth judicial power only by the `courts' designated by Chapter III.

speech.para: These separation of powers issues were played out in the decision in the Communist Party case. In that case the court affirmed that it possessed a power of judicial review of legislative action. This constitutionally entrenched power also extends to executive action. In fact, at issue in the Communist Party dissolution case was a discretion conferred upon a member of the executive. Under section 5(2) of the Communist Party Dissolution Act 1950, an organisation could be declared unlawful where:

quote.para: ... the Governor-General is satisfied that a body of persons is a body of persons to which this section applies and that the continued existence of that body of persons would be prejudicial to the security and defence of the Commonwealth or to the execution or maintenance of the Constitution or of the laws of the Commonwealth ...

speech.para: The problem with that section and also with section 9(2) of the act lay in the fact that it conferred an unreviewable discretion upon a member of the executive. According to Mr Justice Fullagar, the sections were invalid because they imposed `legal consequences on a legislative or executive opinion which itself supplies the only link between the power and the legal consequences of the opinion'. The attempt by parliament to determine the scope of its own powers by conferring an uncontrolled discretion upon the executive breached Mr Justice Fullagar's maxim `that a stream cannot rise higher than its source'.

Let us make this absolutely plain: the only certain way that any measure that this parliament passes will meet judicial approval in the High Court, when ultimately somebody is prosecuted and raises these issues, is to follow the recommendations that have been put forward by the shadow Attorney-General and put to the Prime Minister. They are included as measures now within the Criminal Code to deal with subversive organisations. They are framed in that way to avoid the very issues that I have just referred to.

Politics is driving this. The government knows that the way it can most properly and securely address the protection of Australian citizens when it is dealing with a decision to outlaw an organisation is to follow the course that was recommended to it by the opposition five months ago. Instead, the government wishes to persist with the proposal that would vest the sole determination as to whether or not an Australian who gives support or belongs to a certain organisation becomes a criminal, subject to 20 years imprisonment, in a single member of the executive—the Attorney-General. That is precisely what was held to be unconstitutional in the Communist Party dissolution case. The government might say that the court has changed and some years have passed. But why proceed with a way which is obviously doubtful in its constitutional application when a secure means is available? Why, having made that choice, does it then seek to blame the opposition for raising, quite properly, the appropriateness of an alternative means of dealing with a substantial and substantive issue?

I want to address a couple of other points about accountability. The government said that a regulation could be made. Yes, it could. And what regulation would have been made in this instance if this parliament was not exercising a power of review? It would have been different, because put initially to the opposition was a proposal that did not distinguish between the military arm of Hamas, the terrorist arm of Hamas and the charitable and social arms of the organisation. What we would have seen is those Australians who have provided and will, no doubt, continue to provide support to their relatives and friends in areas which are under the social and administrative control of Hamas but who do not provide any assistance whatsoever to the terrorist arm of that organisation being subjected to a possible 20-year imprisonment.

Let us go through the kind of circumstance that I am troubled with. If we did have a regulation which made law the fact that Hamas, broadly, was illegal, what remedy would be available? Yes, it could be disallowed, but who seriously proposes that any party is going to disallow a regulation of that nature? But, because the government had to put it before and get it through this parliament, we have improved the drafting of it so that we are not picking up the innocents and making the scope too broad. Parliament is playing a part. I am not suggesting that these issues are simple for Australia. Equally, I am not suggesting that they are new.

The claim of urgency is absurd in the case of Hamas. I once played a part in the executive government, and in the time that I held ministerial office I was briefed about the security threat to Australia that Hamas potentially provided. I was told that it did not present a present threat. I think similar advice has been tendered to the current government. We have to think very carefully about the consequences when we consider our approach to organisations that engage in conduct we disapprove of overseas. For about 100 years we have been developing a multicultural Australia. Absorbed into our community are people from all over the world. Some of them come from countries with hundreds or thousands of years of blood feuds. We have both Croatians and Serbs. We have people from both Catholic and Protestant Ireland. We have people from Sri Lanka and people who are Tamils. We have people from Turkey and we have Kurds. In each of their countries there are low-level and sometimes high-level wars, civil wars or acts of terrorism occurring.

Most of us would know people who have been supporters of some of those organisations that engage in acts that we disapprove of. Within this country, there have been many who support the IRA, some who support the PKK, some who support the Tamils, some who support Protestant Ireland's groups—the Unionists that have been involved in terrorist-like activities—and some who support the Serbian and Croatian activities which have been entirely reprehensible. Yet the thing we have managed to do is keep those conflicts out of this country. That is one of the advantages of proceeding normally through the UN. This is not just a wise precaution to prevent executive governments simply choosing organisations; it is to make certain that there is basically a common view that an organisation has acted in so reprehensible a way that the entire world community agrees that not only should no Australian play any role in it but also if they do they should be subjected to criminal prosecution and face 20 years imprisonment.

But if we are going to go beyond that and start being pressed by various causes on various sides of these intractable dividing issues that have been live in other countries but not hitherto brought into our own nation—if we are going to be asked by the Kurds to proscribe various organisations on the Turkish side, if we are going to be asked by the Sri Lankans to proscribe the Tamil groups and if we are going to be asked by the Tamil groups to proscribe the Sinhalese—it is very likely that we will bring into our own domestic political environment debates on matters that we wish were left aside, and there may not be the consensus that we would otherwise rely on.

It is easy for us not to see the world as others see it. Take, for example, the situation in Kashmir. We all know that we have a divided community in relation to Israel. Nobody can pretend that there are not people within our own community who see the acts of the Israeli government when it bulldozes houses as applying something like group punishment which should be condemned in the same way as we would condemn terrorist acts committed by those on the Palestinian side. So we know there is a lively debate about the position of Israel and how people within our domestic community see it, and so too with Kashmir. I recently read an article in GRANTA by a Hindu Indian who had spent some time in Kashmir. He said of that country:

quote.para: About 50,000 people—militants, soldiers and civilians—have been killed in the uprising that the Muslims of the Kashmir valley began against Indian rule in 1990. The Indian press prefers to describe the situation in the valley as a spillover from the jihad in Afghanistan, the timid Kashmiris having been overwhelmed by Pakistani and Afghan terrorists looking to wage fresh holy wars. This broad picture, which depicted Pakistan and Islamic fundamentalists as the major villains, blurred and then dissolved altogether during the several weeks I spent in Kashmir last year. Most Kashmiris still follow an unorthodox Sufi version of Islam. The brutalities of the 400,000 Indian soldiers in the valley was, in my view, what had pushed a small number of young Kashmiri Muslims into the kind of jihadi extremism promoted by religious groups in Pakistan and created popular support for the increasingly large number of Pakistan-backed militants fighting the Indian army in Kashmir.

speech.para: That is the view of Pankaj Mishra, a secular Indian with a Hindu background. I do not know whether that is a fair account, but I can certainly say that the world is much more complicated than we give credit to in this parliament. We need to make certain that, when we pass a law that says that support for or membership of an organisation warrants 20 years imprisonment, we do not do so driven by a government focusing on politics, seeking to wedge its opponents and seeking to use fear for political reasons. Rather, it needs to be done in a way which is transparent, objectively justifiable and capable of being explained either to the United Nations or to a court or at the very least to this parliament.

The member for Cook illustrated the point when he said, `We are accountable for our decisions.' We should not allow the executive to make the sole decision. We, each of us, are elected by our constituents to exercise judgment. We exercise that judgment wisely or unwisely, and we are each accountable for our decisions. We cannot ignore our accountability and our responsibility and invest it in the executive. If we do, we allow unreviewable discretion. As a consequence of that, you can do the same as you would have done with the Communist Party Dissolution Bill—that is, make the existence of an organisation unlawful and punish any person who is resident in this country, citizen or non-citizen, and who belongs to that organisation not by a small criminal penalty but by 20 years imprisonment. These are matters which are so serious that you do not give them to a single person, you do not give them to an Attorney-General and you do not give them to an unreviewable body. You make certain that you have an accountable, transparent process which is not capable of abuse, and this government has shown the capacity for abuse too many times. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —When I gave my first speech in this chamber, I spoke about the difference between liberal democracy and social democracy. I spoke about my adherence to the liberal democracy philosophy and how it stood and I stood in revulsion of social democracy. The other side of the chamber takes the view that the collective stands above the individual; I take the view that the individual stands above the collective. In large part, the debate today on the Criminal Code Amendment (Hamas and Lashkar-e-Tayyiba) Bill 2003 and the debate in the broader context of how we as a liberal democratic nation face up to the threat of international terrorism is played out along those same lines.

speech.para: We hear the sophistic arguments of the ALP—and their claim that they are the ones concerned about the individual. We just heard the member for Denison, who represents the hard Left of the ALP, talk about how he takes the view that it is all about providing protection for the individual and about what motivates the ALP when they put forward their argument that it should not be this parliament but rather a member of the judiciary that makes determinations about whether to proscribe an organisation.

To expand on this a little further and to put it into the context of the debate that this parliament and other parliaments of Western democracies around the world are currently grappling with, it comes down to this: on September 11—and it has almost become a cliche now—the face of modern liberal democracy as we know it changed, and on October 12 with the terrorist bombings in Bali it changed in our own backyard. The responsibility that we as a government must face up to now is how to respond to the changing paradigm—changing from the threat that previously existed against our country from rogue nation states to the modern-day threat. The modern-day threat is no longer, as it was in much of the last century, the scourge of nation states with rogue armies; rather, the modern day threat is cells of maybe five, 10, 50 or 100 individuals who are motivated to wreak havoc. How do we deal with those individuals that would like to make the most of the freedoms we have in liberal democracies like Australia, the United States and the United Kingdom and that exploit those liberties in a way that maximises their ability to rain havoc on the people of those countries?

In the main, history demonstrates that the people who live in Western democracies are peace loving, but we will always stand firm in the face of those nations or those individuals that would seek to threaten our existence and our way of life. We will also stand firm in the face of those nation states that support those individuals that would threaten our way of life. That, in essence, underscores in large part the reason I was proud to be part of a government that took a very principled and solid stand against the Taliban in Afghanistan and against Saddam Hussein's regime in Iraq.

The great irony in this debate is the fact that we saw during the presidential addresses two weeks ago members of the Greens—of the hard Left—come into this chamber and wear on their lapels the faces of the two detained Australians. In this particular instance, I have some sympathy for the argument that these people should not be detained for two years without charge—I do have sympathy for that argument, and the Prime Minister has sympathy for that argument as well. Indeed, the Prime Minister raised the issue with the US President. But what a great shame that those on the left of the political spectrum do not have the same temerity when it comes to having lapel pins for the several hundred thousand Iraqis that have been murdered by Saddam Hussein's regime or, perhaps, for the hundreds of women in Iraq that were gang raped under Saddam Hussein's regime. I never ever hear the Greens make comments about those things. I never ever hear the hard Left of the ALP talk about some of the fundamental values that we on this side of the chamber are prepared to stand up for and about which we are prepared to say throughout the world, `We will not turn a blind eye to that kind of disgraceful behaviour by rogue nations and by totalitarian leaders.'

There were people that took the Left's point of view in World War II. There were the appeasers. Highlighted among them was Neville Chamberlain. But I say thank goodness for Winston Churchill, because were it not for Winston Churchill we might never have risen up to face the fight against the Nazis. And who can say whether, had we risen to the occasion earlier, the Nazis might not have been prevented from causing the kind of havoc they caused—havoc they had ample time to cause while the appeasers of the Centre Left stood around saying, `What we need is more time. What we need is to be more reasonable people. What we need is to sit down at the table and to talk these things through.' Sometimes decisions have to be made. That is the reason the Australian people elect governments and it is the whole reason that governments in liberal democracies across the world are elected: to make decisions.

We start to see again the philosophy of the ALP, the Greens and the Democrats and their inherent inability to ever make a decision. We see that played out in the argument that is before the chamber today. Principally we see it when the Leader of the Opposition comes into this chamber to speak about the way in which he believes executive proscription is the wrong thing and how, according to the opposition, the right thing is judicial proscription. The logic of this fails me. It absolutely fails me. Apparently, if you take the opposition's argument, it is being more responsible to the Australian people to have decisions about which terrorist organisations are proscribed made by an unaccountable, unreviewable judiciary than it is to have those decisions made by a member of the executive. A member of the executive is someone who comes into this chamber and is subject to question time in every sitting, a member of the executive must be re-elected by his constituency in order to come once again into this chamber and a member of the executive is subject to the full review and spotlight of the press gallery, which is full on a regular basis. Apparently, it is not enough that the people taking such decisions should be members of the executive, who are entirely accountable not only to this parliament but, through this parliament, to the Australian people. Apparently that is not enough.

The opposition's ridiculous argument is, `No. What is better for the Australian people and what provides for a greater degree of accountability is for a judge to make the decision about which organisation should be proscribed.' Apparently, it is the judiciary that provide accountability to the Australian people. The logic of that argument is completely and totally flawed. I would be very interested to hear the member for Griffith, who I suspect recognises the inherent flaw in the ALP's position, give a defence that explains how a member of the judiciary is more accountable than a member of the executive, who is accountable through this parliament to the Australian people. I issue that challenge to the member for Griffith, who is sitting in the chamber. I challenge him to explain that to the Australian people.

In terms of fearmongering and scare campaigns, we have heard the ALP mention, time and time again, that the Australian people are subjected to some kind of ruthless campaign of wedge politics by the Howard government on this issue. The only organisation engaged in a scare campaign, the only organisation I hear constantly telling the Australian people they ought to be afraid, is the Australian Labor Party. I heard that from numerous speakers on the opposition benches today. I heard the member for Denison talk about how we cannot trust our minister and how we have to question the motives of our minister. Shamefully, I heard the Leader of the Opposition stand up in this chamber and say to the Australian people that he had proved what great liars the Prime Minister and the Attorney-General were, and I heard him tell the Australian people that they ought to be suspicious of the government they elected.

It is absurd for the opposition to engage in such hypocrisy. It is hypocrisy for the opposition to sit there and say that it is the Howard government that is engaging in wedge politics when the whole time every single one of their arguments is predicated upon one fundamental proposition—and that is, `Don't believe what the government tells you.
