The government's up to no good. You can't believe its bona fides. You should be suspicious. You should question its motives.' I can give an actual quote from the Leader of the Opposition. He said, `We should question the motives of the Attorney-General.' If anyone is promoting a culture of fear or mistrust, it is my contention that it is very clearly the Labor Party. It is the Labor Party who would rather walk down the path of denying the responsibility that we as a government have to the Australian people to take decisions and to stand by those decisions. The Labor Party would rather take the soft option of saying, `This matter is too complicated. Let's get the judiciary to deal with it. That is a safer situation.'

I also want to consider for a moment the argument that the member for Denison put forward when he said that his primary concern about this bill was the constitutionality of executive prescription. It would seem to me that the ALP are carrying a lot of baggage on this issue. It would seem to me that ingrained in their psyche are decades of concern and outrage about the Communist Party case. We are seeing that bubble up now. We are seeing it rise to the top in this debate, as the ALP say, `No, we stand opposed to executive proscriptions of terrorist organisations,'—and when you ask why they hark back to the days of yore when the Communist Party case came before the High Court. This is not the same; this is not remotely the same. There is a great divide between the situation we have here today and the Communist Party case. But unfortunately in the ALP's mind there is a great link there; there is a bridge there. We see the opposition carrying all this baggage from the Communist Party case as they stand defiant in the face of executive proscription. I have to say that I do not really understand it. The Communist Party case is quite different.

I ask the member for Denison, the Leader of the Opposition and the members for Barton, Griffith and McMillan, who are in the chamber: if they are so concerned about the constitutionality of executive proscription, don't they realise that the Constitution still remains supreme? If there is so much concern that the government is going to misuse executive proscription, why would it exist, when we all know that the Constitution remains supreme? If this government tried to do something unconstitutional, you could expect that it would be ruled out of order by the High Court immediately. There is no need for great concern. There is no need to tell the Australian people that they have to mistrust their government. There is no need to incite concern in the Australian people on the pretence that it is all about individual liberties. Under our Constitution this government cannot do something unconstitutional, because our Constitution remains supreme. This is where the member for Denison pulled the rug out from underneath his own feet when he spoke about his concern about executive proscription. If the executive were to do something illegal under the Australian Constitution it would be ruled unconstitutional by the courts. The safeguard that the founding fathers of this nation set up on day one of federation is the required check and balance that the member for Denison claims that he does not see. It is right there; all he needs to do is open his eyes to see it.

I also want to cover the situation this bill is dealing with. It comes down to this: when we originally moved for proscription as a power for the government we did so on the basis that we believed certain terrorist organisations needed to be confronted head on. We believed that certain organisations were concerning themselves only with creating fear and spreading terrorism. We took the view that, in order for a government to deal in a sustainable and appropriate way with the threat that these organisations posed, we should allow for these organisations to be proscribed or listed. In doing so, we set in place a number of checks and balances in the legislation. The Australian people should know what those checks and balances are so that they can see through the misinformation that the Labor Party spreads when it talks about the great concerns that we all have and when the member for Denison talks about innocents being locked up for 20 years. Let us be clear about what the safeguards are as they already exist.

I want to outline to the House the process for executive proscription, because it is very clear. We are not seeking to change the process in this bill, except for one part—and I will explain that in a moment. The first step in the process is that the Director-General of Security provides material to the Attorney-General's Department regarding the background, training activities, terrorist activities and relevant statements of the organisation that proscription is being sought for. The second step is that the Australian Government Solicitor provides advice on whether the material provided by the director-general is sufficient to enable the Attorney-General to be satisfied on reasonable grounds that the relevant criteria for the listing of the organisation have been met.

The third step is that the Attorney-General's Department provides a submission for the Attorney-General, setting out the information and recommending that the organisation be listed as a terrorist organisation, based on the advice received from the Director-General of Security. The Attorney-General then considers that submission, and he must be satisfied on reasonable grounds—which is a legal test and subject to review—that the relevant organisation is engaged in preparing, planning, assisting in or fostering the carrying out of a terrorist act, whether or not that act will or will not occur. If the Attorney-General is satisfied that all of the criteria have been met, he signs a statement summarising the grounds upon which the organisation meets the requirements for listing as a terrorist organisation and approves the proposed regulation for the listing of the organisation and accompanying documentation.

They are all the steps. But the ALP insisted, through the Senate, that there be a step in there as well that says for the Australian government to list a terrorist organisation it must already be listed by the United Nations Security Council. This government is the only government in the world that faces that additional hurdle. The United States does not, New Zealand does not, the United Kingdom does not and Canada does not. None of those jurisdictions face the additional hurdle of the requirement that the organisation be listed with the United Nations Security Council as a terrorist organisation.

Let there be no confusion about what we are attempting to do today. It is simply to remove that requirement for the organisation to be listed by the UN Security Council. That is it. All the other safeguards stay. We heard the opposition talk about merits review. That is a merits review. It requires a merits review by the Attorney-General. That remains, but we want to remove just the requirement for it to be listed by the United Nations Security Council. Why? Firstly, because it is an unnecessary and burdensome requirement for the Australian government to comply with and, secondly, because the UN Security Council does not concern itself in large part with terrorist organisations. In fact, the listing process for the United Nations Security Council was principally concerned only with al-Qaeda. That is where it all commenced. Many organisations are not listed, and I highlight one for example. Jemaah Islamiah, an organisation that has proved to be a direct threat to the Australian people and indeed successfully murdered 88 Australians in Bali, was not listed by the UN Security Council. So we had to take the cumbersome path of seeking to have it listed.

What is the response that we hear from the Labor Party when we say, `That's not good enough. We want to be able to expedite the process so that we can respond in a timely fashion'? We heard the response today. We heard it from the mouth of the Leader of the Opposition. His response was: `You haven't tried hard enough to get it listed with the UN Security Council.' That is absolutely pathetic. For a party which claims to be an alternative Australian government to say: `Sorry, you haven't tried hard enough to have it listed with the UN Security Council,' to me underscores their whole attitude on this issue. It can be summarised as an incapability to make a decision in the first instance. They want to tender it all out: `Let's contract it out to the UN Security Council. Let's contract it out to the judiciary.' That is not good enough. The Australian people demand of their government a willingness to make decisions. The listing process has adequate safeguards as it is. The removal of the UN Security Council listing requirement is very reasonable. I know the Australian people see the falseness of the Labor Party's position of seeking to tender it out to the judiciary. That is a completely unaccountable way of governing and a completely unacceptable way for the Australian people to exist.

talk.start.para: —The first responsibility of this parliament and of the executive government of this country is to provide for the national security of this country. There is no higher responsibility. For the four decades or more that we on this side of the House have occupied the treasury bench of this country, we have taken that responsibility with the utmost seriousness. The Australian people turned to us to govern this country during the First World War. The Australian people turned to us to govern this country at the height of the Second World War. We were the government of this country when this country went to war in the first Gulf War. We are a party, an opposition and an alternative government of Australia rich in the tradition and the responsibility of providing for this country's national security.

speech.para: We stand here today as an alternative government resolutely determined to handle the threat which is represented by terrorist organisations around the world. Why do we do that? Because it is our view, as the alternative government of Australia, that terrorist organisations wherever they are found, whichever country they are found in, represent a threat not just to this country's security, because of the global nature of terrorism, but to civilisation in the broad. Terrorism is repugnant to Australians; it is repugnant to all civilised peoples.

The Howard government most recently has had a very practical national security challenge in its in-tray. That very practical national security challenge has revolved around the case of one Mr Brigitte. Mr Brigitte, a terrorist suspect known to the French intelligence authorities, was allowed into this country on a tourism visa in May of this year. He had been known to French intelligence authorities for three years or more. We do not know exactly how long he had been on the French national terrorism database, but he had been on it for some time.

But despite that fact and despite the fact that we are in an environment two years after September 11 and more than one year after Bali, in an age where the government in this country talks about national security and terrorism threats day in and day out, what happens? The Howard government issues a known al-Qaeda suspect with a tourism visa to come and do some surfing at Bondi. While down at Bondi or thereabouts for some four or five months, he had, we are now informed, considerable association and involvement with other potential terrorist cells in this country and was—in the words of the Director-General of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, if I paraphrase him correctly—plainly up to no good while in Australia. And his presence in Australia was made possible because he was issued a visa by the government of Australia.

Beyond that, we now have the return of this individual to France. But, not learning from this practical experience, and given that tens of thousands of other visas have been issued from France to allow people to travel to Australia on tourism visas without having any access to the French national terrorism database in cross-referencing these individuals before they travel to Australia, the Howard government now—as of this day, 5 November 2003—refuses to say, `We think we should send back the list of those to whom we have issued visas to the French authorities to cross-reference now whether there is in fact any correlation of names.' I would regard this—and I put this challenge to government members in the chamber—as a very practical thing to do, one of those practical things which the Howard government seems disinclined to do.

But of course the practical challenge of national security does not stop there, because the revelations we have had about the inaccessibility of the French domestic national terrorism database do not lie purely with France. In the case of how many other countries with whom we have intelligence-sharing relationships do we not have access to their domestic terrorism databases as well? How many tens of thousands of visas have been issued to German nationals, Italian nationals, Spanish nationals, Greek nationals—to individuals who may be listed on the domestic national terrorism databases of those countries but, because they have not been placed on an Interpol global watch list, are nonetheless issued automatically with a tourism visa to enter this country?

Again the challenge of a practical nature to the Howard government is: how could this have been allowed to happen? It is a very basic question—one of those practical things of national security. We have a government which talks about national security day in, day out, but the Australian people would like to know what the government is actually doing about national security day in, day out. It seems, in the matter of the Brigitte case, that it is not a lot.

It is the Brigitte case which brings us to the chamber today to debate the legislation which is before us. The Howard government, with its incompetence in dealing with a known al-Qaeda suspect in allowing that suspect to enter the country, suddenly seeks to mask its incompetence on this matter by dramatically introducing legislation into this parliament to ban a terrorist organisation with which Brigitte has been reportedly associated—Lashkar-e-Taiba, LET—and, at the same time, the Hamas terrorist organisation. The truth is that this government has been incompetent in not outlawing these two terrorist organisations a long time ago. Why did the government not turn around and ban LET over the last year or two? Why did the government not ban the Hamas terrorist organisation some time ago? What we have seen are parallels to the delays we saw in the government handling appropriately the outlawing of Jemaah Islamiah in the months leading up to the horrible events of October 2002.

How do we go about outlawing terrorist organisations in this country? There are two mechanisms currently available. One is listing with the UN Security Council under Security Council resolution 1267, from memory. The second is that we have the capacity for Australian national legislation to outlaw organisations on an individual basis. These are the two mechanisms available to us: UN Security Council listing and Australian national legislation. The Attorney-General, the master of the half-truth, this morning said in this parliament that the only mechanism advocated by this side of the House is the UN Security Council. He either suffers from extraordinary amnesia or he has been loose with the truth. In this parliament not long ago I remember being party to a debate where we combined as a parliament to ban, by a single legislative act of this parliament, the Hezbollah External Terrorist Organisation. We on this side of the parliament said that, when it comes to dealing with organisations of this nature, where listing through the UN Security Council is not possible for reasons of either time or politics, the parliament of this country is designed for this purpose: to ban an organisation which represents a threat to civilians either in this country or abroad.

The great lie which lies at the heart of the government's case in this debate today is that we on this side of the parliament support only the UN Security Council as a mechanism for outlawing terrorist organisations. That is an unadulterated lie, because we have said in this place time and time again and demonstrated through our actions in the outlawing of the Hezbollah External Terrorist Organisation that that is but one arm in the armoury which we deploy in the outlawing of terrorist organisations. The second arm is specific national legislation. That is the core untruth being advanced by those opposite in this debate today, and it is an untruth which has to be confronted squarely and head on.

Of course, the government itself has supported the UN listing system under UN Security Council resolution 1267. In fact, under that they have sought and obtained, belatedly, the banning of Jemaah Islamiah. In fact, it has become the vehicle through which 14 separate terrorist organisations are outlawed globally: Abu Sayyaf, al-Qaeda, Ansar al-Islam, the Armed Islamic Group, Asbat al-Ansar, the Egyptian Islamic Jihad, Harakat ul-Mujaheddin, the Hezbollah External Terrorist Organisation, the Islamic Army of Aden, the Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan, Jaish-e-Mohammed, Jemaah Islamiah, Lashkar-e-Jhangvi and the Salafist Group for Call and Combat. We have derision from those opposite in relation to the UN Security Council's capacity to outlaw terrorist organisations. I have just read to the parliament and the country a list of 14 such organisations which have already been outlawed, including those closest to the concerns of this country in recent times: al-Qaeda and Jemaah Islamiah.

So why have we got this debate before us now? It is because the Brigitte case has blown up in the government's face. For that reason, we have this extraordinary exercise in the parliament today whereby we rush to the exercise of banning the organisation Lashkar-e-Taiba because that is the organisation with which Brigitte has been associated in the past, notwithstanding the fact the Howard government allowed him into the country in the first place.

On 3 November in this chamber—only two days ago—the Leader of the Opposition posed a question to the Attorney-General. He asked, `Why haven't you looked at the outlawing of this organisation with which Brigitte is associated, either through the UN or through separate legislation of this parliament?' The answer we had was that no such action had been undertaken. Then, mysteriously, on 4 November, what happens? A letter arrives at the office of the Leader of the Opposition suggesting specific legislation to ban this organisation, Lashkar-e-Taiba. On 5 November—today—here we are in the parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia enacting precisely that proposal to outlaw a terrorist organisation.

But there is a pattern of behaviour when it comes to these sorts of delays on the part of the Howard government. Remember Jemaah Islamiah? Throughout the course of 2002 we had warnings from the Australian intelligence community that Jemaah Islamiah represented a threat to Australians in South-East Asia. We had clear evidence from the Australian intelligence community that Jemaah Islamiah was linked with al-Qaeda, which had already been responsible for the atrocious terrorist attacks in the United States on September 11 the previous year. Yet, despite that, was any action taken by the Howard government to obtain the outlawing of Jemaah Islamiah prior to the Bali bombings? No. There was not a single action on the part of this government to outlaw an organisation which, some five or six months ago, the Office of National Assessments, in an oral briefing to the foreign minister, had said represented a potential terrorist threat to Australians.

So we had to go through the experience of October 12 for there to be a mass of panic, both political and policy related, on government benches. That resulted in two weeks of frenetic activity whereby an application was put to the UN Security Council immediately following the Bali bombings on October 12. The organisation, Jemaah Islamiah, was then listed and proscribed by the UN, and therefore proscribed globally, as of 27 October that year. But the principle at stake is the same. Jemaah Islamiah had already been known to Australian intelligence for a long period of time, but no action was taken to outlaw this organisation until a catastrophe occurred.

It was similar with Brigitte. It was a lesser catastrophe but someone arrived in the country who is known already by French intelligence to be associated with an al-Qaeda related organisation, namely, it seems, Lashkar-e-Taiba. Nonetheless, this individual was issued with a tourism visa to visit this country. Suddenly, when this becomes a matter of public and political embarrassment for the government, we have a stampede of activity. Inertia beforehand, but a stampede of activity afterwards. The pattern of behaviour is clear: this government talks all the time about national security, but when it comes to doing something about national security in a relevant time frame we see practically nothing.

Lashkar-e-Taiba has its links with Osama bin Laden and with al-Qaeda that go back, it seems, to the eighties. The briefings that I have been provided with indicate that this is an organisation which sees itself with not just a specific subregional claim within Kashmir but a broader international claim to international jihad as well. Its connections with al-Qaeda and associated terrorist organisations is well documented. Its commitment to international jihadist activity is well documented as well.

So we have this Lashkar-e-Taiba proposal before the parliament, but the question arises: what did the Howard government do about this organisation in the two years following September 11? Despite Lashkar-e-Taiba's known links with al-Qaeda and Osama bin Laden the answer, regrettably, is nothing. The government two years ago knew a lot about Lashkar-e-Taiba—a great deal indeed—including its Australian connection. The Australian connection lies with the discomforting case of David Hicks. `Exhibit A', a release from the Attorney-General of Australia, dated 12 December 2001, states:

quote.para: The man, a 26 year old caucasian male, was captured by the Northern Alliance sometime on or around 9 December 2001. The precise circumstances of his capture are unclear at this stage.
According to preliminary advice, it is understood that the man:
Travelled to Pakistan in November 1999, where he trained with the Lashkar-E-Taiba group;
On the evening of Tuesday 11 December 2001, members of the man's family in Australia were interviewed by a joint team of ASIO and AFP officers.

speech.para: That is a statement from the Attorney-General dated 12 December 2001. It says that at that time this individual, who we have subsequently, presumably, identified as David Hicks, had trained with an organisation called Lashkar-e-Taiba. What did the government do about that organisation then? That was two years ago. Two years ago the government knew and admits through its own statement that David Hicks, who it has allowed to stay in Guantanamo Bay for the subsequent two years without charge and without trial, had been trained by a specific al-Qaeda related terrorist organisation called Lashkar-e-Taiba. What has the government done in that two-year period, despite the Australian connection, to ban Lashkar-e-Taiba? The answer is nothing.

But it does not stop there. We go to the foreign minister's statement of January 2002, which condemns a terrorist attack on the Indian Parliament and which welcomes the detention of JEM—that is, Jaish-e-Mohammed—leader Masood Aszhar, as well as 20 or so leading JEM and Lashkar-e-Taiba figures. The foreign minister condemns JEM and Lashkar-e-Taiba—that is, LET. But what happens with these organisations which the Australian government already condemned and identified as terrorist organisations back in January 2002? The answer again is nothing.

Roll the clock on to April 2003 and what do we have? We have, with the much maligned UN Security Council, the listing of an organisation called JEM—Jaish-e-Mohammed. This was listed on 11 April 2003, and the Attorney-General or the department thereof issues a statement at the time which identifies the crimes of JEM—why they should be listed and why the Australian government therefore supports its listing. It says in this context that in an attack in conjunction with Lashkar-e-Taiba on the Indian Parliament in New Delhi in December 2002 nine people were killed and 18 injured.

So what do we have as all this evidence presents itself? Two years ago Hicks, it is alleged, was trained by a terrorist organisation—in the government's own definition—Lashkar-e-Taiba. Eighteen months ago the foreign minister explicitly condemned Lashkar-e-Taiba as a terrorist organisation and, six months ago, the Attorney-General celebrated the banning of Lashkar-e-Taiba's sister organisation JEM and, in the same context, noted that JEM had conducted joint operations with Lashkar-e-Taiba. So you would think that over this two-year period a government that are so committed to the practical stuff of national security would have lifted a finger to do something about the banning of this organisation, but did they do so? The answer again is no.

When the question, `Have you sought to have Lashkar-e-Taiba listed with the UN Security Council?' was put to the Attorney-General in this place just the other day, what was the answer? The answer was no. When he was asked, `Have you sought, by separate legislation with the Australian Labor Party, to ban this organisation in Australia given its demonstrable Australian connection—through the government's own statement—with David Hicks?' the answer was no—until, of course, today. The reason we are doing it today is because we have a government which has been embarrassed by its handling of the Brigitte matter. Two years of policy inertia have resulted in this rush to political action now—an extraordinary set of circumstances which the government must answer in terms of its two years of inertia on LET.

The political problem facing this government when it comes to the matters before this parliament is that we in the opposition support the outlawing of Lashkar-e-Taiba, just as we support the outlawing of the appalling terrorist organisation Hamas—an organisation which delights in the murdering of innocent women and children; a terrorist organisation which must be destroyed. For these reasons we support and commend this legislation to the House. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The threat of terrorism presents a challenge to both our national security and our legal systems. Here in Australia, as in other countries, the challenge in the wake of the September 11 attacks has been to achieve a set of twin objectives: safeguarding the community against possible terrorist attacks while also protecting the very freedoms that define our democracy in the first place.

speech.para: The Criminal Code Amendment (Hamas and Lashkar-e-Tayyiba) Bill 2003 before the House today is designed to ban two organisations: Hamas and Lashkar-e-Taiba—LET. The United States and Canada have proscribed Hamas. The United Kingdom has also proscribed Hamas but has distinguished between its terrorist wing and its charitable wing. The European Union has adopted a similar position to that of the UK, although the EU listing has the more limited effect of banning financial dealings. The shadow Attorney-General has explained Labor's position on the banning of Hamas in light of the security intelligence that the terrorist wing presents a threat to Australian interests. LET is also proscribed by Canada, the United Kingdom, the United States, the European Union and Pakistan. Again, there is advice from security agencies that the organisation poses a threat to Australian interests.

Looking more broadly at proscription, the idea of giving the executive the power to ban an organisation was knocked back last year when the government and the opposition instead negotiated a regime that hangs off the UN listing of terrorist organisations. The Prime Minister himself acknowledged that the regime settled on last year `got the balance right'. So why are the government now trying to dismantle the whole deal? The simple answer is wedge politics. Wedge politics also explains why the Attorney-General is now publicly arguing that Australia's spy agency needs more powers and he is attempting to rewrite the recent history of Labor's position in the national security debate.

In this light, I want to set the record straight and remind us of where we have already travelled in this national security debate. The government tabled their package of antiterrorism laws under the cover of darkness one night in the middle of March last year. There were 119 pages of legislation and 123 pages of explanatory memoranda. It had taken six months to prepare; it was tabled at 8 p.m., and the former Attorney-General wanted parliament to debate it the very next day. It did not happen that way.
In response to the bills I told the parliament on 13 March 2002:

quote.para: Our commitment to fighting the threat of terrorism is driven by our desire to protect the very systems and institutions that set us apart from the terrorists. I am talking about the reason for the war on terrorism in the first place: to protect the rights and privileges that we enjoy in a functioning democracy. It is about protecting such principles as the rule of law, freedom of speech and the right of free movement.
I worry that the freedoms we cherish are threatened by this government's package of antiterrorism laws.

speech.para: By sticking to those principles, Labor secured important amendments to the government's package of legislation. Let me list just a few. We ensured that humanitarian groups would not be affected by the sloppily drafted new treason offences. We ensured that the definition of `terrorist act' contained the necessary higher level of intent associated with the grave nature of terrorist offences and that the offences targeted only terrorist activities and required the prosecution to prove knowledge of, and intent to commit, a terrorist act. We ensured that the bill would target only terrorists. The original definition proposed by the government was astonishingly wide. It did not distinguish terrorist violence from offences or forms of violence appropriately covered by other legislation. We ensured the removal of any possibility that legitimate protest or industrial action could be dealt with as terrorist offences. We ensured that there would be a full, thorough, independent, public review of these antiterrorism laws three years after they come into being.

The second main platform of the government's anti-terrorism legislation was the ASIO Legislation Amendment (Terrorism) Bill 2002. How did the ASIO bill look when it was first introduced? The original bill did not place any age restrictions on who could have been detained by ASIO. It would have allowed ASIO to indefinitely detain any Australian without charge or even suspicion. While detained, they could be strip-searched, questioned for unlimited periods and prevented from contacting family members, their employer or even a lawyer—not even to say that they had been detained.

Under the government's original ASIO bill, a 10-year-old girl could have been held in detention by ASIO, in secret and alone. The only concession was that a child's parent would have to be present for the strip-search. The parent would then have to leave, as they did not have the right to be present during questioning. The detention would have been in secret and ASIO's handling of these new powers would also have been kept a secret. There were no proper review mechanisms and no review by the courts. It is fair to say that the original ASIO bill was perhaps the worst drafted bill ever introduced into the Australian parliament. It would have given ASIO extraordinary powers with almost no safeguards. It would have made ASIO more like a secret police force than a specialist intelligence agency. Again, Labor achieved important amendments. Labor rejected the government's incommunicado detention regime and insisted that anyone being questioned by ASIO should have access to legal advice for the duration of questioning.

The ASIO bill ended up as a radically different bill in many ways, and I would like to highlight six of those ways. The power for ASIO to detain and strip-search young children was removed. The denial of legal representation was removed. The capacity for ASIO to hold someone indefinitely was removed. The capacity for ASIO to hold someone in secret was removed. High-level judicial supervision was introduced. Three strong review mechanisms were introduced. In summary, Labor's opposition to the original bills delivered legislation that managed to strike the balance between protecting the community against acts of terrorism while also protecting the liberties that define our system of democracy.
The Attorney-General should be clear that Australia already has tough new terrorism laws. In yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald Professor George Williams said:

quote.para: ... it is difficult to see why or how they should be changed even before ASIO's detention power has been used. In these circumstances, enacting even more stringent laws makes little sense.

speech.para: Professor Williams' advice makes a lot of sense. As a nation, we must continue to be vigilant to make sure that we achieve the twin objectives of protecting against terrorist acts and safeguarding the very democratic freedoms that set us apart from the terrorists. This government cannot be trusted on national security. At every stage, they do nothing more than play politics, and they seek to gain political advantage in how they deal. They are masters at creating fear in the community, and they are masters at building on that fear to create situations to their own political advantage. Australia's existing counter-terrorism laws have not been shown to be deficient. That is why the Attorney-General's claims for a whole new set of powers ring hollow at this stage of the process.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the Criminal Code Amendment (Hamas and Lashkar-e-Tayyiba) Bill 2003. I want to make a few comments in regard to the whole process that has resulted in this bill to proscribe Hamas and the LET and in regard to its predecessor, the bill to proscribe Hezbollah. I believe we have become involved in a convoluted, impractical and reactive process that says more about our lack of understanding of the regions these groups come from, both culturally and politically. As the minister stated, the bill now before us will proscribe the Izz al-Din al Qassam brigades of Hamas—its military wing. Hamas's non-military wing is one of the most respected non-government organisations operating in Lebanon and one of the most effective in its assistance to refugees, and it is noted for its lack of corruption. I am struggling somewhat to see what interest this group has in Australia, when its focus is so fixed on the Israel-Palestine situation.

speech.para: As for the LET, my understanding of this group is somewhat limited but I understand that it has been an entrenched player in the continuing battle over Kashmir. The LET is a Pakistan based militant group which is waging war, for an independent Kashmir, against India, which currently controls the territory. A large part of this independence struggle comes from the fact that Kashmir is a largely Muslim region under the control of a largely Hindu India, hence the overt support that the LET receives from Pakistan. Perhaps the best example of the extremely convoluted nature of this war on terror is the fact that Pakistan is an ally to the US and it is leading the war on terror, yet, as I understand it, Pakistan supports this group, the LET, which we now seek to ban as a terrorist organisation.

The link between the LET and Australia is tenuous at best, except for the information in recent days in relation to the Willie Brigitte situation and the fact that quite appropriate ASIO powers apparently were not exercised. If we are truly to overcome the menace of terrorism, should we not be asking just what terrorism is—beyond the obvious examples of recent times—and what the difference is, in some cases, between terrorism and freedom fighting? Why was the Indonesian government's oppression of East Timor's population, through Kopassas and TNI over its 24-year occupation of that country not considered to be terrorism? Some on this planet would argue that Mossad should be proscribed as a terrorist organisation, or the CIA, for that matter, for its involvement over the years in the destabilisation and brutal overthrowing of legitimate governments in various parts of the world, particularly in South America. Some ask those questions, and I believe that any attempt to eradicate terrorism should provide some answers to those questions.

With this bill we are effectively banning names. Terrorism is an amoeba—it can change shape and name depending on circumstances. In many cases, these groups are not rigid and structured organisations as we understand organisations to be in the West. Their infrastructures are more fluid. They are more like loose associations of people that can be organised to achieve their goals. Rather than competing against each other, members move freely among them and each group feeds the other, perhaps where they perceive the need to be. A group gets banned only to change its name and continue as before.

This bill provides on paper that these organisations are specified as terrorist organisations under their current names or `by whatever name that organisation is known from time to time'. How is this going to be practically enforceable? It might give the impression of security to a somewhat fearful and insecure electorate, but how effective can it be? How can it be determined which organisation is going by what name and whether or not they are a completely unrelated group or perhaps even, at some point, an NGO doing apparently humanitarian work only? We are engaged in a largely impractical process here that will certainly serve to score political points in the climate of an upcoming election rather than achieve any real protection for Australia.

We need to address the source of the intifada, this perception of worldwide jihad against the West, exactly where it is—in Israel and Palestine. We cannot ignore Palestinian claims of Israeli state based terror and its encroachment beyond its 1967 borders, in the same way that any fair-minded person cannot deny the right of the state of Israel to exist. We need to honestly place ourselves in the boots of Palestinian refugees as they react to what they see as terrorist attacks on them, in the same way that we should reject in the strongest terms the pointless and seemingly unending attacks on Jewish citizens.

The perception of a less than even-handed peace process foments the hatred and provides a hotbed nursery of potential suicide bombers who are exploited by absolute extremists intent on destroying the West and who are simply dismissed as terrorists by those who close their eyes to the inequities and injustices that created that hotbed nursery in the first place. As I have said before in the contexts of Iraq and Afghanistan, what we need is a Middle East peace process brokered by a third country or a group of countries that are outside the dominant players who have other agendas than just peace—a country or countries trusted by both parties and free from the associations that have undermined the road maps and efforts of the United States to date. Indeed, this could have been a perfect role for Australia, I believe, had we not thrown our lot so unquestioningly into the US war on terror. This country needs not only security but also to reject the rhetoric that fosters insecurity. Let us list these organisations, for what it is worth, but let us really define what we mean by `terrorism'.

talk.start.para: —The Greens do not support the Criminal Code Amendment (Hamas and Lashkar-e-Tayyiba) Bill 2003 any more than we supported the earlier Criminal Code Amendment (Hizballah) Bill 2003 or the Criminal Code Amendment (Terrorist Organisations) Bill 2002. We especially do not support the way in which this bill has been introduced today in the House—with undue and unnecessary haste and with no real time to give detailed consideration to the bill and its implications. Earlier on, we heard the member for Cook say, `We do not want to go through bureaucratic niceties' by going through the normal democratic process of this House, which he called `the nonsense'. The member for Cook then went on to say that we should be accountable to this House. I totally agree with that. But the way in which this bill is being introduced is not in any way accountable. We need to be given time to actually look at this bill and consider it in a lot more detail.

speech.para: We see this bill and the way in which it has been introduced as an affront to democracy and therefore an affront to the Australian people. It is outrageous that the Attorney-General should come into this place and, without a shred of solid evidence and without giving members a chance to read, absorb and understand this legislation, seek to ram it through the basic processes of Australian democracy with the merest pretence that this legislation has been properly examined by the elected representatives of the Australian people. That is just not happening. What we are seeing here is nothing more than another chapter in the government's disgraceful drive to win another election by fear. As we have only just heard, this bill seeks to extend to the federal government, specifically to the Attorney-General, the power to list terrorist organisations that have not been proscribed by the United Nations. In the bill there is much use of the phrase `if the minister is satisfied'. It is all coming back to a determination by the minister.

The Greens do not support this government's problematic attitude towards the United Nations and their continuing trend towards acting outside what the UN establishes as an acceptable norm for the international community. The Greens supported restricting the government's power to list terrorist organisations. We therefore oppose this somewhat extreme action of listing organisations which the government, in its perceived wisdom and in great secrecy, believes should be listed as a threat to this nation. Banning or proscribing organisations is fundamentally problematic, as we have heard some of the speakers in this debate outline. Such moves inevitably trap innocent, law-abiding citizens who are in no way connected to terrorism. Terrorists and those planning terrorist activities are already committing crimes under existing law. But, by banning the whole organisation, it is possible that a member of the group who joined for legitimate reasons and has no intention of committing a terrorist act will be unfairly caught and will face the most serious criminal sanctions.

The Greens are concerned that sufficient evidence has not been presented to this parliament or to the Australian people in regard to why these two organisations need to be black-listed. Frankly, the Australian Greens and millions of Australians do not trust this government—and with good reason. We have seen how the government has drowned the truth and politicised the Public Service to unprecedented levels. One example is the `children overboard' saga. We have seen how this government continues to maintain, despite overwhelming evidence to the contrary, that asylum seekers in desert prisons are being properly cared for in civilised circumstances. We have seen recently how the government has not lifted a finger to help two Australian citizens languishing in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. It is all too happy to deem them to be terrorists without a sliver of a charge or tested evidence. Perhaps worst of all, we have seen this country go to war on the basis of manufactured, sexed-up and misleading spin.

This government simply cannot be trusted to act with candour, honesty or disclosure. Sadly though, it can be predicted that it will act with deceit, wedge politics and less than the full story being placed before the Australian parliament and the Australian people. The Australian people have reason to demand more substantial evidence from the government for taking action in connection with the so-called war on terrorism. On that basis, the Greens would therefore like to hear more substantial discussion and reasoning from the government and the opposition in regard to banning these two organisations.

The Greens have concerns about the government's trend toward taking action where substantial evidence appears not to exist. We have seen legislation via the media this week, not via this House. Australians are intelligent, but we are also very cynical. We are suspicious of politicians—and for good reason. In the aftermath of the war on Iraq, the Australian people have been waiting to see the evidence of weapons of mass destruction in Iraq that the government relied so heavily upon in committing Australians to war. No such evidence has been forthcoming although, seemingly, the government had very reliable evidence before the war commenced. These weapons, which were supposedly such a threat and motivated this government to engage in the war, remain undiscovered. At this stage, it appears the government has risked the lives of Australian people on largely baseless evidence. We must therefore be wary in trusting the government's so-called informed opinion.

The Greens are concerned that American, British and Australian people were sent to war under false pretences. We cannot in good conscience trust the federal government to make the right decisions in the interests of the nation with regard to listing terrorist organisations. This is a responsibility the federal government has not proved itself capable of managing. As the member for Banks just pointed out, it is a government that cannot be trusted in matters of national security. It is episodes like the one currently before us and the war against Iraq, where the government relied upon seemingly unreliable evidence, which make trusting and believing the federal government in these instances a very difficult thing to do. The government has shown it cannot be trusted to make the right decisions in the national interest, and so we should, at the very least, continue to rely upon decisions of the United Nations before terrorist organisations are listed.

However, it must be noted that even relying upon the United Nations is not a perfect solution in this context. The Greens have some concerns about the UN process and believe that close consideration needs to be given to the manner in which organisations are proscribed by the UN. Under the UN process organisations can be proscribed by a member nation of the United Nations—be it Iraq, China or North Korea, for example. Without a trial or without evidence coming from the organisation the UN can then decide that the organisation should be proscribed. This process should obviously be more robust.

Australia needs to tread very carefully in dealing with the threat of terrorism. The Greens are concerned about the political slinging match between the government and the opposition as they scramble to position themselves as being the toughest on terrorism. The Greens acknowledge that we have moved into an era where the threat of terrorism is more real and widespread to Australians than it has previously been. This increasing threat obviously needs to be addressed, but it needs to be addressed carefully, responsibly and reasonably. Instead, the federal government and the opposition are treading a very fine line between whipping up political hysteria about the threat of terrorism and their responsibilities in safeguarding the Australian community. This bill represents a further attack on the democratic process of this parliament and on our democracy. I therefore cannot support this bill.

talk.start.para: —in reply—I thank all the members for their contributions to the debate on the Criminal Code Amendment (Hamas and Lashkar-e-Tayyiba) Bill 2003. I note that the Leader of the Opposition and the members for Barton, Griffith, Banks, Denison, Cook, Dickson, Moncrieff, Calare and Cunningham all spoke, and I will deal with the issues broadly, rather than specifically take up comments from individual members.

speech.para: For an effective counter-terrorism regime it is vital that our laws target not only terrorist acts but also organisations that plan, finance and carry out terrorist acts. September 11 signalled the start of the war against terrorism. The Bali bombings brought the reality of the terrorist threat to our doorstep. Recent terrorist attacks in Baghdad and Jakarta show that terrorism continues to be a real threat to world peace and a real threat to Australia's national security.

Terrorism is not like ordinary crime. The way that terrorist networks are organised and the destruction that acts of terrorism can cause distinguish it from other types of crime. While there is no specific threat to Australia, our profile as a terrorist target has risen and we remain at a heightened state of alert. We need to be well placed to respond to this new security environment in terms of our operational capabilities, infrastructure and legislative framework.

The safety and security of the Australian community and Australian interests is still a top priority of the government. It is a responsibility this government takes very seriously. In the current environment, complacency is not an option. The Criminal Code Amendment (Hamas and Lashkar-e-Tayyiba) Bill 2003 will allow for the miliary wing of Hamas and the LET organisation to be listed in regulations, provided the statutory criteria have first been met. The government has been advised by Australia's own intelligence agency, ASIO, that there is evidence that both organisations engage in terrorist activity. I tabled a very comprehensive, non-classified statement from ASIO for those members who were looking for further evidence, giving those details.

However, neither organisation has been formally identified as a terrorist organisation by the United Nations Security Council. As a result, we can do nothing to list these organisations under the Australian law as it stands. The only way in which we can do anything about them is to introduce specific legislation on a case by case basis, as is happening here. That is not part of a legislative scheme. It is not a considered response to the way in which you need to deal with these issues—namely, in a timely, efficient and effective way. It is an ad hoc decision taken in relation to introducing a specific piece of legislation.

The bill is about doing that—I recognise that. The Leader of the Opposition seemed to think that I did not know I was introducing a bill. This bill aims to rectify the intolerable situation where we are unable, under the legislative scheme in place now, to make a specific determination in relation to the listing of these two organisations. So the bill makes a specific exemption for the listing of these two organisations which does not rely upon the United Nations first identifying either or both as terrorist organisations.

As a result of this bill, either organisation could be listed as a terrorist organisation for the purpose of the Criminal Code, provided the Attorney-General is satisfied that the particular organisation is directly or indirectly engaged in, preparing, planning, assisting in or fostering the doing of a terrorist act, whether or not the terrorist act has occurred or will occur.

This amendment would not be necessary if the opposition had not insisted on this requirement when the listing provisions were considered by the parliament last year. It would not be necessary if the opposition would put politics aside and support our Criminal Code Amendment (Terrorist Organisations) Bill 2003, currently before the Senate. That bill removes the need for a UN listing before Australia can take any action. I do not think it is too much to ask of the opposition to put politics aside in the interest of national security.

talk.start.para: —We have.

—No, I do not believe you have at all, because if you believed in dealing with national security effectively you would agree to the bill that would put in place—not without parliamentary scrutiny—an effective and timely procedure for these matters to be dealt with by way of regulation.

speech.para: Obviously, we welcome the opposition's support for the current bill, because we believe the organisations ought to be proscribed—let me make that very clear. But we disagree with the opposition's view that we should go through this process of passing legislation every time we want to list an organisation as a terrorist organisation for the purpose of our domestic criminal laws. If the passage of a bill can be effectively disallowed by the parliament and a regulation can be disallowed by the parliament—one chamber: the Senate—I cannot see why doing it by regulation would be any derogation of the powers to review these matters through the legislative process that obtain through dealing with a particular bill.

The fact that we are here dealing with this issue today means that we are not dealing with other issues. Each time you have to come back with a specific bill following the same format is a waste of the House's time and is a waste of members' time. It is political grandstanding. People are asserting that there are politics being made out of this. The politics are being made out of it by those who say they are not prepared to give bipartisan support to this bill. There would be no political issue if this bill and the bill before the Senate were agreed to by the opposition. There would be no issue. But the opposition continues its path of resisting the passage of the bill agreed to by this chamber last June, which is now waiting its final passage in the Senate.

I want to draw to conclusion my comments by saying that I understand the opposition is agreeing to this bill but still opposes the broader scheme. It has ratcheted up a lot of the rhetoric in relation to this matter. I would have to say that, if you removed the personal invective in relation to me, there has been very little of substance in the arguments that have been put up.

I must say I have become fascinated by this new term `wedge politics'. I am not sure what wedge politics is all about, I have to say. I must say that as long as I have been in politics political parties have prided themselves on being able to bring an element of choice to the discussion of political matters. It surprises me that it is not wedge politics if you have a different view in relation to health; it is not wedge politics if you have a different view in relation to education and you think there is a constituency out there that you can appeal to. But if you have a view that you ought to be able to proscribe a terrorist organisation by regulation, with the opportunity for parliamentary review by way of disallowance, somehow that is elevated to a huge question of political difference: this new term of `wedge politics'. I have to say all of this invective about wedge politics will not get to me at all.

I want to make it very clear that I am one of those who has, in the time that I have been involved in public life, sought to distil consensus when possible. But I have found a remarkable thing about consensus. People seem to take the view that consensus is appropriate if you agree with them. But if you disagree, you argue for bipartisanship in the expectation that you will get those with a different view onto your side.

Let me say that I think bipartisanship is possible here. But it will not be bipartisanship on the Labor Party's terms. I am not going to relieve you of what I think is in fact a simple problem of loss of face. I think you did not really expect that there would be other organisations that had not been proscribed by the UN that might need to be proscribed here. You thought that by putting those provisions in the enactment—

talk.start.para: (Mr Wilkie)—I would remind the Attorney-General he needs to refer his remarks through the chair.

—The Labor Party opposition thought by putting those provisions in the enactment that this issue would not arise again and now the opposition are in the position where they see that these issues are current but they cannot agree to the bill that would enable it to be dealt with by way of regulation because they would lose face. That is what it is all about: they would lose face. There is no substantial reason why these issues cannot be dealt with by way of regulation. I say to the Leader of the Opposition, who said he would like to see bipartisanship on this matter, yes, bipartisanship is possible. It is possible by passing the bill that is presently in the Senate, which would enable these matters to be dealt with without having to come back to this parliament over and over again.

speech.para: Several other matters were raised during the course of the debate and, if I may, I will take a couple of those up. The opposition, in looking around for other approaches that might be taken to adducing a compromise, suggested that essentially we might take the executive out of the decision making process in relation to whether or not an organisation could be proscribed and handed over to the judiciary. It is interesting that quite frequently I have been criticised for and accused of having infringed the separation of powers doctrine on the basis of my having a view about issues that are dealt with by a court which, in public interest terms, I want to see debated and discussed. I cannot imagine anything that might infringe the separation of powers doctrine more than what is being proposed here by the opposition—that is, that you hand over to a judicial body the decision as to whether or not an organisation ought to be proscribed.

I know that the opposition has dredged back into time and found a section in the Crimes Act that enables a matter to be referred to a court for determination. I am told that section was introduced by my political predecessors. It certainly was; it was the Bruce-Page government. Interestingly, I am told that the provision has never been used. But let me just make the point that I made in question time yesterday. As far as the government are concerned, we are of the view that it is for the executive to determine these issues and responsibility, if there is to be any, should be to the parliament. We are not of the view that having a court being able to set the timetable is the appropriate way to go.

Other points have been made. The member for Griffith is on a crusade at the moment to unwind tourism to Australia essentially by requiring every visitor from our larger source countries to undergo comprehensive security checking. The fact is that security checking by Australia is probably the most comprehensive in the world. But your checking is always only as good as the inputs to the alert systems you develop. In this case we—Australia—have certainly tens of thousands of names of people who we believe could be of security concern. I have seen the most recent published figures; they suggest that a quarter of a million names are on the movement alert system of the department of immigration. I am told that in terms of security listings we probably have as many, if not more than, the United States of America.

But the adequacy of those lists is really dependent upon the liaison you have with other governments as well as your own inquiries to establish who may be potential risks. In the context of the French, the only reason we found out about Mr Brigitte is that the French gave us the advice. We work very closely with them and we believe that they work closely with us. But the expectation that we are able to dictate to other countries what information they will provide to us—which I think is the view of the member for Griffith—is extraordinarily naive.

I will conclude my remarks by saying that today we have moved on to the question of the broader powers that ASIO has to be able to detain and question people. I just wish to make it very clear—as I think the member for Banks did—that there was a lot of debate about this issue before; a lot of issues were raised. This was an issue about checks and balances; I acknowledge that. But sometimes, when you endeavour to put in place checks and balances, the checks can outweigh the balances. That is what I think can happen. I certainly have asked questions—and I do not apologise for that—about the powers that ASIO has. Certain powers are not being used because people formed the view that they could not be used with certainty—and that is clear from the advice that was given by ASIO's head to the Senate estimates committee; he described the use of the powers as being a moot point—suggests to me that there is a potential defect, something you have to look at. Just because you took the view of not trying to use it and took, in a sense, a course that made a good judgment about how you might be able to get a better outcome—that is, to send the individual back to his country of origin, which is France, because those there know more about his activities and are better placed to question him—in no way derogates from the first point I was making: that there is and has been identified a weakness in the way the power can be used.

I have never asserted that that particular weakness was as a result of a particular compromise; it is a weakness. And there are other weaknesses that I have identified in discussions with officials. The impact of interpreters: unless you deal with interpreters every day, you are not aware of how much time it takes to translate observations, get them understood and then for there to be another translation back and forth—which effectively doubles the time. With any questioning regime that is rigorously managed in terms of time—and ours is: 24 hours of questioning in three eighthour blocks—the requirement for interpreters, in effect, halves the amount of time you thought reasonable.

There are other issues that came out—and I am not suggesting this is an exclusive list. In fact, I know it is not an exclusive list. One of the other issues that arose in considering these matters was looking at what you would do if a person said, `I'm not going to stick around. I'm going. I'll be available when you want me, but I'm going to leave.' If you look at the words in the legislation, they say that if you think somebody is going to abscond you can detain them, but if somebody says, `I'm going to be available, but I'm going to go overseas,' you have no evidence they are going to abscond. So it seems to me that the question of what you should do if you think you are going to lose somebody you want to question is a proper issue to be looked at. They said, `These are practical questions, and if you ask us maybe we will look at them.' The fact is that these are issues in relation to this legislation and its adequacy which have come to notice and which I am going to ensure are quickly and effectively addressed. Having said that, I thank all members for their contribution to the debate. I welcome the fact that it will receive a speedy passage here. It will be interesting to see how it progresses elsewhere.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: Mr RUDDOCK (Berowra—Attorney-General) (1.23 p.m.)—by leave—I move:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a third time.

subdebate.1.para: Question agreed to.
Bill read a third time.
Debate resumed from 4 November, on motion by Mr Slipper:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —We had a good debate on the Financial Services Reform Amendment Bill 2003 yesterday, with excellent contributions from both sides. My remarks will be happily brief because of the comprehensive contribution of the member for Moncrieff. To refresh the memory of the House, the bill is an amendment to the Financial Services Reform Act. Stan Wallis, the eminent Australian figure of commerce, conducted an inquiry for the government into the operation of financial services in Australia. He concluded two things: that financial services and products were in a special category because of the fact that they were intangible and complex and often required high levels of expertise to understand and to sell, and that the regime for the regulation of the sale of financial services and products was incoherent, fractured and differed between the states and territories—and, in some areas, economic activities were entirely unregulated. So he proposed to the government that we introduce one uniform licensing regime to cover everything from the operations of a financial planner in his or her study at home to the conduct of a major investment bank.

speech.para: The Financial Services Reform Act was the measure introduced by the government to achieve that outcome. It recognised the magnitude of the proposed reform with a twoyear implementation period, which we are more than halfway through now and which will conclude on 10 March 2004, with licensing to begin on the 11th. Anyone without a licence on 11 March will no longer be in business. It is critically important during the transition period that we iron out the wrinkles and engage in high levels of consultation. That is precisely what has happened in this instance, and the proposed amendments result from those consultations. I might say that I am arriving late on the scene. Everywhere I have gone my predecessor, Senator Ian Campbell, in the other place, has been described to me as an exceptional minister who was entirely on top of a complex brief, and it is constantly reinforced to me that I have big shoes to fill. In fact, Nick Greiner, the former Premier of New South Wales, described my predecessor, Ian Campbell, as the best briefed minister he had ever dealt with in his public and private life.

We have in this reform four key measures which do not depart from the core architecture or philosophy of the act but involve ironing out problems in the implementation, where the implementation has resulted in unexpected consequences. The first measure is to amend the definition of a basic deposit product to include term deposits of up to five years. The current definition is limited to term deposits of two years. The carve-out here is because term deposits are well understood in the marketplace. They involve little complexity and the customer in effect knows exactly what they are getting. The desire is to avoid imposing on the banking system such heavy compliance obligations that it may make the taking out of these basic deposit products less attractive. It has been suggested by those opposed to the change, and suggested in debate yesterday, that the proposed change will reduce the attractiveness of the twoyear term deposit product. In fact, the measure will have the reverse result. As it stood, it would have positively discriminated against fiveyear deposit products, and the level of training and explanation that bank staff at the teller would have been required to provide would have made it simply unattractive to banks to offer the longer term products. What we are proposing here is that the extension go out to five years, and there is no good reason in practice why that exemption should not be available.

The second measure the amendment addresses relates to ASIC's exemption and modification powers. As most people would be aware, the Australian Securities and Investments Commission is the enforcement agency, or police power, for corporate conduct, sharing some responsibility in that regard with APRA, who are responsible for prudential regulation. In terms of market conduct, disclosure and conflicts of interest, ASIC plays the central role. We do give ASIC a number of opportunities to exempt aspects of corporate conduct from the licensing regime or to modify the application of the regime in individual cases. The so-called E&M—exemption and modification—powers are already present throughout the Corporations Act, including in other parts of chapter 7. So there is no great novelty or innovation in this current measure.

This measure is intended to give ASIC greater flexibility to deal with situations that arise where applications of the legislation result in unintended or unduly harsh outcomes. For those who suggest that this would result in unnecessary laxity in the regime I advise that the overwhelming chorus of criticism of ASIC is that the commission uses those exemption and modification rules too cautiously and too infrequently. So we are not dealing with an organisation that has any interest or any history in diluting the consumer protections involved in the bill.

It was suggested in debate yesterday that the problem this will create is that ASIC's use of these exemption and modification powers would not be disallowable instruments, which would therefore place them outside the purview of supervision by this parliament. I simply want to note that the government's Legislative Instruments Bill—which is not at present law but which I expect to pass in this parliamentary session—will make such instruments of ASIC disallowable where they provide exemptions or make modifications applying to a class of persons or a class of financial products. So those who are concerned by the theoretical possibility that the powers may not be used judiciously should be reassured. I also note that exercise of those powers is, and will remain, subject to review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and judicial review by the Federal Court. And, as members would be aware, the executive of ASIC are accountable to the parliament through their many appearances before our parliamentary committees.

I turn now to the further market related advice amendments, commonly referred to as stockbroker amendments. The architecture of the act relies heavily on disclosure between a person selling a product or giving advice on purchasing that product or accepting the advice. A central element of that is the so-called statement of advice which is required to be provided as an account of the transaction which has taken place, setting out its key ingredients. It was intended that that statement of advice would be provided each time advice was given that resulted in a financial transaction or purchase of a product, and it simply was not tailored well to the situation where advice had been given in a so-called live market situation. For example, in a stock market, where brokers may be advising clients to take advantage of a movement in the price of, for instance, a share, they have to act very quickly in order to take advantage of that movement. So the speed required to advise and to act on the advice was not really sympathetic to this process of signing and sending written summaries of the transaction—certainly not contemporaneously with the giving of advice. So, while maintaining the underlying rationale of disclosure and preserving the other consumer protections of the bill, this measure will provide a regime which is more neatly tailored to the actual circumstances of live market transactions.

The bill also amends the current definition of `execution related telephone advice' with a new definition of `further market related advice', which simply reflects the fact that the advice may be to do nothing at all—in effect, to hold rather than to buy or sell—involving no element of execution. The new definition of `further market related advice' addresses that inaccuracy in the former bill. The measures to ensure that the current protections remain and the exemptions are not abused include that the provision applies only to participants on licensed markets and their authorised representatives in relation to advice on financial products traded on such markets; the advice provider must have a reasonable belief that the advice is required promptly; and the prerequisite remains that any new client has already been given a statement of advice at the beginning of the relationship with the advice provider.

Advice providers will also remain subject to the `know your client' obligations in the legislation, which require them to keep up to date with their client's circumstances and ensure that any personal advice given is appropriate to those circumstances. The existing consumer protection elements of section 946B are retained, such as the requirement that the adviser must keep a record of the further market related advice, with the client having a right to request a copy of this record for up to 90 days from the date the advice is provided.

Finally, the member for Werriwa made a spirited, and I think creative, contribution in relation to the savings implications which arose, I suppose, by reference to the changes to the deposit products definition. While his contribution was not, as far as I could tell, strictly relevant to the scope of the bill, it was, nonetheless, an interesting contribution. I simply refer to the fact that the government is seeking to encourage savings among low-income earners, most recently through the co-contribution measure providing dollar-for-dollar matching for personal contributions up to a maximum of $1,000, by qualifying low-income earners to their superannuation—up to an income of $27,500 and phasing out at $40,000.

I conclude by noting the fact that the entire financial services reform agenda is designed to create an environment that promotes confident and informed participation by Australians in an increasingly complex financial system, including better protection for consumers in relation to banking products, superannuation, life insurance and shares. It aims to ensure that advice is provided by advisers with sufficient qualifications and competencies. I present a supplementary memorandum to the bill and commend the bill to the House.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
