talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, you always know when they are uncomfortable because the level of interjections increases. There are a number of questions for the Australian Labor Party. Does the Australian Labor Party support these prosecutions? We have heard nothing but silence in relation to this. Will the Australian Labor Party—
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I am happy to answer that question. I did a doorstop interview today answering—

—The member for Rankin will resume his seat. I have already indicated on previous occasions that the answering of rhetorical questions is not helpful to the chair and in fact involves people participating without having the call. The minister has the call. He will avoid rhetorical questions.

—There are a number of issues here to which the Australian Labor Party is the only group of individuals that can respond. There are questions, for example, such as: do they support all Australians? Will we have a situation—

answer.para: An opposition member—He's doing it again!

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I seek to answer that question as well—
—The member for Rankin will resume his seat.

—I warn the member for Rankin! Let me make it perfectly clear to every reasonable individual in the House that the way in which the minister just phrased his response to the question was perfectly reasonable. The earlier response was perfectly unreasonable and I took action.
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Isn't the purpose of question time for ministers to give answers rather than ask questions?
—The member for Werriwa will resume his seat or I will deal with him as well. I have already attempted—

—I warn the Chief Opposition Whip! I have already attempted to ensure that question time is productive by discouraging the minister from doing the very thing that the member for Werriwa had raised. In response to that he rephrased the way in which he went about posing the question, and it was not an offence to the chair.

—In the absence of any indication otherwise, we can assume that the Australian Labor Party will take the $2.7 million rather than take into account the interests of ordinary Australians. I think the $2.7 million from the CFMEU was about the amount that the winner won in the Melbourne Cup yesterday.
—Before I recognise the member for Rankin, I remind him that he has been warned. Of course he has the right to raise a point of order but I expect it to be a valid point of order.
—Mr Speaker, in that case I will raise the issue after question time in a question to you.

—Mr Speaker, they are very sensitive. There is a choice for the Australian Labor Party in relation to the building and construction industry: they can continue to take the $2.7 million from the CFMEU or they can deliver a $2.3 billion productivity bonus for all workers in Australia. The issue before the Australian Labor Party is that they know privately that they are dealing with rogue elements of the union movement in Australia—rogue elements that bring into disrepute the union movement generally and cost this country and ordinary Australian workers some $2.3 billion. Do they want to protect ordinary Australian workers or do they still want to take $2.7 million from Martin Kingham and his mates in the CFMEU? That is the issue. The bill will be in this place tomorrow. We will see how they vote.

—My question is to the Minister for Health and Ageing. Is the minister aware that 25 electorates across Australia, including the electorates of the members for Corangamite, Dickson, Dunkley, Indi, Gippsland, New England, Mayo, Page, Wannon and, tragically, Wakefield—
—What's left of it!

—have all seen bulk-billing rates fall below 50 per cent in the June quarter this year? Does this mean that on average not even all concession card holders are being bulk-billed in these electorates? Given that the minister has rejected a national bulk-billing target, is he prepared to set targets for bulk-billing for families in these electorates?

—I am aware that bulk-billing rates have dropped. I made this very point myself in an article in the Australian on Monday. I should point out that the average bulk-billing rate over the life of this government has been 77 per cent. The average bulk-billing rate over the last seven years of the former government's life was 74 per cent.
—What is it now?
—The member for Lalor has asked her question.

—The average bulk-billing rate today is 68.5 per cent, which is higher than the average bulk-billing rate over the life of the former government. So the bulk-billing rate today is higher than the average bulk-billing rate over the life of the former government. Let me make this point very clear: bulk-billing is important and bulk-billing should be available, but it has never been the position of this government, and it was never previously the position of the Australian Labor Party, that bulk-billing should be compulsory. It is not the position of this government and it was not the position of the former government that bulk-billing should be compulsory. Let me make this point clear: Medicare is not about universal bulk-billing; Medicare is a universal safety net delivering affordable, high-quality health care to all Australians, and that is the Medicare system that this government has delivered to the Australian people.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry. Would the minister update the House on the Australian government's assistance measures to drought affected farm families across Australia? Is the minister aware of other assistance that is available?

talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
Mr TRUSS
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to report to the member for Parkes, and indeed the House, that the Commonwealth continues to provide very significant assistance to Australian farmers. Around 25,000 applications for income support, through federal assistance, have now been approved, and that is certainly providing great help to many struggling farm families around Australia. Around $300 million has already been paid out in specific payments to farmers and considerably more will be required over the months ahead.

answer.para: In the couple of weeks since I last reported to the House on this issue, another 12 areas have been declared eligible for full exceptional circumstances assistance or have been given access to prima facie support. These include farmers in the Condoblin area in the electorate of the honourable member for Parkes; the areas of Molong, Dubbo and Moree West in New South Wales; Stanthorpe and Inglewood in Queensland; Moss Vale and the South Coast in New South Wales; some farmers in the Atherton Tableland in Queensland; and Whittlesea in Victoria. Eligibility has been extended to horticultural producers and nurserymen on the central coast and south-east coast of Queensland. Farmers in the Mackay area, the central-west of Queensland, the Emerald-Bauhinia area of Queensland and Young in New South Wales are now eligible for prima facie support.

This is a clear demonstration of this government's commitment to helping farmers through these tough times. Unfortunately, we continue to get no help in this task from the state Labor governments of Australia. Without exception, they are walking away from farmers. They are very loud in their criticism of everything the Commonwealth does but they try to make a lot of noise to cover up their own inaction. Just a couple of days ago, Henry Palaszczuk, perhaps the worst performer of all the state agriculture ministers—
Honourable members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I know it is a tough call, but I think he is just about the worst. He made the comment that the federal government had denied assistance to pork and dairy producers in Queensland. That was only a couple of days after specific assistance was provided to the Atherton Tableland pork and dairy producers. Indeed, there is no EC area in Australia where pork and dairy producers have been specifically excluded, as has been suggested by Henry Palaszczuk. Of course, this is typical of Mr Palaszczuk's effort. He has sat by and done nothing in Queensland while the farmers have suffered drought, and now he is demanding that the Commonwealth give assistance to areas that not even the state has declared to be drought affected. He wants us to help farmers where he will do nothing.

answer.para: But Henry Palaszczuk's noise is worse than that. He has sat by and done nothing and provided no assistance to farmers while at the same time the Queensland government have increased taxes and introduced a range of special taxes that apply to farmers. He claims that they are providing sometimes $7 million and sometimes $12 million of assistance, but I think the amount of new taxes that the Queensland government have introduced for farmers will be greater than the total amount of financial support he has offered during the drought. There is the new tax on dams, new rail freights, new taxes on stock movements and, of course, the infamous ambulance levy, which many Queensland farmers have to pay time and again. So on the one hand they claim to be providing a little bit of assistance—although very few farmers have actually seen it—and on the other hand they increase a whole range of taxes.

Then there is Victoria. The Treasurer keeps reporting on the 300 extra taxes in Victoria. There are also several hundred in New South Wales. Indeed, the states are putting up taxes at a far greater rate than they are providing benefits to farmers. Agriculture ministers with that sort of record ought to be shutting up and complimenting the Commonwealth on our achievements instead of resorting to petty, stupid criticism without any decent substance. We are there to help farmers, while Labor simply makes a noise and walks away from people in need.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Health and Ageing. Is the minister aware that, based on the recently released June quarter figures, out-of-pocket expenses for seeing a GP have risen by an average of 23.5 per cent in just the last three years? Given that increasing out-of-pocket expenses are associated with a decline in GP attendances, what information has been provided to the minister about the increase in the burden of preventable disease that is likely to arise because Australians are seeing their doctor less?

—I am aware that the patient copayment has increased over the last few years. In fact, under this government, patient copayments have increased by six per cent a year. But I can inform the member for Lalor that, under the former government, the patient copayment increased by 11 per cent a year. Under the former government, there was a bulk-billing rate of 68 per cent and an 11 per cent copayment increase. Under this government there is a 77 per cent bulk-billing rate and a six per cent—
—Bowl up another one!

—The member for Maranoa is warned! The member for Lalor must be well aware of the fact that she has absolutely no licence to continue to ask a question after she has asked it or to interject. She will hear the reply in silence.

—The government are concerned about the out-of-pocket expenses faced by Australians when they visit a doctor. The government are concerned to make Medicare an even better and stronger system. The government are concerned to strengthen the universal safety net which is Medicare, and that is why, as part of the A Fairer Medicare package, we have before the Senate right now a proposal to strengthen the safety net. If members opposite were serious in their concern—if they actually wanted to help patients rather than try to turn them into a political football—they would support that aspect of the government's A Fairer Medicare package.

—My question is to the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources. Will the minister update the House on recent developments in the automotive sector? How is the automotive sector contributing to job creation and the strength of the Australian economy?

talker.name: Macfarlane, Ian, MP
Mr IAN MACFARLANE
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Dunkley for his question and for his strong interest not only in the automotive industry in Victoria but also in all manufacturing industries in Victoria. The automotive industry in Australia moved up a gear today with the announcement and opening of the V6 Holden plant in Melbourne. This plant—some $400 million worth of investment by GMH—is one of only two plants in the world and will produce over 200,000 engines each year. These engines will not only be fitted to our locally built Commodores but also be exported around the world.

answer.para: In scooping this plant for Australia, the industry has again confirmed the reputation that Australia is now enjoying in terms of being a leading automotive manufacturer in the Asia-Pacific region. Of course, as well as the investment in the V6 plant, GMH has invested some $200 million in an upgrade at Fishermans Bend and $400 million in an upgrade in the Elizabeth plant in South Australia. This further confirms the confidence that the Australian automotive industry has in its future both in Australia and in terms of exports.

In terms of the process, the federal government was involved and, of course, the Victorian government was involved. Steve Bracks was this morning only too happy to be involved in creating jobs in Victoria. The SIC process is, of course, one which this government uses to ensure that these sorts of investments in Australian industry are made. It is worth noting that that process is under threat from the Labor Party. I will table a document from the member for Rankin in which he clearly says that it is Labor's policy to abolish the SIC process.

Mr Bracks this morning was only too pleased to announce that, as part of that process, Victoria will gain some 500 jobs in direct terms from this investment by GMH. Some 6,000 indirect jobs will also come that way. The confidence that the industry is enjoying is also very much due to the policies of this government, but not only in terms of the some $10 billion to $12 billion worth of tax cuts to the price of motor vehicles. On top of that some $7 billion has been invested by this government, through the ACIS, in the future of the automotive industry. Over the term of those two schemes, some $15 billion—perhaps even as much as $20 billion—will ensure that that industry continues to grow and that we continue to export one in three cars produced.

In terms of the free trade agreements that secure those markets for export cars, we have already had the Thailand free trade agreement, and the US free trade agreement is under negotiation. Industry continues to prosper here in Australia under the policies of this government. The strength of the manufacturing sector has been reinforced this week by the rise in October's Australian Industry Group performance manufacturing index.
Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I know they do not like good news—
—The minister will address his remarks to the chair.
—In terms of a strong rise in domestic orders in that industry, we are also seeing strong future prospects. All this is good news for jobs in Australia and good news for the economy.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I have a question for you, and it relates to your statement to the House on Monday in respect of the addresses to the House and the Senate by the presidents of the United States and China. I would have asked this yesterday but for the special circumstances yesterday. I quote from your statement on Monday:

quote.para: In accordance with House practice and procedure, which I remind the House both chambers had agreed would apply, the Leader of the House moved for the suspension of the two senators. This question was put and, as recorded in the proof Votes and Proceedings, was passed by members and senators present. This is not recorded in the proof Journals of the Senate for 23 October 2003.

question.para: My question to you, Mr Speaker, is: what steps have you taken or do you propose to take, either by yourself or jointly with the President of the Senate, to resolve this clear conflict between the record of the House and the record of the Senate? If that conflict is not able to be resolved, what version will stand as the actual historical record?

talk.start.para: —I am grateful to the member for Perth for giving me notice of what I consider to be a very important matter. From the sentiments expressed around the House, I think it is felt to be important by all members of the House. I have therefore put two or three dot points together that I would like to place into the Hansard record. These are points concerning the Journals of the Senate of 23 October this year.

answer.para: The Votes and Proceedings of the House are the official record of the proceedings of the House. The Journals of the Senate perform the same function for the proceedings of the Senate. Both publications are prepared and issued in the name of the Clerk of the respective house. The accuracy of each is the responsibility of the respective Clerk. If there were a serious error or omission in these documents of record and the Clerk concerned refused to recognise this by correction of a proof issue or a corrigendum for a final issue, it would be open to the house of parliament in question to pass a resolution requiring a correction. In the instance in question, as indicated in the statement to the House on 3 November, the Journals of the Senate for 23 October contain no reference to the suspension by senators and members present of Senator Brown and Senator Nettle.

There is no doubt that the suspension happened. Should the final version be issued in the same form as the proof version, those now or in posterity wishing to see a true record of the Senate meeting of 23 October 2003 will be called on, perhaps somewhat ironically, to consult either the official record of the House of Representatives or the Senate Hansard. These matters are clearly of concern to me and I have taken these matters up with the office of the President of the Senate. As the Senate is not sitting this week, we have not had an opportunity to pursue them any further.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, under standing order 150, I seek your assistance to get an answer from the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations in relation to a question on notice appearing under my name from 14 August 2003.

speech.para: Opposition members interjecting—

The member for O'Connor has the call. He will indicate where he has been misrepresented, which is what the standing orders provide. He cannot enter into debate on the issue.

—I will follow up the matter raised by the member for Cunningham as the standing orders provide. I think we could get to the point at which questions to the Speaker, which are only scarcely covered by standing orders, last longer than question time.

—Mr Speaker, I raise this issue at this stage because I would like to know, for the benefit of this parliament, when the documents tabled by the member for Canberra that have been removed from the table by the member for O'Connor are going to be returned.
—They are on their way to being returned.

—The member for O'Connor is warned! Let me respond to the Chief Opposition Whip by reassuring her—and I am sure this is not necessary—that there is never any action taken in this chamber by the clerks that is not entirely consistent with the standing orders or precedent. The access by the member for O'Connor to the particular documents was not in any way extraordinary. I have witnessed it on many occasions in the past on both sides of the House and I am grateful to those on my left who, by the nod of their head, are indicating their support for my statement.

—I present the Auditor-General's performance audit report No. 12 of 2003-04 entitled The administration of telecommunications grants: Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts; Department of Transport and Regional Services.

interjection.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

debate.para: Mr ABBOTT (Warringah—Leader of the House) (3.40 p.m.)—Papers are tabled in accordance with the list circulated to honourable members earlier today. Details of the papers will be recorded in the Votes and Proceedings.

talk.start.para: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Werriwa proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

quote.para: The impact on Australian families of record household debt and today's increase in interest rates.

interjection.para: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

para.inline: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

talk.start.para: —Today's interest rate rise will have a big impact on family budgets. Because of the huge increase in household debt in recent years under this government, it takes only a small change in nominal interest rates to knock home buyers and small businesses around this country for six. The average home buyer in Australia will be $30 per month worse off because of today's interest rate rise. Why does a 25 basis point increase in interest rates have such a profound impact on the family budget? Why is it that the interest rate rise will force home buyers in this country to be $30 per week worse off? It is because of the explosion in household debt, particularly in recent years.

speech.para: In March 1996 the average household debt in Australia was $43,000. Even a couple of years ago Australian household debt was still below the international standard. But in recent years it has absolutely exploded; it has gone whooshka. Household debt has gone whooshka, and that is why the impact of a 25 basis point interest rate rise is so severe on the household budget. Today, average household debt in Australia is $91,000. It has more than doubled in the time of the Howard government. We have the most severe debt servicing ratio in Australia's history.

The Treasurer earlier quoted me from April 2002, but what was the Reserve Bank saying at that time? At that time the Reserve Bank was looking at the increase in household debt and thinking it would come up to the international standard and not beyond. But in the 18 months since, it has gone absolutely whooshka; it has gone through the roof. This is the whole problem with the Treasurer: he lives in the past. He does not care about the current circumstances of Australian home buyers, who are $30 a month worse off because of today's interest rate rise. Twenty months ago the Reserve Bank was expecting household debt to come up to the international standard; today it has gone way beyond. Now the Reserve Bank regards that household debt as excessive, as a warning signal, as a risk factor for the future of the Australian economy. Everyone can hear the warning bell, except the Treasurer. Everyone can hear the Reserve Bank's warning bell about excessive household debt, except the Treasurer.

The government talks a lot about past interest rates; it is a government that is living in the past. It is a government that does not care about the future of Australian small businesses and home buyers. It never mentions the debt servicing ratio. It never mentions the real-life impact on Australian home buyers and their capacity to sustain a loan. If the Treasurer is looking for the figures—I know he does not talk that much to the Reserve Bank these days—he should read the speech the Governor of the Reserve Bank, Ian Macfarlane, made on 3 April 2003. He pointed out that the debt servicing ratio—the household interest paid as a percentage of household disposable income—is the worst in Australia's history. The debt servicing ratio used to bounce around four per cent, it lifted in the mid-1990s to 5.8 per cent and now it is over six per cent and rising. In April the governor said:

quote.para: Currently, about 6 per cent of household disposable income is devoted to servicing the interest cost of mortgages. This is higher by about 1 percentage point than the peak value in 1990—

speech.para: the government wants to talk about the past, but here is the truth—

quote.para: despite the much lower level of mortgage interest rates, because the size of mortgage debt outstanding is now so much higher.

speech.para: These are the words of the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia. He concluded:

quote.para: Allowing for principal repayments as well as interest would increase this by about 2½ percentage points, an amount which is likely to be larger now than in the past because of the higher levels of debt.

speech.para: That is the truth of the matter, in the words of the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia. In the real-life circumstances of people trying to service a home loan, the debt servicing ratio has never been worse. It is in 2003—not through the eighties or the nineties—that the debt servicing ratio for Australian home buyers is at its most punishing. This is a heavy burden. Because of today's interest rate rise, the average Australian home buyer is going to face an extra cost of $30 per month.

This comes on top of the other cost-of-living pressures imposed by this government. It is a government that is asking people to pay more, but it gives them less in return. It is a government that has the highest level of taxation in Australia's history. Since 1996 the average Australian household has paid an extra $8,000 in federal taxes, including $5,000 in income tax. On top of that, the Treasurer wants people to pay more for their doctors' fees and to get their kids through higher education, he wants pensioners to pay more for pharmaceuticals and, to cap that off, he slugs them with an extra $30 in interest rates. When Menzies was around in the fifties and sixties, they used to say, `Where's the money coming from?' With this Treasurer you have to ask, `Where's all the money going to?' He is the highest taxing Treasurer in Australia's history, but he still wants people to pay more for the basics of life. No wonder they call him Costello.

talk.start.para: (Hon. I.R. Causley)—The member for Werriwa will refer to members by their title or seat.

—`Costello' is costing us an arm and a leg. He thinks that tax reform is bringing in new taxes—goods and services tax, milk tax, sugar tax, ticket tax, gun tax, Timor tax, wharf tax. He has never seen a tax he did not like. And, on top of that, he wants people to pay more for the basics of life. When there is a $30 slug because of an interest rate rise, all he can do is laugh. He is all smirk and mirrors in his economic world. The government is out there saying, `The economy is growing and people have never had it so good.' This raises the point that, if the economy is so good, why are people paying so much for the basics? The Treasurer's trick is to say, `I've lowered public debt.' He has lowered public debt by selling off public assets, but where has the debt gone? It has gone to everyone else: record household debt, record credit card debt, record foreign debt, record current account deficit. Ask the Treasurer about his university policy—student debt. Ask him about his Centrelink policy—family debt. He has gone debt crazy. Australian households are bearing the heavy burden of this cost-of-living slug and, on top of that, today they get a $30 slug in higher interest rates.

speech.para: What about the impact on first home buyers? The great Australian dream is fading away under this government. Usually in this country, first home buyers make up about 23 per cent of the housing market, so about one in four people traditionally in this country who are purchasing a home are doing it for the first time. That was the thing that always sustained the great Australian dream of home ownership. It kept the dream alive. Today fewer than 14 per cent of people in the housing market are first home buyers—an all-time low. That is why the dream is fading away. We have a housing affordability crisis in this country. What is the government's response? What is the arrogant, complacent response of the Treasurer opposite? Blame the states and call another inquiry. Inquiries do not put people into home ownership. Blaming the states will not get a federal government solution to Australia's housing affordability crisis.

What about the impact on small business? We have got the highest official interest rates in the Western world. This was confirmed by none other than the Minister for Small Business and Tourism, Minister Hockey, on 9 September in an MPI debate. He raised the point, `Why is the Australian dollar rising?' I interjected, `The high relative interest rates,' and he responded, `Well, it has that.' Australia has high relative interest rates, according to the minister for small business. Too right.

The Treasurer is always making taxation comparisons with Botswana and exotic parts of the world, but one comparison he will never make in this debate today is the level of relative interest rates internationally. He will never make an international comparison between Australia's cash rate of five per cent and the cash rates in the rest of the world. What are the cash rates in the G7 countries? In the United States, it is one per cent—not five per cent; in the United Kingdom, three; in Canada 2.8; in Germany, two; in Italy, 2.07; and in Japan, barely above zero. Then, if you look at Europe—and the Treasurer was talking about comparisons with France and Germany—you can compare our interest rates with these European examples: Austria, two; Denmark, 2.2; Finland, two; Greece, two; Portugal, two; Poland, four; Spain, two; and Sweden, 2.9. Australia has the highest official interest rates in the Western world, and this is a competitive disadvantage for Australian small businesses.

Why have the rates gone up? Why does Australia have the highest official interest rates in the Western world? Why are home buyers facing such a heavy burden for their cost of living? Why are small businesses internationally disadvantaged by today's announcement? It is because of government policy neglect. You only have to read the Reserve Bank statement issued today accompanying the interest rate rise to see their concerns and the warning bells that they have been sounding for quite some time. What is the warning and the concern they have had about the housing market? They pointed out today, `The housing market continues to be buoyant.' That spells bubble, and it is not just the Reserve Bank talking about the bubble; the head of Treasury has identified it. The chief adviser to the Treasurer has identified a housing bubble as a substantial risk for the future of the Australian economy. So too has the IMF and APRA. Everyone can see the housing bubble except this arrogant and complacent Treasurer who does not give two hoots about home buyers and the need to stabilise the housing market, smooth out the housing cycle and address the Reserve Bank concern about the housing bubble.

The other concern that the Reserve Bank list in their statement today is the explosion in household debt over the last 18 months, an issue on which the Treasurer is totally complacent. He is a man living in the past and talking about the past instead of addressing the real-life concerns of Australian home buyers today. The Reserve Bank have been issuing these warnings and ringing the warning bell for month after month after month, but the dog is always asleep on the porch. He is always asleep, doing nothing. We always see the same old complacency and arrogance that defines his treasurership.

The government have had these warnings from the Reserve Bank, the IMF, Ken Henry and APRA. We again call on the Treasurer to take some action. We do not need more inquiries into housing affordability. We do not need political blame shifting onto the states. We need action now. The Australian people are calling for action. The Reserve Bank is calling for it—so too are APRA and the IMF. The head of your own department, Treasurer, is calling for action, so you need to adopt Labor's policy plan to smooth out the housing cycle.

talk.start.para: —Ha, ha!

—He laughs. He thinks it is funny. He thinks it is funny to blame the states, to call inquiries and to do absolutely nothing. The truth is that the Treasurer is just a spectator to the housing and property rollercoaster. I urge him to adopt Labor's policy proposals for smoothing out the housing cycle. Wouldn't it be a good start if they had a housing minister? Wouldn't it be a good start if they developed urban policies to influence housing supply and land releases in our major cities? The Treasurer laughs, but what is his response to calls by the Governor of the Reserve Bank for national regulation of the real estate promotion industry? He should be amending the Corporations Act in cooperation with the states to ensure that ASIC has the power to regulate property investment advisers. The Governor of the Reserve Bank has been calling for this policy action by the federal government, and all we have is an arrogant, out of touch Treasurer who laughs about suggestions of public policy.

speech.para: How about adopting a national population policy—specifically, the redirection of migration growth pressures out of the Sydney housing market? A Monash University study recently showed that 50 per cent of the price pressures in Sydney come from migration population pressure. The Chifley Research Centre has put out an outstanding paper demonstrating how we can have a different, more dispersed pattern of migration settlement. The government is always saying, `We decide who comes into Australia.' How about deciding on a different, more dispersed pattern of migration settlement that takes the sting out of expensive, big city housing markets and provides a bit of stability and a safeguard against the housing bubble? How about ensuring that the release of Commonwealth land-holdings has regard for the state of the housing cycle—that is, they act in a countercyclical way to stabilise the market? How about ensuring the comprehensive national regulation of mortgage brokers and originators, plus preventing the recent practice of lending against car equity, the so-called liberty loans? How about introducing new savings programs and incentives for Australian families, thereby improving the household balance sheet and lowering the risk of excessive household debt?

Treasurer, is that enough policy for you? Is that enough policy for someone who is just a spectator to the housing rollercoaster? The Labor Party is advocating policy change and the Reserve Bank is advocating policy change. I dare say that the head of your own department, having defined a housing bubble, is saying, `Let's have housing policy change.' That would be the logical conclusion for someone who has identified a housing bubble, which by definition at some stage will burst. That is why the head of the Treasury talks about a bubble—bubbles burst. How about the Treasurer adopting these policy ideas for economic stability and some downward pressure on interest rates?

So this is a government that lives in the past, a government that blames others, a government that always delays with more unnecessary inquiries. The Australian people want action and some improvements in housing policies—some action to smooth out the housing cycle and provide a savings culture rather than a debt culture in this country. The Australian people want the government to build a new savings culture to help families stabilise the family budget and ease the problem of excessive household debt. Labor built the modern Australian economy. That is why we want these policy changes. We built the modern Australian economy and we want to keep it strong. A reformer's work is never done. It is about time the arrogant and complacent Treasurer opposite woke up to himself and put in place the necessary reforms to place some downward pressure on interest rates and give the Australian people a fair go for the future. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I was expecting a speech which was not as weak as that. I noticed that there was no occasion on which any of the backbench actually endorsed what the speaker was saying. There was no `hear, hear', there was no applause and there was no yelling in support, because the speech lacked logic and argument, and what it lacked in logic and argument it made up for in abuse. I think the abusive tactics of the member for Werriwa are well known. There would be nobody in modern Australian parliamentary terms that has engaged in as much personal abuse as the member for Werriwa. He has heaped personal abuse on journalists, on people like Tony Staley and on members of the House, and he has heaped personal vitriol on others to make up for his own deficiencies.

speech.para: I believe that the people of Australia have figured out that the abuse tactics of the member for Werriwa actually make up for a lack of intellectual rigour and a lack of consistency in policy. I have noticed that it is a tactic of his when he is caught on policy and caught intellectually to make up for it with personal abuse. Many of us were entertained to see him shake the hand of the American President, given the personal abuse that he had heaped on President Bush and indeed upon the Prime Minister in relation to Iraq.

talk.start.para: —And he interjects again that President Bush is incompetent. That may be your view of Mr Bush; I wonder what his view of you is. If one were to look at the various responsibilities that are exercised by the member for Werriwa compared to those exercised by the President of the United States, I wonder who actually has the more difficult job to discharge, and I wonder whether or not there is a basis for the member for Werriwa to breathe fire and loathing against the American President.

speech.para: So what did we hear? We heard a speech which began by saying that interest rates, presumably, are too high, and ended up by saying that to deal with this problem what we should do is adopt the Labor policy. And what is the Labor policy? It is a population policy—a population policy as an answer to rising interest rates! I must say, that is a novel proposition. It is not one that has ever occurred to macroeconomists—that when you see interest rates rising what you need is a population policy. Apparently it never occurred to the Labor Party that in the late 1980s when home mortgage interest rates were 17 per cent they could be fixed with a population policy. It has not occurred to anybody in the IMF and it has not occurred to anybody in the OECD. It has not occurred to anybody in the Treasury and it has not occurred to anybody in the Reserve Bank. But apparently, according to the member for Werriwa, the answer to rising interest rates is a population policy. That, I have to say, is bizarre.

What else did he say? He said that the regulation by ASIC in relation to property investment seminars is somehow an answer to rising interest rates—again something that has apparently eluded all of the macroeconomists that have dealt with interest rates this century and in the post-war world. I might just say, in passing, in relation to that, that nobody has supported ASIC more than this government and nobody has sought to undermine it more than the member for Werriwa. We do find it rather interesting that he should stand up here and call for more powers for ASIC when he is engaged in a campaign to undermine the chairman of that commission. He calls for more power for a commission which he is busily undermining—because, as he himself said, it had the temerity to take on `the son of a Labor icon'. That is what he said in this House: it took on `the son of a Labor icon'. We hear big calls for increased regulation—what!—unless it involves the son of a Labor icon. Now, we cannot take that proposition from him seriously.

However, let me make this point: the ACCC and ASIC have recently brought joint proceedings against a property seminar operator, a Mr Henry Kaye. I do not prejudge the outcome, but they have certainly found that the powers they have are great enough to bring proceedings. The proposition that is advanced here is that somehow giving further powers to ASIC—an institution whose chairman he is undermining—is a response to rising interest rates. This is not serious stuff; this is the kind of stuff that you would expect in an urban policy in a state government, which I sometimes think is where the member for Werriwa really wanted to end up—in state politics doing urban policy.

However, his foray as an adviser in state politics was not a successful one, because even then he had a preoccupation with property. His preoccupation with property then, of course, was not to make property less expensive but to make it more expensive. Whilst he was working on Premier Carr's staff he wrote articles calling for property in Western Sydney to be made more expensive. His view was that it had to be made more expensive so fewer people settled there. He published his article in Australian Quarterly. It was called `Urban policy and the environment in Western Sydney', and the member for North Sydney has referred to it previously. This was not a demand to make property less expensive but to make it more expensive. It was not a demand to increase housing affordability but to decrease housing affordability. He goes through all his policies then: urban—

talk.start.para: —You're living in the past.

—He says that I am living in the past: when you confront him with his own statements, it is so embarrassing that it sort of gets expunged from the record. Here are the headings to the so-called policy that he put forward: `Environmental consequences of the urban sprawl'; `Urban planning', which was calling for urban planning; `Land financing', which was calling for land financing; and `Migration policy', where he was calling for a migration policy—back then. But this was not a policy which was designed to actually make housing more affordable; he was running that policy in pursuit of the opportunity to make housing less affordable! Of course, one of the policies that he was championing at that time, in order to make it less affordable, was a capital gains tax on the private home. He said:

quote.para: It is not too late for the State Government to use taxation policy as a disincentive for growth ... Other options include the extension of the Federal capital gains tax to the family home and the introduction of a local government betterment tax.

speech.para: All of the propositions that he now puts forward on migration policy, urban sprawl and land release are not new policies; they have been put forward for a different cause. The cause for which they were previously put forward was the cause of making housing less affordable; now they are put forward to make it more affordable. This is the urban housing policy of somebody who worked in Premier Carr's office—

talk.start.para: —Premier Carr?

—All right, Mr Carr was the leader of the New South Wales state opposition, and Mark Latham was an alderman on the Liverpool City Council. The propositions that he was putting forward then were that there should be local government betterment taxes, capital gains tax, migration policy and urban land release, in order to push up the price of housing; today, he says we want migration policy, land release and urban planning, in order to push down the cost of housing. It is the same policy, but with a different objective, because times have changed.

speech.para: In question time in the House of Representatives today I went over the question of the sincerity the member for Werriwa had in relation to this question of household debt. He got up and asked a question suggesting that he was concerned about household debt. When did the concern about household debt develop? At what point did that develop? It developed when he thought he could turn this around for some political advantage. As recently as April 2002, he was saying, `There is no problem with housing debt.' Why? `Because housing debt has to be measured against assets.' During question time today, I quoted his words from the Sydney Morning Herald, and here they are; the subject of the MPI today is concern about housing debt, and this is what Mark Latham told the Sydney Morning Herald in April 2002:

quote.para: ... Latham isn't worried about debt—

speech.para: says the Sydney Morning Herald—

quote.para: Like all good capitalists—

speech.para: I am not sure that that is accurate—

quote.para: he thinks our increased debt has been put to good use. `Debt is always relative to assets' ... `In the mid-1980s, Australians held $4 in assets for every $1 in household income. Today they hold $6.50 in assets for every $1.'

speech.para: That was in April 2002, and it is still the case. They hold $6 in assets for every $1 in debt. The mover of the motion said, `Not a problem.' We can dispose of the MPI on that basis.

talk.start.para: —Nothing has happened in 18 months? Nothing has changed?

—Now he says, `Yes, that was right in April 2002, but it has all changed in the last 18 months.' Do you know what has happened in the last 18 months? They still hold $6 in assets for every $1 in debt. That is what has happened. Their position has been based on rising asset prices. There has been no change in asset to debt ratios in the last 18 months. So, by your own admission in April of 2002, this whole MPI is useless. There is no problem, according to the member for Werriwa.

speech.para: Now I said earlier that, because he has held every position on every issue, he can always pull out a quote for some particular situation but there is always an opposite and countervailing quote. No doubt he will say that he is no longer in favour of capital gains tax on the family home, but he has been in favour of every policy. He is like a magpie that picks this policy and that policy and puts it all together and tries to make it into a nest, and says, `There it is.' He's been into the Asian miracle; he's been into communitarianism; he's been into the Third Way; he's been into Tony Blair—and he's been out of Tony Blair. He's been into everything, but there is no consistency and no intellectual rigour in any of this. `We'll just pick up this and we'll pick up that, and if they're internally inconsistent, don't worry about it. If I have to be Arthur and I have to be Martha, I'll be both Arthur and Martha.' He has the capacity to hold contradictory positions all the time, and I ask the people of Australia: could somebody like that be trusted in the Treasury portfolio? Of course not. He would never have the stability to be able to run a decent economic policy. He would never have the stability to take a position and defend it and run it through.

This government did have a position, and we did defend it. We said that we would balance Australia's budget. When debt was haemorrhaging at $96 billion and we had had five deficits in a row, we said that we would balance Australia's budget, and we did—and we have now had six budget surpluses out of eight. What is the claim that he has made—that Labor built the modern economy? I suppose Labor built those surpluses, did it? After rescuing Labor from five financial deficits and $96 billion of debt, we have had six budget surpluses out of eight—and we were opposed every step of the way.

What about the taxation system? This was the party that took on the issue that defeated Labor as early as 1985, when the hero, another Labor icon, wanted to introduce a broad-based consumption tax—that was Mr Keating. What did we do? We abolished the wholesale sales tax. We abolished bed taxes. We abolished stamp duties on marketable securities. We abolished the financial institutions duty. We cut income taxes by $12 billion. We halved capital gains taxes. We brought the company tax down from 36 per cent to 30 per cent. We introduced full dividend imputation. We rebuilt the whole taxation system, and the Labor Party opposed it—and when it was finished they said, `Me too.' That is what they said. They are all now in favour of the GST. We appreciate that, we really do, and it would have made a difference back in 2000.

What the Labor Party wants the coalition to do is to build the economy, balance the budget, get the debt down and fix the taxation system, and its greatest desire in life is to get into government and reap the benefit of all that. That is its greatest desire in life. The proposition that Labor built the modern economy is absurd. In the context of a debate on interest rates, let us remind Labor where they were on interest rates: they had 17 per cent home mortgage interest rates and 22 per cent overdraft interest rates. The relative comparison is the comparison between today and where the economy was when this government came to office. Interest rates for home mortgages were 10½ per cent; today they are 6.8 per cent. The average Australian is saving $585 per month on the average mortgage—

talk.start.para: (Hon. I.R. Causley)—The member for Werriwa is warned!

—because this government had the decency to do the hard work. We were opposed every step of the way by people who had no position on anything and every position on nothing—and that sums up the member for Werriwa. This MPI is wrong, by his own admission. He is not concerned about household debt—which is matched by assets. He appears here as the prize witness for the government. He was right in April 2002. We endorse the position that he held. Economic reform is far too important to be left to the Labor Party in this country. (Time expired)

—Household debt has increased over the last decade by roughly 14 per cent per year—well in excess of the growth in household incomes. Ten years ago the Australian household debt to household income ratio was low by international standards. The Australian household debt to household income ratio is now high compared with other industrialised countries. The ratio at the end of 2002 was 125 per cent—a figure which has to be unsustainable. This means that Australian households are very vulnerable to any rise in interest rates, and that includes today's rise of 25 basis points.

speech.para: It is interesting to note the make-up of household debt and how each component has moved. At the end of December 2002 housing debt was 83.5 per cent of household debt, while personal debt was 16.5 per cent. Of the housing debt, just under one-third relates to investment and two-thirds to owner-occupied housing. The growth in these categories has been steady over the decade at about 20 per cent for investment housing and 13.5 per cent for owner-occupied housing, although it is disturbing to note that the level of first home buyers is at the lowest point ever. This is largely because of increasing prices fuelled by lower interest rates.

Of personal debt, which is 16.5 per cent of all household debt, the major item is borrowing to buy cars and other big items. The other item is credit card debt. It is credit card debt that bothers me the most. Credit card debt is the smallest of all the debt categories, but it is the fastest growing. It grew by 17.5 per cent over the last decade and by 20.9 per cent over the last five years. In dollar terms personal debt—that is, non-housing debt—has grown dramatically. In June 1996 it was $7,079 per household. By August 2003 it had reached $12,402 per household. At around the same time credit card debt was sitting at $4,643 per household.

Let me make the point that these figures are averages across all households and therefore hide the real situation for many families and households, because not all households have credit card debts. A number pay off their debts at the end of the month or do not use a credit card at all. Therefore, for every household without a credit card debt, another household has an average debt of $9,000. Those households paying off the plastic at the end of every month are probably not the households most under stress. The ones that are paying off the huge debts are under a lot of stress, and it is being added to now.

We hear criticisms from time to time of those in debt—the criticism being that they should not have gone into debt in the first place, if they could not afford the repayments. I want to make two points to deal with that criticism. The first is that there is nothing wrong with going into debt in the right circumstances. Those circumstances are that the debt is to purchase an ongoing benefit, such as somewhere to live, and that the repayment commitments are within the financial reach of the borrower. It is interesting to note that lower interest rates actually lead to increased borrowing. Lower rates mean that households often borrow more than they used to. When my family took out our home loan many years ago, the bank focused on the percentage of the family income that would go to the repayments, in order to determine the amount we could borrow. Interest is a significant part of repayments, especially in the early years of a loan, so any movement in interest rates has a marked effect on repayments and therefore the amount one can borrow.

In the days of lower interest rates, households can borrow a bigger principal than in the days of higher interest rates. This leaves them exposed to upward movements in interest rates—an exposure that is not always obvious and is not always pointed out to first home buyers. This is one of the reasons that I think it is simplistic to argue that people should not borrow more than they can afford to pay back. The other reason that it is simplistic to blame the victims is that not all borrowings are voluntary. Most of us have borrowed to buy our homes, which is a reasonable thing to do, and governments borrow to provide infrastructure for future generations, which is also a reasonable thing to do. What is not usually reasonable or sensible is to borrow to fund everyday ongoing expenses like visits to the doctor or to borrow to pay off a Centrelink debt. This government is forcing an increasing number of people to do just these things.

Just like every other member of this place, I have had—and continue to have—a stream of people contacting me about their Centrelink debt. It should not be called a debt, by the way, as it is actually an overpayment caused by faulty system design. These people are in receipt of Centrelink payments because they are in difficult financial circumstances or because we as a society rightly judge that families need support while they raise their kids and that people need support if they are caring for sick or disabled relatives. These people do not need, firstly, a system that creates an overpayment situation, despite every effort on their part to avoid such a situation, or, secondly, to be told by the minister to repay a Centrelink debt by going into debt on their credit card, thereby incurring interest repayments.

People in my electorate are now facing decisions about how they are going to pay to go to the doctor, and they are, in that process, adding to their debt levels again. Bulk-billing rates are down, falling to 68 per cent in March this year from 85 per cent three years ago. This means that many people in Isaacs are being forced to pay for visits to the doctor or to queue up in the emergency department of Dandenong or Frankston hospitals. At the same time, doctors' fees are rising sharply. I know from personal experience that it is very hard to visit a doctor these days without paying before the consultation. This is done on the plastic by many people, mainly because they are not sensible enough to get sick when they are flush with funds.

To add insult to injury, credit card fees are also on the rise. The Commonwealth Bank has recently announced rises of 25 per cent in its annual fees for the `no awards' credit cards, 25 per cent for late payment fees and a new fee of $15 for each additional credit card holder. The ANZ has announced a 40 per cent increase in late payment fees and over-limit fees, a tripling of the conversion fee from foreign currencies and a 15 per cent increase in annual fees. If the government is going to promote the use of credit cards by suggesting to Centrelink clients that they use the plastic to repay their overpayments then the government should have the goodness to monitor bank fees and credit card fees and to offer some protection to those struggling with debt.

We keep hearing the argument that interest rates are lower now than when Labor was last in government. Let us get some of the facts on the record today. Australian interest rates for mortgages are today very high by international standards, as are our cash rates. In Australia in September 2003 the standard variable interest rate for a mortgage was 6.6 per cent, beaten only by New Zealand at just over seven per cent. The USA is at 6.05 per cent. All other countries have rates that are around four or five per cent. Germany's is at 4.06 per cent; the UK's is at 5.32 per cent; the rate in the Netherlands is at 4.42 per cent; Canada's is at 4.55 per cent; and Japan's is at 2.6 per cent. The Australian debt servicing ratio is now at six per cent—the highest on record. So much for that claim about high interest rates.

The government is adding to the household debt problem in other ways too. The trend towards casualisation in the work force is driving households into personal debt. Some households are driven to personal debt because their income will not always stretch to cover everyday living expenses. The casual nature of many jobs leaves the household budget in a state of disarray. Households cannot budget on a consistent and steady stream of income when they do not know when they will be working or when they will be told not to bother turning up to work for a few days or a few weeks. This leaves many households with little choice but to use the credit card.

Even those with casual work which seems to be ongoing are at a disadvantage. These workers find it hard to get mortgage finance because of the lack of reliable income. Reputable lenders like to see evidence of an ongoing income stream before they lend. Usually this is in the form of an ongoing job. Those with a casual job often find the mortgage door shut to them and these families have to resort to disreputable lenders or give up the dream of ever owning their own home.

Another push to personal debt is the current government's attempts to fund higher education from the private purse rather than from the public purse. This push to the private purse is happening by increasing HECS fees, introducing full fee paying university courses and retarding the increase in income above which HECS fees are paid. All of these actions are designed to make families and students decide between going to university and incurring a debt or not going to uni and avoiding a debt. As I said before, it is reasonable to incur a debt if that debt is used to finance an ongoing benefit. A university degree is obviously an ongoing benefit.

Research published in 2000 shows that, using 1976 data—that is, before HECS—the individual rate of return was 21.1 per cent while the social rate of return to the community was 16.3 per cent. When the same calculations were done on 1997 data—that is, after HECS was introduced but before the recent increases—the individual return rate was 15 per cent and the social rate was 16.5 per cent, a much more balanced allotment of the costs and clearly a reasonable rate for individuals. But to move the HECS contribution beyond those levels is pushing the cost unreasonably onto the student or the private purse and exposing families to the risk of increasing interest rates.

Householders are facing more and more personal debt and there is a fair bit of evidence around that says that this increase in personal debt is because of government policies. They are therefore vulnerable to moves in interest rates. They are facing increasing stresses on their family lives and their budgets because of the policies of this government.

talk.start.para: —I am happy to respond to the matter of public importance which I understand to involve four principle charges lodged against the government: that we are engaged in some sort of national crisis of household debt; that that crisis is reflected—
(Hon. I.R. Causley)—The member for Batman!

—in particular in housing affordability; that Australia's high interest rates represent a failure of government policy; and that the government is guilty more generally of policy neglect. Access to a house, a home—to the Australian dream—is essentially reliant on three factors: the availability of income, the availability of credit and the availability of collateral to those seeking to acquire a home.
—The member for Batman!

—When we talk about the availability of income, I am reminded of Tony Blair's speech to the trade union movement when he urged them to come in out of the cold. He said that their job was not simply to protect the perquisites of those who already had a job but to create the opportunity for those outside the jobs club to get in. This has been the problem with the ACTU fortress mentality that `Once you're in our little employment club, we're going to look after you.'
—It's not as good as your visa club!
—The member for Batman is warned!

—But to all those banging on the door outside whose great aspiration in life is simply to hold down a job—to earn a regular income—the ACTU and, regrettably, the ALP seem to show scant regard. But this government sought to improve housing affordability by making it easier for people to find a job.

speech.para: If we look at my electorate of Parramatta, when I was elected in 1996 unemployment was just under 14 per cent; 13.9 per cent of my constituents who wanted to find work could not find it in the economic environment created by the Australian Labor Party. Today, eight years later, we have gone from 13.9 per cent unemployment in Parramatta to 4.7 per cent—from 13.9 per cent unemployment in March 1996 to 4.7 per cent in the Parramatta local government area today. That turnaround, that statistic, means literally hundreds of households in my electorate that did not have an income when John Howard was elected have an income today. It means that dozens and dozens of those households have two incomes today where previously they perhaps only had one. It means that hundreds of households who were underemployed and who were always struggling on the revenue side of the equation now have access to well-paid employment.

I say in relation to the income side of the equation that when you sit down with a mortgage originator and he or she says to you, `What sort of income is the household generating?' the answer under a coalition government is fundamentally different from the answer under 13 years of Labor. One of the things that has happened under the coalition is sustained growth in real wages—faster growth under the coalition. In spite of all the ALP's rhetoric of looking after the workers, if you want real wages to rise, vote for a Liberal-National government, because the record shows that real wages under this government have grown by about 12 per cent as opposed to something like just 1½ per cent in the last five years of Labor's management of the economy.

Not only do you have more likelihood of having a job on the housing affordability index, but when you have one you have the likelihood of increasing purchasing power. The growth in purchasing power also arises from good economic management which has produced low inflation. The government's target of the agreement with the Reserve Bank under which we have put inflation into a medium-term, transparent, accountable framework has attracted particular praise from the IMF in the report to which the Treasurer referred in question time. What we have achieved is a kind of holy grail of high economic growth and low inflation. So we are seeing that, in terms of the wages that Australian families are earning, the purchasing power is not being eroded year by year by a rapid increase in prices.

The first thing we want to do in terms of making housing affordable is to try to ensure that Australians have access to a job—and a well-paid job. I want to note, as the Treasurer did during question time, that debt should not be considered in isolation from assets. That was the second factor I referred to in relation to the chance of getting into a home—that is, collateral. The ABS tells us that we have had the most rapid wealth creation in the past eight years that we have seen in the last century. Australia's wealth creation is moving ahead in leaps and bounds.

The averages show that the wealth of the average Australian has almost doubled in this country in the last eight years. It has not been entirely evenly spread across the population but it is nonetheless the case that the trend line is overwhelmingly up. That means that those who have managed to get into the home market and who have acquired the asset are seeing that asset significantly appreciate in value. That means that debt levels are serviceable.

If we turn it around it is probably the case that Australia has higher levels of debt today than it has had in its history. That is because the economy is bigger today than it has ever been in its history. With regard to the issue of job creation, when we talk about zero unemployment right after the Second World War we are talking about a period of time when only half the work force was even participating—when it was essentially a male work force. Today we have very high levels of participation by men and women. We have seen a revolution in the work force. In my electorate we are still producing an unemployment figure of less than five per cent, which reflects a tremendous amount of economic activity and growth in productivity.

When the member for Werriwa referred to the allegedly high relative interest rates, he quoted one sentence from the Hansard of 9 September from my colleague Joe Hockey. He failed to quote the rest of the paragraph, where, when referring to Australia's relative interest rate position, Joe Hockey said:

quote.para: Because Australia is not in the depths of recession that other jurisdictions are in, yet interest rates today are more affordable for Australians than ever before. They are now lower for Australians than ever before. That is primarily because we still have a strong and sustainable economy at a time when everyone around us is struggling in one form or another.

speech.para: So we had a situation where the Australian economy was growing at the fastest rate in the OECD where seven out of 10 of our top trading partners were either in recession or depression. It is true that the Reserve Bank has raised the home mortgage rate by a quarter of a per cent. The Reserve Bank has done that because the Australian economy is strong and is getting stronger. This is exactly the kind of problem that our trading partners would be desperate to have. In Japan they had a situation where they could not give money away—where the banks were charging negative interest rates. They were saying, `We will pay you to take our money we are so desperate to generate economic activity'. The Reserve Bank today has taken a prudent, moderate step. It is a small rise in interest rates but it signals that the Australian economy is strong. It signals that we are in a growth phase and it signals the Reserve Bank's confidence that we will continue to grow.

I want to turn finally to this suggestion that we are guilty of government policy neglect. I want to refer in a little more detail to the IMF report released at the end of October, to which the Treasurer referred very briefly in question time. With characteristic humility he refrained from quoting some more of the detail of their analysis—that is, the IMF executive board's assessment of the Australian economy and in particular of this government's management of the economy. These are not my words; I have no particular vested interest. This is what the directors said about this government's apparent policy neglect. The report said:

quote.para: Executive Directors commended the continued strong performance of the Australian economy in the face of persistent weakness in external demand and a severe drought at home. They attributed Australia's ability to generate robust economic growth with low inflation to the enhanced resilience of the economy, brought about, in turn, by steadfast pursuit of prudent macroeconomic policies and structural reforms within transparent policy frameworks.

speech.para: It continued:

quote.para: Directors agreed that the appreciation of the Australian dollar is generally in line with its medium-term equilibrium value and is mostly due to the relative strength of the Australian economy.
Directors regarded Australia's fiscal position as fundamentally sound, reflecting the authorities'—

speech.para: That is, the Treasurer's, the government's—

quote.para: disciplined implementation of their policy framework.

speech.para: That is what you get from the coalition. You get sustained commitment. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Mr Barresi)—Order! The discussion is now concluded.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
(Mr Barresi)—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—Please proceed.

—During the contribution of the Treasurer he claimed that whilst our shadow Treasurer and member for Werriwa was speaking no opposition member supported his remarks or said, `Hear hear' to his remarks. I cannot speak for other members but I certainly did so myself.

talker.name: Williams, Daryl, MP
Mr WILLIAMS
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the amendments be agreed to.

speech.para: The Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002 was introduced in the House of Representatives on 27 June 2002 and it makes a series of minor amendments to the Australian Communications Authority Act 1997, the Freedom of Information Act 1982, the Radiocommunications Act 1992, the Telecommunications Act 1997 and the Telecommunications (Consumer Protection and Service Standards) Act 1999. The bill was passed by the Senate with three minor amendments: two by the government, and one by the Democrats as amended by the opposition.

Amendment (1) relates to the commencement of schedule 2 to the bill, which amends the Freedom of Information Act 1982. It changes the commencement date of schedule 2 from 27 June 2002, the date the bill was introduced into the House of Representatives, to 27 March 2003, the date the bill was passed by the House of Representatives. It is appropriate that the proposed amendments have a degree of retrospectivity so that the Freedom of Information Act cannot be used to undermine the operation of the online content scheme in schedule 5 to the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 by allowing the uncontrolled disclosure of potentially prohibited Internet content. Due to the delay in passing the bill, this amendment reduces the retrospectivity of the proposed amendments to the Freedom of Information Act while ensuring that the aims of the amendments are not frustrated.

Amendment (2) relates to the commencement of schedule 4 to the bill, which abolishes the specially constituted Australian Communications Authority. The amendment changes the commencement date of schedule 4 from 1 April 2003 to the day after the bill, when enacted, receives the royal assent. 1 April 2003 was the date on which the appointments of the original members of the specially constituted ACA expired. However, due to delays in passing this bill, new members of the specially constituted ACA were appointed from 2 April 2003 until the enactment of the bill. The amendment ensures the validity of any decisions made by the current members of the specially constituted ACA for the purposes of schedule 3 to the Telecommunications Act from 2 April 2003 until the enactment of the bill. After that time the ACA will consider any applications for facility installation permits.

Amendment (3) is a Democrat amendment, as amended by the opposition. This amendment, which requires further consultation prior to the issuing of a facility installation permit, is unnecessary. However, the government is prepared to accept this amendment in order to ensure the bill passes, on the basis that the amendment has no practical effect on the existing consultative arrangements and sets no precedent. The amendment only applies to the granting by the ACA of a facility installation permit, not to the installation of facilities in general. By allowing this amendment, the government does so recognising that similar consultative mechanisms are not required in other areas of the Telecommunications Act. The Telecommunications Act states that facility installation permits can only be sought in relation to telecommunications networks of national significance, and, in any case, prior to issuing a facility installation permit, the Australian Communications Authority must hold a public inquiry in relation to the permit.

This amendment purports to require community consultation, consideration of alternative sites, and minimisation of electromagnetic radiation, requirements that would be considered anyway by the ACA in the course of the public inquiry process already established in the Telecommunications Act. The amendment requires that the community, wherever possible, has agreed to a proposed facility. The government encourages the telecommunications industry to consult with the community on the siting and roll-out of its infrastructure. However, it is inappropriate that a telecommunications carrier can be prevented from installing a facility that forms part of a network of national significance, where that facility complies with all Commonwealth legislation, including electromagnetic emission standards. Therefore, whilst this amendment would require carriers to seek the agreement of the community, if a community unreasonably withheld its agreement the ACA could still issue a facility installation permit.

The Telecommunications Act provides that all telecommunications facilities, except for temporary Defence facilities and those defined as low impact, require state, territory or local government approval. Facilities, including many mobile phone base stations, are not low impact and are therefore regulated by existing state, territory or local government planning regulations. Regardless of whether a carrier is installing a low-impact facility or other telecommunications facilities, it is required, either by an industry code or by state, territory or local planning regulations, to consult with the community. (Extension of time granted)

By providing immunity to carriers for the installation of low-impact facilities the government is balancing the needs of the community to have access to high-quality and competitive telecommunications networks with the requirements that community concerns regarding the aesthetics of a community be addressed. On the basis of these other elements in the act, the government does not consider that this amendment provides a precedent for other provisions in the Telecommunications Act. Thus, given that the Democrat amendment, as amended by the opposition, restates elements of the existing process, the government is prepared to accept the amendment in order to pass the bill. However, the government would not be prepared to accept similar clauses being inserted into other provisions of the act. In conclusion, the government supports the bill as amended.
Question agreed to.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed.

talk.start.para: —In this debate earlier we reached our approach to the provisions contained within section 26A of the draft bill and whether those provisions would be in need of any amendment by the time this bill reaches the Senate. Our argument overall is that amendments to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Actare welcome and, in fact, overdue, but the proposals that have been put forward need to balance the need for a stronger protection regime for nuclear materials and nuclear facilities with the need to ensure the continued right to legitimate protest and to ensure that inadvertent communication of information is not caught up by the scope of the bill. For these reasons, the opposition will, prior to consideration by the Senate, examine further legal advice from beyond government on the adequacy or otherwise of the current drafting of section 26A.

speech.para: We are in receipt of an exchange of correspondence between the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Attorney-General's Department on this matter. We are thankful to the department for making those items of correspondence concerning section 26A available to the opposition. However, we also wish to test the argument advanced in the Attorney-General's Department's brief on this matter that legitimate protest activity will not be inadvertently impeded by the current formulation and drafting contained within section 26A of the act. Should the opposition conclude that the concerns foreshadowed in the foregoing remarks are well founded then the opposition would wish to signal that we would move appropriate amendments in the Senate.

Of course, the broader context in which this debate is cast is where we stand on the overall question of nuclear weapons proliferation. I have already referred to the respective records of the Hawke-Keating government on the one hand and the Howard government on the other when it comes to the priority attached to the overall nuclear weapons proliferation regime. We are proud of the record we have on these matters and we are concerned at the problematic departure from both the spirit and the substance of that record by the government which has succeeded us.

Of course, when we look at the particular challenges which the proliferation regime faces around the world, we are mindful of the specific challenges within our region. I have referred already to the challenges which present themselves on the Korean peninsula, the Indian subcontinent and elsewhere—and prospectively in Iran as well, as the disagreement between the government in Tehran and the International Atomic Energy Agency comes shortly to a head. These are serious matters of nuclear weapons proliferation, which responsible governments around the world have to deal with seriously.

I contrast that with the attitude which was brought to bear on the question of nuclear weapons proliferation in this government's critique of the former regime in Iraq. We had an extraordinary set of arguments advanced by those opposite for going to war with Iraq. One argument was in relation to the use of aluminium tubes and a second was in relation to the use of uranium which, the government purported, the government in Baghdad had sought to import from Africa—specifically, from the state of Niger. On the question of aluminium tubing, the opportunistic use of this argument by the government to advance the view that Iraq was in the process of the active reconstitution of a nuclear weapons program immediately prior to the war has subsequently been fundamentally undermined. Back in September 2002 the foreign minister used this attempted importation of aluminium tubes into Iraq as possible evidence of the reconstitution of a nuclear weapons program.
