Of course, this has recently figured prominently in television documentaries covering the history of how that particular piece of intelligence was collected and the actual use to which the aluminium tubing was subsequently put.

The chronology is important because, as of the middle of 2002, Mr Greg Theilman, formerly of the Bureau of Intelligence and Research of the United States State Department, has gone on the record and concluded that, as of mid-2002, the consensus across allied, US and Australian intelligence communities was that that particular piece of equipment was not relevant to Iraq's nuclear weapons program or to any reconstitution of that program. I raise this because these conclusions were reached, according to Mr Thielman, in the middle of 2002; but, three months later, in September 2002, the foreign minister stood in this parliament and said that the attempted importation of aluminium tubes provided an element of evidence about a possible reconstitution of Iraq's nuclear weapons program. I do not regard that as the foreign minister's finest moment in this place. Plainly, the intelligence record which he had available to him by that time would have cast sufficient doubt over the argument that this tubing was somehow destined for gas centrifuges and were therefore destined to be part of Iraq's reconstituted nuclear weapons program. That sufficient doubt existed on all these propositions should have cautioned any responsible minister against advancing these arguments from the dispatch box, but it did not so caution our foreign minister.

The misrepresentation on this matter did not stop there. The other and grander misrepresentation lay in what the Prime Minister had to say in August last year. He said that there were some signs that Saddam Hussein was developing an embryonic nuclear weapons capacity as well. Again, on 4 February, in very definite terms, the Prime Minister declared:

quote.para: Iraq continues to work on developing nuclear weapons. Uranium has been sought from Africa that has no civil application in Iraq ... Iraq is reconstituting its nuclear weapons program.

speech.para: Again, by the time the Prime Minister stood up and made that claim on 4 February 2003, not long before he took this country to war, a mass of evidence was available through allied intelligence shared with Australia which cast fundamental doubt on the entire claim about Iraq having imported uranium from Africa. In fact, within the US intelligence community, former ambassador Joe Wilson was dispatched to Niger in February 2002 to investigate whether or not this claim was true. This was fully 12 months before the Prime Minister stood here and said, definitively, that it was the case. Ambassador Wilson returned to the United States and said, definitively, that it was not the case.

Subsequent to that, we had a series of reports from throughout the US bureaucracy—through the Bureau of Intelligence and Research of the State Department and through other elements of the US bureaucracy as well—ultimately filtering through to this country as the National intelligence estimate on Iraq's continuing programs for weapons of mass destruction, which was completed some time towards the end of 2002 and then shared with Australia, as is the normal practice, through normal intelligence and liaison circles. These various reports, in their own way, all cast fundamental doubt on the accuracy of the Niger uranium claim. Nonetheless, the Prime Minister stood here and made that claim in this parliament. Only in June 2003, three months subsequent to the war, did the foreign minister have the decency—not in this parliament but in the Sydney Morning Herald—to seek to correct the record.

I raise these because they are examples of the irresponsible engagement in this debate about nuclear weapons proliferation. It is a non-substantive engagement in the debate about nuclear weapons proliferation, in contrast to the great challenges of weapons proliferation and the importance of the safeguards regime which applies to so many other regions and subregions of our immediate strategic environment. These require high-grade, substantive, serious policy engagement on the part of the Australian government. They do not require the exercise in political expediency that we saw on the matters of aluminium tubing and Niger uranium, as we saw in the lead-up to the Iraq war. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —There are two main purposes for the Non-Proliferation Legislation Amendment Bill 2003. Firstly, it seeks to amend the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Act 1987 in order to strengthen security for nuclear material and information relating to that material. Secondly, it aims to amend the Comprehensive Nuclear Test-Ban Treaty Act 1998 so that Australia can apply legislation banning nuclear weapons tests before the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty enters into force internationally.

speech.para: To put it more simply, the purposes of the bill are, firstly, to strengthen the security of nuclear material and information in Australia—that is, to safeguard it from terrorists—and, secondly, to allow Australia to ban nuclear weapons tests even though the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty or the CTBT still has not come into force internationally. I believe these to be worthy purposes. Who in this House is going to argue that we should not take great care to prevent terrorist organisations from obtaining the means to make nuclear weapons—the means to create horror, terror and havoc and to hold the country to ransom? Who in this House would argue that we should allow nuclear weapons tests in Australia?

However, there might well be some confusion, and responsible people are not comfortable agreeing to something when they are unsure of its meaning or of its repercussions. With this legislation, such uncertainty might well arise because of the complexity of some material. Some of it is even obtuse if you are not really conversant with the subject. Because I believe this legislation is important to the security of our country, I hope to resolve any uncertainty my colleagues might have.

First of all, the three schedules of this bill cover totally separate matters. As the Assistant Secretary of the Australian Safeguards and Nonproliferation Office told the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Legislation Committee hearing, they are not linked. Looking for the link creates confusion, because it is not there. Items were included as three schedules of the one bill simply for convenience, rather than having three separate pieces of legislation. Schedule 1 of the bill covers the strengthening of security, both for nuclear material and for information pertaining to it. Schedule 2 relates to the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty. Schedule 3 is simply a technical one allowing name changes for certain offices and positions. These schedule 3 amendments only allow for a change of name after due gazettal. They do not in any way change the power or responsibility of those offices or positions.

So what specifically are the amendments to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Act 1987 contained in schedule 1? What is their purpose? Apart from the broad, overall aims of preventing the proliferation of nuclear weapons and the theft of information and materials to make such weapons, these amendments are designed basically to do five things: to strengthen procedures to protect information relevant to the proliferation of nuclear weapons and to protect the physical security of nuclear material; to ensure that regulatory arrangements apply, not only to actual nuclear material but also to any material specially suited to use in nuclear activities or in the production of nuclear explosive devices; to require a permit for activity to establish a nuclear installation; to create offences, firstly, for unauthorised access to specific areas and, secondly, for causing damage to an installation or mechanism intended to protect nuclear or associated material; and to update existing penalty provisions, bringing them into line with current legislative practice.

A number of these amendments are actually only small changes to definitions, to update them and make them more relevant. Items 1 and 2, for instance, deal with extending the definition of `associated material' to include materials used in nuclear activities as defined in the safeguards act or materials used in the production of nuclear explosive devices. The definitions of `containment device' and `surveillance device' are broadened to accommodate physical and technological change. For example, the explanatory information says that the definition of `containment device' is extended from a physical barrier to include `any device used to contain relevant items or information.' This, of course, could include computer security and electronic barriers.

I believe it would be difficult to argue against the necessity for a permit to establish a nuclear facility. This bill states that, before such a permit is issued, the director must report to the minister that he or she is satisfied with the security of nuclear material and associated items at the proposed facility. If a permit is granted, it can be made subject to restrictions and conditions with respect to design, inspections and reports on the work carried out there.

While the Senate committee report recommended that the bill be passed by the Senate in its current form, there was some discussion on a couple of items, including item 26. This item deals with the giving out of unauthorised information which could prejudice the physical security of nuclear material or an associated item. The penalty for this is two years imprisonment. There was some concern that this might intimidate whistleblowers, even though it is certainly not the aim of the amendment.

Mr Andrew Leask of the Australian Safeguards and Nonproliferation Office addressed these concerns at the Senate committee hearing. He said that, for the divulgence of unauthorised information to be an offence under this amendment, it has to be prejudicial to the physical security of nuclear material or an associated item. The unauthorised communication must be such that it could enable an adversary to defeat physical protection arrangements that are in place.

Mr Leask also noted that, if an insider had access to certain information and wanted to make a complaint or to improve the system but did not feel they could approach a more senior officer, they could report the matter to either of the two nuclear regulators in Australia. So if an insider, or a whistleblower, believes there is a problem with a nuclear facility he or she can take the information to a regulator, a very pertinent authority. This enables them to report the problem to an authority without divulging secure information to an authorised person. They are therefore not endangering the security of nuclear material, which means that they are not committing an offence under the act.

Item 45 inserts a new section 31A into the safeguards act, making it an offence for a person to enter restricted areas. Such an area can include a vehicle, aircraft or ship. A protest group which periodically makes headlines with its civil disobedience and sabotage efforts complained that this new section interferes with its right to protest. I believe in the democratic right to protest in a number of ways, including gathering in public places. What I do not believe in is the right for groups to demonstrate in restricted nuclear sites. Maybe those involved are simply intent on making a point by entering such a place, but they would be doing more than that. They would also be endangering their security, the security of the site and its workers, and possibly the lives of thousands, because they would be providing an opportunity, a vehicle, for a terrorist organisation to use a protest as cover for sabotage or theft of nuclear material.

These restricted sites are not designated at whim. The minister or director cannot say: `There's a strike tomorrow. We'd better make this a restricted site.' This section specifically only applies where the holder of a permit is required by a condition of that permit to restrict access to designated areas or vehicles and also to mark those places with signs indicating that entering without authorisation is an offence under the act. Australia has obligations under the Convention on the Physical Protection of Nuclear Material to protect particular areas in particular ways. A protected area is a limited area containing more sensitive materials or items—for instance, the reactor area as opposed to the general office buildings at Lucas Heights.
I would like to quote from Mr Leask's response to the Senate committee on this matter. He said:

quote.para: ... I do not believe this bill is in any way ... restricting the right of lawful protest. But, clearly, unauthorised people entering a protected area—whether it be by legal means, such as through a gate, or by illegal means, such as over a gate or breaking down a gate and going in—which contains sensitive materials and which has as part of its design philosophy defence in depth, begin to compromise those arrangements and have to be treated ... as a genuine threat to the security of the material and the facilities.

speech.para: The aim of this amendment is to make accessing one of these specifically designated—and therefore signed—protected areas a more serious offence than that of mere trespass. Item 71 of schedule 1 clarifies the power of an Australian Protective Service officer to effect an arrest without a warrant. The item simply includes the new offences from this bill in the list of offences for which these officers are already empowered. APS officers have protection and security responsibilities for the Commonwealth in certain places, including designated airports, diplomatic premises, Parliament House and Lucas Heights. These officers have authority to meet those responsibilities. They are also empowered to arrest without a warrant but only if they have reasonable grounds to suspect the person has committed, or is about to commit, an offence which is prescribed under the act.

The reason for, and the benefit of, this power is that it allows immediate action to be taken in suspicious and possibly dangerous circumstances. However, there are checks and balances to this power. If an APS officer does arrest a person, he or she must deliver that person forthwith to a police officer for the matter to be investigated and dealt with under the law. It is a very limited power of arrest for specific offences in specific places, which then must be investigated by a police officer.

As I said in the beginning, this bill has two main purposes. I have already talked about the schedule 1 amendments aimed at strengthening security for nuclear material. Before discussing the schedule 2 amendments to the Comprehensive Nuclear Test-Ban Treaty Act 1998, I would like to give a quick background sketch of the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty. In 1996 the United Nations General Assembly voted 158 to three to approve the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty. It was signed by Australia and the five declared nuclear powers on 24 September and ratified by Australia in July 1998.

The treaty establishes an international monitoring system and introduces on-site inspections to strengthen verification once the treaty banning nuclear tests comes into force. The problem is that article XIV of the treaty provides that it does not enter into force until it has been ratified by all 44 nuclear capable states. Although about 100 nations have now ratified it, only 31 of the 44 nuclear capable states have done so—which means, of course, that the treaty is not yet in force. One of the 44 resisting ratification is the United States.

While Australia passed the Comprehensive Nuclear Test-Ban Treaty Act in 1998, giving effect to Australia's obligations under the CTBT, that act does not commence until the treaty enters into force—that is, until the specified 44 countries have ratified it and triggered its entry into force. As the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Christine Gallus, said in her second reading speech, entry into force remains `more distant than the government would wish' but this bill is a `clear gesture of support for the test ban'.

This bill amends the commencement provisions of the Comprehensive Nuclear Test-Ban Treaty Act 1998 so that key provisions can be proclaimed in advance of entry into force of the CTBT. What this means is that Australia can bring into effect provisions which ban nuclear testing in Australia or by Australian citizens in other parts of the world.

The amendments to the Comprehensive Nuclear Test-Ban Treaty Act also enable Australia to respond to any request for an inspection to demonstrate compliance. While such a request may be unlikely, it means that our legislation is consistent with our treaty obligations. Once again we are demonstrating Australia's support for the CTBT. I note that neither the report by the Senate committee nor the dissenting reports argue against the schedule 2 amendments contained in this bill.

The bill is another measure in the fight to keep our country and our world as safe as possible. It aims to prevent terrorist organisations from obtaining nuclear explosives or the means to make them. It also bans nuclear testing in Australia or by Australians. I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —I am happy to follow the member for Fairfax and also the shadow minister for foreign affairs, Mr Rudd, in this debate on matters which are indeed of great national significance—matters that should really have been dealt with more speedily by this government. The fact that they have not been is an indication of the government's priorities. It is also an indication of the government's view of these matters.

speech.para: The member for Fairfax quite rightly pointed out that in 1996 the UN voted 158 to three to approve the nuclear test ban treaty. You can pretty much almost immediately guess who the three were who voted against it. My guess would be the United States, China and Israel. I would not think I would be too far off the mark. They are still the countries that are most against stopping nuclear testing. The United States has been from the very beginning a consistent and complete opponent of the attempt on the part of Australia and other nations to push forward a comprehensive test ban on nuclear weapons. The United States thinks that it is its sole sovereign right to continue nuclear testing, despite the fact that 100 countries have signed up to this approach and despite the fact that there continues to be some progress with the 44 who need to sign up.

But progress is difficult when you have a country as significant as the US involved—when you know that it has stockpiles of nuclear weapons greater than anyone else and when you know that it also has vast stockpiles of other weapons of mass destruction, biological and chemical. If you look across the four areas of weapons of mass destruction—nuclear, chemical and biological and the missile capacity to deliver those—and you look at the countries around the world, the United States is at the top of the list.

It was of course at the top of the list in being the first country in the world to develop and then use nuclear weapons. It did so in a race with Nazi Germany but, having defeated Nazi Germany, it used those weapons on Hiroshima and Nagasaki. Both weapons, used on 6 August and 8 August 1945, had a tremendously devastating effect. They also had a psychological effect on people in the United States because when hundreds of thousands of people perished in an instant—when a city that had thousands of years of history simply disappeared before the eyes of the US Air Force people who conducted the strike—the terrible strength of these weapons became apparent.

In possibly the best book about nuclear weapons and their development, a book called Brighter Than a Thousand Suns—which dealt with the tremendous efforts put in by the United States to develop these weapons in the first place and then to quickly move on to the hydrogen bomb—you get an indication of not just how powerful these weapons are but also what a temptation they were to the United States, not only to develop but to then use to demonstrate that power, and what a temptation they were to all of the other countries that wanted to get them.

We know from the spy cases against the Rosenbergs and the spy case against Klaus Fuchs that those people—who betrayed information about nuclear weapons systems, who had inside information—would have been caught up in the provisions of the Non-Proliferation Legislation Amendment Bill 2003. In Fuchs' case, he was part of the development programs and a leading scientist in that. In terms of the Rosenbergs, it was long argued that they were not acting as agents of the Soviet Union but now it has been demonstrated conclusively that they were. They communicated to another party information they had about nuclear weapons that could cause those weapons to be used or developed in a country that did not have them. That is part of what this bill is about. We know that the Soviet Union very quickly developed a weapons program based on the information that was given to them illegally due to the spying activities of those who were involved—not just the people I have mentioned but a series of others.

We know that once a second power—the other basic pillar power of the Cold War—got weapons of mass destruction in nuclear form the world could not be safe from the potential use of those once again. We also know that a lot of the spies argued that they were whistleblowers and that what they were trying to achieve was some form of balance by allowing another nation—here the Soviet Union, which had been an ally during the Second World War—access to information about how to make weapons; not just the original thermonuclear devices but the hydrogen bomb. I think by about 1952 they had exploded their first one, so that was not very long after the United States had achieved that.

In doing so, those people argued they were benefiting humanity in that they were trying to spread information and knowledge; they were trying to create a counterbalance—one could argue `a counterbalance of terror'—to the United States. Because of what those people perpetrated, the world lost the possibility of the United States, having invented nuclear weapons and then having used them, being the sole power—until those weapons were demonstrably developed by the Soviet Union—with the ability to not allow any further proliferation or further development of such programs.

We know that history after that, in the fifties and sixties, was dominated by the proliferation of nuclear weapons of mass destruction in the United States and the Soviet Union. We know that the key thing that stopped those weapons being used, particularly during the Cuban missile crisis in 1962, was the recognition that mutually assured destruction would inevitably follow their broad use if the Soviet Union or the United States attempted a first strike, either one against the other. We know also that at the time there were enormous fears that nuclear weapons would spread to the majority of countries in the world. In the intervening time they have spread to about 25 countries—roughly, because some countries will still not own up to it. South Africa, after Nelson Mandela took over as its President, admitted that it did have a nuclear weapons program and that it had pulled that weapons program to pieces. A number of other countries have admitted that they were in a similar position; but they have forsworn it.

We know that particular countries that are against the comprehensive test ban will not own up to the fact that they are nuclear armed and nuclear ready. We know that over time there has been a great deal of speculation about Israel: that Israel has its own weapons program and has developed those weapons fully. We are in no doubt about the great problem posed for the world by both India and Pakistan having developed such programs. Because of the inequality between those two countries, the fact that one or other side could use those weapons is of great significance.

We also know that earlier today bills were before the chamber dealing with two organisations and proscribing the military wings of those organisations as terrorist organisations. One of those organisations is operative in Kashmir and is party to the conflict between India and Pakistan. It would seek, through the vengeance and devastation that has been wrought so far, to set up an Islamic state in Pakistan and Kashmir. With the destruction that could be wrought by the programs already in place and the systems capable of delivering those programs, we also know fundamentally that the world is a very much more unsafe place than it was on 5 August 1945, despite the fact of having gone through two great world wars already and having reached the end of the 20th century.

We know that countries with weapons of mass destruction at their disposal are quite likely to use them, as the United States did. We also know that countries have had that temptation placed in front of them—as Australia had in the 1950s. From memory, the leading exponent in Australia was Sir Macfarlane Burnett, who argued strongly that Australia should establish its own nuclear weapons program. However, the government of the day eventually said no, that they would not be in that. We know that Maralinga in South Australia was used as a nuclear weapons testing area by the British government. We know that had a deleterious effect on the Aboriginal population of that area; they were long held out of their lands, and there is still potential trouble with their being affected.

We also know that in 1973 the nonproliferation treaty was pushed; in fact, the first bill in this regard was brought into being by the Whitlam government. We also know—it has not been mentioned by the other side, of course, but it has been mentioned by the shadow minister—that during the period 1983 to 1996, when Labor was in government under Prime Ministers Hawke and Keating, when the comprehensive test ban treaty was voted in 158-3, as was pointed out by the member for Fairfax, Labor had an unblemished record (1) of striving to increase the utility of the nonproliferation treaty, to expand the number of countries that signed up to it and to bring it more into effect and (2) of seeking year after year to bring in a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty.

In fact, in 1983, the first year we were in government, Australia and New Zealand cosponsored the first resolution regarding this treaty at the UN General Assembly—and it did not get up. But every alternate year after that, until we were finally successful in 1996, whilst we were in government we kept putting that forward. In doing so, we argued that it was not right or proper for the United States, the Soviet Union—in 1983 it still was the Soviet Union—China, India or Pakistan, any of the recognised nuclear states, to continue to test their weapons to the detriment of people world wide because of the negative health effects of those weapon testing programs. We were against the weapons testing that the French undertook in the South Pacific and we actively sought to try to bring that to an end. We indicated that we did not believe it was in the world's interest that more refined, more powerful and more deadly weapons of mass destruction should be developed.

Towards the end of our period in government, in November 1995, Prime Minister Keating moved to form the Canberra Commission on the Elimination of Nuclear Weapons. This was a group of eminent thinkers who were charged with developing ideas and proposals for a concrete and realistic program to achieve a world totally free of nuclear weapons. It recommended a phased program of reduction of nuclear weapons, with a series of safeguards to that program. Mr Deputy Speaker Barresi, you probably will not be surprised, but the Howard government did not support that initiative. In the period since 1996, it has done very little to push forward the cause of nonproliferation and has been almost inert with regard to these matters—except for the context provided post September 11, because the only context in which this coalition government wishes to look at these matters is the one of whether terrorist organisations such as those we sought to proscribe today, Jemaah Islamiah, al-Qaeda and other proscribed organisations, might somehow get access to these weapons.

The greater problem is the fact that the world is still in peril because of the existence of such weapons. The Soviet Union had a nuclear program for providing nuclear energy, and since its fall there has been a great peril to the world, not just because of what had happened in Chernobyl but because of the fact that a bankrupt Soviet Union did not have the capacity to fix the problems it had with its aged reactors. More importantly, the fall of the Soviet Union meant that fissionable material from its weapons program could be put up for sale to terrorist organisations, terrorist states or states that wished to gain that technology, and the materials could and would be provided either by individuals or by organisations in states that formed part of the Soviet Union, because desperation can lead to people being willing to do almost anything in order to provide for themselves. The world is much less safe because those problems are still there and apparent and have not been properly addressed.

What is also important in dealing with the effect of this bill is that Australia would be dramatically affected by a major nuclear conflict. However, most of the operations of this bill deal with something very clear and present, and that is the transport of waste materials coming from nuclear materials which have been developed at Lucas Heights in a peaceful way, largely for medical uses. This transportation is of great concern to the people in my electorate, because we are extremely close to Lucas Heights. There is an evident problem that has been there for many years, and it seems that no federal or state government, council or community group have been able to deal with the fact that we need an efficient mechanism for either reprocessing spent nuclear materials or moving them to a repository that is a long way away from the millions of people who live in Sydney.

Arguments have been put before the relevant Senate committee by a number of different groups about the fundamental right to democratic process, to have access and to be able to protest against the movement of these materials. The concerns they have put forward—that the government may be going too far with regard to people communicating, such as councils letting people know whether nuclear materials are being moved through their electorate—have been very volubly made. I have my own particular concerns, and one of those concerns is that we live in an age where there is a war on terror. We live in an age where there are Jemaah Islamiah and al-Qaeda operatives in Australia and where it is known and broadly put about what the route will be to transport those materials from one place to another. You cannot just expect that the ability to make a democratic protest about this, such as jumping all over the material that is being transported, should have a higher value than the significant possibility that, unless you do this transportation sensibly and in secret, terrorists could target those materials and we could have a nuclear event here—not an accident, but a perpetrated event—involving those materials. Even though the materials are of a low grade, the lives and safety of my constituents and others would be in peril as a result of it. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The Non-Proliferation Legislation Amendment Bill 2003 was introduced into this House by the government on 26 June. The Democrats then referred the bill to the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Legislation Committee, and that committee tabled its report on Thursday, 11 September, which sees us debating this legislation today. The purpose of this bill is to amend the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Act 1987 to strengthen Australia's arrangements for the security of nuclear material and related information and the Comprehensive Nuclear Test-Ban Treaty Act 1998 to enable Australia to apply legislation banning nuclear weapons tests ahead of the international entry into force of the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty. The bill is essentially in three sections. Schedule 1 has a domestic focus, and schedules 2 and 3 focus on more international and administrative aspects.

speech.para: There have been concerns raised on this side regarding particular sections of the legislation. Those concerns were also raised in the public hearings of the Senate committee. I would like to give details of the items of the bill which concern us. The items are described this way in the Bills Digest:

quote.para: Item 26 inserts proposed section 26A in the Safeguards Act making it an offence to `communicate information to someone else' which `could prejudice the physical security of nuclear material or an associated item'.

Item 21 inserts proposed section 25A in the Safeguards Act making it a criminal offence to breach a duty to ensure the physical security of information that could be used for nuclear weapons or other nuclear explosive devices. The Explanatory Memorandum notes that a duty to ensure the physical security of such information may arise `from the person's employment by the permit holder, or pursuant to a contract between them'. Proposed sub-section 25A(2) provides that an offence is committed if a person either performs an act or omits to perform an act resulting in a breach of a relevant duty. An `intention' to engage in the relevant conduct and `recklessness' as to the breach of duty are minimum re-quirements for the proposed offence by virtue of the Criminal Code Act 1995. The `recklessness' requirement means that the prosecution would need to establish that it was unjustifiable for a person to risk breaching such a duty.

Item 45 inserts proposed section 31A in the Safeguards Act making it an offence to enter into an area or to get `onto or into a vehicle, aircraft or ship' to which access is restricted in a permit issued under the Act. The area or vehicle must be clearly signposted to indicate that access is restricted. The offence is one of `strict liability', meaning the onus is on the person charged with the offence to establish an `honest and reasonable mistake of fact' to avoid prosecution.

speech.para: The shadow minister earlier today outlined the concerns that we have in relation to proposed sections 26A, 25A and 31A of the safeguards act. While doing this, he foreshadowed the possibility of amendments being moved in the Senate relating to and clarifying the tests on recklessness and the intent of action taken by protestors and for the communication of protest activity.
When the Senate inquiry held its public hearings, representatives of the Australian Conservation Foundation appeared before it and said:

quote.para: ... above all, we question sections like item 45, which creates an offence for unauthorised access to areas restricted under a permit that is issued under the provisions of the act. ... this offence applies to any area, vehicle, aircraft or ship. That is a very broad definition.

We believe that it is putting communities in fear not only of an industrial activity in the form of moving radioactive waste—an imposed industrial activity—but also in that they are not sure whether or not they can stand on or beside the road to protest.

We do not believe that is advancing the cause of a credible international nuclear safeguards regime. We must keep coming back to the name and the intent of this legislation. ACF looks at this and sees nonproliferation. We support moves towards an enhanced and effective international nonproliferation regime—but not one that can be used to cut down the legitimate and important democratic space to discuss matters of real public interest.

speech.para: Also appearing before that committee were representatives of Greenpeace Australia. They referred to the recent example—which has been referred to here—of the whistleblower talking about the construction errors with the new Lucas Heights reactor as:

quote.para: ... a very good way of highlighting those problems. If it were not for the fact that the whistleblower had the bravery to speak out ... it would appear there would have been a significant cover-up of those problems and that the reactor containment vessel would not have been built to the highest possible standard.

speech.para: They went on to say:

quote.para: The penalties in these provisions—two years jail, for instance—would provide a massive disincentive to a whistleblower or, in fact, any organisation revealing details of nuclear activities that they believed the public had a right to know about. But I do not believe that they are going to provide a real disincentive to a terrorist organisation with ulterior motives or more sinister objectives.

speech.para: They are just two major and respected organisations within our community that appeared before the Senate inquiry to express their concerns about these sections of this legislation. These will be the types of areas on which we may move amendments in the Senate, which we would be asking the government to support in order to clarify these issues. Surely it is not the intent of the government to suppress legitimate protest activities by Australian citizens who legitimately want to make a statement or get a message across in relation to any kind of movement of nuclear material by road, water or rail across this country. Such people run the risk of being penalised and prosecuted for conveying information—whether it be through the Net or through print media—to other people who may be interested. I understand that the media outlets in this country also have a concern about whether or not they could be prosecuted under this legislation, as it stands, for being a vehicle for the conveyance of such information.
These concerns were also raised in the dissenting report by Labor senators which was tabled on 11 September this year. In the dissenting report the Labor senators said that they:

quote.para: ... have serious reservations about the provisions in this Bill which purport to limit the right to protest, and which affect potential whistleblowers. The wording of these offences and the penalties provided do not appear to allow for any consideration of the intentions of protestors and whistleblowers. There is a fine balance to be struck between provisions which legitimately enhance security and provisions which impose unduly on citizens' legitimate rights to protest. Labor senators are also concerned about the increasing tendency to delegate police powers to non-police personnel.

speech.para: Just to put it on the record, those dissenting Labor senators were Senator Peter Cook from Western Australia, Senator Chris Evans from Western Australia and Senator Gavin Marshall from Victoria.

Just over a week ago, we gathered in this chamber to listen to the addresses of President Bush and President Hu Jintao. As we are talking about nuclear proliferation, I would like to quote a couple of sentences from President Bush's speech. He said:

quote.para: Our nations must also confront the immediate threat of proliferation.
We are working together to convince North Korea that the continued pursuit of nuclear weapons will bring only further isolation. The wrong weapons, the wrong technology in the wrong hands ...

speech.para: They are good and honourable aims for any nation. However, I cannot let the opportunity pass in this debate to point out that, while President Bush was in this parliament talking about the nuclear aims of countries like North Korea, in his own backyard he has 10,000 nuclear warheads that belong to America. That is a third of the nuclear warheads that exist around the globe; America has 10,000 of them. To add more value to his words, I would call upon the American President to do his best to destroy the nuclear warheads America has at the moment and to make good his aims to have a world where we are free of any threat of nuclear activity and the threat of the nuclear destruction of any of our countries. As I said, there are 30,000 nuclear warheads around the world and America has one-third of them.

I am a member of the Parliamentary Network for Nuclear Disarmament. This is a nonpartisan forum for parliamentarians nationally and internationally. We share resources and information, develop cooperative strategies and engage in nuclear disarmament issues. The risks of nuclear proliferation are increasing daily. Countries like India, Pakistan and Israel refuse to join the nonproliferation treaty. Instead, they are developing their own nuclear weapons. North Korea recently announced its withdrawal from the nonproliferation treaty and is likely to be developing nuclear weapons. Other countries, like Iran and Saudi Arabia, could follow suit. Meanwhile the existing nuclear weapons states are reneging on their obligations to pursue nuclear disarmament. Some of them are developing new nuclear weapons and expanding their nuclear doctrine.

The recent war against Iraq to enforce Iraq's disarmament obligations shows how nuclear proliferation stimulates conflicts into war and destabilises whole regions. Progress on nuclear disarmament is vital in order to prevent conflicts escalating to war and to prevent a nuclear catastrophe. I would like to refer to a media release put out in Australia by the Medical Association for Prevention of War on 3 October, the anniversary of the first United Kingdom nuclear test conducted on the Montebello Islands, which are Australian territory, 51 years ago. In it they say:

quote.para: Yet, half a century later and after knowing about the horrors of nuclear explosions from Hiroshima and Nagasaki, the detrimental health effects of nuclear testing, and the people's fear that a nuclear explosion will happen again, why do we still have 30 000 nuclear weapons?

speech.para: They went on to say:

quote.para: Yet the US is seeking to develop more nuclear weapons. Iraq has had and Nth Korea has designs for nuclear weapons programs and China, France, India, Israel, Pakistan, Russia and the UK maintain nuclear stockpiles and weapons at the ready. Why? Ready for what?

speech.para: In conclusion, Mr Deputy Speaker, I would like to pose some questions and give you the answers. A question that needs to be asked is: how many tonnes of depleted uranium were left in Iraq and Kuwait after the Gulf War? The answer to that is 40 tonnes. How many countries are known to have nuclear weapons? The answer to that is eight. How many nuclear warheads has the US got? It has over 10,000. Which is the only country to use nuclear weapons? The answer to that is the US. I agree with the Medical Association for Prevention of War: when we are talking about nuclear weapons, why do we have them and what are they ready for?

talk.start.para: —I welcome the opportunity to speak on the Non-Proliferation Legislation Amendment Bill 2003. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs told us, in her second reading speech, that the bill strengthens Australia's efforts to prevent the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. This is a noble aim which we all support—there is no question about that. The bill does this by amending the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Act 1997, the Comprehensive Nuclear Test-Ban Treaty Act 1998 and the Chemical Weapons (Prohibition) Act 1994. However, the actual bill before us goes beyond the aforementioned noble aim and, as a result, the Greens have serious concerns about it. These concerns fall into three broad categories: firstly, the linkage within the bill of domestic and international issues, when such a linkage is inappropriate and unnecessary; secondly, the failure to distinguish between the actions of terrorists and the right of ordinary Australians to protest; and, thirdly, the hasty passage of the legislation through the parliament without detailed discussion and debate.

speech.para: The Non-Proliferation Legislation Amendment Bill 2003 has been presented by the government as an opportunity to strengthen Australia's commitment to the comprehensive test ban treaty and to the prevention of the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. Schedules 2 and 3 of the bill serve to tighten up some administrative processes with regard to Australia's international commitments under the comprehensive test ban treaty and bring the language in the act in line with the language used in that treaty. However, the primary domestic provisions under schedule 1 present a number of significant concerns with regard to a lack of transparency in the nuclear industry in Australia, especially in relation to waste transport, and the construction and operation of the nuclear reactor at Lucas Heights, located some 50 kilometres north-west of my own electorate of Cunningham.

Furthermore, amendments that create offences in relation to communications about the physical security of nuclear material or associated items are broad ranging and do not discriminate between real and perceived threat and there is no requirement for there to be any intent to prejudice the physical security of the items or activities disclosed. While the bill purports the strength in Australia's efforts to prevent proliferation, provisions under section 1 will not only inhibit public access to information relating to the nuclear industry; they could facilitate Australia's ongoing sponsorship of nuclear activities that undermine commitments to nonproliferation.

This bill is government doublespeak. It promises to increase security but will in fact do the opposite. The insertion of section 25A creates a new offence for `breach of duty to ensure the security of associated technology', making it a criminal offence to fail to ensure the physical security of documents containing information set out in subsections (a) and (b) of the definition of `associated technology'. The offence specifically refers to people who are authorised to possess associated technology and the provision also includes a penalty of two years imprisonment for an offence. This amendment is explicitly about the leaking or other failure to ensure the physical security of documents and/or information.

The inclusion of this new offence will significantly impact on the release of information that may be of interest to the public. It will also inhibit potential whistleblowers who may determine that they have information that is pertinent to the public good. We heard, for example, revelations earlier this year about significant construction errors that had occurred at the new nuclear reactor at Lucas Heights. They were made public by a whistleblower who released the information to a journalist. Given the fundamental nature of the construction errors in that case—that is, holes in the main tank were drilled in the wrong place—there could well have been issues of public safety involved. That the information only reached the public domain through the mechanism of a whistleblower not only reflects poorly on the public accountability of the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation, ANSTO, and the veracity of the regulator, the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency, ARPANSA, but also reinforces the role that those working closely with the issues can contribute to public debate. The inclusion of this new offence will serve to deter those who may well have legitimate grievances that impact on the public interest. The legislation should include protection for people and of disclosures that relate to acts or emissions causing serious risk to public health, safety or the environment.

The insertion of section 26A creates an offence for unauthorised communication that may prejudice the physical security of nuclear material or an associated item, which, according to the definition section of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Act 1987, includes a very broad range of items. This provision has the potential to have a significant impact on the public's right to know with regard to nuclear activities in Australia and will prevent information being released in the public interest. Activities such as alerting communities to the timing of radioactive waste transports and disseminating maps of transport routes could be made illegal under this section.

The federal government should provide more information than it currently does to ensure that emergency services at the state and local government levels can effectively develop contingency plans to deal with the consequences of a radiological incident. Information, such as the consequences analysis of an accident at the Lucas Heights reactor, is critical to emergency planning. This document has been kept out of the public realm, seriously affecting the ability of the Sutherland Shire Council to develop emergency planning activities. In my own electorate of Cunningham, people would very much like to know what is in the consequences analysis because any fallout of radiation could reach the Illawarra. Not only would information about the movement of nuclear waste not be made publicly available but the provision could also extend to such legitimate actions as, for example, publishing photos in an attempt to highlight the inadequacy of spent fuel storage at Lucas Heights.

Provisions under section 26A are so broadly drafted that there is no requirement for there to be any intent on the part of the person communicating the information to prejudice the physical security of the nuclear material or associated item. Nor does the communication of the information have to prejudice the safety or the physical security of the nuclear material or associated item for a person to be under threat of criminal charge. The only requirement is that it could prejudice the physical security.

Finally, there is no overriding requirement that the information be information that is not already available to the public or a section of the public, although that requirement does apply to some of the items covered by the offence—namely, associated technology. Potentially this could capture communications that do not reveal any further information to the public but are not considered under the definition of `associated technology'.

Both sections 25A and 26A add new offences that apply not only to the NNP(S) Act but also to the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Act 1988 under section 82(1), which states `an inspector is not excused from complying with sections 25A, 26 and 26A'. This provision is concerning as there already exists a lack of transparency to governments and bureaucracies at all levels with regard to information relating to the activities of the nuclear industry in this country. Australians are asking: `Why all the secrecy?'

There are serious concerns about the apparent lack of independence of ARPANSA and its ability to carry out its role as a vigorous regulator. A requirement for ARPANSA to comply with these sections will substantially restrict the information flow to other public agencies and result in a more secretive culture around the management of information. This could potentially result in poor regulatory outcomes and a lack of public accountability of the regulator.

The inclusion of sections 25A and 26A threaten to burden communication about government and political matters with regard to the nuclear debate in Australia. While these amendments are being proposed with a raft of other amendments that appear to be fulfilling legitimate international objectives under the comprehensive test ban treaty, sections 25A and 26A do not fulfil a legitimate or justifiable domestic policy objective, but their effect will be to stifle public debate.

The government has outlined that the amendments affecting domestic arrangements will `strengthen Australia's arrangements for the protection of nuclear facilities, material and related information'. However, it is questionable that such broad requirements will in fact necessarily do anything to achieve this objective. For example, the potential threat to Australia from a terrorist attack would not necessarily be mitigated by preventing information about the construction or operation of the reactor at Lucas Heights. In fact, the most effective way to mitigate terrorist risk is to not have a nuclear reactor in a major metropolitan area at all. However, the measures imposed by sections 25A and 26A may well serve to undermine public and environmental safety, as public scrutiny and accountability will be compromised.

The proposed amendments have been highlighted by the government as evidence of its commitment to nonproliferation. However, the reality is that, while the government is strident in its criticisms of Iraq, Iran and North Korea, it stands silently by while its ally the United States undermines international nuclear nonproliferation treaties. As the member for Charlton has just pointed out, during his recent visit to this country US President Bush spoke of the threat of the proliferation of nuclear weapons. Yet the United States refuses to meet its obligations under the nuclear nonproliferation treaty to dismantle all nuclear weapons and makes definite moves towards the development and manufacture of a new generation of nuclear weapons. The United States refuses to ratify the comprehensive test ban treaty, creating the fear that a resumption of nuclear weapons testing by that country is imminent and that a new nuclear arms race is about to begin. With 10,000 nuclear warheads in the US—a third of the world's total—that fear is very real.

Under the proposed legislation, long-held questions relating to uranium exports, national interest implications of the defence treaty that Australia has with the United States—making Australia a nuclear weapons state by proxy—and questions over Australia's nuclear cooperation with countries in the region—North Korea, for example—may all be beyond investigation. The level of secrecy surrounding the operations of ANSTO—a civil organisation which has been actively promoted in the public realm as playing a vital role in public health through the provision of radioisotopes—is alarming. Officials have claimed that it is essential for Australia to have its own cadre of national nuclear scientists on which the federal government can rely for nuclear expertise. Should such expertise also be taken to mean that Australia would have its own independent nuclear weapons capability? Such a question may never be answered, or even debated, without risk of penalty under the amendments proposed, and that is shameful.

The bill has been the subject of an inquiry by the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Legislation Committee, and one of my colleagues in the other place, Senator Kerry Nettle, in dissenting from the main report made a number of important points that are germane to this debate. The Australian Greens welcome the provisions that ensure that a ban on nuclear testing in Australia will be given effect prior to the entry into force of the comprehensive test ban treaty. However, there are significant flaws with the provisions of the bill that deal with domestic matters. The Assistant Secretary of the Australian Safeguards and Non-proliferation Office in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade told the Senate inquiry that there was no policy reason for linking domestic and international issues in this legislation.

talk.start.para: —You don't like being interrupted in your speech, do you?
(Hon. B.C. Scott)—Order!

—Far be it from me to ask that the minister be removed from the House! The Greens object to the government tying widely supported measures to implement the comprehensive test ban treaty in Australian law with security measures that have serious implications for civil liberties. This is a political tactic that the government is increasingly employing with matters relating to terrorism. This undermines the parliament's ability to legislate widely supported measures by linking them to excessive security measures that fail to guarantee proper protection for citizens' rights.

speech.para: This legislation seeks to deal with the current climate of increased proliferation uncertainty. The Greens support the view of the Australian Conservation Foundation that the best ways to address this uncertainty are to reduce the amount of fissile material that is in circulation and to use the full range of our international influence to support active nonproliferation measures. As evidenced by the public debate around the ASIO legislation, it is extremely difficult to draft legislation that deals with security concerns without curtailing civil liberties. This government finds it so difficult that it does not even bother and, as a result, we see a further erosion of our civil rights.

The same is true of this legislation. As already noted, item 26 of schedule 1 creates an offence if a person communicates information that could prejudice the physical security of nuclear material. This item contains no requirement for an intention on the part of the person actually communicating the information to prejudice the physical security of the nuclear material or associated item. As this provision is currently drafted, the communication does not actually have to prejudice safety or physical security; it is sufficient if it could prejudice the safety or physical security of the nuclear material or associated item, as noted in the Greenpeace submission. Without any reference in this item to an intention to prejudice the physical security of the nuclear material in this offence, the offence clearly captures those communicating information about nuclear material or transportation of nuclear material for the public interest.

The government has provided no justification for why this legislation is being rushed through the parliament. An inquiry into this legislation allowed just two weeks for public input and two hours for a public hearing. Having regard to the lengthy debate on the ASIO legislation dealing with security concerns and civil liberties, I note that it is appropriate that more public consultation should occur on these particular provisions of this bill. Such consultation would allow the issues raised in the public hearing to be appropriately addressed. In summary, the bill is fundamentally against the interests of Australia's people and the environment and in its current form must be opposed.

talk.start.para: —The purpose of the Non-Proliferation Legislation Amendment Bill 2003 is twofold. Firstly, it will amend the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Act to strengthen Australia's arrangements for the security of nuclear material and related information. Secondly, it will enable Australia to apply the Comprehensive Nuclear Test-Ban Treaty Act 1998 banning nuclear weapon tests ahead of entry into force internationally of the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty.

speech.para: Most speakers have given a great deal of attention to the first purpose of the legislation, that of the provisions strengthening Australia's arrangements for security of materials and information. The principal issues that have been under consideration there relate to the impact of the provisions on currently legal protest activities against nuclear facilities and also to the impact of the provisions on whistleblowers in relation to nuclear facilities. In the time available to me I do not wish to talk a great deal about the first purpose of the bill. I want to focus more on the second and talk about issues in relation to the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction—particularly nuclear materials. I think all members of the House would agree that issues in relation to weapons of mass destruction proliferation are probably among the most pressing issues on the global security agenda presently. It was, after all, the principal rationale to justify the recent war with Iraq—and we are aware that that particular threat has not been substantiated to date. Nonetheless, there are significant consequences continuing to flow from that conflict. The justification used in this country and elsewhere for involvement in that war was very heavily focused on the threat of weapons of mass destruction.

Closer to home, the issue of weapons of mass destruction is the central issue in the North Asian security environment at the moment, particularly given the intention of North Korea to repudiate the non-proliferation treaty and the potentially catastrophic consequences that could flow from such action. I give those two illustrations to reinforce the centrality of weapons of mass destruction issues to global security concerns presently.

The Economist magazine on 18 October produced an article by Mohamed ElBaradei, the Director-General of the International Atomic Energy Agency, based in Vienna. I want to quote quite extensively from Dr ElBaradei's article in that magazine, to illustrate the complexities of some of the issues that face the global community. ElBaradei says at the start of his article:

quote.para: The very existence of nuclear weapons gives rise to the pursuit of them. They are seen as a source of global influence, and are valued for their perceived deterrent effect. And as long as some countries possess them ... and others do not, this asymmetry breeds chronic global insecurity.

The present nuclear-arms-control regime is looking battered. But any reform of that regime must begin by conceiving a framework of collective security that does not rely on nuclear deterrence. The rise of terrorist groups makes this essential. A nuclear deterrent is clearly ineffective against such groups; they have no cities that can be bombed in reply, nor are they focused on self-preservation. Moreover, their constantly shifting targets and modes of attack demand a more co-operative and flexible international response. The “war on terror” should provide an impetus to work towards a global security culture that will serve the interests of all countries equally, and will make reliance on nuclear weapons obsolete.

speech.para: In this article, Dr ElBaradei goes through in considerable detail—far more detail than I intend to reproduce today—the problems that exist within the international nuclear weapons control framework. He makes the point that countries such as India, Pakistan and presumably Israel have raised the number of nuclear armed states to at least eight by using a significant loophole: the treaty relied on the premise that the signatories would use nuclear material for peaceful purposes only. He says:

quote.para: In fact, however, they—

speech.para: that is, countries that may well be signatories to the nonproliferation treaty—

quote.para: have been able to operate very close to a nuclear-weapons capability.

speech.para: He also makes the point that the five major nuclear weapon states—excluding India, Pakistan and Israel:

quote.para: ... agreed to move towards full disarmament - a commitment renewed “unequivocally” by all five states as recently as 2000 - although without a timetable.

speech.para: Despite that commitment, not a great deal of progress has been made in recent years. There are still some 30,000 nuclear warheads in existence. The Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty, which is seen by some in the debate—and I agree—as having the potential, were it implemented, to be the jewel in the crown, was concluded in 1996. It has now been open for some seven years, but it still languishes unimplemented.

In the context of the current arrangements, there are obviously very significant problems in terms of compliance: the loophole that enables non-signatories to proceed nonetheless to acquire nuclear capacity and the failure to date to get significant disarmament measures from the declared nuclear powers, despite their commitments to disarm within the framework of non-proliferation. ElBaradei also talks in his article about emerging issues. He says:

quote.para: But controlling access to nuclear-weapons technology has grown increasingly difficult. The technical barriers to designing weapons and to mastering the processing steps have eroded with time. Much of the hardware in question is “dual-use”; for example, it is hard to justify restrictions on exporting “hot cell” technology that could be used for plutonium separation when the same equipment is vital for producing radioisotopes used in modern medicine.

speech.para: He also talks in his article about the changing economic and political circumstances in many parts of the world. The former Soviet Union is a good example of this, with significant numbers of people with nuclear scientific qualifications, experience and knowledge which these days is on the world market.
He also talks about the sheer diversity of technology. He says:

quote.para: ... the sheer diversity of technology has made it harder to control both procurement and sales.

speech.para: He continues by saying:

quote.para: Under the current regime ... there is nothing illicit in a non-nuclear-weapon state having enrichment or reprocessing technology, or possessing weapon-grade nuclear material. And certain types of bomb-making expertise, unfortunately, are readily available in the open literature. Should a state with a fully developed fuel-cycle capability decide, for whatever reason, to break away from its non-proliferation commitments, most experts believe it could produce a nuclear weapon within a matter of months.

speech.para: He estimates that at present some 35 to 40 countries globally have some capacity to move very rapidly to meet that sort of timetable. ElBaradei proposes, I think very constructively, the need for a new framework within the global security environment, to address the issues of, on the one hand, the increasing complexity of nuclear weapons technology and, on the other, the increasing capacity of states to make use of it in various ways. His first proposal is:

quote.para: ... time to limit the processing of weapon-usable material (separated plutonium and high-enriched uranium) in civilian nuclear programmes, as well as the production of new material through reprocessing and enrichment, by agreeing to restrict these operations exclusively to facilities under multinational control.

speech.para: I think that is a very interesting proposal and a very important one indeed. His second proposal is:

quote.para: ... nuclear-energy systems should be deployed that, by design, avoid the use of materials that may be applied directly to making nuclear weapons. These systems should have built-in features that would prevent countries diverting material to weapons production; prevent the misuse of the facilities and equipment for clandestine manufacture of such materials; and facilitate efficient oversight to ensure continued peaceful use.

speech.para: He goes on to say:

quote.para: This is not a futuristic dream; much of the technology for proliferation-resistant nuclear-energy systems has already been developed or is actively being researched.

speech.para: There are some quite constructive proposals there, I think.

In discussing a new framework, ElBaradei also makes reference to the fact that the Fissile Material Cut-off Treaty, which some 10 years ago was the subject of a United Nations resolution, has not yet been proceeded with. He is obviously an enthusiastic supporter of progress being made to put such a cap on fissile materials globally. He also makes the suggestion, which is certainly one that is worth considering in my view, that the new framework should be regarded as:

quote.para: ... a `peremptory norm' of international law—not vulnerable to any nation subsequently withdrawing, based on the whim of a new government or a vote of the latest parliament.

speech.para: I think those proposals from the Director-General of the International Atomic Energy Agency are quite radical but, given the centrality of the problems of weapons of mass destruction in the global community and the global security environment, they are well worth considering and well worth considerable discussion within international forums.

In the past Australia has had a proud record, punching well above its weight in international forums on nuclear arms issues. I refer, for example, to the work of the Canberra Commission on the Elimination of Nuclear Weapons and the important lead it provided to the setting of an agenda in relation to the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and initiatives to get them under control. I also refer to Australia's leadership in the process that led to the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty, which is regrettably still languishing and not in effect. It is against that background that I want to express disappointment that the present Australian government is certainly not actively pursuing an agenda in this context in international circles.

I have had drawn to my attention recently initiatives that have arisen from a number of foreign ministers, including those of Ireland, New Zealand, Sweden and Brazil, as well as others. These foreign ministers call themselves the New Agenda Coalition and they are setting a new agenda. Over several years now this New Agenda Coalition has put forward resolutions to the United Nations, and I believe some may have just been debated—or be just about to be debated—by the United Nations General Assembly. These resolutions set forward some very important principles that Australia ought to be supporting. For example, the present declaration of the ministers of the New Agenda Coalition says, among other things:

quote.para: The ministers expressed their deep concern at the lack of progress to date in the implementation of the thirteen steps on nuclear disarmament to which all States parties to the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons agreed at the 2000 NPT Review Conference.

speech.para: That was the matter I referred to somewhat earlier in my remarks. The declaration also says:

quote.para: The Ministers recalled that a fundamental pre-requisite for promoting nuclear non-proliferation is the continuous irreversible progress in nuclear arms reduction. In this context, they called upon the Russian Federation and the United States of America to make the Treaty on Strategic Offensive Reductions (`the Moscow Treaty') irreversible and verifiable and to address non-operational warheads, thus making a nuclear disarmament measure.

speech.para: The declaration further says:

quote.para: The Ministers stressed that the recent international debate on weapons of mass destruction has only highlighted that the sole guarantee against the use of any weapon of mass destruction anywhere, including nuclear weapons, is their total elimination and the assurance that they will never be used or produced again.

speech.para: The ministers call upon the international community to:

quote.para: ... intensify efforts to achieve universal adherence to the NPT.

speech.para: They call on India, Israel and Pakistan to accede to the treaty. They refer to North Korea and say:

quote.para: The Ministers expressed their deep concern with the announcement by the Democratic People's Republic of Korea of its intention to withdraw from the NPT and related developments.

speech.para: What is extremely regrettable is that Australia abstained from those resolutions on the previous two occasions that they were put forward, I believe, and is likely to abstain again—if, in fact, we have not already done so.

The vote in the United Nations General Assembly in 2002 was yes for the motion along the lines set out in the foreign ministers' declaration, No. 125, with six noes and 32 abstentions, including Australia. Frankly, that is extraordinarily disappointing, because in the past Australia, as I said, has had a distinguished record as a leader in relation to setting the international agenda—the Canberra Commission and the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty. This government talks a lot about the threat—and it is a real threat—of the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, yet when it had an opportunity to join in the United Nations in multinational forums, in relation to taking the agenda forward and setting a new agenda along the lines of what the Director-General of the International Atomic Energy Agency, Mohamed El Baradei, has suggested, it wimped out and abstained. Frankly, that is not in the tradition that this country has established in its international conduct, and in the context of this debate I urge the government to reconsider and to assume a leadership role on these important issues.

talk.start.para: —I rise today to speak on the Non-Proliferation Legislation Amendment Bill 2003, because of my long-term involvement in the peace movement and my great interest in ridding the world of nuclear weapons whatever their shape or form. As has been pointed out, the purpose of this bill is to amend the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Act 1987, to strengthen Australia's arrangements for the security of nuclear material and related information, and to amend the Comprehensive Nuclear Test-Ban Treaty Act 1998, to enable Australia to apply legislation banning nuclear weapons tests ahead of the entry into force internationally of the Comprehensive Nuclear Test-Ban Treaty.The bill is in three sections. Schedule 1 has a domestic focus and schedules 2 and 3 focus more on international and administrative aspects.

speech.para: In speaking on this bill, I would also like to bring into this House the concerns of the people of Stirling and some of the groups that have contacted my office, who would also like to see the world rid of nuclear weapons. I might add that I have no problem with the use of nuclear reaction for purposes such as science, research and medicine, which are the main focus of the Lucas Heights reactor in Sydney. I am not so happy about other aspects of nuclear usage, but that is not the subject of this speech.

I would like to draw to the attention of the House the location of the nuclear stockpiles in the world. This is a list I have received from a very credible source: the Medical Association for Prevention of War, Australia. Their list shows that the total number of warheads held by the US is 10,500; the total number held by Russia is 20,000; the total number held by China is 400; the total number held by France is 348; the total number held by the UK is 185; the total number held by Israel is 150; the total number held by India is 80; and the total number held by Pakistan is 20. That makes the total number of warheads in the world 31,700. The number of weapons on alert is 4,600. This is of great concern because, as the photo I am holding displays, a 12.5 kiloton bomb razed Hiroshima in August 1945 and many of today's nuclear weapons have hundreds of kilotons—or more—of destructive capacity. It is obvious, just on a simple mathematical basis, that the total number of warheads in the world could destroy the whole world. So it is an issue of great importance, and in dealing with this issue we cannot get away from what Australia's role is in helping to reduce the number of nuclear weapons or to provide strategies for phasing them out altogether. To ensure that the members of the House who are not here understand the full impact of the destructiveness of nuclear weapons, I would like to table this photo, with the leave of the Clerk.

talk.start.para: (Hon. B.C. Scott)—Is leave granted?
—Not by the Clerk.
—By leave of the government.
—Minister Hockey, have you sighted the material?
—Yes, I have.

—Thank you. I will table this photo, because I think it is so important that we understand in a human way the destructiveness of these weapons. In talking about this, I would also like to draw to the attention of the House the fact that the bill basically has support but that there are some elements that have raised concerns in me, my colleagues and many people out there in the community. These concerns are mainly focused around section 26A.

speech.para: We all support whistleblower legislation, so why is this section a concern? It is a concern because the focus of the proposed section 26A of the safeguards act, which makes it a criminal offence to communicate information which `could prejudice the physical security of nuclear material or an associated item' seems very broad. The concern of the community, my colleagues and the groups who have come to me is that this is too broad; it is not specific enough. The concern is that this is an attempt by the government to obtain the power to stop protests at places like Lucas Heights or other places people may gather where nuclear waste material may be in transit—that is, the natural points where protests happen. The community are extremely concerned about what they see as the looseness in this section and the far-reaching nature of it.

They are also concerned about the proposed section 31A of the safeguards act, which would make it an offence to enter without authorisation an area to which access is restricted under the act. Even though this section of the act says the area must be clearly signposted to indicate that access is restricted, the offence is one of strict liability, meaning that the onus is on the person charged with the offence to establish an honest and reasonable mistake of fact to avoid prosecution. As I said, some of my local groups are concerned about this section, and I am too.

But we have all agreed on one thing in relation to this bill, and that is that in dealing with the safeguards and the transport of nuclear material we need to step back and look holistically at what is happening in the world. The thing is, if this parliament is honest and positive about reducing nuclear weapons or even stopping the proliferation of them, we need to be taking more active steps. A number of governments now believe that the abolition of all nuclear weapons is one of the most urgent security issues facing the international community. In line with this, the New Agenda Coalition of seven nations—Brazil, Egypt, Ireland, Mexico, New Zealand, South Africa and Sweden—is now working for the elimination of nuclear weapons. Since 1998 the New Agenda Coalition has been working towards a program that would achieve nuclear disarmament. I am very saddened that Australia is not a member of the New Agenda Coalition and has failed to support recent attempts in the international arena to get up motions that would ensure more active work was done to phase out the weapons and the stockpile.

An email I received from the Medical Association for Prevention of War outlines a little bit of the history of the recent vote before the United Nations disarmament committee 2003 on the New Agenda Coalition resolutions L.39 and L.40. On the resolution about the reduction of non-strategic weapons, debated on 15 October 2003, Australia abstained from the vote. In the first committee, 118 countries said yes, four said no and 41 abstained. Sadly, Australia was one of those abstainers.
