Again on 15 October 2003 on the motion `Towards a nuclear-free world: a new agenda', which has a very long text, in the first committee 117 countries voted yes and six voted no, which included Australia. Again, in the voting results in the first committee of the whole, the countries that voted yes numbered 121 and Australia abstained.

If we are going to progress this work at all, if we are going to move towards having a world that is safe and free of these weapons then Australia needs to be more up front in taking action. I understand that Australia is part of another grouping, called the Australian grouping, that has been meeting with other European countries to progress some of this work. But where it really is all happening is in the United Nations. Our attempts there have not been appreciated by many community groups and have shown that Australia is not really putting its energy into getting some real strategies going.

The new agenda came about because of the unhappiness of many of the countries that the agreement between United States President Bush and Russian President Putin, the Moscow treaty of May 2002, had major flaws. The concern in many of the countries is that the idea that they would reduce the number of nuclear weapons on each side to between 1,700 and 2,200 by the year 2012 is not really happening. Both sides will retain many weapons on hair-trigger alert. Both sides may take these weapons off active deployment, but the concern is that they will just be stored and brought out later. The treaty deals only with strategic weapons. It does not seek to reduce the number of tactical or short-range weapons. The retention of thousands of nuclear weapons by two nations is unacceptable. It is a long time to wait until 2012.

In this parliament on many an occasion when we have wanted to progress something such as settling events in East Timor and have some progression in the development of a democracy there, many nations have got together, talked it through and come up with some strategies as well as the money and necessary policy, in this case to ensure that East Timor moved to being a democratic country. Why is it that we can do some wonderful projects in other countries and between countries, do wonderful projects with countries in our region, yet when it comes to the whole issue of the elimination of nuclear weapons, it seems to be a case of very little goodwill on many countries' part, including Australia's, to actually make it happen?

I will read briefly from a media release I received from Greenpeace in Canberra. They say that they have deep and serious concerns about this legislation. They appreciate the strength of it and the good things it intends to do. Particularly after it went to a Senate inquiry, their concern is:

quote.para: ... the legislation creates legal confusion over emergency planning and has not been properly aired publicly.

speech.para: They are also concerned that the public is not really aware of this bill and what is happening with it. They say:

quote.para: The Non-Proliferation Legislation Amendment Bill 2003 brings in anti-terrorism style penalties for communicating information about Lucas Heights, nuclear waste dumps and nuclear transport.
Greenpeace and other environmental groups had only 8 days to prepare their submission to the Senate inquiry.

speech.para: In support of the groups and the concerns of constituents, I draw the attention of the House to these flaws in the bill and to the concerns of the community, particularly with regard to the whistleblower aspects, the protests and the safeguards act, and ask that the House ensure that amendments that will clarify and improve these sections of the bill are accepted. I also ask that you ensure that the House and the government do take action and that we take a more up-front, active role in the United Nations and support motions and strategies that will ensure the elimination of nuclear weapons in the world.

talk.start.para: —The Non-Proliferation Legislation Amendment Bill 2003 raises issues that have considerable impact on and are of great significance to both this country and the global community in general. The use of nuclear technology in the development of weapons of mass destruction has been the subject of contention and controversy since the emergence of the arms race during the Cold War. For over half a century the world community has tried to deal with the collective threat posed to it by the development of nuclear weapons. Their development and potential use is arguably the single most deadly threat to the survival of the human race, and attempts to limit and then ultimately abolish their capacity have too often met with resistance from some of the major stakeholders in the nuclear weapons industry. Nevertheless, such efforts remain paramount and it is important that this parliament takes note of its responsibility to contribute to a nuclear-free world by ensuring that all measures are taken to limit the proliferation of nuclear weapons.

speech.para: The purpose of the bill before us is not so much to limit the proliferation of nuclear weapons but rather to strengthen the existing measures for the protection and safeguards relating to nuclear material and its transportation, information and facilities. The bill also provides for legislation that bans the testing of nuclear weapons prior to entry into force of the comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty. It also allows for some changes to the application of nonproliferation measures. It is a widely held view and hope that the further strengthening of the nonproliferation regime will prevent nuclear materials, fissile material and technologies falling into the hands of criminals and terrorists and as such protect the global community from any unforeseen catastrophes. Overall, Labor therefore supports the government's initiatives as defined in this bill.

The bill proposes amendments to three separate pieces of legislation. It seeks to amend the Nuclear Non-proliferation (Safeguards) Act 1987, the Comprehensive Nuclear Test-Ban Treaty Act 1998 and the Chemical Weapons (Prohibition) Act 1994. However, in doing this, the government through this bill has tried to link issues which have no apparent clear linkage. This is of concern not only to Labor but also to community activists and other non-government parties, because it does not give due and separate credence to each of these very important areas.

In fact, Mr Andrew Leask, who is the Assistant Secretary of the Australian Safeguards and Non-proliferation Office, noted in evidence to the Senate inquiry into the bill that the linking of these issues was a matter of convenience for the government rather than policy. In response to a question he noted:

quote.para: I think in one sense the answer to your question is that there is no great linkage. There is no linkage that has to be there, but we have done it by virtue of the mechanical processes ...

speech.para: This bill was introduced in June 2003. Subsequently its provisions were referred by the Senate for examination, with a report due by 11 September 2003. This is a regrettable date given that we need no reminder that this is the anniversary of the worst terrorist attack on American soil. In many ways those terrible actions have influenced considerations in drafting this bill and its provisions. Although the Australian Strategic Policy Institute makes the point that the risk of terrorists obtaining nuclear weapons has not increased considerably since 9-11, the international community's emphasis on ameliorating these risks has increased. There is no doubt that the Australian public has become more concerned about the increase of a nuclear weapons threat.

In proposing measures in the bill, Mr Leask raised concerns about the protection of nuclear material and facilities and the possibility of theft and sabotage of these facilities or materials by would-be terrorists. However, public debate following the second reading of the bill raised concern about the bill's impact on people's democratic rights to demonstrate their opposition to nuclear weapons. In fact one of the roles of the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Legislation Committee was to investigate the impact of parts of the bill on what are now legally valid protests against nuclear facilities and on whistleblowers with regard to nuclear facilities and the provision of information.

In submissions to the Senate committee, community activist groups, such as Greenpeace, Friends of the Earth, the Australian Conservation Foundation and the Anti-Nuclear Alliance of Western Australia, all noted their concern regarding the possible restrictions to civil liberties inherent in the bill and raised concerns that passing the bill in its current form would curtail legitimate grievances and public interest concerns. The Anti-Nuclear Alliance of Western Australia in its submission stated:

quote.para: ... as long as the nuclear industry exists in Australia, a sizable proportion of the community will oppose its operations. On occasion this opposition will be expressed as direct action undertaken to highlight the threats posed by the technology and its waste products.

Nowhere in these documents is it stated that the bill is intended to provide authorities with powers to crack down on protest activities or the actions of whistleblowers, and yet the bill quite clearly establishes these powers.

speech.para: These points of concern were also supported by the dissenting Labor senators' report, wherein Labor raised concerns that the wording of the bill could have potential punitive impacts under its provisions. This is regardless of the intentions of legitimate protestors and whistleblowers.

In an attempt to reach a balance between enhancing security measures and the effect on the civil rights of peaceful legitimate protestors, we believe that the government has potentially gone too far. When as legislators we attempt to address threats of terrorist attacks on nuclear facilities, it is important to keep a balance between this and the need to preserve civil and democratic rights, which, after all, are fundamental to the aims of the so-called war on terror, and it is important to ensure that there is comprehensive and open debate, which is, I guess, more important than anything else.

In the case of this bill it appears that a number of submitters complained of the short time frame for submissions and public consultations. Indeed it appears that submissions were made by invitation only, and open public consultation did not take place. The Medical Association for Prevention of War, with whom I have a close working relationship through a parliamentary policy committee that I am involved with, noted in their submission that the lack of time allocated for detailed public debate was of key concern to them and other organisations. A letter protesting their concerns states:

quote.para: Medical Association for Prevention of War (MAPW) wishes to raise concerns regarding the lack of timely public and parliamentary notification of the above named Bill.
MAPW was only contacted and informed of the Bill by the Senate Committee the week that submissions were due.
The short time frame of the Bill has not allowed adequate parliamentary and public debate regarding its effects.

speech.para: The ASNO in evidence indicated that they wanted the legislation passed without delay. Unfortunately such attitudes do not assist in ensuring adequate public participation but instead lead to public suspicion that the government is trying to ram through measures, measures which are designed to combat potential terrorist threats and as such deserve support—and in fact they have our support. But it needs to be acknowledged that rushed measures can prohibit full public examination and debate.

Nuclear and missile weaponry remain an issue that continues to evoke passionate debate in our community. To say that the issue is controversial—in particular when you look at the recent US national missile defence initiative, the nuclear brinkmanship between India and Pakistan and the nuclear ambitions of Iran and North Korea—is a bit of an understatement.

While the provisions contained in this bill are important, this bill also provides an opportunity for us, or for me in particular, to speak about some of the overarching issues of nuclear and missile nonproliferation. The reality is that the better we control the proliferation of nuclear weapons and other weapons of mass destruction the better we can stop these weapons falling into the hands of terrorists and criminals. The Comprehensive Nuclear Test-Ban Treaty Act 1998 brings Australia into line with its international obligations under that treaty. The treaty bans nuclear weapon testing and requires the setting up of a monitoring system to verify compliance. The International Atomic Energy Agency provides this nuclear compliance and verification system.

Bringing the treaty into force will allow an international monitoring system with on-site inspections and increased transparency of those states with nuclear capabilities. Over 100 nations have ratified the treaty with only 12 key states, including the current US administration, yet to fully ratify the treaty. Australia has a role as an international citizen to lobby these states, and in particular, given our friendship with the United States, to lobby them to fully ratify the treaty.

The Bush administration has opposed the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty and suggested a possible resumption of some nuclear weapons testing. In claiming that they reserve the right denied to the rest of the international community of resuming nuclear weapon tests the United States makes a mockery of world attempts to eliminate the threat of nuclear weapons. The Missile Technology Control Regime provides export controls on delivery systems and importantly limits the spread of ballistic missiles and associated technologies and, as such, should be supported.

Nuclear and missile nonproliferation receives growing attention within the General Assembly and Security Council of the United Nations. On this side of the House, our support for the United Nations and the role it plays in collective international security is undiminished. The government often professes the same support but only, of course, if its partisan concerns and public polling do not dictate otherwise. Labor understands and appreciates the value of the United Nations, the discussion and debate that takes place there and the importance of its role in holding the international community together in working for peace.

Nonproliferation is a key example of the valuable role it plays and we see the importance of this role in the recent discussions within the General Assembly pertaining to the resolutions put forward by the New Agenda Coalition and by Japan. The New Agenda Coalition is a grouping of non-nuclear states within the General Assembly of the United Nations. It was formed in the aftermath of the nuclear tests conducted by India and Pakistan in 1998 and was launched in the same year with a joint declaration by the ministers for foreign affairs of Brazil, Egypt, Ireland, Mexico, New Zealand, Slovenia and Sweden. Its declaration, which is entitled `Towards a nuclear free world: the need for a new agenda', urged the nuclear weapons states to make an unequivocal undertaking to accomplish the total elimination of their nuclear arsenals.

The New Agenda Coalition has also raised quite legitimate concerns about the development of a new generation of nuclear weapons that could undermine attempts to lessen proliferation of nuclear weapons. Although the United States claims that it has refrained from developing any new nuclear weapons and that it has not manufactured nuclear warheads for 10 years, it still has plans for the alteration of existing warheads to produce strategic `mini-nukes' or earth penetrating bunker-busting nuclear bombs as they are known—I presume affectionately.
Julian Borger of the Sydney Morning Herald on 21 February 2003 reported on a leaked account of plans by the United States military to construct a new generation of nuclear weapons:

quote.para: Nuclear weapons strategists believe low-yield weapons would be a more credible deterrent against outlaw states and terrorist organisations with weapons of mass destruction.

speech.para: As some nonproliferation experts note, the current United States administration believes that, in a post 9-11 environment, a more offensive approach in broadening the range of weapons available to it, including strategic weapons to respond with flexibility to differing threats, is required. Others argue that such proliferation, whether high- or low-risk, increases the risk of terrorists accessing nuclear weapons.

Nonproliferation measures can lessen risks of terrorists obtaining weapons or material, but they do not alleviate all risks. These measures can halt the illicit obtaining of a nuclear weapon, the misappropriation of dual-use technologies or the transfer of technologies and equipment between nation states. Other measures to assist in lessening terrorist nuclear risks include having, for example, nuclear weapon free zones, a prohibition on manufacturing fissile material and, above all, universal nuclear disarmament. These measures need multilateral actions and require the end of US, and in this case Australian, unilateralism. Playing footsies with the Bush administration over the national missile defence system, `running up the flagpole' ideas in the Australian community and media and our government's uncritical support of the United States are a threat to international cooperation on nonproliferation and form part of this government's shortcomings in international security cooperation.

Since its formation, the New Agenda Coalition has submitted draft resolutions to the UN General Assembly's First Committee on Disarmament and International Security. These resolutions have all been uniform in their call for the urgency in the abolition of nuclear weapons. In the short time of its existence, the New Agenda Coalition has been impressive in pressuring nuclear weapon states to commit to a nuclear disarmament process. It is a group that has shown itself to be fervently committed to a process that in the global context bears no equivalent.

However, as the Prime Minister indicated in a letter to the member for Stirling recently, the Australian government has abstained on New Agenda Coalition resolutions in the past. Instead, the Australian government has consistently supported the formulation in Japan's disarmament resolution, which is, I understand, a somewhat watered down approach to that adopted by the New Agenda Coalition. The Prime Minister refers to the Japanese resolution as being `pragmatic and realistic', and this is the reason he uses to justify Australia abstaining on resolutions put forward by the New Agenda Coalition. The Prime Minister seems to believe that the motions put forward by the New Agenda Coalition do not sufficiently recognise that nuclear disarmament is a complex, incremental process. I think this is a criticism that reeks once again of toeing the line of foreign interests instead of putting Australian interests ahead of all other interests.

While Japan has been lobbied to join the New Agenda Coalition, it has declined such invitations and has chosen to abstain from voting on the 1998 resolutions. It has sometimes been difficult to understand how Japan, with a war renouncing constitution and being the only victim of two nuclear attacks on its soil, would vote against or abstain from a nuclear disarmament initiative. Unfortunately, as has been documented, one reason given is that as long as Japan remains under the US nuclear umbrella it is unlikely that it would vote for any New Agenda Coalition resolution.

The close security alliance with the United States since 1951 and the fact that the US has consistently voted against New Agenda Coalition resolutions make it difficult for Japan to support these resolutions. Unfortunately, it would appear that this also makes it difficult for Australia to be supportive of similar resolutions. This is a country that, as a deputy sheriff—or perhaps even after promotion to sheriff in more recent times—has fallen under the same nuclear protection of the United States and, as a result, we are being gagged by it.

The government takes a defeatist approach in calling for a pragmatic and realistic approach to bringing about an end to nuclear weapons. While the New Agenda resolution stresses the need for the urgent abolition of nuclear weapons, the Japanese resolutions talk instead of an ultimate objective. Again, it is the latter option, which I believe is the lowest common denominator, that this government supports. Unfortunately, it is an ultimate objective with no practical time frame and which runs the risk of remaining an ultimate objective in theory without any practical application. If several former nuclear aspiring powers—Algeria, Belarus, Kazakhstan, Serbia, South Africa and the Ukraine—can be convinced or coerced to abandon their nuclear programs, the world community can collectively banish these weapons from our military arsenals.

Despite all the tough talking on the national security issues from the so-called man of steel, the Prime Minister seems unable and unwilling to take strong and definitive leadership on this very important issue. Instead, we have a government that continues to take its cue on non-proliferation from foreign interests. While the Prime Minister may bask in the glory of being labelled `fair dinkum', Australians ask why his government is not fair dinkum when it comes to the abolition of nuclear weapons. The abolition of nuclear weapons is a global obligation. Australia has a political and moral obligation to be at the forefront of global efforts to curb the proliferation of nuclear weapons. We should be supporting the efforts of the New Agenda Coalition. We should be leaders, not followers, and anything short of this compromises the safety of Australia and the world community in general.

talk.start.para: —The spectre of a nuclear arms race cast a shadow over the world's future during the Cold War, and that must not be allowed to happen again. However, recent brinkmanship between Pakistan and India, and by North Korea, as well as the fear of future nuclear terrorism, has raised that unease again, and it is incumbent on the world's governments to restrain the acquisition of weapons and, where that capacity exists, to disarm it.

speech.para: Australia is signatory to a number of international treaties and regimes designed to limit the spread of such weapons. The Non-Proliferation Legislation Amendment Bill 2003 allows Australia to bring into force legislation banning nuclear weapons tests despite the worrying fact that the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty or CTBT has yet to be implemented. It is worth noting why this international treaty, signed by the five declared nuclear powers in 1996, is still not in force. All 44 nuclear-capable states must not only sign but also ratify the treaty before it may allow the full implementation of the international monitoring system that would strengthen and verify the comprehensive nuclear test ban. This would also fully implement the monitoring system that would detect breaches of the ban.

Many of the US allies, including Australia, have signed and ratified the CTBT, as have Russia and Japan. But in 1999 the US Senate refused to ratify the treaty, and the current US administration openly opposes it. Twelve of the 44 nuclear-capable states are yet to ratify, and China and other countries have indicated they would work to bring the treaty into force only when the United States has done so. It would be commendable indeed to see our government working hard to convince the recalcitrant states which have not yet ratified the treaty to do so.

Schedule 2 of this bill amends the Comprehensive Nuclear Test-Ban Treaty Act 1998 to allow Australia to bring into force legislation banning nuclear weapon tests ahead of entry into force of the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty. It also deals with the establishment and operation of monitoring facilities and operations, particularly providing for the practicalities of on-site inspections. This is an important and proactive step in the right direction, and I commend the government on taking it. Those parts of the existing CTBT act which deal with clarification and consultation on treaty compliance and which confer powers in relation to the use of land for monitoring facilities, under the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty, will only commence when the treaty comes into force.

Schedule 3 of the bill provides consequential amendments to establish the implementing office, and its staffing, by amending the Comprehensive Nuclear Test-Ban Treaty Act 1998, the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Act 1987 and the Chemical Weapons (Prohibition) Act 1994. However, there are amendments to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Act 1987 within schedule 1 of the bill which I am concerned will restrict the flow of information that is necessary to ensure the public good, and which will curtail informed debate, limit the right of people to legitimately protest and intimidate potential whistleblowers who may raise legitimate concerns.

Indeed, as noted in the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Legislation Committee hearings, while schedules 2 and 3 of this bill focus on Australia's international obligations under the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty, and on administrative issues, schedule 1 focuses on the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Act 1987 and on largely domestic issues which do not affect nuclear test ban matters. Certainly it was confirmed by Mr Andrew Leask, Assistant Secretary of the Australian Safeguards and Non-Proliferation Office, that schedule 1 was inserted into this bill more as a question of convenience. With this in mind, I hope the government is sincere in its wish to implement nuclear test ban provisions and that no devious attempt is made to equate concerns about civil liberties with a lack of support for the banning of nuclear weapon tests. This would be misleading indeed.

In the explanatory memorandum for the bill, the government's stated intention under schedule 1 is to strengthen domestic arrangements for the protection of nuclear material, facilities and associated information. I am sure that no-one would argue prima facie against the need for increased protection of national security, especially within the current international climate of escalated terrorist activity. Schedule l provides measures that establish a permits regime for work to be carried out to establish a nuclear facility, a facility for carrying out nuclear activities, or for the use of associated equipment. Schedule 1 also increases the penalties for the offence of possession of nuclear material or an associated item without a permit, and for the unauthorised passing on of information, as well as unauthorised access to a restricted area.

I support ensuring the physical protection and security of nuclear facilities and material from theft and sabotage—and who wouldn't? The provisions in schedule 1 purport to do just that. But those same provisions also cast a very wide net over what I believe is legitimate protest and the passing on of information to ensure safety and transparency. Proposed section 25A makes it a criminal offence for a person who may be authorised to deal with an associated technology—for an example, an employee of a nuclear facility—to have in their possession, without a permit, associated technology. Further, it is an offence for that person not to ensure the physical safety of such material. It is worth noting here that the definition of `associated technology' is any information applicable primarily to the design, production, operation, testing or use of equipment or plant that involves nuclear facilities or material.

We do want to ensure that insiders or employees who deal with associated technology are committing an offence if they pass on classified or security sensitive information with the intention of using this for terrorism or other illegal activities. However, existing sections 23 and 26 already prohibit the unauthorised possession or disclosure of associated technology without reasonable excuse. Consider this: in a submission to the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Legislation Committee inquiry into the bill, an example of such conduct was highlighted to illustrate how a person acting in the public interest and with public safety in mind could be imprisoned for two years under this bill. In this instance, a whistleblower blew the whistle on the inappropriate drilling of holes in a tank at the Lucas Heights containment building, which posed a considerable safety risk. The end result was improved scrutiny and practices that, in turn, improved the safety of not only the people working within the reactor but also the community. Would this person, acting with the best intention of exposing dangerous and neglectful practices, fall under the government's proposed section 25A, which omits the `without reasonable excuse' proviso?

Proposed section 26A makes it a criminal offence to communicate information to someone else which could prejudice the physical security of nuclear material or an associated item. Under this section, `communication' could be taken to include public communication such as reports in a newspaper, council alerts about the transport of nuclear material or protest organisers publishing information on a web site. There is no definition about what sort of information may not be passed on; thus, the passing on of any information that has absolutely no inherent security sensitivity or no official national security classification, such as in the examples I gave, would presumably be caught under this bill.

Currently, there is disquiet and protest expressed by all levels of community at the issue of the transportation of waste from the Lucas Heights nuclear reactor to Woomera. One proposed route crosses the Blue Mountains National Park and travels through my electorate of Calare. Under this bill, the individuals and councils in my electorate who communicate that a shipment of waste is about to leave Lucas Heights and travel through their area and the journalist who reports the matter could conceivably be committing a criminal offence. Again, in section 26A, there is not even the minimum qualification that might take into consideration the intent behind any action, such as the `reasonable excuse' proviso, despite it existing in the present section 26.

I am proposing amendments, which have been circulated in my name, to both section 25A and section 26A that I believe will ensure that people possessing and passing on information with a reasonable excuse for the communication of such material, such as the public interest and safety, will not be committing an offence under this bill. I also propose that, in order to commit an offence, the information communicated must have an official national security classification and must not already be in the public domain, and that the communication does not include public communications such as the print or electronic media, local government authority advice or circulars concerning the transport of nuclear material, or communications from citizens wishing to register concerns about the transport of nuclear material, including the communication of information on a web site.

My amendments would ensure that whistleblowers who pass on information in the public interest are protected by the `reasonable excuse' inclusion. The amendments will also make certain that the responsible and active citizen is still entitled to pass on, receive and debate information that does not pose any real security risk. These amendments, however, still ensure that the release of classified nuclear material or information with the intent of serious threat to security and safety remains a punishable offence under the bill.

The final section in schedule 1 that is causing great concern is section 31A, which seems clearly aimed at protesters trespassing on property containing nuclear material and equipment. Given that community disquiet persists about the safety of the Lucas Heights reactor and about the transport of radioactive waste, it is reasonable to assume that protest is highly likely to occur within restricted areas. Likewise, the well-known Greenpeace protests that involve the draping of banners on ships transporting nuclear materials is not likely to cease. Indeed, if a restricted area is declared through the Blue Mountains or Calare as waste is moved to a dump site—and we need such a dump site, perhaps, but many people, including me, do not believe that road transport is the way to go—under section 31A, these types of protests in the name of public interest and safety would presumably be an offence with a six-month jail sentence. This is truly draconian for a trespass offence, and I believe it is unacceptable.

I propose an amendment to section 31A to ensure that a person may be prosecuted for unauthorised access to an area, vehicle, aircraft or ship only if their act is accompanied by the intention and knowledge that their trespass will seriously threaten the physical security of nuclear material or of the restricted area. Where a person deliberately and seriously threatens the safety and security of an area, they may still be prosecuted and penalised. However, protesters acting in good faith should not fall under these measures.

I understand that an argument may be made that the Criminal Code Act may provide a defence for the concerned and active citizen who may be caught up in the provisions of this bill. However, I do not believe that legitimate and democratic actions which do not pose any true security threat should be criminalised. There are many people in my electorate who do take an active interest in the freedoms, the safety and the wellbeing of our communities, and they should not be running a risk of punishment each time they pass on information that contributes to informed debate about the security and safety of our nuclear facilities and waste in the context of the worldwide concern about nuclear proliferation.

We should not have to rely on a court to recognise the best intentions of those who are acting in the public good without endangering security and safety. It should not be up to such a person to bear the burden of liability. Yes, we must take what steps we can to ban nuclear tests and halt the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, and we must provide for effective monitoring of nuclear facilities and activities—and this bill to a large degree does that. And yes, we must ensure the security of sensitive information and facilities, which this bill purports to do. But we must also ensure that the right to protest, to be aware of and to discuss and debate matters—any matters, but in this case matters to do with nuclear material or activities or associated items—is not a punishable offence when it does not compromise the safety and security of such matters. In fact such discussion and activity generally ensures that practices to do with nuclear materials and waste will be as safe and secure as possible. I commend the bill to the House but with the amendments that I will move in the detailed consideration stage.

talker.name: Gallus, Christine, MP
Mrs GALLUS
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs

talk.start.para: —in reply—The Non-Proliferation Legislation Amendment Bill 2003 will strengthen Australia's efforts to prevent the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. The bill will amend the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Act 1987, the Comprehensive Nuclear Test-Ban Treaty Act 1998 and the Chemical Weapons (Prohibition) Act 1994. It enhances domestic arrangements for the protection of Australia's nuclear facilities and proliferation of sensitive materials and information. In doing so, the bill helps underpin Australia's treaty and international legal obligations. Indeed, the bill ensures that Australia's domestic nonproliferation legislation continues to set a high standard. This bill, contrary to assertions by the member for Griffith, is not a case of the government playing catch-up with the International Atomic Energy Agency's 1999 recommendations on physical protection of nuclear material and nuclear facilities. In fact the government has already implemented these recommendations through Australia's nuclear permit system.

speech.para: The government is deeply concerned about the spread of weapons of mass destruction. The government's decision to join the successful international coalition to disarm Iraq reflected its determination to take action against this threat. The government was prepared to take the hard decision to tackle this threat—in contrast, I might say, to the opposition, who took the easy option of being poll driven in a cheap bid for votes. Our actions in Iraq helped remove Saddam Hussein's barbarous regime, which through its defiance of 17 United Nations Security Council resolutions showed that he never intended to give up his weapons of mass destruction ambitions. The success of the coalition's actions has sent to rogue states a clear signal of the seriousness with which the international community views proliferation of weapons of mass destruction.

In spite of, or perhaps because of, the success of the government's actions in Iraq, the opposition continues to bleat about alleged exaggeration of prewar intelligence. The member for Griffith's allegations about government comments on the purpose of the aluminium tubes is mischievous. The government was never categorical about the purpose of the tubes, precisely because it was aware of the debate about their use. Indeed, far from there being consensus that the tubes were not destined for Iraq's nuclear program, the balance of opinion among US agencies, as reflected in the October 2002 US National Intelligence Estimate on Iraq's WMD, was:

quote.para: Most agencies believe that Saddam's personal interest in and Iraq's aggressive attempts to obtain high-strength aluminum tubes for centrifuge rotors—as well as Iraq's attempts to acquire magnets, high-speed balancing machines, and machine tools—provide compelling evidence that Saddam is reconstituting a uranium enrichment effort for Baghdad's nuclear weapons program.

speech.para: The member for Griffith also seems intent on repeating misleading claims about the government's alleged exaggeration of intelligence about Iraq having sought uranium from Africa. He does this despite the fact that the UK government continues to stand by its assessment that Iraq sought uranium from Africa and despite the findings of the UK Intelligence and Security Committee that the UK SIS judgment on this issue was reasonable.

The government has maintained Australia's strong commitment to existing nonproliferation treaties, such as the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, the Chemical Weapons Convention and the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty. It has taken a lead in international consideration of nuclear proliferation issues. In the case of Iran, Australia took a lead in co--sponsoring the 12 September resolution of the International Atomic Energy Agency Board of Governors, which has helped encourage Iran to take a more cooperative approach to addressing the international community's concerns about its nuclear activities.

The system of international treaties, export control regimes and other instruments built up over several decades remains the mainstay for stopping the spread of WMD. But the international nonproliferation agenda must allow for new means of addressing the threat of WMD proliferation. For this reason, Australia, while supporting and engaging in non-proliferation forums, has taken on a significant role in the Proliferation Security Initiative. Australia, working with other participants in the Proliferation Security Initiative, is developing practical measures to impede the illicit trade in weapons of mass destruction, associated technologies and their delivery systems.

As vital as these international efforts are, the government recognises that further efforts to strengthen domestic protection of proliferation sensitive materials and information are essential. It is clear that there are few barriers, other than technical and financial ones, to rogue states and groups obtaining WMD related materials and knowledge. Therefore we must make every effort to deny access to unauthorised persons and protect to the maximum extent materials and knowledge which might aid an adversary or place Australians at risk. We need to make full use of the existing tools at our disposal. But, where these tools can be improved, we should improve domestic regulatory frameworks to ensure they are effective. This is precisely what the Non-Proliferation Legislation Amendment Bill will do by improving domestic legislation in three critical areas. Firstly, it will strengthen Australia's arrangements for the protection of nuclear facilities, material and related information and the arrangements for application of nonproliferation safeguards to them.

Secondly, the bill will give legal effect to Australia's actions in support of the Comprehensive Nuclear Test-Ban Treaty ahead of the treaty's entry into force. The government was instrumental in securing the adoption of this treaty by the United Nations General Assembly, having rescued it from the Conference on Disarmament in Geneva, which had failed to reach a consensus. Under the CTBT, Australia has already established 15 of the 20 planned nuclear test monitoring stations. All 15 are already providing data to the CTBT's International Data Centre in Vienna. Once the bill's amendments to the Comprehensive Nuclear Test-Ban Treaty Act 1998 are in place, the government will bring immediately into effect provisions which ban nuclear testing in Australia and any contribution to testing by an Australian citizen anywhere in the world. Thirdly, the bill implements changes to the machinery of government, including updated penalties in line with current practice, which will improve the effectiveness of each of the acts affected.

The government is conscious that the opposition and minor parties have expressed concern that some new offences listed in the bill, particularly those relating to the divulgence of sensitive information and trespass in specified areas, could be applied too broadly. I can assure the House that this is not the case. As with all modern legislation, this bill cannot be interpreted without application of the Criminal Code—part of the Criminal Code Act 1995—which, inter alia, seeks to ensure that criminal offence provisions are constructed, interpreted and enforced in a uniform way by the Commonwealth. The bill's criminal offence provisions are focused, rather than defined broadly, and there is an appropriately high burden of proof required for successful prosecution.

I am aware that particular concern has been expressed that this bill will limit the rights of whistleblowers. The relevant section, 26A, is focused on the protection of information which could compromise security arrangements, clearly vital for the protection of nuclear facilities, materials and the public. I note that the fault elements of recklessness and intention apply to this section in accordance with the Criminal Code, thus there is no need for qualifying language. This bill does not impact on the right of whistleblowers to report concerns relating to nuclear safety or the management of radioactive sources, which are the regulatory responsibility of state governments and the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency. Clearly, however, communication of specific details about security arrangements that could be used to defeat those security arrangements would not be in the public interest. Indeed, most people will recognise that it would be irresponsible, and could endanger public safety, for a person to publish specific and vital details about security arrangements.

Another concern raised has been that the provisions within the bill that deal with unauthorised access to restricted areas could curtail the right to protest. These are in section 31A. This is not the case. This bill does not limit further the right to protest, as areas likely to be designated under this section are already off-limits to protesters and must be well defined and clearly marked. This bill recognises, however, that some parts of a nuclear facility and some nuclear materials are particularly sensitive. Accordingly, the bill increases the penalty for unlawful entry into these sensitive areas which are designated by permit requirement. The member for Griffith has claimed that this section is one of strict liability. Strict liability applies only to paragraphs B and C. By virtue of the Criminal Code, at section 5.6, any prosecution still has to prove intention beyond reasonable doubt for paragraph A. In the government's view, it is absolutely essential to ensure that nuclear material and nuclear items are properly protected against theft, sabotage or terrorist acts. Responsible persons will recognise that their actions should not endanger public or personal safety and that there are some places to which access must be tightly controlled.

This bill will strengthen Australia's efforts to prevent the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. It will contribute to enduring efforts to minimise the risk that terrorists might gain access to proliferation sensitive material and information. Crucially, the bill does so without impinging on the reasonable rights of all Australians to freedom of expression and legal protest. Governments have a duty to ensure that domestic regulatory frameworks are effective in deterring and meeting possible threats. The Non-Proliferation Legislation Amendment Bill strengthens Australia's protection of proliferation sensitive material and information and, accordingly, I commend the bill to the House.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: Bill—by leave—taken as a whole.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move amendments (1) to (6) together:

quote.para: (1) Schedule 1, item 21, after paragraph 25(1)(d), after line 8 insert
`(da) the person does not have a reasonable excuse for the conduct; and'.
(2) Schedule 1, item 26, after paragraph 26A(1)(a), after line 6, insert:
`(aa) the person does not have a reasonable excuse for the communication of the information; and'.
(3) Schedule 1, item 26, after paragraph 26(1)(b), after line 9, insert:
`and

(c) the person communicates the information with the knowledge that the physical safety of nuclear material or an associated item, to which Part II applies, is likely or could reasonably be expected to be seriously threatened by the communication of the information.'.
(4) Schedule 1, item 26, after subsection 26A(1) insert:
`(1A) In this section:
information means information with an official national security classification.

person means a person who has access to or who knowingly receives inform-ation about nuclear material or assoc-iated items that has a national security classification and that information is not in the public domain.

communicate means transmit or convey information to another person or persons', but does not include public communications, such as the comm-unication of information in the print or electronic media, local government authority advice or circulars concerning the transport of nuclear material, or communications from citizens wishing to register concerns about the transport of nuclear material, including the communication of information on a website.
(5) Schedule 1, item 45, after paragraph 31A (1)(c), after line 10, insert:
(c) the person intends to seriously threaten the physical security of nuclear material, or of a restricted area, vehicle, aircraft or ship; or
(d) knows that the physical safety of nuclear material, or of a restrict-ed area, vehicle, aircraft or ship; is likely or could reasonably be expected to be seriously threatened.
Penalty: 6 months imprisonment
(6) Schedule 1, item 45, after paragraph 31A (1)(c), line 12, omit “(b) and”.

speech.para: My amendments essentially shadow the government's proposed sections 25A, 26A and 31A but with provisions that protect legitimate discussion, protest and concerns, which ensure a balance. I hope the government and opposition recognise that. The government's proposed section 25A, `Breach of duty to ensure security of associated technology', makes it a criminal offence for an employee of a nuclear facility to possess or pass on associated technology. Associated technology is any information or document applicable to the design, production, operation, testing or use of equipment or plant that involves nuclear facilities or material. This includes photographs, models or things that may illustrate any such information. However, this section does not differentiate between a whistleblower who in fact wants to ensure the safety and security of such facilities or a person who takes such actions with the intent of serious threat to security and safety.

My amendment to section 25A simply inserts the clause that the person who engages in such conduct commits an offence under this section if `the person does not have a reasonable excuse for the conduct'. This insertion simply mirrors the existing reasonable excuse provision in the existing section 26 and allows intent to be taken into account.

The government's proposed section 26A, `Communication prejudicing security of nuclear material or associated item', makes it an offence for any person to communicate information to someone else if the communication could prejudice the physical security of nuclear material or an associated item. An associated item is material suited for use in the construction or operation of a nuclear reactor, or equipment or plant designed or suited for use in nuclear activities, or the aforementioned document or information. The government's section 26A does not differentiate between public or secret modes of communication and does not differentiate between information that has absolutely no inherent security sensitivity, or official security legislation or information that is classified or which could actually threaten security.

My amendments to section 26A—amendments (2) to (4)—again mirror the government's proposed section 26A but, again, with the reasonable excuse proviso that exists in the current section 26. They also determine that it is an offence if `the person communicates the information with the knowledge that the safety of nuclear material or an associated item is likely or could reasonably be expected to be seriously threatened by the communication of the information'. The amendments also include definitions to ensure that, for a punishable offence, the information is only classified information that could seriously threaten security and safety and that the intent is one of secrecy and knowing about a serious threat posed by the passing of information.

The government's proposed section 31A, `Unauthorised access to areas etc to which access is restricted under permit', details that people who enter a restricted area or get onto or into a vehicle, aircraft or ship without a permit may be prosecuted and jailed for six months. My amendments to 31A—amendments (5) and (6)—add the proviso that such a person may only be prosecuted if their act is accompanied by an intention to seriously threaten the physical security of nuclear material or of a restricted area, vehicle, aircraft or ship, or if they know that such a trespass `is likely or could reasonably be expected to be seriously threatened'. They still allow prosecution and penalties to be applied to a person who deliberately and seriously threatens the security and safety of an area, and they protect legitimate protest or trespass that does not aim to compromise security and safety. I commend these quite reasonable amendments to the House and will seek to progress them in the other place, should they not be acceptable here.

talker.name: Gallus, Christine, MP
Mrs GALLUS
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Calare for his comments on the bill and for his amendments. The amendments are not acceptable to the government. Indeed, the government believes that there has been a slight misunderstanding of the Criminal Code by the member for Calare. Further, I would just like to clarify for the member that the definition of `associated technology' does not mean just any information—as I infer that is what he thought it meant, from what he said—but refers to the special information that ASNO classifies. I repeat: the government will not be accepting these amendments for those reasons.

speech.para: Question negatived.
Bill agreed to.

subdebate.1.para: Mrs GALLUS (Hindmarsh—Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs) (7.20 p.m.)—by leave—I move:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a third time.

subdebate.1.para: Question agreed to.
Bill read a third time.
Debate resumed from 27 March, on motion by Mr Slipper:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Trade Practices Legislation Amendment Bill 2003 contains two main sets of amendments to the Trade Practices Act. The first set concerns part IIIA of the TPA, which deals with access regimes. These amendments address implications arising out of the High Court decision in Queen v. Hughes for cooperative national schemes. Part IIIA of the TPA establishes a regime to promote competition by providing access to the services of facilities of national significance—for example, electricity grids or gas pipelines. At present, part IIIA provides that the ACCC and the Australian Competition Tribunal may perform functions and powers conferred on them by state or territory legislation which establishes an access regime.

speech.para: The constitutional validity of cooperative arrangements of this nature was thrown into doubt by the decision of the High Court in R v. Hughes in 2000. The Hughes case concerned the cooperative scheme that underpinned the Corporations Law. The central question in Hughes was whether the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions could perform functions conferred by state law. The High Court suggested that the Commonwealth may need to impose a duty on its authorities or officers to perform functions or exercise powers conferred by state law. Significantly, the court also indicated that the Commonwealth may be unable to impose these duties unless it could have imposed the functions by its own legislative powers.

The decision therefore cast doubt over a number of cooperative schemes which are designed to overcome deficiencies in Commonwealth power. The bill seeks to insert provisions to deal with the implications of the Hughes case in the context of access regimes. The amendments provide that the TPA does not impose a duty on the ACCC or the Australian Competition Tribunal if state or territory power is sufficient to do so. In such a case, the Commonwealth will simply consent to its officers performing the functions conferred. However, if state power is not sufficient to impose a duty but the Commonwealth can, then the TPA imposes the duty. Labor will support these amendments, but we are concerned that the government has failed to take action to remove all constitutional doubt surrounding the scheme.

This bill is simply a bandaid. The amendments fail to deal with the central problem in Hughes for cooperative schemes—namely, that the court may find that Commonwealth power is not sufficient to impose the duty needed to make the cooperative scheme effective. This is not the first time the government has gone for the bandaid on cooperative schemes. Amendments similar to this were proposed in relation to the cooperative schemes dealing with therapeutic goods and agricultural and veterinary chemicals. For some time, Labor has been concerned about the implications of the Hughes case for Commonwealth-state cooperation. At the last election, Labor called for a long-term solution to the problem in the form of a constitutional amendment to ensure that the federal and state governments can put in place joint legislation to address issues of national importance for which neither the federal nor state governments have complete responsibility.

In May, the Leader of the Opposition in his Fraser lecture repeated this call for a constitutional amendment of this nature to assist nation building. The problems presented by the Hughes case for the TPA go beyond access regimes. The Treasury has acknowledged that the Hughes case raises doubts about the ACCC's ability to enforce the competition code. The code extends the restrictive trade practices of the TPA to cover unincorporated bodies such as the professions. As the law stands, after Hughes, there is doubt about the ability of the ACCC to prosecute a group of professionals such as lawyers or architects involved in, for example, a price-fixing arrangement. Amendments like this one will not fix the problem—only constitutional reform will.

I will now turn to the second set of amendments. Schedule 2 of the bill inserts a new part into the TPA which will provide for a prices surveillance regime. As a consequence, the bill repeals the Prices Surveillance Act 1983. The Prices Surveillance Act was introduced in 1983 as a key element of the Labor government's prices and incomes policy. To further the objective of bringing inflation under control and promoting economic growth, the Prices Surveillance Act was intended to encourage price restraint as a counterpart to the wage restraint being exercised by employees. The act provides for three forms of prices oversight: price inquiries, prices notification and price monitoring. The Prices Surveillance Act does not allow the government to prevent price increases indefinitely; however, it does allow increases to be delayed pending investigation by the ACCC of whether they are justified. This process brings some moral pressure to bear on firms wishing to increase their prices without justification.

In February 2000, the government directed the Productivity Commission to examine the operation of the act. The Productivity Commission completed its report in August 2001. The Productivity Commission recommended a number of reforms, including that the minister should not be able to implement price monitoring without an inquiry or recommendation from the ACCC or National Competition Council and that the price notification provisions should be abolished. The opposition is pleased that the government rejected both of these suggestions. We believe that the existing range of price controls should be preserved and that the decision about whether they are implemented should remain a matter for the minister. The new prices surveillance part inserted into the Trade Practices Act by the bill differs in only a minor respect from the existing Prices Surveillance Act. It contains an objects clause, which states:

quote.para: The object of this Part is to have prices surveillance applied only in those markets where, in the view of the Minister, competitive pressures are not sufficient to achieve efficient prices and protect consumers.

speech.para: We do not oppose this clause. Having said that, I would like to make it clear that Labor see more industries where competitive pressures are insufficient and in need of price oversight than the government do. The banking industry is one prominent example, and I will return to this issue in a moment.

One change from the Prices Surveillance Act that we do disagree with is the proposal that the minister should be able to appoint a body other than the ACCC to conduct a price inquiry. The argument behind this change seems to be that the ACCC may have a conflict of interest. It is implied that the ACCC would have a bias in favour of recommending ongoing price monitoring because this would attract increased resources to the commission. We believe that this is an unwarranted slur on the professionalism of the commission's staff. The ACCC has a proven track record of conducting price inquiries. There is no reason to question its independence, rigour or expertise. The minister should not be given the opportunity to have inquiries conducted by other bodies that may not share these characteristics. The opposition will not oppose the bill in this House, but we will move amendments in the Senate to ensure that only the ACCC can conduct price inquiries under the TPA.

Of course, it is all very well to have prices surveillance powers, but the government must commit to using them. One area where Labor has consistently called for prices oversight is bank fees and charges. According to an analysis by PricewaterhouseCoopers, total bank fees in 2002 were $7.8 billion, with household fees at $2.7 billion. Just in the past few days, more fee increases have hit customers of the ANZ Bank and the Commonwealth Bank. From 1 November 2003, the additional fees Commonwealth Bank customers were slugged with include annual fees for no-awards credit cards rising from $24 to $30, a 25 per cent increase; late payment fees also rising 25 per cent, from $20 to $25; and a brand new fee of $15 to be charged for each additional cardholder. ANZ credit card customers are also paying more for using their credit cards, with late payment fees and over-limit fees rising from $25 to $35, a massive 40 per cent increase.
Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 7.30 p.m., I propose the question:

motion.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —I would like to share some good news with you this evening by telling the remarkable transformation story of Tasmania. That story is no better illustrated than by the fact that in August last year we had one ferry plying between Devonport and Melbourne and now, one year later, we have two ferries plying Bass Strait, bringing in heaps of tourists—and we also have one more ferry that will be coming from Sydney into Devonport, my home port, and that will start in January. Already the estimates for tourist bookings for the state have increased by 100 per cent on last year—and, of course, that was up from a relatively modest base prior to that.

speech.para: So in terms of tourism Tassie is going gangbusters, but of course that is not the only area in which Tasmania is progressing so well. Indeed, it is the flavour island in every sense of the description. It is not only the flavour island in the production of its excellent food and its clean green image but also in terms of real estate and people moving to Tasmania. We are actually moving into positive growth for the first time in some time, and the economic indicators in Tassie are excellent. Indeed, the economic indicators are the best for employment in some 20 years—the lowest unemployment rate, the highest employment rate and in terms of the job ad surveys the best in 12 years. So this is all excellent news regarding Tasmania.

I would like to share with you, if I may, some of the excellent good news stories that accompany this terrific growth in Tasmania—growth that of course we look forward to sustaining. Only recently the University of Tasmania was granted a $2 million ARC grant for a very highly specialised science project, separating chemical components from complex mixtures. This project is not just for the land of academia; it has broad application in industries that are particularly related to Tasmania, including those related to food and beverage, agriculture, minerals processing, power generation, biotechnology and even forensic science. All of those are very important industries that are very much developed in Tasmania—and progressing.

Our IT concept in Tasmania has been fairly well understated, but the industry now spends $9.5 million on research and development alone and employs well over 2,700 people—again, that is an excellent story, demonstrating that Tasmania is an innovative island as well as being the isle of flavour. As further proof of that you only have to look at Clifford's Incat shipbuilding business. It has cutting edge shipbuilding and it has tremendous prospects for the future—as does our aquaculture industry, which has spawned a world provider of fish-feeding technology.

In my own bailiwick of Braddon, on the magnificent north-west coast of Tasmania, we have a world-leading mining engineering and equipment firm called Caterpillar Elphinstone, which exports to Indonesia, Brazil, the US and Africa. I noticed only today that Caterpillar Elphinstone is in the major manufacturing group as a national finalist for the Export Awards again. It is a superb company, employing well over 450 to 500 people in my electorate, and so too is MineCom, an excellent communications in mining company, which has world contracts as well. That leads on to information technology and a firm like Phoenix Computer Systems based in Ulverstone, who just happen to be the proud sponsors of the Ulverstone RedHoppers Basketball Club, of which I am the proud president.

Hydro Tasmania's story in terms of wind development and wind energy is unsurpassed. They have recently got a $100 million contract to develop a wind farm in South Australia, so it is bound to be good. Working with Vestas on the development of the nacelle plant, we look forward to blade development as well. We have to make sure, of course, that the MRET scheme is carried on by this government. These are just some examples of the tremendous developments that are taking place. I have not even mentioned the tourism development that is taking place in my electorate, particularly with Tall Timbers up in Circular Head and Reliquaire in Latrobe. Examples include Dismal Swamp in Circular Head, and Anvers Chocolates—well, who could go past them? So congratulations to all those that are making Tassie happen. Members, I hope you all go and visit soon, but book well in advance and make sure you make it to the north-west coast of Tassie. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Today a report I instigated as regional services minister was tabled in this place. The report was into wildfires, and it was prepared by a select committee of this House, which I hoped would guarantee the exclusion of party politics and consequently provide a worthwhile report designed to save the environment, private property and people's lives. Three committee members representing the Labor Party were granted leave today to speak on its tabling. Notwithstanding the important issues, including life and death, involved, each Labor member commenced their comments with personal criticism of me and in particular of my alleged comments immediately following the fires—and the effect of them—in Canberra. By way of personal explanation I challenged those MPs to produce to this House clear printed evidence of remarks that could be so categorised—categorised, that is, as offensive, party political or insensitive.

speech.para: The member for Canberra subsequently tabled three print media articles and two transcripts of radio interviews. Further, she highlighted sections within those documents that she apparently believes met the above criteria. I wish to read these comments to the House, starting with the transcripts, which I accept as genuine quotations of my comments. It is worthy of note, however, that the print media article highlights identified by the member for Canberra are not quotes made by me, notwithstanding that within those articles some of the comments she chose to ignore for good reason—because they did not support her claims—do appear in quotations. Some quotes identified are in fact made by other persons. To turn to the radio transcripts, on 20 January I did an interview with Rod Quinn on the ABC. The comments highlighted are as follows—this is me:

quote.para: And my response to this, in the circumstances, is to announce that I'm proposing an expert inquiry into all aspects of forest fires and ... so that we can have a much more preventative program—

speech.para: in other words, so that we can try and prevent fires before they burn down people's houses. The transcript goes on:

quote.para: I think we've changed the ecology of the forests dramatically compared to how the Aboriginals managed it, and we have wreaked a whirlwind.

speech.para: Further on, it says:

quote.para: But I'm sure they, themselves—

speech.para: these are the people who lost their homes—

quote.para: would rather be sitting in their home watching television tonight than looking at a heap of embers because we were unable to contain or prevent fires of this magnitude.

speech.para: We go on in that same transcript of interview to where the member for Canberra has underlined my words:

quote.para: But, the fundamental issue is we cannot go on burning down people's houses and ... as, unfortunately, I predicted in one of the newspapers only a week ago, it was eventually going to intrude on the suburban areas.

speech.para: That is a real mind-bending insult, and it is such party political stuff, isn't it? Then she quotes me again:

quote.para: But, I mean, if you're going to have a planning problem and you clearly understand that there is a fire risk, a bushfire risk, you know, even the positioning of trees in your backyard is a significant issue.

speech.para: This is tabled by the member for Canberra as evidence of me being insensitive, insulting and so on. In the second transcript, which is of an interview I did with Linda Mottram, the member for Canberra's highlighted quote is follows:

quote.para: Canberra is a bush capital and I am not totally convinced that it is as vulnerable to fire as it has been. I think it's got a lot more to do with the management of forests and the amount of fuel loads that have been allowed to accumulate there ...

speech.para: The member for Canberra brought this to the attention of the House today.

Those highlights were from the transcripts of two radio interviews. I now want to turn to the print media reports. The first quote the member for Canberra identified is from the Financial Review on 21 January:

quote.para: Federal Territories Minister Wilson Tuckey said local authorities had failed to do enough to prepare for the weekend bushfires ...

speech.para: I never said that; it is not in quotation marks. That all came from Jim Middleton, who said something similar during a television preamble. When we rang his office and asked, `Where did you get that from? Where is that in the transcript?' it was not there. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Stirling Electorate: Stirling Lions Soccer Club

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to tell you about one of the great sporting clubs in my electorate. The Stirling Lions Soccer Club is a progressive and multicultural club that has grown rapidly over the last three years to over 250 registered juniors and 60 seniors. Led by its president, Don Evans, secretary and treasurer, Lou Adamos, and team manager, Richard Debarro, the club plays a vital part in the development of young soccer players in the Stirling area. This year, the Stirling Lions had no fewer than 10 players selected for state team representation in carnivals in the eastern states. If you need an example of how important clubs like the Stirling Lions are to the health of our community, I would look no further than this comment from the club's president, Don Evans:

quote.para: The success of our juniors and their development as skilled soccer players is only part of the Lions philosophy with a big emphasis on youngsters developing skills of fair play and a responsible attitude toward community and environment.

speech.para: In this age of increasing family breakdown, crime and rampant drug use there is a pressing need for us to regain our sense of community. I am proud to support all the sporting groups in my electorate that instil this into our young kids. We read constantly about the alarming trend towards childhood obesity, and we all know the only cure for this scourge is to get our kids active again. Where we can support clubs to do this, we should; where we can protect sporting clubs from spiralling public indemnity insurance costs, we should.

I would like to offer this recent article written about the club as a further example of how special a role they play in our community. This article was written in early April this year and appeared in my local newspaper, the Stirling Times. It tells a remarkable tale of recovery from a health incident by one of the club's most respected and valuable volunteers, Erin Debarro:

quote.para: Stirling Lions Soccer Club believes one of its committee members is pretty special. So special in fact, the club plans to have a Courage award to honour her brave fight with death. Against all odds, Erin recently survived a brain aneurism, but continues to volunteer for the club on a regular basis with her husband Richard.
She said the experience was surreal—it started on a Sunday night in February before she was about to start a night shift at work.
“I did everything absolutely normal that afternoon, but I said to my husband `I've got a really bad headache',” she said.
“By four that Monday afternoon I was having brain surgery.”
When she lay down, Erin said she lost vision, started vomiting and could not feel her limbs, before her husband called an ambulance.
She spent 15 days in hospital after the surgery, which surprised many people because her recovery has been fortunately swift, although she had to stop working and driving.
Mrs Debarro said she felt very lucky.
“You would be amazed how many people it happens to,” she said. “Most people die of it. I still can't believe I went through that.”
Club President Don Evans said he hoped Mrs Debarro's survival story would inspire club members.
“Erin's story should prove inspirational to anyone battling adversity on or off the field,” he said.
However, Mrs Debarro attributes part of her success to her fellow committee members.
“The handful of people at the committee have been great,” she said. “They have been a huge help and support.”
She also said the most upsetting part of the surgery was losing her hair, because she always had lots of hair before the operation.
She joked the award should not be called the Erin Debarro award, but the “bandana award, because I have to cover my head all the time—it's the Sinead O'Connor look.”

speech.para: Mrs Debarro's three sons all play with the Lions regularly—Christian is 17, Matthew is 13 and Mitchell is nine.

I had the pleasure of attending the Stirling Lions trophy night on 24 October this year. The club now presents the Erin Debarro award to players who show courage and never give up. Jordan Conti, an 18-year-old goalkeeper, won the award this year. On the night, I had the honour of presenting a Commonwealth Sport Achievement Award to Erin Debarro. She earned the award because of the long-term and multifaceted support she has provided, and is providing, to the soccer teams. Erin does everything from taking the uniforms home and washing them to assisting in the kitchen at the soccer club on games days and at social events. She is an aunty figure to many of the young players and their friends. She does lots for the club. Even at the trophy night to honour her, she decorated tables and blew up the balloons. She is a great inspiration to many in the club and is a real team player, excellent at motivating people to get involved. She is also a devoted wife and mother and a popular figure in the Macedonian community. A woman of Erin's stature in the community should be honoured, and it has been more than a pleasure here tonight to tell her tale of recovery and of the soccer club that rallied around her.

talk.start.para: —I rise this evening to speak on behalf of hundreds of thousands of residents and businesses in Victoria that are outraged at the Bracks Labor government's blatant dishonesty in breaking its election pledge and its written undertaking with the federal government to build the Scoresby Freeway without tolls, and on behalf of a large gathering of local residents who took the time to attend a public meeting in Lilydale in my electorate last Wednesday evening. Community leaders, including Shire of Yarra Ranges Councillor Clive Larkman and Mayor Alan Fincher, as well as President of the Lilydale Chamber of Commerce Alan Dobbin, attended and spoke to the large gathering. It was also great to see representatives from other business from further afield, such as Terry Paget from the Ringwood Chamber of Commerce and Industry.

speech.para: These residents are angered that prior to last year's state election Steve Bracks signed a memorandum of understanding to build a toll-free road as a condition of receiving the Commonwealth's $445 million contribution for the construction of the Scoresby Freeway. During last year's state election, Steve Bracks made the pledge a feature of his campaign day and night. In the dying days before the election, he wrote to residents in the eastern suburbs and said:

quote.para: Labor will build the Scoresby Freeway on time and on budget. These are not just election time promises. They are my firm commitments to you and your family, and they will be honoured.

speech.para: The families and businesses of Melbourne's outer east now know that Steve Bracks's word is worth nothing.

In the 205 days since the announcement of his backdown—that is, that he would put a toll on the road—he, his ministers and local members have stonewalled, hidden and dissembled. State Labor's excuses have ranged from the absurd to the laughable. At one point Steve Bracks blamed the drought, as if it were unique to Victoria. The state member for Evelyn, Heather McTaggart, in the local papers went so far as to blame the cost of the war in Iraq for Steve Bracks's lack of funding, apparently thinking that Victoria funds a defence force—something that would indeed be news to her constituents and other Victorians who would be under the impression that, since Federation, defence priorities have been a matter of national governance.

The member for Kilsyth, Dympna Beard, sums up the attitude and the arrogance of the Bracks Labor government in her frequent dismissive statements of the electorate. In the Maroondah Journal on 3 June this year she stated:

quote.para: .... the freeway is going to go ahead and it's going to be tolled and that's just not open to negotiation.

speech.para: Since Mr Bracks's toll backflip on 14 April this year there has been nothing but silence from another Labor leader, the member for Hotham. The name `Scoresby' has not passed his lips. His silence and his complete failure to take a position have not been lost on the people in the outer eastern suburbs and the Yarra Valley. That silence and failure to castigate Steve Bracks is, to the people of the outer east and the Yarra Valley, full confirmation that, like the Bracks Labor government, he supports tolls, supports the deceit and cares not one jot about the people of the outer east.

However, his 200-day silence was recently broken by some members on the other side of the House with the revelation of Labor's true agenda on Scoresby, which is clearly to pinch all the federal Scoresby money and spend it on roads on the other side of Melbourne.
