The member for Bendigo has confirmed in this House that he wants the federal component of the Scoresby money to be allocated to the Calder, in Bendigo. Last week Labor members from Ballarat and western Melbourne waved placards at a western highway intersection at Deer Park, with the Leader of the Opposition, attacking the federal government for not funding a $200 million bypass with the Scoresby money that was pledged to the outer eastern suburbs.

The breathtaking hypocrisy and dishonesty of this will not be lost on the people of the outer eastern suburbs and the Yarra Valley. Federal Labor made a pledge at the last election—it swore black and blue—that like us it wanted a toll-free Scoresby Freeway. Now it supports Steve Bracks's toll breach. On top of that, to add insult to injury, it now wants to ferry the money away from the eastern suburbs to the western suburbs in breach of Mr Bracks's commitment and its own commitment at the last federal election.

At least the residents know where they stand. Simon Crean and Steve Bracks are out of the same box. Both pledged a toll-free road and both have shown they cannot be believed. Simon Crean's word, like that of Steve Bracks, is not worth one red cent. When the member for Hotham stands in the eastern suburbs between now and the next election and promises more money for health or Medicare or education, the people of the east will remember the Scoresby. They will remember that every Labor promise in every policy area will be a Scoresby promise and will not be delivered. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Tomorrow evening I will be pleased to attend this year's presentation of the Sydney Peace Prize. This is the only international peace prize awarded in Australia and it has achieved global significance in terms of the support and recognition given to leaders for peace. The prize is awarded to an organisation or individual who has made a significant contribution to global peace, including improvements in personal security and steps towards eradicating poverty and structural violence.

speech.para: Past recipients of the Sydney Peace Prize include Mary Robinson, the former United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights; Sir William Deane; Xanana Gusmao; and Archbishop Desmond Tutu. This year the Sydney Peace Prize has been awarded to Dr Hanan Ashrawi and will be presented by the Premier of New South Wales, the Hon. Bob Carr. I commend the Sydney Peace Foundation on its choice and congratulate Dr Hanan Ashrawi on her selection. I had the pleasure of meeting Hanan Ashrawi in Palestine in January 2000. Hanan Ashrawi is an outspoken advocate of the Palestinian cause. Her selection arose from her commitment to human rights and to the peace process in the Middle East, and from her courage in speaking against oppression, against corruption and for justice.

She was born into a wealthy Christian Palestinian family and grew up in the West Bank city of Ramallah. In 1967, when Israeli forces invaded the West Bank, she was a student at the American University in Beirut. Hanan Ashrawi went on to gain a PhD in literature from the University of Virginia. Only in 1973 was she allowed to return to her homeland, where she became chair of the Department of English at Birzeit University. In 1974 Dr Ashrawi founded and led the Birzeit University legal aid and human rights action project to assist students and others suffering human rights abuses at the hands of the occupying Israeli forces.

She came to international attention in 1988 at the time of the first intifada. As a member of the Palestinian Diplomatic Committee and the Intifada Political Committee, Hanan Ashrawi became the face and voice of Palestinian people around the world. In 1991, as official spokesperson of the Palestinian delegation to the Middle East peace process, Hanan Ashrawi played a vital role in presenting the Palestinian case to the world community. With the establishment of the Palestinian Authority, she served as minister of higher education and for one year as head of the political committee. She is now a member of the Palestinian Legislative Council for Jerusalem. In 1998, in a move which shows her personal integrity, she resigned from the government in protest against political corruption and went on to found the Palestinian Initiative for the Promotion of Global Dialogue and Democracy. Its aims are the ending of Israeli occupation on humanitarian rather than historical or ideological grounds.

Hanan Ashrawi's influence in Palestinian and world politics flows from her intellect and her passionate support for human rights for the Palestinian people. She is neither male nor Muslim, and that closes many doors in Palestinian politics. As a Christian and a feminist, her pleas strike a chord in Western countries, and her focus on the human rights impact of the Israeli occupation of Palestine leaves her opponents in both Israel and Palestine without a defence against her arguments.

Hanan Ashrawi is an inspirational figure. In standing up for the cause of the Palestinian people, or standing against corruption and abuse of power, she sets an example of courage and integrity. As Dr Ashrawi said in accepting the Sydney Peace Prize:

quote.para: Women contribute to peace by sustaining life and making it meaningful. Women all over the world have to work against the forces of dehumanisation. Peace has to be embedded in human rights ...

speech.para: In the search for a just and lasting peace in the Middle East, the principles of democracy and human rights will prove more effective than bombs, bullets, bulldozers or dividing walls.

talk.start.para: —It is a great pleasure to be able to stand in this place tonight to celebrate the awards for Discovering Democracy achievements today. In July 2001 the Commonwealth awarded Discovering Democracy grants to schools throughout Australia. Today, Robyn Cleaver, the acting head of the Department of Society, Environment and Language at Narrogin Senior High School shared the national award for the year 9 Discovering Democracy achievement awards. These awards are given out to encourage the promotion, recognition and celebration of the outstanding achievements of teachers in the areas of civics and citizenship education.

speech.para: I have had the great pleasure to know Robyn Cleaver from the time I was elected to the electorate of Pearce in 1993, when she was then working as a teacher at Northam high school. Robyn is a dedicated secondary teacher who has always placed great emphasis on the importance of civics education within the school framework. Narrogin Senior High School is a regional government high school with 750 students, located approximately 2½ hours east of Perth. One-third of the students reside within the town, another third board at the Narrogin Residential College and another third bus into school every day from the outlying districts. It is a particular pleasure for me because the Narrogin Senior High School is my old school. So it was a double pleasure to see this award go to the school and in particular to Robyn Cleaver.

The school was awarded a grant of $7,500 to implement an action research project in civics and citizenship. The project, which makes a really interesting read, was called `Narrogin: past, present and future'. The project aimed to encourage citizens in the community, in particular the school community, to become involved in the future decisions of their town. It also aimed to encourage students to realise that a well-organised democratic decision-making process is crucial for citizens to become empowered. It encouraged a more direct link between the Narrogin Senior High School and the wider community to promote a positive image of the Narrogin students as active, interested and respectful citizens within their community. It also aimed to stimulate leadership roles within the school and the wider community.

One hundred and sixty students from the 2003 year 9 class conducted a survey of 600 people in the community. They analysed the data and published their findings in this very fine report. Youth forums were held with the assistance of the town of Narrogin. Students identified in those forums the need for a skate park, and a steering committee was formed. Eighteen months later, these students are still involved in the decision-making process, with the construction of the skate park commencing early next year.

One hundred and sixty of the year 9 students participating in the project were nominated for the 2002 WA Youth of the Year award and they were named finalists in the group citizenship category. The project involved many individuals and groups within the town of Narrogin, providing them with an opportunity to have their say. Narrogin—and I remember this well from my time living there with my family—is a town that, like so many of our rural towns in Australia, takes great pride in its sense of community. They are people who are prepared to work very hard to achieve their aims and to achieve the ambitions and aspirations of the town. This presentation really does examine the volunteer work and contribution that is made in a country town. The leadership provided by people such as Robyn Cleaver is crucial to assisting young people to reach their goals, to understand their responsibility as citizens and also to understand their rights. My congratulations go to Robyn and to all the students and teachers who participated in the project and guided the students in this report.

business.start.para: The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. I.R. Causley) took the chair at 9.40 a.m.

talk.start.para: —Last month Medicare turned 20 and, to celebrate this milestone, there were birthday parties thrown across the nation, including in my electorate of Bass. The reason that this birthday was so significant is that this government is killing Medicare, and it may not live to see the age of 21. In protest at the government's intention to destroy what has been a successful system that has given guaranteed health care to all Australians over two decades, Labor has been inundated with people wanting to sign petitions to register their remonstrations. In my electorate of Bass, I have already collected nearly 3,000 signatures from people who are fed up with the government's attacks on their health care system. These petitions are still coming in thick and fast. I now wish to table petitions with 2,619 signatures on behalf of those people who have signed them to formally register their protest.

speech.para: The people of Bass are protesting because nationally we have seen a 20 per cent drop in bulk-billing and an increase by 55 per cent in the amount that people have to pay to see a doctor. In Bass, the rate of bulk-billing has dropped 46 per cent with many families making decisions to see a doctor based on the amount of money that they have in the bank that day and not on their medical needs. It is no coincidence that there have been 10 million fewer bulk-billed consultations since this government took office. The Prime Minister has been well documented in his plans to destroy Medicare and has said that Medicare is a miserable, cruel fraud; a scandal; a total and complete failure; and an unmitigated disaster.

We need to let the Prime Minister know that the people of Bass disagree; they disagree because in Launceston alone there are very few doctors left who bulk-bill under anything other than special circumstances. The people of Bass have no choice but to either pay the increasing amounts of money to see a doctor or turn up to the emergency department at hospitals for minor ailments. Alternatively, they decide not to seek medical help at all and then they end up in their local hospital when their condition has deteriorated to that stage. Not only does this have an impact on the way that families manage their health care needs; it also has an impact on our already struggling public hospital system.

Labor created Medicare as a universal health care system to ensure that all Australians were treated fairly when they went to a doctor. Now Labor, along with a growing army of people across Australia, are the only ones standing between Medicare's survival and its complete obliteration by this government. I want to make sure that Medicare is here to look after the health needs of the people of Bass next year and for another 20 years, and I will not stand by and watch this government destroy it. Australians should know that they can take their children to a doctor without having to make the choice between buying food and using their entire budget on doctor's fees. The people of Bass are no longer interested in standing back and allowing this cash grabbing meanness to continue. The signing of these petitions in such great force is an indication of that. It is time that this government started listening to the community's needs and stopped imposing its draconian reform agenda on essential services, which continues to slug families in the hip pocket—these families that this government waxes lyrical about being there to support.
To the honourable speaker and members of the house of representatives assembled in parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House. The need to keep bulk billing for the families and communities of Bass.

We therefore pray that the House takes urgent steps to restore bulk billing by general practitioners and reject John Howard's plan to end universal bulk billing so all Australians have access to the health care they need and deserve.
from 2,167 citizens.

talk.start.para: —In December 2002, the Zurich District Attorney, Mr Nathan Landshut, investigated a fraud at Bank Leumi le-Israel, Switzerland. In the course of that investigation, Mr Rene Rivkin, the Sydney stockbroker, told Mr Landshut that a mystery 38 per cent stake in an Australian company called Offset Alpine Printing, which had enjoyed a $50 million insurance windfall, was owned by Bank Leumi, 81 per cent by him, seven per cent by Mr Graham Richardson and 12 per cent by Mr Trevor Kennedy. Mr Rivkin is the well-known Sydney stockbroker recently convicted of commercial malpractice who should be languishing in jail. Mr Graham Richardson is the former Labor minister. Mr Trevor Kennedy is the former media executive, a director of OzEmail who made millions out of its sale. It was announced in the Channel 9 Sydney program on the weekend, in an interview with one of his fellow directors, that he had left the country.

speech.para: Of course, these persons should be presumed innocent, at least until they have given their version of the story of share trading through the Swiss bank accounts revealed last week by the Australian Financial Review. The Australian Securities and Investments Commission is right to reopen its investigation into Offset Alpine Printing. I believe Rene Rivkin's admissions to the Swiss prosecutor raised serious questions under Australian security and tax laws. This tale of big money, political influence and so-called mates is one involving secrecy and other matters that require investigation into suspected breaches of our security laws. It raises fundamental questions about the efficacy of our laws. It also raises questions of public policy. As the Australian Financial Review wrote yesterday in one of its editorials, questions arise such as: how much help can our regulators expect from their foreign counterparts when they are investing suspected breaches of the law and the money trail ends up overseas? Can we expect foreign authorities to help us investigate suspected offences that are not offences under their own laws? Is there one law for the rich and another for the poor in this regard? Of course, in theory there is not; but in practice it does give rise to these serious questions.

I believe the Treasurer was right to remind the parliament that it is necessary to work through international forums such as the OECD to secure arrangements for international cooperation in the development of better laws. In addition, I believe that we need to look at aspects of our tax system that provide incentives for the rich to go to Switzerland and other places such as that with their millions, leaving middle income earners to foot the bills for roads, hospitals and other facilities. I also believe Australians are entitled to minimise their tax, and possibly even to use Swiss banks—but not willy-nilly. One suggestion was mentioned which has merit, but I will deal with that at another time. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —This morning I wish to pay tribute to the work done in my local community by the City of Bayswater, one of the local authorities in my electorate of Perth. The reason for drawing attention to the good work done by the City of Bayswater this morning is that, at the beginning of this month, it celebrated the 20th anniversary of its establishment as an authority. My congratulations on that anniversary go to Councillor Lou Magro, the Mayor of the City of Bayswater, and his councillors, and to the Chief Executive Officer of the City of Bayswater, Mario Carosella, and his officers. The City of Bayswater provides excellent services to the residents of the suburbs of Bayswater, Morley, Bedford, Embleton and Maylands—all of which are wholly contained in my electorate. Whilst the City of Bayswater has been in existence for only 20 years, its historical predecessors—the Shire of Bayswater and the Bayswater Road board—have been in existence since 1898. As a consequence, the relevant Bayswater local authority has been providing excellent local services to the people of Bayswater for over 100 years.

speech.para: One of the very excellent services provided by the City of Bayswater these days is the City of Bayswater's early settlers lunch, which is an annual event held at Hillcrest Oval—which is the home ground of the Bayswater-Morley Cricket Club, whose most famous son is Bob Massie. I am proud to be a vice patron of that club. The early settlers lunch pays tribute by way of care and respect to early settlers of the area of Bayswater. To get a ticket for the lunch you have to have been a resident for 40 years or more. In addition to this gesture, there is a long and extensive list of achievements which the City of Bayswater has effected for its residents. Perhaps the most recent is the establishment of the Bayswater Community Bank, a Bendigo Bank, in the old Bayswater town site. This is one of the most successful community banks established by the Bendigo Bank and the first to be established in Australia in a metropolitan area.

Earlier, in the 1990s, the City of Bayswater was instrumental in ensuring that the Morley Galleria, the largest regional shopping centre in the north of Perth, was established at the old Boans Store site, which was destroyed by fire in the 1980s. Other achievements include the establishment of the Bayswater Waves swimming pool, the restoration of Ellis House, the Riverside Gardens foreshore development, the Progress Street precinct development, the development of the old Bayswater town site, the establishment of the Gerry Leeuwangh Library in Morley, the preservation of the wetlands area now known as the Eric Singleton Bird Sanctuary, the restoration of Remembrance Park in Bedford, the restoration of the old parcels office at the Maylands Railway Station and the refurbishment of the Maylands Water Park. This is a considerable list of achievements by a first-class local authority giving excellent service to residents in my community.

talk.start.para: —The report of the Select Committee on the Recent Australian Bushfires was tabled in the main chamber this morning. Its principal focus was the summer 2003 fires, which ravaged some four million hectares across several states and caused widespread loss of property and, tragically, some loss of life. The worst hit areas were in New South Wales, Victoria and the ACT; yet many of the issues raised in the inquiry apply more broadly than to just the fires earlier this year. They apply to some of the other recent fires, including those of summer 2002, which had a bigger impact on my electorate in the Blue Mountains and the Hawkesbury region than the 2003 fires did.

speech.para: There were some very clear messages from more than 500 submissions to the committee. There were issues regarding the causes and responses necessary to avoid the kind of devastation that we saw earlier this year. The main evidence to the inquiry covered four areas. Firstly, the intensity of the fires was largely due—in addition to the adverse and extreme weather conditions—to a build-up of fuel due to inadequate hazard reduction in recent years. Secondly, the problems of suppression were exacerbated by inadequate access to national parks and the poor maintenance and, in some cases, deliberate destruction of fire trails. Thirdly, the disregard for local knowledge and expertise by central authorities in their approaches to fire prevention and suppression made management and suppression much more difficult and led to loss of morale by a lot of our firefighters. Fourthly, the slowness and inadequacy of early response to fires, particularly those around the ACT, led to the increased extent of the damage that we saw.

Many other issues were raised in this report—including organisation, communication, equipment and research—and were covered in some 59 recommendations. I will seek an opportunity at a later date to address these in more detail. I want to thank all of those who made a contribution to this report, and I thank the more than 500 people and organisations who made submissions. I want to particularly acknowledge those people in my electorate in the Blue Mountains and the Hawkesbury, representatives of the local fire brigades and other people who gave evidence at the public hearings. I want to also thank the many volunteers who, in addition to the paid staff, put their own lives at risk to protect life and property summer after summer. Without their magnificent efforts, the losses would have been far greater than they were.

talk.start.para: —One of my constituents wrote a note to my office in which he asked me to investigate his belief that the price of unleaded petrol is raised to coincide with social security paydays. I pursued the matter on his behalf with the ACCC, and their petrol price monitoring reveals some interesting data. The monitoring of petrol prices in the Sydney region in the period May to August 2003 showed that all 18 petrol price peaks occurred on a Thursday, with the most common day for low prices being a Tuesday. Unfortunately, they were unable to provide me with any data specific to the Illawarra region. My office then undertook a sample survey of four local petrol stations—one independent and three majors—over a four-week period to see if a similar pattern emerged. The results were very interesting and coincided with the ACCC data. Our local analysis showed that, firstly, the peaks in the price of unleaded petrol occurred overwhelmingly on Thursdays and, secondly, that the highest average cost of unleaded petrol was also on Thursdays, at 94.1c per litre.

speech.para: What is the explanation for the peaks and the highest prices for petrol on Thursdays? I would suggest that petrol retailers are acting to maximise their profits on a day when the bulk of social security recipients, like pensioners, receive their benefits and when workers across both public and private sectors traditionally get paid. I intend to draw the results of our small local survey to the attention of constituents and suggest that they avoid buying petrol on Thursdays. With the support of my local ALP branch members, I will endeavour to extend this sample survey to other areas of the electorate that I represent. It is also my intention to refer this data to the ACCC for their response. I will certainly be requesting that the ACCC add the Illawarra region to their regular petrol price monitoring system.

talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —I want to take this opportunity to defend Steve Irwin, who is a Sunshine Coast icon and really a world representative of Australia, against criticism from the Australian Labor Party for a payment of $175,000 by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service to the Steve Irwin wildlife park with respect to a campaign to boost Australia's quarantine and appreciation of it.

speech.para: We all know that Australia is an island continent. We know that many exotic diseases that exist elsewhere in the world are not in our country, and we also appreciate how vital it is that returning travellers to Australia are aware of Australia's quarantine rules and regulations to make sure that our nation remains protected. The sum of $175,000 was paid to the Steve Irwin wildlife park, not to Steve Irwin as an individual. I know Steve and Terri Irwin very well. I have known them ever since they employed three people, and they now employ over 300 people. They are very much part of the Sunshine Coast. They are very much part of our local economy and they have assisted our area to grow and develop.

The Steve Irwin wildlife park is an environmental trust established by Steve for the purchase of conservation land as a wildlife refuge for threatened and endangered species. The trust has already purchased land in parts of Queensland for this purpose. The criticism was that the $175,000 payment was for a day's work. The fee covers TV ads, posters, print ads and postcards from December 2002 until December 2003—not one day's work. The fee represents excellent value for money. Steve reduced the fee that he would usually charge, because he strongly believes in quarantine. Several people were looked at and tested by focus groups but Steve emerged as by far the most popular and credible candidate. Ninety per cent of recipients said that they rate quarantine as an important issue on the basis of TV ads. Four in five respondents believe that Steve is a credible spokesperson for quarantine and environmental issues.

AQIS believes the campaign has been an outstanding success because of the change in behaviour that it has generated. Officers have reported a significant number of returning Australian travellers declaring items of quarantine concern because of the TV ads. The Quarantine Matters! campaign will help spread an important message by telling all Australians about their quarantine obligations before they go overseas. It is a serious problem, demanding a serious response. That is why anyone caught smuggling these items into Australia now risks a fine of up to $60,000 or even jail. The federal government has boosted spending on our quarantine program. The opposition needs to be reminded: Quarantine Matters! Don't muck with it.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 3 November, on motion by Mr Williams:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: upon which Mr McClelland moved by way of amendment:

motion.para: That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

“whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for failing to ensure that federal age discrimination legislation contains the best standards of protection of older Australians, a failure which is consistent with its neglect of the human rights of all Australians, as evidenced by its introduction of legislation to weaken the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and other actions to wind back protections for Australian citizens”.

talk.start.para: —Prior to the last election this government spelt out its commitment to introducing anti age discrimination legislation. The Age Discrimination Bill 2003 and the Age Discrimination (Consequential Provisions) Bill 2003 fulfil that commitment. They will assist in modifying attitudes that deny Australians at either end of the age spectrum the right to fully participate in our society. The explanatory memorandum summarises the basic issue: attitudinal change is needed so that people are judged on their actual capacity, rather than age being used as a blunt proxy. Attitudinal change is needed so that people are not unfairly excluded from access to the whole range of social goods and activities.

speech.para: These bills are part of the government's wide-ranging response to an ageing population. They recognise the dignity of all Australians and the important contribution they make to the community. The bills' objectives are to: eliminate as far as possible discrimination on the basis of age within our society; ensure as far as practicable that everyone has the same rights before the law, regardless of age; allow appropriate positive discrimination, recognising the special circumstances of young and older persons; and promote community recognition and acceptance of the principle that people of all ages have the same fundamental rights.

A focal point of contemporary public debate is the fact that older people comprise an increasingly large section of the Australian community. According to Budget Paper No. 5 2002-03, otherwise known as the Intergenerational Report, in the past century the proportion of the population aged over 65 has risen from just over four per cent to nearly 12.5 per cent—one-eighth of the Australian population. By 2042 around 24.5 per cent of Australia's population is expected to be aged over 65—nearly one-quarter of the population. The United Nations Second World Assembly on Ageing concluded:

quote.para: We celebrate rising life expectancy in many regions of the world as one of humanity's major achievements ... This demographic transformation challenges all our societies to promote increased opportunities in particular for older people to realise their potential to participate fully in all aspects of life.

speech.para: I believe that the United Nations has got it right. The object of this proposed legislation is to respond to demographic change by removing barriers to the participation of older people in society, particularly in the work force, and changing negative stereotypes about older people, bearing in mind the international commitment to eliminate age discrimination.

Age discrimination is not very complex. It means treating someone less favourably than you otherwise would because of the person's age or imposing unreasonable conditions that disadvantage people of a certain age. We all know that age discrimination exists, but if we need additional confirmation, the Anti-Discrimination Board of New South Wales reports that age discrimination is the fourth most common ground for complaint, after issues of race, sex and disability. The states already have age discrimination legislation, but there is a gap in federal antidiscrimination law in relation to age.

There is federal legislation prohibiting discrimination on the basis of sex, race and disability. There is, however, no wide-ranging federal prohibition on discrimination on the basis of age. This leaves individuals vulnerable and it also may, and probably does, contribute to a perception that age discrimination is less serious than other forms of discrimination. Accordingly, the very passage of these bills should be seen as an important step towards reaffirming and enhancing the principle of equal opportunity in the Australian community.

As I said earlier, we all know that age discrimination exists, and further empirical confirmation has been amply provided by several studies and reports published in recent years. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission report Age matters stated:

quote.para: In many cases older workers were able to identify clearly that their age is the primary reason they failed to obtain employment, promotion or training.

speech.para: Surveys reveal the persistence of common but unfounded perceptions that older workers have outdated skills, are hard to train, inflexible, unwilling to change and lacking in technological experience. Age discrimination is particularly notable in relation to employment. According to HREOC's Age matters report, this is a significant problem in other areas of life as well, including income support, health care, accommodation, insurance, financial services and concessions. The commission found that age discrimination is a major barrier to full participation by both older and younger Australians in our society. It recommended that the parliament should enact a more rigorous and effective regime; one which would prevent and remedy acts of discrimination based on age.

Similarly, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Workplace Relations reported that in many cases age discrimination has contributed to the unemployment of older workers—unemployment that has led to psychological and financial problems—and that loss of self-esteem and confidence amongst the older unemployed was found to be responsible for a range of serious health problems for unemployed people and their families. Findings like this cannot be ignored.

Apart from the fundamental issues of equal opportunity and human rights, there are broader social factors underscoring the need for this legislation. Thanks to public health advances, improved lifestyle habits and modern technology, Australians are living longer. Despite this better health and improved longevity, we are retiring from work earlier and having fewer children. The proportion of people participating in the labour force is decreasing relative to those outside the paid work force. Australia does need to address future labour force needs and manage the complex aspects of an increasingly ageing population.

We already have one of the lowest participation rates of workers aged over 55 within the OECD. Commentators have said we should not just think about a glass ceiling but a grey ceiling. The relationships between economic growth, population growth, work force participation and growth in productivity are fundamental. Expanding the number of working older Australians has the potential to significantly impact on our future labour force growth and work force participation.

Access Economics has reported that wages earned and demand generated by working older Australians who would have been retired under current trends would increase the growth rate of the economy, generating more jobs. Older Australians who keep working would also keep paying taxes instead of receiving pensions. They would increase revenues and reduce outlays. This legislation is a step towards addressing the complex task of trying to offset the diminishing number of labour force participants. Workers, regardless of age, should be viewed and treated as individuals based on what they can bring to the workplace. This legislation will encourage community recognition of the contributions that both older and younger Australians can make to our work force and the contribution of knowledge, wisdom, corporate memory, experience and enthusiasm can only be a benefit to our workplaces.

There is also an important psychological argument for making it easier and more attractive for older Australians to participate in the work force. People are living for decades beyond the traditional retirement age. It is desirable that people in their 60s and beyond remain both physically and mentally active so that they can maximise their enjoyment of life. Maintaining active and regular participation in the community through work will help older Australians avoid being isolated or socially excluded and suffering a diminished sense of self-worth.

I have focused thus far on older people and discrimination. Indeed, this is what is at the forefront of current concerns in Australian society. But discrimination against younger people on account of their age also occurs. This legislation will act against such discrimination. It will make it unlawful, for example, for education authorities to discriminate on the basis of age in relation to admission or expulsion or access to benefits. It will also make it unlawful to discriminate on the basis of age when providing or refusing access to accommodation in rental properties or when evicting people from their lodgings.

It is important to note that before framing this legislation the government committed to comprehensive consultation with stakeholders, and it has met this commitment. There are two main arms through which the bills will work to prevent age discrimination. The first arm will make certain discrimination unlawful; the second arm will seek to counter negative attitudes about certain age groups through community education. The bills will make it unlawful in certain spheres to discriminate on the basis of age, either directly or indirectly. They will bring such unlawful age discrimination under the jurisdiction of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission.

The spheres in which it will be unlawful to discriminate on the basis of age are employment and employment related matters; education; access to premises, including public places and public transport; the provision of goods, services, facilities and accommodation; the disposal of land; the administration of Commonwealth laws and programs; and requests for information on which age discrimination might be based. This is not an exhaustive coverage of all areas where age discrimination might occur, but community consultation has indicated that these are the major areas of concern and the areas that are generally the subject of existing antidiscrimination laws in Australia.

A complaint of unlawful age discrimination may be made to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. Age discrimination complainants will have the same rights as exist in relation to complaints of discrimination on the grounds of sex, race or disability. Complaints will be handled either by conciliation or, if conciliation is unsuccessful or inappropriate, by action in a court. It will become an offence to publish an advertisement indicating an intention to commit unlawful age discrimination or to victimise a person because they made a complaint of age discrimination to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission.

In pursuit of the bills' educational objects, the commission is given substantial educational functions. These include promoting understanding, acceptance and compliance with the anti age discrimination legislation, undertaking research and educational programs and preparing and publishing guidelines for avoiding age discrimination. The enactment of this legislation will help to mitigate negative stereotypes about older and younger people and promote attitudinal change in the community.

Discrimination usually has negative connotations—and this has been the focus of my speech until now—but there are certain circumstances where treating people differently according to their age is appropriate. A range of exemptions in the principal bill will mean that, in some circumstances, whilst the treatment of a person may constitute discrimination, it will not amount to unlawful age discrimination. These exemptions are intended to ensure a balance between preventing inappropriate discrimination while allowing for legitimate distinctions. This was an important factor in consultations with business and the wider community. For example, an exemption applies where there is broad community agreement such as for limits on children's access to alcohol, tobacco or adult theme films, or where a person seeking employment—notwithstanding their qualifications, experience and any other relevant factors—is judged to be unable to carry out the inherent requirements of the job because of their age. The applicant cannot complain of discrimination if they were not given a job that they could not do.

Of course, in some cases, older and younger people are discriminated against quite openly and to their advantage in the provision of bona fide benefits to people of a particular age. There are measures intended to meet age related needs and measures intended to reduce disadvantage. This positive discrimination will be exempt from the operation of the legislation to allow for the continuation, for example, of discounts for goods and services for the holders of seniors cards, special employment and assistance programs for young people or those of mature age, and welfare services for young homeless people that are intended to meet a need arising out of the age of such people.

This legislation is intended to strike the right balance between, on the one hand, banning age discrimination and, on the other, the need to ensure sufficient flexibility to allow for situations where age has particular policy significance. The government hopes to send a message not just to employers and policy makers but also to the community at large that generalised and unfounded negative stereotypes about younger and older Australians have no place in a fair and equitable Australian society.

Newspaper commentators have described the government's anti age discrimination proposals as welcome and as a sensible and well-balanced approach in keeping with the spirit and reality of the times. I believe that the proposals are an important step forward. I also note that there is a well-argued report by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee into the provisions in the bills—in particular, with regard to the definition of a dominant reason for doing an act and specifying what should be considered in determining whether a practice is reasonable in the circumstances. The report does raise important issues regarding exemptions, the funding of HREOC and an extension to the coverage of the bill. I believe that this report will be treated seriously by the government, and I commend the bills to the House.

talk.start.para: —I too would like to speak in this cognate debate on the Age Discrimination Bill 2003 and the Age Discrimination (Consequential Provisions) Bill 2003, because I think that it is a very important step for our nation to be introducing legislation which addresses the important issue of age discrimination. In this country we do have quite a proud record of legislation that protects against discrimination on different grounds and it is a welcome addition to add age as one of the other grounds upon which discrimination is prohibited to assist people in all fields of life—education, employment or elsewhere.

speech.para: Identifying the fact that age is a consideration people take into account when offering services or jobs or other opportunities is relevant; it is a recognition of how our society works, and it is welcome that there is in the Age Discrimination Bill 2003 in particular some focus on older Australians. I would not like any of my further comments, which are going to be critical of aspects of this proposed legislation, to be taken to be a criticism of the core changes that we do believe are a step in the right direction. Clearly the government has paid quite a lot of attention to and put a lot of energy into making sure that older Australians get protection, particularly in employment, through this legislation, and I think that is important.

We should acknowledge—and I think this legislation recognises the fact—that older Australians do have a lot to contribute to our society and that it is not appropriate to suggest, if they have been retrenched, that once people are 45 or 50 they will not be worthy of being employed for the next 10 or 15 or 20 years of their lives. Unfortunately, many of us have a lot of experience in our electorates of people from middle age onwards being retrenched and often finding it very difficult to gain employment after that, and I think that these bills set out some useful guidelines and make a very clear statement that it is not appropriate to deny people opportunities because they are a certain age. I think that is welcome.

My main concerns, and the points that I would like to focus on mostly in my speech, centre around the fact that I think there is a gap in this legislation which is quite significant because, if you are going to talk about age discrimination, you should look at the whole spectrum, and that means that discrimination against young people should be taken into account as well as discrimination against older people. There are some significant exemptions which mean that the sorts of discrimination that young people experience are not going to be dealt with if these bills are enacted. That is of great concern to us. Certainly, as a former shadow minister for children and youth, my particular concerns for young people in Australia need to be flagged here.

I am concerned—as I am sure would surprise no-one in this House—about the specific exemption that is continuing for youth wages. I think that there should be a preference where possible for us to be able to say that all Australians should be treated equally in the workplace. In an ideal world we would actually have people paid according to their skill level, not according to their age. It is not a novel idea to talk about competency based wage systems; it is something that many people across the community—in the business sector, in the union sector and elsewhere—have been arguing for, and I think it is a shame that, when we addressed this issue as a community and the government consulted with the community, this was expressly excluded. By even excluding it as an issue in the consultation process, it means that the government was not prepared to listen to views in the community about whether it is appropriate or not. I find that really a very disappointing part of the process.

There are, of course, lots of arguments that people make in different directions about the pros and cons of youth wages, but I think it is an extraordinary thing to have a consultation process on age discrimination and not be prepared to listen to people's views on this matter. It means that in this House it is important for me to record a concern that I believe these issues should be discussed and that there should not be some automatic exemption for them. I have spoken previously on this subject in the House in 1998 or 1999. When I was first elected there was a youth employment bill and I argued that the government denied that youth wages were discriminatory. So this is not an issue that they regard as constituting discrimination—that is, treating one person differently to another because of a particular ground.

Now, by specifically exempting youth wages, they have proved my point. They are discriminatory. They do require a particular exemption. The general provisions of this bill will be enforced unless that exemption is there, and we should not kid ourselves about that. We might say—as I know many on the other side do—that although youth wages are discriminatory, there are other reasons why they might be appropriate. That is something that the government are quite welcome to argue, but it seems to me that they are not really prepared to have the strength of their convictions tested in any way, because they are not prepared to consult the community on this very issue which does have a lot of impact on our community.

I do not mean that young people in all circumstances should be paid the same as adults. That would be ridiculous. In fact, the newest and least experienced person on day one of the job should not necessarily be paid an adult wage. But I do believe—and many of us have many of these people in our electorates—that a 20-year-old who runs a shop on Saturday morning, is responsible for opening and closing the shop, is there on her own for the entire day and is responsible for the till and the banking should be paid for those responsibilities. If an owner of a business is happy to leave a 20-year-old in charge of those duties, then they should also be prepared to pay them for the skills and responsibility that they are clearly exercising.

It is a particular concern for young adults who are trying to provide for families and who are trying to make their way in life to be paid these lower rates of pay. Although we all know that many young people work while they are still living at home and while they are studying and that they might work for less than 15 hours a week—I think about 75 per cent of young people work for less than 15 hours a week—many other young people, who often get forgotten in this debate, are still trying to provide for children, set up a family and set up a house. The fact that they happen to be 18 or 19 when doing that should not be used against them if they are required in their employment to exercise the skills that adults are.

The idea that everyone will take on adult responsibilities, whether in the workplace or in the family, at a particular age is a nonsense. The introduction of an age discrimination bill should highlight that to people. But it seems to me that young people are still left out in this process. It is interesting that, when we are having a debate elsewhere about how difficult it is becoming for young people to get into the housing market—and our Treasurer in particular seems to be interested in this—we are not prepared to look at the income that young people are able to earn or whether we should really revisit this debate about what is appropriate for young people. If they are taking on the responsibilities of adults, should they not be being paid in that way as well?

Another particular gap in this legislation is an issue that was, as I understand it, consulted on, and that was the question of age based harassment. Feedback was given, and I think that the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee that also looked at this draft legislation did make recommendations about it, certainly in the minority report. I know that evidence was given to them. This question is one that could have an impact across all age groups. We do hear a growing, and disturbing, number of reports, particularly from older women, of harassment based primarily on their age but perhaps combined with their gender. We all know that in the workplace the people who are most vulnerable to harassment are the newest and youngest employees, and leaving this out of the bill has made a significant point about the importance we place on this issue.

That is disappointing, because I think that harassment in the workplace, victimisation of apprentices and all sorts of other inappropriate behaviour really could have been covered in this legislation. Young women who are being harassed because of their gender may still be able to make a complaint under the Sex Discrimination Act, but it seems to me that this would have been an appropriate bill in which to make a more comprehensive spread of protections, and that would have acknowledged what is a community problem—that is, that a large number of young people are harassed, whether it is in their jobs, in seeking housing, in trying to get into the rental market or in trying to get into educational services. We do see young people regularly treated quite badly, and it is something about which we as a community could have afforded to say, `We do not think this is acceptable and the legislation is going to cover it.'

We also know in this area that more than nine times out of 10 people never make complaints and never formalise them, but the fact that the law is there as a statement of what is inappropriate is a useful tool. It is useful for educating people and to be able to say that we as a community do not find this behaviour acceptable. It is disappointing, and I hope that in the future it might be able to be revisited. It is no reason for Labor not to support the provisions that are there, but we certainly want to make clear that we would have liked an additional number of matters to be covered in this legislation. The shadow Attorney-General, Robert McClelland, has made those points and moved some second reading amendments to try to highlight them.

The final point I want to make is with respect to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. This bill gives additional responsibilities to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission but, at the same time, the government says in its explanatory memorandum that there is no financial impact or cost impact of introducing this piece of legislation. I want to put on the record my concerns that the human rights commission has been under attack for a long time by this government. It has had its funding cut and its powers limited. There have been many attempts—one is still before the House or the Senate—to limit its powers even further. While we welcome the fact that the government sees an ongoing role for the human rights commission in administering this sort of legislation, if they insist on not giving the commission sufficient resources to implement its new charter, it will really be worth nothing. I find it disappointing that, if the government is going to add this additional role, they have not seen it as appropriate to look again at the resource issues.

The government is still seeking to abolish the role of the Sex Discrimination Commissioner and, as we know, has tried to stop the human rights commission having the power to participate in court proceedings, unless it has had the specific permission of the Attorney-General. Since 1996, the government has cut the budget of the human rights commission by 40 per cent in real terms. That is an extraordinary thing to do, and to expect that they will be able to conduct themselves and comply with all of their various obligations within that tight budgetary constraint is quite ridiculous. So I express some reservations about giving the human rights commission new powers and a new act to administer when they are struggling under the current financial arrangements and restrictions that the government has put on them.

My final point is that I welcome this development in the discrimination laws of this country. There are some major issues that have not been dealt with, particularly the concerns of young people; the issue of harassment, particularly in the workplace; and my reservations that the human rights commission is being given more duties but less power and fewer resources. If we are serious about this, we need to give them the tools to be able to promote and administer this piece of legislation. I hope that in the future or in any review in the future, those issues will be taken account of.

talk.start.para: —There are a number of important measures for the government to consider—and the Age Discrimination Bill 2003 and associated bill is one of them—in respect of improving the respect that older people have in our community and their feeling of self-worth. Amongst those that I have mentioned in recent debate is, firstly, the need to reconsider the abolition of compulsory retirement ages around the states and, in some indirect fashion, in the Commonwealth. Secondly, there is the need to review the superannuation arrangements with respect to older Australians, especially their entitlement to accumulate or contribute to superannuation, and age limits in that regard. Thirdly, there is the need for a program of public education, through the media, the ministry and other administrative arrangements, to ensure that older Australians have the feelings of self-worth and recognition that are the right of all Australians. Finally, there is a need for legislation of the type that is currently before the House. This legislation has been somewhat long in coming; nonetheless, it is welcome, it is significant and it is an important tool in ensuring that our older Australians and their contributions to society are duly and properly recognised.

speech.para: There has been some debate, from both an economic and a social point of view, about the position of older Australians in our community in recent times. The Treasurer's Intergenerational Report and the 2002-03 Budget Paper No. 5 provided a detailed analysis of the consequences of the ageing of our population. From the same point of view, but starting at the other end—what I would call the mewling end of the age continuum—the issue of fertility gives rise to a question as to whether or not it is best for economic and fiscal arrangements to try to address that end of the spectrum rather than the other end. I believe it is appropriate to have a double-pronged approach and that this legislation is part of such a constructive approach.

Another important contribution is a document released in January 2001 by Access Economics, called Population ageing and the economy. A further important document is The recruitment of older Australian workers: a survey of a high growth industry. Some of the information from those documents was, importantly, mentioned by the member for Mackellar—and I commend her contribution to this debate not just now but over the years—and has been mentioned in the explanatory memorandum and in other public debate before today. I would also like to mention briefly the recent UN Second World Assembly on Ageing conference in Madrid, Spain, which issued a declaration stating:

quote.para: We celebrate rising life expectancy in many regions of the world as one of humanity's major achievements—

speech.para: This is a point I made a little while ago—

quote.para: We recognize that the world is experiencing an unprecedented demographic transformation and that by 2050 the number of persons aged 60 years and over will increase from 600 million to almost 2,000 million and the proportion of persons aged 60 years and over is expected to double from 10 per cent to 21 per cent. The increase will be greatest and most rapid in developing countries where the older population is expected to quadruple during the next 50 years. This demographic transformation challenges all our societies to promote increased opportunities, in particular for older persons to realize their potential to participate fully in all aspects of life.

speech.para: The Intergenerational Report indicated that the ageing of the population will dramatically increase the number of older people in our communities, with significant implications for our economy generally. While the total population of labour force age is projected to grow by just 14 per cent, the number of people aged 55 to 64 is projected to increase by more than 50 per cent over the next two decades. That report also noted that in 2002 the proportion of people aged over 65 to people of traditional labour force age—15 years to 64 years—was 19 per cent. That is projected to rise to almost 41 per cent by 2042.

It follows that the economic considerations of an ageing work force and a population in which there are many more older Australians relying for support on a shrinking pool of workers—so far as the taxation system and public welfare are concerned—are a major impetus for legislative reform and parliamentary debate. The ACTU and the Business Council of Australia have examined this issue, and they have issued a joint report entitled Age can work: the case for older Australians staying in the workforce. That report resulted in Katie Lahey and Sharan Burrow, the respective heads of those organisations, commenting, `As a result of demographic changes, while there are currently six working Australians supporting each retired person, by 2025 this ratio will be one to three.'

In addition to those economic and social considerations, it is clear from other reports that have been made available, from the examination of these issues and, indeed, from our own experience as representatives in our electorates that there has been and remains in Australia age discrimination in the existing work force. The report Age counts of June 2002 indicated that, and the HREOC report Age matters made similar observations. Planning for retirement, a July 2003 Senate select committee report on superannuation, provided extensive evidence of age based discrimination in the work force.

One of the oft quoted studies was by Drake Consulting, which found that, of the top 500 human resource executives, none would choose to employ managers and executives in their 50s and 65 per cent said this group would be the first to go in the event of retrenchments. Other findings included that 62 per cent choose their executives from the 31 to 40 age group, only 23 per cent prefer those in the 41 to 50 age bracket and almost 16 per cent opt for 20- to 30-year-olds. Drake formed the conclusion that the problem had been getting worse and noted that there are indications that ageism has grown in Australian business. In 1999, it was noted, ageism was concentrated in the top companies, but it seems to have cascaded down to medium sized businesses. Bearing in mind the Australian Financial Reviewreport today indicating the wage structures of senior executives in some of these companies, it is a disgrace that some of these people are not taking a more constructive role in dealing with this important issue of discrimination.

A University of New South Wales academic from the Research Centre on Ageing and Retirement commented that Australians tend to confuse age with a lack of acuity and are overwhelmed with respect for newness, novelty and technology. We have not paid due respect to the wisdom that age brings. I would pause to say this: the wisdom of age is something that cannot be underestimated. Over time and through history it is older members of the community who have been the main repositories of what may humbly be called wisdom. Often it is wisdom that is the saving grace of many societies, groups and even families. We see that when we look at family structures in very settled societies, of which there are many communities exemplified in Australia. The Italian community is a very good example of that.

Families which respect their older members—their grandparents and great-grandparents—seem to be stronger and more cohesive than others. So this whole approach of ageism, adopted by what might be described as flashy executives, is something we need to look at very carefully. It is therefore very appropriate that this federal parliament, as a result of the detailed reports that have been prepared, examined and acted upon, take action in this important area of social endeavour and constructive improvement to make a better and happier society.

Let me look briefly at some aspects of this legislation. The Age Discrimination Bill 2003 sets out the objects in section 3. I will refer to them and some parts of the act, briefly, because I have experience in the administration of a statute such as this. For six years I was a judicial officer in the Equal Opportunity Tribunal of New South Wales and, subsequently, the Administrative Decisions Tribunal of New South Wales. In the course of the administration of that tribunal and my work as a judicial officer I frequently had to decide cases involving age discrimination. Therefore, I know it is important to ensure that the legislation put in place by the parliament is appropriate for the purpose which the objects in the statute are intended to bring about and that the legislation itself achieves the objects that are described. I will say more about that in a moment.

So, what are the objectives? They are stated in the statute, and that is important—having regard for the provisions of interpretation legislation—because courts are entitled to know and must have regard for these objectives in determining the construction of the statutes, in their application to ordinary cases and also in the application of the Age Discrimination Act to the particular facts of a case. First, the bill seeks to eliminate as far as possible discrimination against persons on the ground of age in the areas of work; education; access to premises; the provision of goods, services and facilities; accommodation; the disposal of land; the administration of Commonwealth laws and programs; and requests for information. The first comment I would make about that is that the range and scope of the bill are broad. The bill covers almost every conceivable area of endeavour. I appreciate there has been some criticism by some organisations that the scope of the bill could be broader—I will come to those criticisms in a moment—but the general tenor of the bill is clear.

Second, the bill seeks to ensure as far as practicable that any person has the same rights to equality before the law, regardless of age, as the rest of the community. Third, it seeks to allow appropriate benefits and other assistance to be given to people of a certain age, particularly younger and older persons, in recognition of their particular circumstances. It is important to note that the bill will not be applied willy-nilly, as it were; it will be applied in cases where there may be special circumstances requiring a younger person as distinct from an older person—for example, if heavy lifting is required. There are also some trades and areas of employment where young people are more appropriate than older people.

Fourth, the bill seeks to promote recognition by and acceptance within the community of the principle that people of all ages have the same fundamental rights. Here I mention again the third objective that I touched on in my opening comments. It is absolutely necessary that the government do not just sit on their hands and that the minister, in particular, does not just sit on his or her hands—I am not commenting on any particular minister—but, rather, act in conjunction with this legislation, by way of public education, to make sure that the broader Australian community understands fully the implications of this legislation and that the respect that older Australians deserve is achieved not just through this legislation but through an improvement in the public profile of and respect for older Australians. Finally, the bill seeks to respond to demographic change by removing barriers to older people participating in society, especially the work force, and by changing negative stereotypes about older people, bearing in mind the international commitment to eliminate age discrimination reflected in the political declaration adopted in Madrid, Spain, on 12 April 2002 by the Second World Assembly on Ageing—and I have already quoted from that declaration.

Section 14 of the bill describes the nature of discrimination. Section 15 deals with indirect discrimination. I am not going to go into the details of what is direct and what is indirect discrimination other than to say that the High Court has on several occasions examined the question of the difference between direct and indirect discrimination. Often indirect discrimination can be as insidious as direct discrimination—insidious because it is harder to prove and more difficult to recognise. Often people are discriminated against by deceitful people who are not prepared to come out and say what they really believe or think; they try to hide their real motives in discriminating against people. That is why the laws relating to indirect discrimination are important. I mention that to show that the bill does cover both direct and indirect discrimination.

Section 18 deals with the important area of discrimination in employment. I will deal with this section only because the other sections that deal with various other topics, as mentioned in the objectives of the bill that I have just outlined, deal with those areas in the same fashion as section 18 deals with discrimination in work. Subsection (1) states:

quote.para: It is unlawful for an employer or a person acting or purporting to act on behalf of an employer to discriminate against a person on the ground of the other person's age:
(a) in the arrangements made for the purpose of determining who should be offered employment; or
(b) in determining who should be offered employment; or
(c) in the terms or conditions on which employment is offered.

speech.para: Subsection (2) deals with the maintenance of employment and also the dismissal of an employee. So all aspects of employment are covered: the engagement, the terms of the employment and the dismissal. The legislation is therefore comprehensive in relation to dealing with aspects of employment and discrimination, both direct and indirect, in relation to age discrimination in the workplace. It is therefore to be highly commended, and I do not understand the opposition disagreeing with those contentions.

Let me come to some of the criticisms that have been suggested in relation to this matter. Firstly, some significant interest groups have commented that this proposal would `simply create havoc among businesses trying to employ the most suitable people'. That is the comment of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry. I would respect what the ACCI had to say on most issues, but I do not respect the position that they have adopted in relation to the age discrimination legislation.

There ought to be in our community and among the business community of this country proper respect for the contribution that older Australians can make to this community, to businesses and to the work force in those businesses. I am pleased that this legislation has paid scant regard to those objections and is getting on with the job of making sure that business and business executives comply with both the spirit and the letter of the law.

As soon as we start allowing exemptions based on the discretion of a senior executive about whether or not an aged person is more suitable than a younger person, a woman is more suitable than a man or vice versa or whether a person of one race is more suitable than a person of another race or a person of one colour is more suitable than a person of another colour—discretion in matters of this type—the law becomes a laughing stock. We do need consistency; we do need a fair and reasonable approach to these matters, and that is set out in the legislation.

Another objection has come from the Council of Ageing, which suggested that some exemptions ought to have been included in the legislation but were not. This seems to have been taken up in the amendment proposed by the opposition, which appears to seek further deferral of the legislation so that their proposals can be considered. I will say this about the opposition's position: if they are really calling for a further consideration of matters such as the `best standards of protection of older Australians' and a failure to consider the human rights of all Australians then they are really calling for a delay of this important legislation yet again. But that is one of the very criticisms they made about the legislation in the first place. In short, the opposition's amendment exposes them as hypocritical and as having a hollow concern for older Australians in relation to this important improvement to our laws. I support the legislation. It is an important piece of social policy legislation and deserves to be passed through the House and the Senate without further amendment. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The Age Discrimination Bill 2003 and the Age Discrimination (Consequential Provisions) Bill 2003 have come about in a particular context—that is, the changed demographics that are evident in Australia and that are considered will have significant effects in the future for the whole of our work force, not just for those people who are aged and part of that work force. This legislation also has a series of ramifications across almost every part of government.

speech.para: We have seen in the last year or so the Treasurer attempt to use that change in demographic circumstances to argue that there should be an increase in cost in the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, because there will be an effective doubling—from about 12 per cent to 25 per cent—in the aged category of Australia's population. In the past we used to term it as the pensionable category: 65 years of age for men and 60 years of age for women. But progressively we are ending up with a situation where, for both men and women, the pensionable age or the retirement age would normally be seen as being 65.

Some women regard themselves as having spent their lives well in not only bringing up their families but also supporting those families through the work that they did in partnership with their husbands. One could argue that these women expended far more effort than their husbands did: they had charge of most household matters and they brought up the children, as well as being breadwinners. A number of women in the community thought that it was unfair to make this change to their retirement age. They thought there was a positive discrimination which took into account the fact that so much extra had been done by women, enabling them to retire at 60 or so.

What we see in this legislation is a redrawing of the landscape in terms of the expectations of people who are aged. What we do not see in this legislation is any direct Commonwealth action, as far as I am aware, in terms of the practical realities of what you do with Commonwealth public servants who are 55 and over or indeed what you do with Commonwealth public servants who are one day short of turning 55 and who retire 10 years before they could be expected to do so. If they delay their retirement until later they can have another 10 years of service in Commonwealth employ, yet their superannuation benefit will be virtually no different from what it would be if they were to retire a day before they turned 55. As far as I am aware, there is no Commonwealth government legislation which attempts to address this particular problem. We have seen people serving this parliament, in both the House of Representatives and the Senate, who have retired early because of that. In the past when we used to have more Commonwealth drivers, we saw many retire at age 55 because they could not see any continuing benefit, apart from their continuing wage. We have seen in case after case—

talk.start.para: (Mr Mossfield)—Order! Is the member for Mackellar seeking to ask a question?
—Yes, I am.
—Will the member for Blaxland allow a question?
—Absolutely.

—I ask the member for Blaxland whether or not he would point out that this superannuation scheme about which he is speaking is closed now and that the other superannuation schemes that are in place no longer have this impediment to remaining at work and becoming a Monday to Friday employee?

—I take the member for Mackellar's point. The scheme may be closed but there are still people in employ who are in fact in that scheme. There are still Commonwealth public servants who, when they have reached that point of decision, take a decision in their own interest because they cannot see the point or merit of going further. We know that that particular scheme was closed. We also know that the other avenues that have been made available to people—the alternatives—do not have that particular effect. But there still has not been any direct means of addressing it, apart from closing the scheme. The government is saying that it needs to take action for the community at large and to encourage people in the community at large, including private businesses, as well as its own instrumentalities, to take note of this legislation and—except for a particular range of circumstances—not inhibit the employment of people who are past normal retirement age. But there is still this fundamental anomaly that Australia is losing Commonwealth public servants of great capacity, skill and experience because of the arrangements that we have made.

speech.para: I still think, despite the fact that that has been closed, that no compensatory mechanism has been found to induce those people to stay on. We know that a previous set of legislation that has been passed by the government has put out an inducement for people to stay on longer. What the government sought to do was to say that, if people choose to retire later, they can build up a credit with regard to the payments that they would otherwise have got from the Commonwealth in terms of pensions and, in building up that credit, they can seek to have a better retirement period than they would otherwise have had. It is sensible to redraw the balance in Australia in terms of age discrimination, because for too long we have deprived people—and this is particularly the case in government instrumentalities—from exercising their abilities, powers and intelligence and from drawing on their experience at a time when they are most fruitful in terms of the advice they could give to government or when the government could draw down on that experience to the benefit of both the government and the people of Australia. We have seen that across a range of other industries.

However, we have another set of problems that are building significantly. If you look at the demand or the need—and therefore the correlative demand—for keeping people in the work force, you not only need a mechanism to encourage them to stay longer and have a better pension benefit, you would also be sensible to do what this government has not been sensible enough to do and put in place a superannuation mechanism that would not only prohibit people effectively acting against their own interests to go further but also encourage people to continue to invest for a more extended retirement, because they would wish to work for longer if the rate was greater than nine per cent. When we were in government we pledged to move the nine per cent—and we were the ones who moved it from three to six to nine and legislated that effectively—to 12 per cent and then in a further step later to 15 per cent. The reason we did that is that we recognised that people's expectations in terms of retirement income would be better met, and the increased costs would be better able to be met, if you had a higher level of contribution. We could therefore entice people to stay in the work force longer if the longterm benefit that would accrue to them for their retirement years would be greater.

The other particular element that is important here is that people are living longer—significantly longer. They have a longer prospective period in the work force, and they also have a much longer time in retirement. It is therefore sensible to give people the options that, if they wish to do so, they can stay in the work force longer than they previously would have done and that they can seek to use this Age Discrimination Bill to try and stop an employer throwing them out the door if they are still entirely capable of doing that job. Indeed, the bill could stop them being unfairly dismissed. There is an interesting balance in this. There is a great deal of discussion in the second reading speech and the EM about the proper balance with regard to people who are aged and about a proper balance in terms of their position in the work force. I argue that that proper balance was not there when the government attempted to put through more than 12 pieces of legislation regarding the original Workplace Relations Act—and the core of them, which they have been attempting to put through over and over again, is the unfair dismissals legislation. This is about stopping unfair dismissals on the basis of age and encouraging people to continue to contribute to the Australian community.

I alluded to another set of problems that are increasingly becoming evident. The fact is that we have not as a society adequately or sufficiently invested in apprenticeships. They have been transmogrified into Australian traineeships.
