What that means of course for most people who have had to undertake them is that the previous commitment of employers—whether it be employers like Telstra or the State Rail Authority—is no longer evident. Those big institutions are not training large numbers of young people in full apprenticeships. Major Australian companies which in the past had large apprenticeship programs have substituted traineeship programs and have the expectation that others will provide the education that is needed for them.

There is a corollary to this. Not only have we had a decade-long movement towards decreasing the number of people in apprenticeships—and, since 1996, a dramatic change to the nature of that training—we also have an age problem across Australia in just about every trade one can imagine. It is not only the farmers who have a significant problem in terms of their average age. From memory, I think 58 years old, or even a bit older, is the average age of farmers across Australia. That of course has been a significant question for this government, because of the approach that they take to that area.

My area, the area of Blaxland, encompasses the city of Bankstown in the middle of Sydney. It is an area that is typical of an Australia that is a combination of manufacturing expertise, trades, commercial activity and retail. What is being increasingly felt in my area—as it is across Sydney, Melbourne and the other great cities in Australia—is that we have not invested enough at the start of process. If you look at the average age of people who are plumbers, electricians and so on, you see that the average age is in the mid-fifties.

All of those people are aware that, between them and the next lump of people who are qualified in their professions, there is a decade-long gap. They know that, if they choose, like Commonwealth public servants have chosen in the past, to use their option and to go out at 55, the average age, there will not be sufficient people in trades to deal with the demand that has been generated by an increasingly complex society—a society that is utterly dependent on people providing these services. In order for society to adequately function properly and for it to continue to tick over, we need a mechanism to ensure—and I think this bill in part provides it—that those people in the age bracket of 55 or so, who would expect to have another 10 years, are encouraged to continue, so that we do not have a great dearth of capable people.

The other great thing we have missed—because we have not properly invested in the education of apprentices in the trades area—is the possibility of building significant company business within the Asian region. We have done it in part, but the potential is there for Australia to address its problems in terms of gaining foreign income by pushing overseas our people with skills. We need to make that investment. We can do it in part if we are willing to adequately fund education in the trades area in TAFE and to build it to the levels that we had some 30 or 40 years ago. We need to recognise that region wide there is a great demand for those skills.

There is also a great demand for people who are trained in aged care, as people are getting older and living longer and as medical assistance and medical interventions are allowing for the situation of either people being able to age in place—as the previous minister typified the government's approach to this problem—or consolidating the three different levels of care in one particular place instead of having separate hostels, separate nursing home care and so on.

There is a great demand for a building up of this industry. It is possible for older people who have passed normal retirement age to actually build another career, not just on a voluntary basis but on a basis where they can be remunerated for helping others. Throughout my electorate, and every electorate I know in Sydney, the people who work for Meals on Wheels and the people who provide other voluntary services do so in part because they were prohibited from working longer—once they had got to compulsory retirement age that was it.

These age discrimination bills will have a positive effect in sending a message to people Australia wide and to employers and employees that there is no reason for them to be denied what is one of the most significant functions of their lives—that is, if they want to, the ability to use their skills within the community and to do it on a basis where they can be remunerated. We have the possibility that we may in fact have a stronger economy, one in which we combine almost legislated volunteerism—which we have had now for a long period of time—with a new economic platform that could be created because people will be allowed to continue to support themselves.

This is also particularly important because of the current structure of our superannuation system. We are at almost a midpoint in terms of that. I do not believe we have a sufficient amount of investment to secure the future of the baby boomer generation into retirement. There needs to be, firstly, more saving because, as a generation, we have come to it particularly late. Secondly, that will continue to be necessary because I seriously doubt whether the younger generations coming through—when one quarter of the population is aged and a proportion of those are increasingly dependent—will think it is right and proper that their taxes should be increased in order to efficiently and effectively serve the interests of that quarter of the population that are now retired. My expectation is that they could be quite hard-hearted about that. Therefore, a mechanism which will allow people to gain income from their own exertions and not just from shares and from other investments is an important step that should have been taken a very long time ago, in my view, by this parliament. It sends a signal that not only is there worth and dignity in being aged but there should not be, if people so choose, a dependency associated with that.

In fact, as we all know, King Lear made the wrong decision to retire early. On giving up to Goneril and Regan it was made quite evident that they would deal with him as he should be dealt with. So as he was withering on the heath he learned a pretty hard lesson: if you leave yourself to the tender mercies of the younger generation, even if you have spawned them, you may in fact find out that life can be somewhat harsh and cruel and that the tempest that you are engaged with can actually be very difficult to overcome.

I do not think we have had any Tom O'Bedlam speak within this debate, except possibly in part for the cry that I would make here. Despite the fact that that super scheme has been closed, the government would be well advised in bringing in these bills, with Labor support—with the minor amendments that we seek to advance—to have another look at those Commonwealth public servants who have not been forced to retire at 55 but who have chosen to in their own economic interest. We should fix that discrimination as well. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The Age Discrimination Bill 2003 and the Age Discrimination (Consequential Provisions) Bill 2003 before the House today result from extensive consultation after the AttorneyGeneral released the government's information paper on 9 January 2003, which outlined the government's proposals for this legislation. The information paper was released after the AttorneyGeneral's Department had met with over 90 organisations and written to a further 180 organisations and subsequently established a core consultative group to assist the department in developing detailed proposals for age discrimination legislation.

speech.para: Overall, there was widespread support for the government's proposals with regard to age discrimination. I commend the AttorneyGeneral and his department for taking the time to consult widely and for encouraging a wide range of community and legal groups representing both older and younger Australians to make submissions to this very important process in developing the legislation we have before the House today.

In a nutshell, this legislation proposes that age discrimination in public life will be unlawful, and it covers a range of areas. Age discrimination will be unlawful in employment; in the provision of goods, services or facilities; in access to premises, places or public transport; in the administration of Commonwealth laws and programs; in education; in the provision of accommodation; in dealings with land; and in requests for information on which age discrimination might be based. Discrimination on other grounds, such as race, sex or disability, is already prohibited in these areas of public life by existing Commonwealth antidiscrimination laws.

Today I would particularly like to address my comments to the area of age discrimination in the work force. Mature age unemployment is a problem in this country, although it has to be said it is not just an Australian problem; it is an international problem. I have met with many mature age unemployed constituents in my electorate and also during the inquiry into issues specific to mature age workers, which was conducted by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Workplace Relations. The report from the standing committee, entitled Age counts, was tabled in the House in June 2000.

During the inquiry members of the committee were made aware of a very strong perception among mature age job seekers that age specific barriers to their gaining employment exist. The committee was told repeatedly that unemployed mature age applicants are not given job interviews, because of their age. Some applicants even advised the committee that they do not put their age on their job applications for that very reason. Others, particularly women, were told to appear younger or at least look up to date. Several witnesses indicated to the committee that they believed they were given job interviews just so the hiring body could not be accused of discrimination. Never mind whether these job applicants had excellent qualifications or the skills and experience to undertake the position advertised; even with excellent qualifications they failed to secure the job.

It would be of no surprise to anyone in this House that Australia's population is getting older. As close as anyone can tell, there are approximately 4.6 million baby boomers in Australia, and I would suggest that we have quite a few of those in the Australian parliament. The oldest of those born in the early post World War II period are now 58. Therefore in just two years time the largest population spike in history will begin to reach the current average retirement age. However, with fewer and fewer Australians born in the last 20 years, there will not be enough employees to take the places of those who will shortly be retiring from the work force. Because of this trend, we will have to rely on older Australians to work longer into those years that would normally have been thought of as retirement years—longer than the generation before them and much longer than their grandparents.

This would have been a much easier task 40 years ago, when 20 years of service to a company was standard. However, we do not live in a time where a job is measured in terms of a lifetime. Today the workplace has become much more fluid. Gold watches for 50 years service to a company, common 30 years ago, have now been replaced with 18-month stints at several different places of employment, often in several different fields. Australia now finds itself in a time characterised by two trends: an ageing work force and a work force that shifts constantly between jobs. This is an interesting, though not concerning, phenomenon in itself. What is concerning is that, in a fluid work force, mature age Australians often have difficulty in securing employment. This was certainly evidenced by the standing committee's report on mature age issues when it came to employment. The report Age counts made several recommendations with regard to mature age unemployment, particularly in the area of age discrimination in the workplace.

The committee was particularly interested in looking at how retrenchment and redundancy processes are managed and the extent to which these processes actually contribute to the problems faced by those leaving employment. The Australian Bureau of Statistics reports that in 1997 almost half of the number of men over the age of 45 were out of the work force through retrenchment, redundancy or retirement. Statistics also show that longterm unemployment in this age bracket is much higher and that the difficulties in finding new employment are often compounded by age.

When it comes to ageing there is a need to challenge and change the attitudes of some employers and society in general. Wisdom, skills and life experiences can offer an employer a wealth of knowledge that cannot be found in the young. The old saying that you cannot put an old head on young shoulders was never more true than in the area of mature age unemployment. The Commonwealth government is working to combat mature age unemployment and underemployment to allow older Australians the surety of finding work and to upskill those who have been made redundant.

The federal government recently introduced the Australians Working Together package, which includes a transition to work initiative, training credits and work credits. This package offers practical assistance and funding for training to help participants develop their skills. Once more, the assistance package is tailored to suit the individual's needs. The transition to work initiative may include activities such as helping with writing a resume or a job application, courses to upgrade skills like those provided by TAFE, career counselling and even driver training to gain either a car driver's licence or a specific licence. Training credits assist job seekers in meeting the cost of those retraining courses.

To make these programs work effectively and to assist as many of our mature age job seekers as possible, this age discrimination legislation unfortunately is necessary. In this legislation the government is attempting to address the negative perceptions about mature age persons in the work force. There continues to be a perception in the community associating older persons with ailing health and a loss of faculties, instead of with wisdom and experience. If this perception continues there will remain a barrier of prejudice preventing the wisest, most experienced members of the community from securing gainful employment. This would be a tremendous waste of what is a very valuable, very important resource which we will have to increasingly rely on.

To combat these incorrect perceptions, the government is committed to educating employers on the benefits of employing older Australians. With existing programs in place and the legislation before us signed into law, I predict—hopefully—that the rate of unemployed and underemployed older or mature age Australians will drop significantly. It is important to note that the unemployment and underemployment rates measure those who are actively seeking work; they do not measure every person who is available for work.

This government is all about choice, and this legislation is all about choice. It does not include a requirement that older Australians go back to work; it only provides an opportunity to perform in a workplace free from outdated and untrue stereotypes. This government has always been committed to making it easier for Australians to work. That is why it introduced programs like Work for the Dole, the Job Network, the New Apprenticeships scheme and the New Enterprise Incentive Scheme.

This government has also been committed to making our workplaces more diverse. While it is easy to see that older people, on whom we must rely to keep our economy ticking, can be the subject of age discrimination in the workplace, it is a little harder to see that younger people may also be discriminated against in the workplace. However, it is true that young people are sometimes perceived as being erratic, uncommitted and untested, instead of energetic, vibrant and willing to learn and participate. We need both `the wise and the experienced' and `the energetic and the vibrant' in our work force to strike a perfect balance. The only way to do this is to give everyone a fair go at every job they apply for. In 1975 the Commonwealth passed the Racial Discrimination Act; in 1984, the Sex Discrimination Act; and, in 1992, the Disability Discrimination Act. The bills before us today are complementary to those pieces of legislation and further reinforce this government's position that every person should have a level playing field, regardless of their race, religion, sex or age.

This legislation is a celebration of equity in diversity, a recognition that everyone has different but valuable skills. This bill is not so limited in its scope as to only include workplace discrimination; this act will cast a very wide net, attacking all manner of age discrimination without affecting things like the different treatment of age groups with genuine age related needs and circumstances or areas where there is broad social support for age differentiated treatment, like the restriction of young people's access to adult movies.

I commend this bill to the House as legislation which will give Australians of all ages a level playing field while recognising that they have divergent skills. While it is a wide-ranging and far-reaching bill, it is not all-encompassing and therefore excludes circumstances where discrimination on the basis of age is accepted or desired by the community. Importantly, this legislation will remove barriers to mature age work force participation. This is a significant issue of national importance given our ageing population. Demographic necessity makes this legislation a social and economic imperative. It will help break down the stereotypes of older and younger people and recognise the social and economic contribution that both younger and older people make to the Australian community and, indeed, to the Australian economy. I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on this very important piece of proposed legislation, the Age Discrimination Bill 2003. I wish to state my support with all speakers on this legislation, though I have to note the government's tardiness in introducing it to the House, given that the Liberal Party had it as part of its policy in the 1996 federal election. I suppose seven years is better than never.

speech.para: I am pleased to speak in the debate, because I believe that this is a serious public policy issue that for too long has been placed in the too-hard basket. We all know of people who have been cast aside from their jobs or overlooked for employment due to their age. These are not aged people by any means but, due to the harsh commercial mindset that idolises youth and exuberance, perfectly healthy, intelligent and skilled people are being thrown onto the employment scrap heap.

This legislation will prohibit age discrimination in employment; education; access to premises; access to goods, services, facilities and accommodation; the disposal of land; the administration of Commonwealth laws and programs; and requests for information. It will also cover direct and indirect discrimination. The bill will, however, allow the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to grant exemptions. I am comfortable with this provision as there are certain specific areas where a strict interpretation would indeed become a folly—for example, in the provision of a youth allowance or an age pension.

But the legislation has been a long time coming. I remember the Keating government establishing an age discrimination task force—we referred to it as `the' task force—and discussed introducing age discrimination legislation. The task force also debated the abolition of compulsory retirement at the age of 65 in the Commonwealth Public Service. In the 1996 election campaign, both the Labor and Liberal parties promised to introduce legislation to prohibit age discrimination. The present crisis in mature aged employment has forced this government to act, after seven years.

Many commentators have expressed their support for the legislation. I was pleased when I read in the editorial in the Advertiser on 10 January 2003 that the `proposals to make discrimination on the basis of age illegal are in keeping with the spirit and reality of the times'. The Age in January of 2003 said:

quote.para: ... plans by the Federal Government to make it unlawful for employers and job agencies to discriminate against older workers should help to change the culture of early retirement.

speech.para: Also, the Mercury in the same month—on 11 January 2003—hit the nail on the head when it said:

quote.para: In a society obsessed with the beautiful and the youthful it is hardly surprising that discrimination against Australians based on age is widespread.
The ... plan to outlaw discrimination on the basis of age under Commonwealth law ... is welcome.

speech.para: However, I note that the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry has now publicly stated its strong reservations about the effect of the proposed laws. To quote from a press release issued by Peter Hendy, the chief executive of the ACCI, dated 9 September 2003:

quote.para: ACCI ... has expressed concern that proposed national age discrimination laws could be counterproductive and end up discouraging more employment of disadvantaged age groups—particularly mature aged workers.
That Bill is well intended, but remains flawed.

speech.para: The ACCI goes on to say that the laws would be a further disincentive for employers to take on mature age workers and argues, I believe obliquely:

quote.para: If the community believes that more needs to be done by employers to employ mature aged workers, then why would employers be prohibited from advertising for mature aged workers?

speech.para: Peter Hendy also asserts that the proposed laws could hurt efforts by business to get the best from employees. Can the ACCI answer their own question? Can the ACCI explain why company managers who are over 40 are seen to be now over the hill? Can anybody argue with a straight face, either in this parliament or in the community at large, that being aged over 40 is being past it? I look around this room and I would say there are few here who could stand up and be counted in that regard. The ACCI will argue that that is what the market wants. Is that right? I am sure that the market will be forced into a radical rethink when these millionaire whippersnappers begin to hit 40 and are themselves consigned to the `past it' waste bin. The average life duration is 78 for men and 81 for women, so the prospect of living half your life in semi or enforced retirement is becoming a frightening prospect, especially considering that the baby boomers are now in the age range where retirement is certainly on their minds.

The Treasurer's Intergenerational Report of 2002 states that the ageing of the population will dramatically increase the number of older people. The report contends that the number of people aged between 55 and 64 will increase by more than 50 per cent over the next 20 years. At the end of the baby boom, Australia's population was growing at more than two per cent per year. What is it now? One per cent. Our population is growing at less than half of what it was in the early 1960s. Louise Rolland from the Business, Work and Ageing unit at Swinburne University claims labour shortages will be a big problem within only seven years. She said:

quote.para: There will be major issues around the supply of labour by the end of this decade and by 2030 it be looking very dim. The rationalist view is that the market will deal with it. But the market will not diagnose the problem until it has become critical. Right now the market is not even aware of the issue. Businesses need to address, as a matter of urgency, structural and cultural changes that will promote increased participation by older workers.

speech.para: In a report entitled Age can work: the case for older Australians staying in the workforce, the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Business Council of Australia both agreed that, as a result of an ageing population, by 2025 there will be three working Australians to support each retired person, whilst at the moment it is six workers to support each retiree. I hear a number of people in the human resources industry state that there is no evidence of age discrimination, and they say to me, `You can't prove it.' They repeat the mantra that they always employ the best person for the job. However, a number of reports have come to the opposite conclusion, including a report tabled in this parliament titled Age counts: an inquiry into issues specific to mature-age workersand a report published by HREOC in May 2000 titled Age matters: a report on age discrimination. Both show quite conclusively that age discrimination is commonplace. In Age matters, a person submitted that they were advised quite openly at the age of 45 that there was little prospect of them finding a job. He said to that committee:

quote.para: I was told privately by an employee of the now debunked CES that my only hope was to get on a pension or if possible start my own business as no one would employ me at my age.

speech.para: That is, at age 45. In another submission a person angrily stated:

quote.para: It is nonsense and ridiculous that the year I was born dictates that I have to be retired, when I am both an excellent performer and in dire need of the dollars. And have never been ill or incapacitated or absent. Performance and attendance should be the only criteria—measurable ability to do the job, and being there to do it every day.

speech.para: I could not agree more. There would not be too many of us in this House today if those attitudes were enforced upon politicians. The leaders of both major parties would have been pensioned off long ago—and, I admit, I would have been with them. Whilst conducting my research for this speech, I noticed in many of the articles I read that a study commissioned by Drake Consulting in 1999 was often quoted. What did this study show? It showed that, of the top 500 human resource executives, not one would employ managers in their 50s and only 23 per cent would employ managers in the 41 to 50 age group. They mostly—and I am talking about 62 per cent—wanted executives aged between 31 and 40. And Drake believes that the instances of discrimination against aged workers have increased since then.

The government in recent times has seen the writing on the wall. Many mature age people out of work means more welfare support, which means higher taxes. Ministers Andrew and Minchin have been out on the hustings, attempting to convince Australians to retire later. The previous Ageing minister, Kevin Andrews, pleaded, `We need you.' I hope that behind the scenes the ministers have had a quiet word to the employer groups and put it to them that, in the interests of the nation and society, they should reconsider their twodecade-old policy of `Once you hit 40, you're finished.' I am sure ACCI would be screaming blue murder if the government increased their taxes to pay for the increased welfare burden.

In May the Secretary of the Treasury, Ken Henry, painted a picture of a grim economic future unless the participation rate amongst the mature aged increases. He claimed that the low participation rate was stymieing economic growth. Currently those between the ages of 55 and 59 looking for full-time work are, on average, out of work for 120 weeks. Therefore, they are out of work for more than two years—and, undoubtedly, for many it is a lot longer. An estimated 125,000 Australians over 45 years of age are out of work and are still actively looking for a job. I agree with Mr Henry that training and reskilling are part of the solution, but employers will not pay for them. So that leaves only the government, and what are they doing? I say: very little. I hope the stark realities of the near future will force the government into some action on this front.

However, some of the states, I am pleased to say, are now taking up the reins. In Queensland the Department of Employment and Training has introduced a mature workers age subsidy. Businesses are offered wage subsidies of up to $4,400 to employ an unemployed person over the age of 45. In New South Wales the Carr government has a mature workers program for people aged over 40, which found jobs for 3,500 people in 2002.

Since the idea of restructuring the workplace became a byword for cost cutting during the 1980s, it has generally been the case that older workers are the first to receive the axe. So how do government, business and the community change this culture? Do we need the demographic reality of more people being supported than working to hit us in the face? We should demand changes to be implemented now. The problem, I think, is a corporate culture that demands constant change. `You can't be competitive unless you are keeping up with change,' is the common catchcry. But our society have indicated to us in the political process that they are tired of change. That would suggest that consumers are tiring of change in the corporate world as well. Consumers want quality and reliability. But can we really believe that we are getting that? Bureaucratisation of customer service to establish low-cost service provision is one example of this. I have even heard of a new phrase in the lexicon where the aim is to `get rid of the customer'. How will this happen? I do not know. But it goes to show the contempt that the top end of town have for everyone. Nobody matters except themselves, and their bank accounts. It is typical of those who believe that money is the be-all and end-all to believe that consumer service and experience is of no significance.

In an article in the Australian on 18 March 2003, Kate Legge provides an example of a firm refusing to relocate managers over 35 years of age from Melbourne to Sydney `because they were considered too old to make a successful transition to a racier city'. Mr Deputy Speaker Mossfield, you and I are living in that racy city. It is amazing, isn't it, that your ability to party and participate in the long after-hours bonding sessions is more important than your skills and experience? Fortunately, according to Legge, there are some companies that are facing up to the realities rather than the hype and are establishing recruitment systems for older workers. Australia Post, Hertz Car Rentals and Westpac are but three of them. I am particularly glad that Westpac is doing this, as the finance sector is very much into the modern mantra that youth rules.

Mark Tucker-Evans, the Executive Director of the Council of the Ageing in Queensland, has argued that human resource managers who are under 40 and who, in the main, have university degrees, `see things differently from the previous generations', who do not have tertiary qualifications but have limitless on-the-job experience. Tucker-Evans also argues that people under 40 do not have an expectation of keeping their jobs for extended periods of time and readily accept that changing jobs is part and parcel of modern life. Older workers are used to a job for life, and that is a crucial difference—constant change versus steady progression.

While Australia has a culture where you are washed up as you get older, other countries actually respect the skill and experience of their mature age work force. Japan, Korea, China and the US all have tremendous respect for experience. Particularly in the East Asian countries I have just mentioned, you are not seen as having enough experience until you are about 50. I am not suggesting that this is the perfect system; in fact, a system in the middle of ours and theirs is probably somewhere near the optimum. Finland has participation rates for mature age workers at more than 70 per cent, in comparison to Australia which is currently at only 49 per cent. The definition—I repeat—of a mature age worker is a person over 55.

Australia has accepted at least three international conventions that eliminate age discrimination. There are additional grounds under the Discrimination (Employment and Occupation) Convention, ILO111; articles 2 and 26 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights; and article 2 of the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights. We do have international obligations to stop this discrimination, and I am glad that, for once, the government is committed to these obligations. But I do find it ironic—and possibly an example of this government's scattergun approach to public policy—that this legislation is being advanced at the same time as the Australian Human Rights Commission Bill 2003 would undermine HREOC's role. Maybe this legislation is just a bit of tokenism—but I hope it is not.

As we all know, this government is not always mindful of its international obligations and will often ride roughshod over instruments that Australia has committed itself to over the years. For example, the government has steadfastly refused to sign the optional protocol to the Convention on the Elimination of Discrimination Against Women, CEDAW. I have criticised the government on numerous occasions about this lack of activity.

With regard to the issue of age discrimination, the harsh reality of an ageing population and the nightmarish consequences that this will have for our welfare system have forced the government to act—and act it should. There are too many people out there in our community who have been pushed aside for no other reason than their age. They have the skills and experience and, with a touch of training and reskilling, can be of enormous continuing benefit to the community and to the Australian economy. There needs to be mutual obligation here. Mature age workers have to concede some ground as well. They have to try new things and at times retrain themselves. However, employers should also recognise these efforts and employ those who are willing to work in this modern world. If neither side gives way, this country is likely to face a real crisis in the not too distant future.

After seven years, this bill has been a long time coming. I commend the bill to the House, and I again say to the government: if industry will not retrain the mature age workers to whom we are referring in this legislation, government must act. If government does not act, it is we the Australian people who will suffer the most for it.

talk.start.para: —In many indigenous societies around the world, there is extraordinary weight and gravitas attached to the views, the experience and the very notion of the elder. The elder, and the general concept of the elder, is that person who, through their life experiences, is recognised as having made a contribution to society—and I pay due deference, of course, to Mr Deputy Speaker Price in this context. An elder brings with them a wealth of experience and, above all else, accumulated wisdom and abilities. I speak only of the chair!

speech.para: In that context, I look to my own electorate of Flinders. There are a great many people whom I have met who fit into the categories of those who are over 55 or over 60. Compared to the state average, the electorate of Flinders, and particularly that part of it which comprises the Mornington Peninsula, has over 50 per cent more residents who are 60 years or older. In my area, there are many people who are retired but who do not seek to be retired. There are many people who have finished their formal working life but who seek other outlets for professional work. And yet these are people who, on many occasions, are unable to fulfil their desires to contribute to society and to make use of their history and their experience. One of the reasons for that is the problem of age discrimination.

Age discrimination is generally not an overt action—it is not something which people may necessarily even be aware of—but it is a preference, it is a predilection and it is a cultural norm. That is what the Age Discrimination Bill 2003 and the Age Discrimination (Consequential Provisions) Bill 2003 deal with and that is what Australia's society, in its 2003 manifestation, must deal with. When you look to Australia as a whole, what you see is a very simple proposition. It is self-evident and known by all members of this House that we have an ageing society. We have an ageing society because of the success of our health system—people are simply living longer than at any previous time in our history—and because our rate of replenishment, our natural birthrate, is not sufficient to redress the balance.

As a country we face dual risks. The first risk we face is a multitude of individuals, each of whom is seeking to fulfil themselves and wants to continue their utility to society, who are not able to do that. The second risk we face is an imbalance between the working population and the dependent population. Unless we address that imbalance, we face a serious financial risk that there will be an intergenerational transfer, where the baby boomers will take the benefits of their work with them into retirement and draw from the next generation. And so, rather than there being intergenerational equity, there is intergenerational inequality; a transfer of wealth from one generation to the other as the working population of the future supports the retired population.

There should be a constant flow where those who have worked are supported in their retirement—that is what Australia is about. But where that becomes a disproportionate balance and the ratio between those in gainful employment and those who are dependent upon the system changes dramatically, then that is a significant problem because it takes away resources for all of the multitude of needs of society—hospitals and schools, our children's needs, the needs of the disabled and all of the different elements. We need to have that balance where we have a higher proportion of elderly working than has been the case—if they choose to do so. That is what age discrimination is about. It is about removing the barriers for people who are older and who seek to continue their working life. It is as simple as that.

For me this has in a sense been a personal journey. The Age Discrimination Bill 2003 and the Age Discrimination (Consequential Provisions) Bill 2003 take me back to when I was at university. One of the major foci of my study was the problem of age discrimination. In 1989 we identified the problem and set out many of the provisions which are contained in this legislation. To see that passage, albeit that it has taken a considerable period of time, is to see a gradual transformation in Australian society. If my generation can play a role in that transformation, then that is a good thing.

I want to focus on three particular aspects of the Age Discrimination Bill 2003: firstly, its background; secondly, its importance; and, thirdly, its provisions. In looking at the background, this bill implements the government's 2001 election commitment to develop legislation to prohibit age discrimination and it seeks to eliminate, as far as possible, age discrimination in key areas of public life, including employment, education, access to premises, dealings with land, administration of Commonwealth laws and programs, and requests for information.

The second bill contained in this package, the Age Discrimination (Consequential Provisions) Bill 2003, which accompanies the Age Discrimination Bill, provides all the necessary amendments to the full range of Commonwealth legislation. Importantly, protection will be given against age discrimination in business and in the commercial world so as to ensure that all Australians have equality of opportunity. That is the fundamental provision. It is the notion of equality of opportunity, a fair go and a fair tilt at an opportunity. So there is equality of opportunity to participate in the social and economic life of our country.

There is still more to go. Beyond the Age Discrimination Bill we have more to do in terms of age discrimination in the area of superannuation. That is one thing which I would personally like to focus on, addressing the problems of the over-70s in relation to superannuation and some of the disincentives for them and finding the correct balance between incentives for employers and disincentives for employees. The problem which this bill seeks to overcome is a simple one: age discrimination has not, until this point in time in Australian history, been prohibited by Commonwealth legislation. So the bill sets out to acknowledge that, despite existing state and territory laws, age discrimination is an increasingly significant problem for our society. It was dealt with to a certain extent through the states and territories. In particular we see that the United States has a strong regime for dealing with age discrimination. But our regime has been insufficient, so we need to take it further.

The bill also sets out to be consistent with our international commitments to eliminate age discrimination and in particular to ensure full participation in public life by older persons, as was highlighted in the political declaration adopted by the second World Assembly on Ageing last year. The bill seeks to remove barriers to older people participating in society, not just in the work force but in some social areas. There is a further element—to achieve a balance between the need to eliminate unfair discrimination on the basis of age and the need to ensure sufficient flexibility to allow for situations where age requirements have genuine policy significance.

Against that background, what is the importance of the bill? It has three core consequences. The first is that it attempts to eradicate both direct and indirect discrimination in key areas of public life. The second consequence is that it seeks to promote and is intended to promote tolerant workplaces which themselves will comprise greater diversity and ultimately greater productivity. There are very strong correlations which show that, contrary to some popular belief, empirical evidence is that older workers can be more productive, more stable and take less time for sick leave. The third consequence of this legislation is that it will have a broad positive effect on the economy and the achievement of social policy objectives and it complements the government's wider priority to encourage Australians to stay in the work force. So in that respect, it has an impact on the balance between those who are in the productive economy and those who are dependent. It seeks to maintain the balance in favour of productivity rather than emphasising dependency, which is both a real and critical human imperative and a real and critical national imperative.

The third thing I want to do is address briefly some of the core provisions of the bill. In particular I want to deal with the concept of age discrimination as set out in part 3 of the bill. Clause 14 of the bill outlines the notion of direct discrimination, and this occurs where a person is treated less favourably because of their age in circumstances that are the same or not materially different from those of a person of another age. Clause 15 sets out indirect discrimination, and this is a very interesting definition. Indirect discrimination occurs where a person of a particular age is unfairly disadvantaged because the person cannot meet a condition, requirement or practice that is neutral as to age, on its face, but is more difficult for people of that age to meet than people of another age. An example of this is where a condition of employment means the satisfaction of a demanding physical test—which is easier for a young person to satisfy than an older person—which is not relevant to the task. If in our military you have a highly physical job and you need physical requirements, then so be it. But if, for example, there was a physical requirement on membership of parliament, that would be a classic example of indirect discrimination, because what is necessary here is the combination of wisdom, communication and skills. It is not about physical ability. Stamina is important, but it is not about physical ability. The key thing there is whether a test is relevant to the task at hand. That is what indirect discrimination is about.

In closing, I want to return to the notion of the `elder'. Traditional societies do value their elders. Many other cultures value their elders. We have not valued our elders, and in part that is a construct of a modern media society. Perhaps Australia has been more a victim of that than many other Western societies, because there is a very powerful `elderly lobby' in the United States which has redressed that barrier to a certain extent. This bill is part of redressing the barrier in Australia. It recognises the societal need to ensure that we make full use of the skills, talents and capabilities of our elderly, and it recognises above all else the human need—that each individual has the right and the responsibility to play a part in their society for as long as they are able and as long as they wish to. On that basis, I am delighted to support the Age Discrimination Bill 2003, and I commend the bills to the House.

talk.start.para: —I am also pleased to rise in support of the Age Discrimination Bill 2003 and the Age Discrimination (Consequential Provisions) Bill 2003. The Age Discrimination Bill will make discrimination on the basis of age unlawful, subject to various exemptions. The bill identifies the following specific areas of operation where age discrimination is prohibited: employment, including contractors and agencies; education; access to premises; access to goods, services and facilities; accommodation; disposal of land; administration of Commonwealth laws and programs; and requests for information. The bill also provides the following specific exemptions: positive discrimination; inherent job requirements; superannuation, insurance and credit; pensions, allowances and benefits; acts done in compliance with specified Commonwealth laws; acts done in compliance with state and territory laws; and acts done in compliance with awards and agreements—which is primarily aimed at junior rates of pay.

speech.para: The Age Discrimination Bill complements existing Commonwealth, state and territory laws on age discrimination. Currently, all states and territories prohibit age discrimination. The bill will not override the operation of these laws. Under the bill, where a person makes a complaint under a state or territory law, that person will then be barred from making that complaint under the Commonwealth law. The reasons for the legislation were in particular outlined in the minister's second reading speech in June of this year. In his second reading speech, the AttorneyGeneral outlined the need for age discrimination legislation and outlined that this is the government's response to demographic changes in Australia. He also outlined the areas covered by the bill and detailed the exceptions in the bill.

Some of the areas of concern that we in the Labor Party have expressed go to the exemptions and also to the influence that the business community had on the government in relation to this legislation. The Attorney-General also spoke about the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and the so-called public consultation that was under way during the drafting of this legislation.

To put it in historical context, back in 1996 the Keating government pledged to introduce age discrimination legislation if re-elected in 1996. The Keating government had earlier established an age discrimination task force, and in 1995 the Keating government's national action plan talked of the task force's examination of possible age discrimination legislation. It also discussed the abolition of compulsory age retirement in the Commonwealth public sector. In November 2001, the Human Rights Commissioner, Dr Sev Ozdowski, said:

quote.para: Age discrimination complaints made to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission between 1999-2000 and 2000-2001 have tripled. More than 200 people phoned the complaints information line after being deemed `too old' for a position.

speech.para: The National Executive Director of the Council on the Ageing, Denys Correll, has welcomed the legislation but has made comments about its overdue nature. At the same time, the West Australian said:

quote.para: The Federal Government and its predecessors—

speech.para: including the Keating government—

quote.para: took an unreasonably long time to come up with proposals for age discrimination legislation.

speech.para: We do support and welcome this legislation; however, there are inadequacies in it, and that is what Labor's amendment addresses. Those inadequacies include the legislation not being extended to relatives and associates. The extension of proscribed age discrimination to a person's relatives and associates was apparently considered by the government but was eventually rejected. The government's information paper on the Age Discrimination Bill contains the following passage:

quote.para: 2.2.3 Relatives and associates

Some State and Territory anti-discrimination laws extend discrimination on the ground of a person's age to include the age of a person's relative or associate. The Disability Discrimination Act similarly includes the disability of a person's associates (ie a relative, partner, friend, business colleague etc) within the ground of disability.
Such a concept of discrimination would include discrimination against a person who cares for or acts on behalf of another person, where the discrimination occurs because of the other person's age.

In consultations, there were different views about the appropriateness of extending discrimination on the ground of a person's age to cover the age of the person's associate(s) and/or relative(s). Some groups supported this proposal, particularly in the area of the provision of goods and services. Employer organisations expressed concern about the application of this extended ground of age discrimination to the employment field.

speech.para: Discrimination on the basis of the age of a relative or an associate could arise in a situation where an employer discriminates against an employee who cares for an aged relative, because there is an apprehension by the employer that the employee will need to take time off work to attend to the relative. Another example would be where a hotelier might not allow parents with young children to stay as guests because of the hotelier's anticipation of unruly behaviour by the children.

This point was made recently in an article I read in the GoodWeekend magazine of the Sydney Morning Herald, where they were promoting weekend getaways and a number of places indicated that children were not welcome. I know that members opposite would have come across the same situation: travelling with young families and trying to find suitable accommodation is really quite difficult.

Another area of inadequacy in this bill is in relation to the `dominant reason'. The government has watered down the test for whether a particular conduct constitutes age discrimination by requiring that age discrimination be the dominant reason for conduct complained about in order for the complaint to be upheld. This is a harder test to meet than that which applies to other types of outlawed discriminatory acts under Commonwealth legislation and under various state and territory laws dealing with age discrimination. The New South Wales legislation, the Anti-Discrimination Act 1977, reads:

quote.para: If:
(a) an act is done for 2 or more reasons, and
(b) one of the reasons consists of unlawful discrimination under this Act against a person (whether or not it is the dominant or a substantial reason for doing the act),
then, for the purposes of this Act, the act is taken to be done for that reason.

speech.para: The government's reason for the tougher threshold to maintain a complaint is outlined in the explanatory memorandum, which says:

quote.para: However, in this case, the primary solution to most aspects of age discrimination is based on education and attitudinal change. In doing so, it is critical that the legislation not establish barriers to such positive developments, for example, by restricting employment opportunities for older Australians by imposing unnecessary costs and inflexibility on employers acting in good faith.

speech.para: This reason goes against the government's case for introducing the bill. As also outlined in the explanatory memorandum, and arguing against retaining the status quo and not legislating against age discrimination, this argument was advanced:

quote.para: If the status quo is retained, older Australians and younger Australians would bear the cost of ongoing discrimination, suffering the effects of marginalisation, unemployment or under-employment, damage to self-esteem, reduced social participation and reduced access to goods and services. The community would also lose the benefits of diverse contributions to society by people of different age groups.

speech.para: Some other areas of inadequacy which Labor's amendments go to include harassment remedies. There is no cap on damages in this bill that can be awarded in a successful claim; in New South Wales and Western Australia the legislation has a cap of $40,000. We are also concerned about the exemptions contained in the bill and, without going into all of them in detail, we have insisted that after two years the legislation have a review of these exemptions and of the effect the exemptions have on the intent of the legislation.

There have been concerns raised by various groups in the community. The Council on the Ageing, while in favour of age discrimination legislation overall, was concerned about a number of aspects of the bill. It had particular concerns about the width of the exemptions given to the Commonwealth, which it described as demonstrating the Commonwealth's reluctance to embrace its own age discrimination laws. The council expressed concern that, by taking this approach, the Commonwealth provides a negative role model to the community. The council is concerned about the situation of age discrimination within the framework of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and, more specifically, is concerned to ensure that age discrimination has its own commissioner—a concern that may or may not be alleviated by the proposal currently before the parliament to abolish all specifically focused commissioners. The council also identifies the lack of funding for and difficulties in taking cases to the Federal Court as impediments to the proposed bill's effective functioning.

Quite a number of concerns were raised about this legislation, as outlined in the Bills Digest. Most of those concerns are addressed by the amendments that Labor have proposed. They were also outlined in a report by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee on the provisions of the Age Discrimination Bill 2003, which was released and tabled in September 2003—in a dissenting report by ALP senators. Two of the main concerns they raised, which are addressed by our amendments, were with the dominant or substantial reason test for conduct and the need for some of the exemptions to be curtailed. The recommendation of the dissenting senators was that the exemptions from liability for age discrimination be reviewed in two years to ensure that they remain necessary, with the onus on the government to prove an ongoing need for them. The dissenting senators also raised concerns about the inadequate resourcing of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and the need for prohibition of harassment.
I support this bill with the amendment moved by the shadow Attorney-General:

motion.para: That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

“whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for failing to ensure that federal age discrimination legislation contains the best standards of protection for older Australians, a failure which is consistent with its neglect of the human rights of all Australians, as evidenced by its introduction of legislation to weaken the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and other actions to wind back protections for Australian citizens.”

speech.para: I urge the government to accept the amendment moved by the shadow Attorney-General so that together we can move forward as a parliament to completely eliminate all forms of discrimination on the basis of age.

talk.start.para: —I am delighted to speak today in support of the Age Discrimination Bill 2003 and the Age Discrimination (Consequential Provisions) Bill 2003. Newer members of the House might not be aware that for about five or six years I have been actively pursuing the issue of mature age employment, since doing some analysis of circumstances in my own electorate, the Dunkley community in the greater Frankston-Mornington Peninsula area. We have a large number of remarkably gifted and skilled mature age people who are finding re-entering the work force particularly difficult, unreasonably difficult and, in many cases, difficult because of the unjustified attitudes of employers.

speech.para: Through those many years of work I am pleased to say that the Peninsula Job Team, an organisation I convene, has run two pilot programs aimed at creating what we have called the mature age employment advantage, working with mature age job seekers to ensure that they present their skills to employers in a way that is contemporary and valued by employers. We also aim to explore the changing nature of the labour market. Many people who have been in careers for 20 to 25 years and take early retirement thinking that a quick re-employment after a few months off playing golf is what their plans provide for find that it does not always work out that way. When seeking to re-enter the work force, they find it is a very different work force from the one they entered 25 years earlier. So that is part of our work.

Another area that we have been focusing on through these pilot programs is information technology skills. Many workplaces are prepared to, and prefer to, invest in IT skills through specific training of their employees on their organisation's technology and systems. That is a welcome measure that many people embrace. They are looking to recruit future employees who are at least literate when it comes to information technology. Some mature age workers themselves recognise that as an area where they could do a lot more work. We are supporting that so that when a mature age job seeker goes to an employer they can provide evidence of competency in industry standard information technology and give employers the confidence that the training investment in that mature age worker will result in excellent computer skills in that workplace.

Another area we have been working on is career and life planning. I mentioned earlier that the workplace is changing and the economy is changing, and we are finding that many mature age workers are not as expansive or as able to present their competencies in a way that resonates with employers. Let me give an example: someone who may have worked in the timber industry for many years may be out of that industry looking to work in new fields, in new vocations, and may present themselves as a timber industry worker. That may be an accurate and clearly understood portrayal of their capacities to someone in the timber industry, but if you are turning up to a construction facility, a transport organisation or even offering your skills at Bunnings—where many DIY tragics like me rock up and look at a wall full of technology and cannot quite work out which one is best for my job or which is least dangerous for what I hope to do—someone with experience and knowledge in that area is very valuable. Mature age people with, for example, skills in the timber industry might not realise that they could be very valuable frontline customer service staff at places where the tools that they have used all their lives are being retailed. I welcome the fact that Bunnings in Mornington and Frankston have recruited quite extensively from the mature age sector to staff those local outlets.

My point, though, around that timber industry example is that a timber worker or someone running a timber mill actually has a whole suite of skills and capabilities that are very useful and can be readily adapted to a whole range of workplaces in terms of project planning, the logistics involved, the construction technologies, the tools, the equipment, the timetables, the work and safety requirements—highly valued skills in a range of vocations not expressly related to the timber industry. So a part of the pilot projects that I have been leading down in my community is working with mature age people to actually unbundle their successful lives and their successful careers and to pull out of that history transportable competencies and capabilities that are valued, that are sought and that are desired by employers. They have these abilities but they have not actually put them forward when applying for jobs because they have gone for a categorisation of, for example, `I work in the timber industry.' So we are looking to support mature age people to present for themselves what they have to offer, and that sometimes means stepping back from former job titles and former industries and looking at what the activity is and what the competencies are that they have been successfully involved in.

I present that as a backdrop to this Age Discrimination Bill because something else needs to happen. There is a silent tragedy going on in far too many households throughout Australia, where successful men and women are having difficulty engaging in social and economic life because of an inability to get back into the work force because some employers are very unkind and are quite unhelpful when they receive an application from a mature age job seeker. So on the demand side we have work to do—just as I have described on the supply side working with mature age job seekers to make sure they are meeting market expectations and are valued contributors in the workplace. On the demand side, we need to work with employers. Sadly, unjustified myths and stereotypes are carried by far too many employers that represent barriers to mature age job seekers re-entering the work force. That is where this bill comes into play. Those unreasonable stereotypes and unjustified prejudices against mature age job seekers are not only disadvantaging employers—and I will come to that in a moment—but creating a lot of heartache and despair in the lives of mature age people.

This bill is about tackling that discrimination. It is the kind of discrimination reported on in the Agematters report from the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission in 2000. The Age counts inquiry, chaired by Brendan Nelson back in 2000, revealed negative effects of age discrimination in all aspects of our society. The Howard government has been stating for quite some time that it is committed to addressing age discrimination, and a number of prominent measures have been enacted to give life to that commitment.

The 1996 election policy, Security for Older Australians,was part of our commitment to abolishing the compulsory retirement age where that could be passed in areas of Commonwealth responsibility, and that was delivered in December 1999 and was part of the pledge the government had made to take action. Fours years ago the government announced the development of a national strategy for an ageing Australia, and part of that strategy was to develop a broad national framework to address the challenges of our ageing population, identify areas of age discrimination and target major obstacles for mature age job seekers—employment and, at times, employers. There was a commitment prior to the 2001 election by the Howard government to do what we are doing today—introducing age discrimination legislation—and you are seeing action on that front as well.

The Age Discrimination Bill that we are considering today seeks to prohibit discrimination on the basis of age in the areas of employment, the provision of goods and services, access to places and facilities, and the provision of transport and accommodation, with limited beneficial outcome exceptions. Research suggests that economic and social drivers will, over time, increasingly promote mature age employment—that is, it will get to a point where there will be fewer and fewer new entrants to the labour market who are of the sprightly ages of post-secondary school years, but there will be a growing availability of mature age job seekers that employers will be obliged to select from.

The smart employers are recognising the changing demographics today and they are recognising that the best person for the job can quite often be a mature age person. They are the smart people. There are some employers that have not quite got it yet, and more directed immediate action is required to ensure that the talent and the capacity of the current mature age job seeker community is not lost to the economy and to abate the significant personal cost of their joblessness. That is what this legislation is about: this is direct action—a big wake-up call; a `don't you know what's going on?' message to employers and service providers who have not quite got it that there is ageing in our population and that they are undermining their own activities and viability by not embracing mature age people.

To give you a snapshot of that change in our community, in 1976 Australia had 1.3 million people over the age of 65, or nine per cent of the population. In March 2001 there were 2.3 million people over the age of 65, or 12 per cent of the population. By 2016 there will be 3.5 million people, or 16 per cent of the population, over the age of 65. As we look ahead to 2051, we see that 6.03 million people, or one-quarter of Australia's population, will be over the age of 65. If age discrimination is allowed to reign and if employers do not recognise the remarkable resource base that mature age job seekers provide, there will be a disadvantage to them, to our economy and to our society. The Nelson report recognised that work is a key defining element of an individual's character. To quote it:

quote.para: Work puts us in a social context, defines the framework of our lives and gives each of us a sense of belonging and meaningful purpose. Being without a job devastates not only personal finances; it exacts a heavy social and human toll.

speech.para: In 1997 the ABS reported that almost half of men over the age of 45 were out of the work force through retrenchment, redundancy or retirement. The unemployment rate for mature age people is lower than that for the general population but, if you do find yourself unemployed, the duration of your unemployment is much longer. On average I think it is about 97 weeks at the moment. As the Nelson report identified, this represents `the tip of an iceberg of quiet anguish'—nearly two years out of work!

You might be a senior manager or a very effective and valued contributor to a workplace who has been there for years and, maybe through no fault of your own, those opportunities are lost to you. Or you might have thought that early retirement was a great idea only to find that, when you want to get back into the work force, there is a delay of nearly two years on average. What a devastating effect that could have on proud, productive people that have been contributing to their own personal wellbeing and to their own society and economy. There is a need for change. Something has to change and, as I mentioned earlier, the government is pursuing a number of measures, and this bill before the House today represents more direct action.

The Commonwealth has laws to prohibit discrimination and it is implementing laws to prohibit age discrimination. The bill recognises the social and economic contribution that Australians of all ages make to our society. However, there is also a need to challenge the attitudes of societies and employers when it comes to ageing if we as a nation and as an economy are to recognise the changes in our demographics and to embrace the idea that skill, enthusiasm and adaptation to change are not the exclusive domain of the young—they are qualities that are in many people.
Edith Cowan University's Dr Gringart said:

quote.para: Despite having the same qualifications, experience and knowledge as younger counterparts older Australians are less likely to be hired by employers.

speech.para: We need to tackle that attitude. In her address to the March 2001 CEDA seminar on the ageing work force, the then Minister for Ageing, Bronwyn Bishop, highlighted the financial and health impacts of mature age unemployment and the `drag on our growth potential and standard of living'. The National Strategy for Ageing Australia paper on mature age employment in 1999 recognised that mature age workers have the potential to make a continuing economic and social contribution, particularly as an increasing trend towards knowledge based industries opens up opportunities for less physically demanding occupations. All the trends are heading in the right direction, yet we still run into attitudes that undermine the opportunities of mature age people to enter the work force.

This legislation is direct action, but we need to do more. I welcome the legislation, but I also call for a national marketing campaign to change the mind-set of employers wary about employing mature age job seekers. We need that campaign. We need to recognise that black-letter law will not always change what is in people's hearts. We need to get people predisposed to embrace mature age people, not disinclined to embrace mature age people, and we need to change the way they feel and think about this issue.

The bill puts a prohibition in place, and that is one tool, and that tool is important and necessary. However, we need to get an attitudinal change; we need to communicate that there are advantages in an age-balanced work force, that older people have a calming effect on the workplace and have skills and capabilities that are valuable in the workplace, and that a growing share of the expenditure dollar in this country is coming from mature age people.

The demographic trends indicate what is happening and its impact on the labour market and the supply of skills, but this is also changing the way people are spending money. If consumers go to Bunnings—and I used this example before—or are talking about life insurance or any product or service related to their stage in life, many want the comfort of talking to somebody who understands and can relate to their circumstances. What a resource a mature age person could be in workplaces—particularly in retail, services and sales areas—where they can directly connect with people at the same stage in life and be a positive influence on the business's engagement with a changing marketplace.

I mentioned earlier that we are trialling some bold initiatives in my electorate through the peninsula job team, with the support of Your Employment Solutions, with Barry Smith, Kate and the team there; SkillsPlus Peninsula; South East Development; and Life Futures, with Tvzi Lachman and Melody Rewakowski. They are a great team of people who are getting out there and having a go. I mentioned earlier the pilot program Mature Age Employment Advantage. It has been so good, so constructive and so responsive to the issues that the Employment Innovation Fund operated by the Australian government has agreed to fund a further refinement of that program.

We have already had one intake in this second stage of road-testing the Mature Age Employment Advantage program and almost half of the participants either are back in work or have multiple interview opportunities coming up because they are revitalised. They are recharged and they are ready to take on and contribute to the workplace. They recognise that revisiting their skills and the competencies that they have used in other workplaces and putting them forward—not necessarily their position title but the skills and competencies they have exercised effectively—and presenting them to employers is engaging employers. They understand that there are other people in the same circumstances. The peer support which the program we have developed offers gives them encouragement and new insights, and they can share their experiences with each other.

The fear about information technology—if there is a fear—is overcome by participating in an IT program. They get a recognised qualification at the end of it—evidence they can take to employers that says, `I'm not spooked by this technology, I'm ready, I can use it and I can be trained on it.' They are canvassing new career opportunities and are also benefiting from another look at what is happening in the labour market to make sure they can meet the expectations of the workplace.

Next week in the Dunkley electorate, as part of this program, I have organised, in conjunction with the peninsula job team, a mature age employment workshop, a briefing and a luncheon. It is a re-education of employers in our area. The Deputy Prime Minister, who I believe will be acting Prime Minister on Wednesday, will be addressing that gathering at Mornington, talking directly to employers and presenting the facts. We will also be showcasing our program participants and saying, `Have a look at the talent that is here; have a look at the vitality and the ready contribution that these people can make to your workplace.' We will be saying, `Do yourself a favour'—as Molly Meldrum said—`and consider a mature age person for your work force.' That is part of the attitudinal shift that I am calling for today to support the other measures that are in place. We have got to get into people's heads and hearts. We have got to not only put the direct tools like this age discrimination legislation on the table but also show employers that they are doing themselves, their businesses, our economy and the broader society a huge disservice by not embracing mature age job seekers.

Next Wednesday we are going to do some mature talking over lunch—that is the way we have plugged it. It is subsidised by the Australian government's Employment Innovation Fund. We are being looked at as a potential model for that program to be rolled out nationally. It is a product of good, committed people who have a shared purpose to support mature age job seekers in tackling the barriers to their re-entering the workplace, work collaboratively with mature age job seekers and engage employers by saying, `Wake up. There is a fantastic resource, a great capacity and an untapped ability that would enhance your business—the mature age job seeker. You have got to give them a go.'

To all those people over 45 who are struggling to get back into the work force, take out of today's debate, and hopefully out of my comments, that there is plenty going on. I am being kind to the over 45s who are in this room with me. I do not want you guys to face those barriers. I know how competent and capable you are. By the time I am 45, I hope we have got this problem licked. We need to have this problem licked; it is in our national interest to do so. If any of our parliamentary colleagues over 45 find themselves regrettably out of work, I do not want the economy and our society to be disadvantaged by not embracing all that you have to offer. So let us get behind mature age job seekers, let us support this legislation and let us get a national marketing campaign in place. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the Age Discrimination Bill 2003 and Age Discrimination (Consequential Provisions) Bill 2003. This legislation will make discrimination on the basis of age unlawful, subject to several and various exemptions. The Labor Party are supporting the Age Discrimination Bill 2003. We think it is a good bill, but we have moved amendments which, if accepted by the government, would strengthen it.

speech.para: Both direct and indirect discrimination are covered by this bill. Direct discrimination is being told that you are too old for the job. Indirect discrimination is a little more tricky. An example of that would be having to pass a certain physical test in order to qualify for a particular job when, in fact, those physical requirements are not necessary for performing the duties associated with the job in question. In such cases of indirect discrimination, the discriminator carries the burden of proving that a requirement or practice is reasonable in the circumstance.

Regrettably `isms' of various descriptions do influence most societies. While Australia is more tolerant than most societies, we nevertheless are also affected. We are affected by racism, sexism and, of course, ageism. Most people reach an age when they are considered past it, but age itself is not an indicator of a person's ability to perform a particular task. This was brought home to me some years ago on a bus trip through Central Australia. Three of our group, including me, decided to climb Uluru. The person who was quickest to complete the climb was a 71yearold New Zealander, who proved that people can still retain their fitness into older age.

This bill allows the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to grant exemptions, promote the bill and carry out other functions to eliminate age discrimination. The bill complements existing Commonwealth, state and territory laws on age discrimination. Currently every state and territory prohibits age discrimination, and this bill will not override the operation of other laws. It is, in fact, simply the Commonwealth catching up with the states on this issue. Under the bill, where a person makes a complaint under a state or territory law, that person will then be barred from making the complaint under Commonwealth law.

Between 1999-2000 and 2000-01 age discrimination complaints to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission tripled in number. Age discrimination, as with all forms of discrimination, feeds on stereotypes and gross generalisations. In the case of age discrimination, these stereotypes include the beliefs that older workers are slow to adapt, too hard to retain and too fixed in their views. As Diane Sisely, Chief Executive of the Equal Opportunity Commission of Victoria, is quoted in a Financial Review article on 18 January this year as saying:

quote.para: “Some of the stereotypes are that people over the age of 45 lack flexibility, are less productive, cost more, can't learn new skills or are not computer literate ... But when you actually go and look at the evidence, the stereotypes don't add up.”

speech.para: However, the view expressed in that article is, unfortunately, the view that a lot of employers really hold.
