Once again I refer to a source that I think the previous speaker may have referred to, Dr Gringart, and research that he has undertaken. Dr Gringart is a PhD graduate at Edith Cowan University in Western Australia. A report on his research was published in the Sydney Morning Herald on Tuesday, 7 October. The heading is `Older staff not worth training, say bosses'. The article reads:

quote.para: Bosses think older workers cannot adapt to new technology, are not worth training, are not interested in their work and do not have the physical strength or mental alertness of their younger colleagues.
Their discriminatory attitude flows through to recruitment decisions. Many employers say age is relevant in hiring and are therefore less likely to take on older candidates.

speech.para: The article continues:

quote.para: Dr Gringart began his studies into older workers in 1999, when he sent mock resumes from fictitious older and younger job seekers with similar qualifications to 300 companies.
Employers shunned the older workers, with mature women the least likely to get an interview.
For his PhD, Dr Gringart asked recruitment managers in 128 companies across Australia to compare workers aged 55-70 with those aged 25-40 according to 28 measures.
They said older workers were inferior on 12 of the 28 measures, giving them the worst ratings for adaptability, “trainability” and their level of interest in work.
But they were considered superior on 15 of the 28 items, and rated most strongly for reliability, loyalty and dependability.
Even though mature workers were superior on more measures, employers were generally less likely to hire them.
“Employers seemed to [say] they have nothing against older people, they really like them ... but they are just not interested in hiring them,” Dr Gringart said.

speech.para: The article concludes:

quote.para: Dr Gringart said efforts to retain older workers were welcome, but would not help if employers' attitudes did not change.

speech.para: I think that view has been brought out by a number of speakers in this debate. These stereotypes really are an affront to the dignity of older people. They impair the efficient functioning of the labour market. They are also quite untrue. Often older workers are more reliable and more loyal to a company and bring more life experience to their positions, which will allow them to adapt to the changing nature of work. An ageing population has various serious consequences for our society and, for the economic rationalists, great consequences for our economy.

Over the next 20 years, the growth in the population of labour force age in Australia will be around 14 per cent but the number of people aged 55 to 64 is expected to increase by over 50 per cent. An increase of just 10 per cent in the work force participation of Australians aged 55 to 70 would largely cancel out any negative effect of the ageing population. On an international comparison, participation in the Australian labour market stands out because of high rates of younger workers and low rates of older workers.

We often talk about youth unemployment in this place, which in many cases is still too high. However, we are less likely to talk about unemployment rates among older workers. Australia has the highest unemployment rate for men aged 55 to 59 of any country in the OECD—an unenviable record I think we would all agree. This bill will partly address this problem and will give the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission the ability to campaign and educate on the issue of age discrimination and the positives of employing older workers. It is very definitely a step in the right direction.

While this bill is certainly an improvement in Australian human rights law, it ironically comes at a time when the government has the Australian Human Rights Commission Legislation Bill 2003 still before this parliament. Passed by this House late at night on the last sitting day before the winter recess and currently before the Senate, that bill will undermine the effectiveness and independence of the commission. In addition, the commission's budget has been reduced by some 40 per cent in real terms since 1995-96. When one looks at the human rights record of this government in order to obtain the `totality of the context'—as the Prime Minister likes to say—one can see that this bill stands out like a lone figure on the top of a hill in the desert.

It is not just the human rights commission bill which would reduce the number of commissioners and remove its independence, it is also things like the first draft of the ASIO bill. Maybe we are going to go through that exercise again, Mr Deputy Speaker? That bill would have been the most draconian legislation of any country involved in the so-called coalition of the willing. Completely innocent 14-year-olds—who are not suspects and are not facing charges of any kind—could have been locked up for a week and subjected to interrogation without legal counsel under that bill. That is hardly the bill of a government interested in basic human rights. Thankfully, the Labor Party held firm and curbed some of the more outrageous sections of that particular bill.

The government's treatment of asylum seekers—cutting access to appeal mechanisms, the locking up of children behind razor wire, the redefinition of what a refugee actually is in order to make sure fewer people are defined as refugees—and its failure to secure the transfer of the two Australians being held in appalling conditions at Guantanamo Bay to more humane facilities are other examples of the government's poor human rights record. The United Nations Commission on Human Rights even investigated and condemned our treatment of asylum seekers. To quote from a UN press release from 31 July 2002:

quote.para: The situation of persons in immigration detention in Woomera could, in many ways, be considered inhumane and degrading.

speech.para: Section 53G of the report stated:

quote.para: The policy of detaining unaccompanied minors ... must be regarded as totally unacceptable from a human rights perspective.

speech.para: That is not a ringing endorsement of this government's human rights record. The government has failed to sign the protocol for the Convention for the Elimination of Discrimination Against Women, along with countries such as Libya, Nigeria, Sudan and Cuba. Australia, under the direction of this government, voted against the UN protocol against torture. It is not that they simply did not sign it, they actually voted against it. When one looks at the `totality of the context'—the Prime Minister's own phrase—we can see what a dismal human rights record this government has. That is why this bill is so surprising. Of course, age discrimination is a fairly safe issue. As I have said, every state and territory has age discrimination laws and so this is simply bringing Commonwealth legislation into line with the states—catching up, so to speak.

This is a good bill; it has wide support. As I said, we would like to see the amendment accepted. We will not be voting against the bill. The rights of older workers are an important issue that will challenge all sectors of our community into the future as the numbers of older workers or those older people capable of work grow. As I said, this bill has wide support. There has been some indication of some disagreement, but my research indicates that it has wide support, and it is interesting to note a joint press release put out by the Business Council of Australia and the Australian Council of Trade Unions on 23 April this year. That press release is headed, `Business, Unions Unite for Older Workers' and opens with the line:

quote.para: Australia's corporate sector and trade unions are working together to boost the number of older people remaining in the workforce.

speech.para: It is good to see unions working closely with business. I know it is not something that, certainly, the previous Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations encouraged—he seemed to always prefer conflict, and this positive and cooperative move may not have been to his liking.

I would like to refer to the press release I have mentioned. Some of the comments in this press release are worth noting in Hansard. The press release was issued by the ACTU and the Business Council of Australia and the heads of those two particular groups, Ms Burrow and Ms Lahey. It says in part:

quote.para: Over the past ten years, there have been 1.4 million new entrants into the Australian workforce. Between 2020 and 2030, there will be only 120,000 new entrants for the entire decade ...
As a result, while there are currently six working Australians supporting each retired person - by 2025 this ratio will be one to three.

Estimates put the cost of Australia's ageing workforce at $27 billion in lost economic growth and spending each decade. Health, welfare and pension systems will be ill equipped to support a growing class of retired Australians ...

speech.para: The press release then says:

quote.para: Significant cultural change is needed to break down stereotypes about older workers and retirement if Australia is to respond effectively to these challenges. We need to support older Australians who want to stay in the workforce longer, whether it is to maintain their incomes or because they find it fulfilling.

speech.para: I am sure we would all endorse that statement. Another quote from the press release is:

quote.para: For too many mature workers retiring early is not always voluntary—older workers, particularly men, have been vulnerable to downsizing and restructuring ...

speech.para: There is a very real problem facing our community. The Business Council of Australia has recognised it, the Australian Council of Trade Unions has recognised it and now the federal government is coming to the table with this legislation, which is very pleasing to see.

Legislation alone will not change the problem of stereotyping. You cannot legislate against an idea or a belief. Stereotyping is a product of ignorance—the idea or belief that older workers cannot adapt or will be in some way bad for business is a flawed one not based on fact or logic. While this legislation is important, it can only be a first step in what will probably be a very long process. Often, people who discriminate on the basis of stereotyping do not even know that they are doing it. There is always the subconscious battle between the stereotypical idea that a person may be too old for a job and the perfectly reasonable idea that an employer should give a younger person a go.

It is a very difficult thing to overcome. Education is important, and I do not necessarily mean that in the formal schooling sense of the word. Maybe a better term would be an `awareness' campaign rather than an `education' campaign. We must make employers aware of the benefits of employing an older worker; we must make them aware that the stereotype is just that—a stereotype—and that it is one that does not have any basis in reality.

That is where the Business Council of Australia and the Australian Council of Trade Unions come in. It is also where the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission comes in. These are organisations in a position to influence public debate. They are in a position to lead the debate and help bring down the barriers that ignorance builds. I call on the government to rethink the human rights commission bill, which will effectively hamstring the commission in its ability to lead the awareness campaign that is needed on this and so many other issues.

All members of parliament are aware of the well-qualified constituents in the plus45 age range who feel that they are unable to get employment because they are considered by employers to be too old. While discrimination happens in a wide range of areas, such as finance and health services, it is most common in employment. There needs to be an attitudinal sea change in the Australian population about the value of older workers. This can start with the retention of older people in all levels of the work force. While it is not unusual to see older people occupying high positions in the judiciary, in business, on boards of directors, in politics and in senior management, this age variation is not so apparent in middle management, in the trades or on the workshop floor. In an excellent article by Kate Legge on the issue of keeping older workers on the job, the following point is made:

quote.para: The evidence suggests that it is mainly highly educated professionals who remain attached to the work force in retirement years. There are numerous examples of former judges, business leaders, financial planners and high school principals operating boutique consultancy services several days a week. By contrast, participation in conventional work for men aged 55 to 64 has plummeted from 87 per cent in 1960 to about 63 per cent midway through the `90s.

speech.para: Our current uncertain employment market—where people are now less likely to have a lifelong job; where there is a lot of downsizing, restructuring and redundancies; and where employers are using a lot more sophisticated procedures to determine the people they want to employ—is of course much of the reason for unemployment amongst older workers. The more often a person is forced to change employment and the more often a worker is forced to renegotiate his or her employment contract, the more often ageism is likely to be an influencing factor in his or her employment changes.

In most cases the high level of unemployment amongst older workers is basically because of the lack of full-time employment opportunities. If demand for labour were there, more people would be employed and that would obviously include older workers. We are told that Australia has a thriving economy. But this economy is still not providing sufficient jobs to provide full-time employment for all those who want to work. Where jobs are being produced, they are mostly in part-time and casual occupations where workers are expected to beg, negotiate with and be thankful to their employers.

In conclusion, this is legislation that brings the Commonwealth into line with the states. As such, the Labor Party supports it. I will continue to oppose any form of discrimination, whether elitist or racist or on the basis of gender or age. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Before I support the Age Discrimination Bill 2003 and Age Discrimination (Consequential Provisions) Bill 2003, I am compelled to comment on some of the remarks made by the member for Greenway. In a very typical and expected manner, the member criticised the government for the antiterrorist measures and legislation we have been attempting to introduce through this parliament. Will the Labor Party ever learn? Haven't they got the message loud and clear from mainstream Australia? They did not get the message when the Australian public wanted greater border protection. They did not get the message when the Australian public wanted real and effective legislation to tackle the growing problem of terrorism. And they probably still will not get these messages at the next election. But that is all that is to be expected from a party that is governed by the wishes, concerns and aspirations not of mainstream Australia but of very narrow interest groups.

speech.para: The member also made comments about the UN protocols and discrimination against women. I ask, through you, Mr Deputy Speaker, for the member to look not at rhetoric but at actions and perhaps to look closer at the actions of his own party with regard to discrimination. I am very proud to be part of a political party that has had a long tradition of democratic participation by women in the political process. We do not need quotas in the Liberal Party to ensure that women are preselected and elected to this parliament. We do not need the ridiculous situation that the Labor Party have resorted to, because they cannot trust their own preselectors—to enshrine a 40 per cent women, 40 per cent men and 20 per cent on merit preselection process. You should be ashamed and embarrassed about these sorts of processes. If the Labor Party are serious about discrimination against women, then they should start treating them equally within their own ranks.

But back to the legislation: this legislation fulfils an important election promise from 2001. I also speak on behalf of many of my constituents who have contacted me in relation to age discrimination. I have received a series of correspondence from constituents and community groups representing older Australians from within my electorate. This legislation has generated a significant amount of interest and discussion amongst the people of the north-east and I have welcomed this debate. Often individuals are driven away from the political process and certainly the debate on the political minutiae of legislation. It is therefore a good thing to have people involved in the legislative process who take an interest in these matters. This is exactly what has occurred in the formation of this legislation for its passage through the parliament.

It is useful to point out from the beginning that this legislation aims to balance the need to eliminate unfair discrimination on the basis of age with the need to allow for certain decisions where age discrimination is essentially quite appropriate—for instance, in the area of junior wages. It is the balancing of these requirements which has been successful in bringing this legislation to the House.

One particular aspect which interested constituents in Indi was the fact that the Howard government had removed the age restrictions for the appointment or reappointment of company directors. This occurred through an amendment to the Corporations Act and was introduced into the parliament on 12 December 2002 in the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill. In fact one of my constituents emailed and wrote to me late last year informing me of the comments made by the Prime Minister in October 2001 at a National Seniors Association conference in Melbourne during the last election campaign. The comments were related to the removal of age restrictions for company directors and my constituent asked if anything had been done about this. Naturally, and with the aid of the then Attorney-General, I was pleased to be able to inform my constituent Mr Bill Field of Wangaratta that the Howard government had made good on that promise and that we had done what we had said we would.

Even before the formation of this legislation the Howard government illustrated that it was taking the issue of age discrimination seriously and acting on genuine and rightly held community concern. The government has already abolished compulsory age retirement in areas of Commonwealth responsibility. Compulsory age retirement for Commonwealth public servants was removed with the enactment of the Public Service Amendment Act 1999. Commonwealth statutory office holders who hold fixed term appointments are also no longer compelled to retire once they reach a certain age under the Abolition of Compulsory Age Retirement (Statutory Officeholders) Act 2001.

Therefore we debate this legislation in the context of affirming the inherent right of people to work, whatever age they are and in the clear recognition that people have something to offer our community regardless of age. This legislation is a step in the right direction and this particular legislation will go a good distance towards changing negative stereotypes about older people and, for that matter, younger people, particularly in relation to their abilities in the workplace, and it will help remove barriers to mature age work force participation.

By challenging negative stereotypes we are making a strong statement about the values we hold dear as a community and as a nation and recognising the intrinsic dignity and worth of all people, regardless of their age. We are living through a period of immense demographic change in Australia, and it is not solely a domestic phenomenon but one that the entire Western world faces. The reality is that the number of Australians over the age of 65 will increase from the current 2.4 million to 4.2 million in 20 years time. This is a huge demographic shift, the long-term effects of which are not widely appreciated or known within our community so far. It is only when the long-term effects of the eroding birthrate become apparent in statistics like this that we see the significance of the problem confronting Australia in the years ahead.

In January 1901, at the time of the proclamation of Australia's Federation, the median age of an Australian was 22 years. Today, the median age of the Australian population is just over 35 years. The median age has jumped 5.8 years over the past 20 years. In my electorate, the median age is 37, which is, of course, above the national average. These somewhat worrying trends look set to continue. In 2050, after the baby boomers have moved on, nearly one-quarter of the Australian population will be aged 65 or over. In my electorate of Indi, people aged 65 currently make up some 14 per cent of the population. In this century alone we have added two decades to our average life expectancy.

The ramifications of our ageing population are profound: put simply, Australians who are in employment will, over time, be forced through plain generational realities to support a growing number of people who are not in employment. This will place enormous burdens on our social security and welfare systems. Australia's spending on age pension payments has risen from 1.65 per cent of GDP 30 years ago to 2½ per cent today. There are almost two million Australians living on age pensions. Essentially, what all this means is that as a nation we are getting older and we have a declining base from which to support older generations now and into the future.

The Age Discrimination Bill 2003 is the product of significant community input and consultation. The core consultative group was established by the Attorney-General's Department to hear the thoughts and opinions of the various stakeholders in this important debate. Participants came from groups with a wide and diverse range of pursuits, including the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, retirees groups, ageing groups, family groups, youth groups, financial and superannuation bodies, ATSIC and the ACTU. This disparate grouping of organisations and individuals assisted greatly in the development of the bill.

Age discrimination is a significant problem for older Australians as well as for children and young people but, unlike sex, race and disability discrimination, it is not currently unlawful under Commonwealth legislation. Some constituents in Indi have brought to my attention a number of situations where colleagues, friends or associates of theirs have been treated poorly in the past with regard to discrimination on the basis of age. I have been somewhat surprised by the occasions when people have been effectively stopped from continuing to make a valuable and positive contribution to their local community and to society in general. My constituent Mrs Diana Kent from Euroa informed me of a number of instances where a person's age was counted as a liability, and I believe that this legislation will immediately address the concerns that she brought before me. Indeed, I have been surprised by the amount of interest that the people of Indi have shown towards this particular legislation and, as always, I have taken great note of what my constituents tell me.

It is very easy to say that we want to take a stand against unfair discrimination. What is considerably more difficult is implementing legislation that is workable and fair and which balances community interest with individual opportunity. I am confident that this legislation achieves that aim. The areas of public interest which this legislation covers are employment, public places and public transport, access to goods and services, the administration of Commonwealth laws and programs, land, accommodation, and information requests, where age discrimination might be evident. Similarly, these bills allow for exemptions for age discrimination in such important areas as taxation, health, superannuation and social security.

Perhaps the area where the effects of this legislation might be felt most is in the workplace. I mentioned earlier the problems confronting Australia's work force and demographics. Unless we debase these onerous assumptions that individuals have a use-by date in the workplace, we will not adequately address important issues of work force participation so that the skills and practices of older Australian workers can be properly acknowledged—this would be a significant mistake. It is important to institutionalise the attitude that every Australian, regardless of age, is able to contribute to and participate in our society. Through the implementation of this legislation at the Commonwealth level the Howard government is making a very bold statement that age discrimination will not be tolerated. Legislation applied to discrimination on the basis of age is long overdue. I know that these bills will be welcomed by the people of Indi and the wider community and therefore commend the bills to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Georgiou) adjourned.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 19 March 2003:

question.para: (1) Does the Minister's Department administer any Commonwealth funded programs for which community organisations, businesses or individuals in the electoral division of Charlton can apply for funding; if so, what are the programs.

(2) Does the Minister's Department advertise these funding opportunities; if so, (a) what print or other media outlets have been used for the advertising of each of these programs, (b) were these paid advertisements, and if so, (c) what was the cost of each advertisement.
(3) With respect to each of the Commonwealth funded programs referred to in part (1), (a) what is its purpose and (b) who is responsible for allocating funds.

(4) With respect to each of the Commonwealth funded programs referred to in part (1), how many (a) community organisations, (b) businesses or (c) individuals in the electoral division of Charlton received funding in (i) 1999, (ii) 2000, (iii) 2001, and (iv) 2002.
(5) What is the name and address of each recipient.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: My Department administers the following Commonwealth funded programs in the federal electoral division of Charlton.

(1) The Commonwealth Legal Aid Program. Under this program Legal Aid New South Wales is funded to provide assistance for Commonwealth law matters to people who live in New South Wales. Legal Aid New South Wales has a regional office located in Newcastle through which individuals and organisations living in the electoral division of Charlton can apply for assistance.
(2) No. Promoting the availability of its services is the responsibility of Legal Aid New South Wales which is a statutory body established under State law.
(3) (a) The Commonwealth Legal Aid Program provides assistance to individuals. Assistance is not generally available to businesses or community groups.
(b) Legal Aid New South Wales.

(4) Financial information on the provision of Commonwealth funding through the Commonwealth legal aid program is maintained on a financial-year basis and is only available on a State-by-State basis. The Commonwealth provided the following funding to Legal Aid New South Wales:

quote.para: Some proportion of these funds may have been used to provide legal aid to individuals living in the electoral division of Charlton.

answer.para: (5) The Commonwealth does not maintain statistical information on the operation of the program at a level of detail which would enable it to identify the number of individuals in the electoral division of Charlton who have received funding through the program.
(1) The Attorney-General's Department administers Commonwealth funding provided to community legal centres under the Commonwealth Community Legal Services Funding Program.
(2) When new funding opportunities arise they are normally advertised in relevant newspapers through paid advertisements.

(3) The purpose of the program is to support the provision of community legal services to disadvantaged members of the Australian community. The allocation of funds under the program is decided by the Attorney-General.
(4) and (5) No specific funding has been allocated under the Commonwealth Community Legal Services Program in the electoral division of Charlton in recent years.

(1) The Attorney-General's Department administers schemes for the provision of financial assistance for legal and associated costs. People and organisations in the electoral division of Charlton can apply for assistance directly from the Commonwealth under these schemes.

(2) Whilst no print or media advertising is used to disseminate information about the availability of funding under the schemes, they are well known to private legal practitioners, Community Legal Services and State and Territory Legal Aid Commissions. The availability of financial assistance under the two major schemes (the native title scheme and the Royal Commissions scheme) is explained on the Department's website. The Department's website address is www.ag.gov.au.

(3) (a) These schemes exist to provide legal or financial assistance in cases where legal aid is not generally available from Legal Aid Commissions and where the circumstances give rise to a special Commonwealth interest.

(b) The allocation of funds to the schemes is made through the Budget process. Decisions about the allocation of funds to applicants under each of the schemes are made by officers of the Attorney-General's Department under a delegation from the Attorney-General.

(4) and (5) The Department's electronic financial management information systems record information about the people to whom payments of financial assistance are made. In some cases, payments are made to the person who applied for the grant of assistance (the applicant); in other cases, payments are made to the applicant's solicitor. Determining the address (and therefore the electorate) of every applicant on whose behalf payments were made to a solicitor would require a manual cross check of the Department's paper files. This would be an expensive and time consuming undertaking, which could not be performed within the resources available without adversely affecting the work of the Family Law and Legal Assistance Division. Furthermore, it has been a long-standing practice, endorsed by successive Attorneys-General, to treat applications for financial assistance in confidence and not to provide information in relation to individual applications.
(1) Emergency Management Australia's Projects Program.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, upon notice, on 18 August 2003:

question.para: (1) Is he aware that the notional superannuation deduction provisions under sections 20, 21 and 21A of the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 are causing hardship to a number of former public servants who remain on compensation.
(2) To how many former public servants do the deduction provisions under sections 20, 21 and 21A of the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 apply.

(3) Can he confirm that Commonwealth employees who exit the public service under voluntary redundancy provisions continue to have 5% of their former salary deducted from their fortnightly compensation payments as a notional employee superannuation contribution; if so, are those deductions remitted to the superannuation fund and, if they are, do those deductions entitle former officers to any benefits that they can access on, or after, reaching 55 years of age.
(4) Does the Government intend to amend the Act to delete elements of the provisions of sections 20, 21 and 21A for former public servants who are no longer in the superannuation fund; if so, when.
(5) Can he confirm that a deeming rate of 10% applies to the formula used under sections 20, 21 and 21A of the Act.
(6) When was a deeming rate under sections 20, 21 and 21A of the Act first determined and has it been varied since that date.
(7) Does the Government intend to reduce the current deeming rate of 10% to the deeming rate of 2.5% applied by other agencies, such as Centrelink and the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
Mr Andrews
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Representations have been received from former public servants and also from the Superannuated Commonwealth Officers' Association regarding the notional superannuation deduction provisions under the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 (SRC Act).

The Department of Employment and Workplace Relations is reviewing the benefit entitlement provisions which involve interaction with early access to superannuation benefits. The Government will consider whether amendments are necessary when the Department has completed its review.
(2) Comcare has advised these provisions apply to 956 former government employees, 563 former defence personnel and approximately 180 employees of licensees under the SRC Act.

(3) Under the SRC Act benefits for retired employees are calculated in accordance with formulae that provide for a notional deduction of an amount equivalent to the amount which the employee would have been required to contribute to a superannuation fund if he or she were still in employment. This can be an amount between 0 and 5 per cent, depending on the fund to which the employee was contributing. The notional deduction is not remitted to the superannuation fund, but is an element in the calculation of an entitlement. Its purpose is to ensure that a retired employee does not receive a higher net payment than he or she would have received if he or she was still employed.
(4) The Government will consider whether amendments are necessary when the Department has completed its review.
(5) The effect of the formulae at sections 21 and 21A is to apply a deemed interest rate of 10 per cent to lump sum superannuation amounts.
(6) The formulae is a fundamental element of the benefit regime established under the Act. It has not been changed since the inception of the Act in 1988.
(7) The Government will consider the operation of the current deeming rate when the Department has completed its review.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 18 August 2003:

question.para: (1) In respect of potential sites for a second Sydney airport, does he recollect telling the House on 11 August 2003 that “86 percent of the Wilton site is in the catchment for Sydney's water supply. But Labor has raised it explicitly as an option, despite the problems of water contamination, which is why we did not look at it again”.
(2) What are his department's estimates of the contamination on households in the suburbs neighbouring Kingsford Smith Airport.

(3) What warnings has his department issued about the possibilities of contamination to citizens in affected areas around Kingsford Smith Airport and what warnings have been issued in regard to swimming pools and other areas of exposed water that citizens might utilise.

(4) What measures has his department agreed to fund to enable the protection of the hundreds of thousands of citizens around Kingsford-Smith Airport from the pollution he alleges would occur around an airport sited at Wilton.
(5) Is it the case that Wilton has showed up repeatedly as the second favoured site by his department after Badgery's Creek if a second airport site is to be found within the Sydney Basin.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.

(2) (3) and (4) Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport is not built within a drinking water catchment as would be the case with the site at Wilton which was assessed in the 1985 Second Sydney Airport Site Selection Programme Environmental Impact Statement. Therefore, this specific impact relevant to Wilton is not directly comparable with the environmental effects from aircraft operations at Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport.

(5) Badgerys Creek and Wilton were subject to a full environmental impact assessment as part of the 1985 Second Sydney Airport Site Selection Programme Environmental Impact Statement (1985 EIS). In February 1986, the then Government selected Badgerys Creek rather than Wilton as the site for a second Sydney airport. The disadvantages of Wilton were seen as its greater distance from the markets the airport was intended to serve, greater development cost, and greater impact on the natural environment. The 1985 EIS also noted the Wilton site was located in the drinking water catchment for Sydney.

Since that time there have been no formal studies undertaken by my Department which have concluded that Wilton was the second favoured site after Badgerys Creek for a second Sydney airport within the Sydney Basin.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, upon notice, on 18 September 2003:

question.para: (1) Has the Minister seen a Council of Australian Postgraduate Associations report dated 24 March 2003 titled “The Social and Economic Impact of Student Debt 2003”.

(2) Can he confirm the findings of international studies cited in the report which suggest that the increasing cost of education, combined with the reduction of government financial assistance, may prevent many students from continuing with postgraduate studies; if not, why not.

(3) Has the Government's reduction of support-services and structures for students in Australia contributed to (a) insurmountable financial pressure on Australian students, and (b) poor postgraduate student completion rates in Australia; if not, why not.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
Dr Nelson
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.

(2) The Australian Government has increased financial assistance for postgraduate students through the Postgraduate Education Loan Scheme (PELS) which was introduced in 2002. PELS provides a loan facility for eligible students who are enrolled in fee-paying, postgraduate non-research courses. The loan facility is similar to the deferred payment arrangements available under the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS). In 2002, the Commonwealth paid a total of $115 million to institutions on behalf of students who had elected to take out a PELS loan for their tuition fees. This benefited 11,387 equivalent full-time student units (EFTSU) (or 25,213 students), which equates to 33% of the total EFTSU enrolled in domestic fee-paying postgraduate coursework courses. Over 25,000 students took out PELS loans in 2002 while enrolments in PELS eligible courses have also shown a 20 per cent increase in 2002 over 2001, compared to a 15 per cent increase in the previous year.

The findings of research undertaken by Professor Bruce Chapman of the Australian National University show that income-contingent student loan schemes support enhance student participation in higher education, concluding that “the introduction of income-contingent charging systems for higher education has the potential to protect the access of the disadvantaged.”
(3) (a) The Council of Australian Postgraduate Associations report does not state that the Government has reduced support services and structures in Australia.

(b) Internal research from the Department of Education Science and Training has indicated that in Australia annual postgraduate completions increased from 39,733 in 1997 to 43,122 in 2001. No completions data is yet available for 2002.

subdebateinfo.title: Defence: North West Cape Naval Communication Station
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2502)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 7 October 2003:

question.para: (1) Can the Minister confirm that the Government is negotiating an agreement with the United States of America relating to the operation of, and access to, the Australian Naval Communication Station at North West Cape in Western Australia.

(2) What access, if any, to the North West Cape Naval Communication Station has been provided by Australia to the United States since the expiry on 8 May 1999 of the amended 1963 Agreement between Australia and the United States relating to the operation of a Joint Australia/United States Naval Communication Station in Australia.
(3) What access to the North West Cape Naval Communication Station is being sought by the United States in the current negotiations.
(4) Precisely what matters does the proposed new agreement relating to the North West Cape Naval Communication Station cover.
(5) Will the proposed new agreement be confined solely to naval communications matters or will it cover other forms of access and activities.
(6) When does the Government expect the new agreement will be finalised.
(7) Why has the Government made no public announcement about these negotiations concerning United States access to a major Australian defence communication facility.

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
Mr Brough
talker.role: Minister for Employment Services and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(2) Access by the US to Harold E. Holt has been continued in accordance with the 1992 amendment, while negotiation of a draft new Agreement continues.

(3) The draft Agreement provides for the same level of access by the US as the 1992 amendment. The US will continue to have access to three of the four Very Low Frequency radio communication channels, will contribute to operating costs, and assist with logistics support, capital upgrades and technical expertise.

(4) The draft Agreement covers the requirement to maintain the communication station, access by the US, consultation, cost sharing, taxation, technical arrangements, and property transfer and disposal.
(5) Article 3 of the draft Agreement states that the station will not be used for any purpose other than defence communication.

(6) and (7) US agreement has been recently received. The draft new Agreement will now be processed in accordance with the Australian Government's Treaty Procedures, including approval by the Executive Council and review by the Parliament. This is expected to occur within the next 12 months.

In accordance with the Australian Government's Treaty Procedures, the draft new Agreement has been listed on the Commonwealth, State and Territories Standing Committee on Treaties Schedule of Current Commonwealth Treaty Action (the Treaty Schedule).
